text:
[1948-06-01 12:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I know, by rumor, that Peruzzo cursed Don Achille, and Don Achille lifted him up and threw him against a tree, where Peruzzo lay bleeding. I heard Lina talking about "the past," which made me anxious. I imagined Don Achille revealing his evil nature, half animal, half mineral.
[1950-10-01 08:00:00] Mergellina | I saw that I always supported my father. I promised my parents that I would study hard. I heard my mother shouting at my father for money. I heard my father say to me, "Elena, you must study hard at school... if you're not the best student, then you'll have to go to work!" I thought that although these words were spoken by my father, I felt they were forced out of him by my mother. These words frightened me.
[1950-10-20 10:00:00] via Toledo | I saw myself hit twice by Lina with a paper wad dipped in ink, once in the hair and once in the white collar. I saw her not listening to the teacher, continuing to fling it at others. I know she's the same bad girl in front of everyone. I thought I found her very bad, and she left a deep impression on me.
[1950-10-20 10:05:00] via Toledo | I saw Professor Oliviero stumble as he came down from the podium, his face crashing into the corner of a desk, and then he lay motionless on the floor. I saw Lina looking at her with a serious expression. I heard the teacher scream. I saw the teacher's body being thrown onto the ground like a black bundle. I thought that the teacher looked as if she were dead.
[1950-10-20 10:10:00] Spaccanapoli | I know that Aunt Assunta's daughter died of tetanus, Spanuolo's son died of asthma, my cousin was crushed to death, my grandfather died when the building collapsed, and Peruso lost an arm, and so on. I thought of many accidents, realizing that our world is filled with deadly words and dangers.
[1951-02-15 09:00:00] via Toledo | I saw Professor Oliviero return to the school alive and begin to care for and praise Lina. I thought she was dead, and I believed Lina would be sentenced to death. I am amazed by the change that has taken place.
[1951-02-15 09:10:00] via Toledo | I saw Nunzia Lina come in, dressed in her black festive attire, bringing coffee and sugar for the teacher. I saw her swollen feet in high heels. I thought I almost didn't recognize her.
[1951-02-15 09:15:00] via Toledo | I saw the teacher write a word on the blackboard (like "sun"). I saw Lina read it out, angry. I heard the teacher ask, "Lina, what is written here?" I heard Lina say, "Sun." I heard the teacher say, "Good! It really says 'Sun' on the blackboard." I saw the classroom fall silent. I felt somewhat confused, because I was the best student in the class.
[1951-02-15 09:20:00] via Toledo | I saw Lina walk to the blackboard and write with a trembling hand. I heard the teacher telling her to write "chalk." I heard Mrs. Lina say dejectedly, "You wrote it wrong."
[1951-02-15 09:25:00] via Toledo | I heard the teacher ask who had taught her, and Nunzia said she hadn't been taught. I heard the teacher, full of admiration, ask Lina: "Who taught you to read and write?" I heard Lina answer: "I..." I saw Lina then, very thin and small, wearing a dark smock, with a small pink flower on her neck.
[1951-02-16 09:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I know that Rino is six years older than Lina, good at playing games and mending shoes, but can't read. I know that Lina probably learned to read when she was around three by looking at his textbooks, or more likely, by reading the old newspaper used to wrap shoes. I thought it was impossible that Rino had taught Lina by letting her copy his textbook, because he had never done any homework. I felt Lina's early maturity was due to those newspapers.
[1951-02-16 09:10:00] Chiaia | I saw that I was listening very carefully to the teacher. I saw the gray, gloomy morning I remember. I thought about the feeling of weakness I had after the teacher showed that Lina could read. I felt that school was better than home, that it was a safe place. I realized that I liked to please the teacher, because I was unnecessary in my mother's life.
[1951-02-16 22:00:00] Mergellina | I heard my mother stomping on a cockroach with the heel of her shoe. I heard her say it was a "frustrated leg." I saw her with yellowing hair, blue eyes, a swollen figure, a crooked right eye, and a limp in her walk. I saw the cockroaches coming in from under the gate. I thought about how much I hated her body, and I felt she must be very unhappy. I imagined her eyes burning with anger.
[1951-03-01 10:00:00] Chiaia | I often got called to the teacher's desk. I heard Professor Oliviero say, "Greco, come sit in front of me." She said my blonde hair was beautiful. I realized that sitting in front of the teacher was a privilege. Later, when I saw the teacher calling Lina to sit beside her more often, I felt deeply disappointed and even a bit jealous.
[1951-03-15 07:00:00] Mercato | I woke up in the morning and immediately checked my leg. I decided to follow Lina, imitating the way she walked, keeping a close eye on her. I saw Lina's legs were very thin and extremely flexible, kicking them back and forth. I thought about my fear of becoming lame. I believed that if I kept following Lina, my mother's way of walking wouldn't threaten me.
[1952-05-20 10:00:00] Chiaia | I knew the principal organized at least two class competitions every year. Teacher Oliviero used me and Lina as weapons to compete against other classes. I thought that Lina was dazzling to me, but terrifying to others. I studied as hard as I could so I wouldn't fall behind her and so the teacher wouldn't only praise someone else.
[1952-05-20 10:30:00] Chiaia | I see that I usually play as a forward. I recite poems, do calculations, and list mountain names. I saw Lina looking disheveled and dirty, with scars. I saw her eyes narrow to a slit before she gave a brilliant reply. I knew Lina could do complex math problems in her head, write them down accurately, and use formal vocabulary. I thought she was almost inhuman, and acknowledging her superiority was admitting my own mediocrity.
[1952-11-01 09:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I heard Melina call out the child's name every night: "Aida! Micaele!" I know that Melina's husband is dead, and Donato Nino helped her. Melina fell in love with him and decided to fight against his wife, Lidia. I thought that what had once been interesting had now become frightening.
[1952-11-05 20:00:00] Piazza Garibaldi | I saw my mother open the door to look. I heard Melina and Lydia's shouts and curses. I saw two female neighbors fighting and tumbling down the stairs, and I saw Melina's head hit the floor just a few centimeters from my shoes, like a broken white melon.
[1952-11-10 13:00:00] Stazione Centrale | I saw Pinocchia pointing at Melina. I saw Lina slap Pinocchia hard, knocking her to the ground. I helped the weeping Pinocchia up. I heard Pinocchio say, "That bitch!"
[1952-11-10 13:05:00] Stazione Centrale | I turned around and saw Lina, I saw her cross the street and stand close to Melina. I saw Melina holding a black soap and food in her hands. I thought I felt very uneasy. Now I realize she faced her pain firmly, silent like a stone sculpture.
[1952-11-15 09:00:00] Mercato | I saw that we were brought to Professor Ferraro's class, which was for fourth graders. I saw Enzo Scanno, Nino Nino, and Alfonso Carracci also there. I saw Enzo wearing a sign around his neck that said "Donkey." I know Enzo is a repeat student. Alfonso Carracci is the third child of Don Achille. I thought about how much I liked Nino. We both avoided Enzo because he was violent.
[1952-11-15 10:00:00] Mercato | I saw us start a mental arithmetic competition. I saw Alfonso Carracci quickly overtake me. I saw Lina not answering questions actively. I heard Enzo shouting out the correct answer from the back of the classroom. I saw Nino looking dazed, barely answering questions. I was amazed by Nino's performance, and also by Lila's apparent reluctance to beat Don Achille's son. I was surprised when Enzo answered correctly.
[1952-11-15 10:30:00] Mercato | I saw Enzo called to the blackboard for a duel with Lina. I saw Lina later squint her eyes, answering firmly and accurately, and finally winning. I saw the teacher punish Enzo. I heard Enzo answer in the dialect, and after losing, he started swearing. I saw Enzo with a sullen face, feeling both nervous and proud, and finally got his ear pulled. I saw that Lina had finally fully awakened.

[1952-11-15 12:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I know I can't offend Don Achille and his family. I thought about how I had figured out that Lina had deliberately chosen the right moment to not defeat Alfonso Carracci. I realized this fear and submission had been passed down to us from our parents.
[1952-11-15 12:10:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw Nino's pale face, the red veins in his eyes. I saw Lina's face flush with warmth, radiating passion. I thought about how I suspected Nino might be deliberately keeping silent, just like Lina, and it hurt me. At that moment, I felt Lina was more beautiful than me, like a virgin warrior.
[1952-11-16 16:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw Stefano threatening Lina, pushing her against the wall. I learned that Enzo had been hit by Stefano, and that Rino had fought with Stefano. I saw Madame Maria scolding Nunzia. I heard that Stefano threatened to stick a needle in Lina's tongue. I know we learned to use "I didn't mean to" to escape danger, but the consequences still erupted.
[1952-11-20 10:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw and heard Fernando loudly apologize to Don Achille, but Don Achille ignored him. I remembered Enzo and Lina throwing stones, Lina getting hurt and bleeding, Enzo crying, and Rino hitting Enzo. I saw blood dripping from under Lina's hair. I knew that after Enzo was beaten, he didn't tell anyone, and the cycle of revenge came to an end. I thought about how I had screamed in fear at that moment.
[1953-03-10 17:00:00] Stazione Centrale | I saw Enzo throwing stones at us, and we ran away, but I saw Lina didn't run. She calmly dodged the stones. I stopped and waited for her. I know that Enzo is called "the hoodlum Enzo." I thought about how I had realized she possessed a certain elegance. I had developed some sort of feeling for her, something that made it impossible for me to leave her behind; I felt that if I ran away alone, I would lose something irretrievable.
[1953-03-10 17:05:00] Via Caracciolo | I saw myself hand Lina a sharp stone, and she hit Enzo in the ankle. I grabbed her arm to pull her away, but Enzo's thrown stone struck Lina on the forehead. I held her tightly, watching her lie on the sidewalk. I saw blood gushing from Enzo's ankle, saw him stop in surprise. I saw Lina's head broken open. I thought the group of boys would be more aggressive, and I felt filled with fear.
[1953-03-10 18:00:00] Mergellina | I saw myself sometimes covering my ears with my hands. I heard my parents cursing Don Achille, and I heard my mother denying the family relation. I knew Mr. Peluso was the mortal enemy of Don Achille, having lost his carpentry workshop due to gambling and debt. I thought about how I was afraid that Don Achille would hear the shouting and kill us. I imagined Don Achille followed by thousands of tools or carnivores, like a swarm of bees.
[1953-04-15 16:00:00] Porto | I remember her taking my doll and throwing it into the cellar. We had to go down, to look for it. I thought that, in my mind, it was really her fault. I felt that whether going up or down, we were both heading toward fear.
[1953-04-15 16:05:00] Porto | I saw myself talking to my doll. I looked at my doll, her face, hair, and eyes made of celluloid, wearing a light blue dress my mother had sewn. I looked at Lina's doll, made of rags, ugly and dirty. I thought that I felt my doll knew more than me. I imagined the two dolls watching each other, always ready to run away.
[1953-04-15 16:10:00] Porto | I saw us pretending not to be together in the courtyard. Lina sat on one side of the small window in the basement, and I on the other. We placed pebbles, bottle corks, and glass fragments along the iron grid. I wandered around her, then later sat by the window. I heard myself speaking in the local dialect to the doll: "Tina, put on your queen's crown, or you'll catch a cold."
[1953-04-15 16:15:00] Porto | I watched as we scattered through the holes in the iron grid, throwing stones into the basement and listening to the sound they made when they hit the floor. Sometimes we placed the dolls near the opening. I felt the cold air blowing out from the basement, saw the spiderwebs on the iron bars and the rusted mesh. I heard the terrifying rustling sounds below. I thought about how I felt excited and scared. I imagined Don Achille as the spider among spiders, with a gaping mouth and a black backpack, gathering everything we threw down into it.
[1953-04-15 16:20:00] Porto | I saw us exchanging the doll through our eyes and gestures. I saw her, as soon as she got Tina, throw Tina out of the hole. I saw the doll fall into darkness. I know Lina knows I'm very afraid.
[1953-04-15 16:25:00] Porto | I saw and felt the pain. I saw Lina, without a word, throw my doll down. I heard Lina ask, "Don't you care?" I saw tears welling up in my eyes. I knew from that moment on, we were both daring. I thought that I felt the celluloid doll was my most precious thing, and I was overwhelmed with despair. I learned to suppress my despair.
[1953-04-15 16:26:00] Porto | I saw myself throwing her doll Nao into the basement. I saw the look of surprise in her eyes. I heard myself shouting, "Whatever you do, I'll do the same! Now, go down and pick it up for me." I know I'm taking a risk, my heart is filled with extreme fear, but I have to do it.
[1953-04-15 16:30:00] Mergellina | I saw us squeeze into the basement through the dilapidated small door. Lina went in first, and I followed her down five stone steps. I heard her say, "If you pick up my doll too." I saw that the door was held up by only one hinge. The basement was damp and dark, with only a small hole letting in light. I thought about how we were filled with fear.
[1953-04-15 16:35:00] Mergellina | I saw myself stumbling forward. I saw a face hanging there and screamed. I saw Lina put the thing on her face, and I screamed in terror; she then threw it away. I heard Lina say that it was just a gas mask. I heard the creaking sound beneath my feet. I saw broken chairs, scrap metal. I saw the glass eyes and black elongated chin of a gas mask, and the rising dust. I thought about how scared I was, that face filled me with fear.
[1953-04-15 16:40:00] Mergellina | I saw that we had been looking for the doll but hadn't found it. I thought I saw Tina, but it was just a newspaper. I followed Lina through the broken door and gave up on Tina. I heard Lina say, "The baby was taken by Don Achille, he put it in a black bag." I felt lost and confused. I seemed to hear the sound of Don Achille crawling like a snake.
[1953-05-01 10:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw that I had a feverish illness, recurring again and again. I saw the solid surfaces of objects become soft and swollen. I felt my cheeks round as a ball, my hands covered in scars, my earlobes like overripe rowan berries. I felt myself squeezed between an expanding balloon underground and Don Achille's balloon, trapped by the iron bars. I thought about believing Lina's words, imagining Don Achille holding the doll. I felt nauseated and exhausted, as if I were about to be squeezed into a pulp.
[1953-05-15 18:00:00] Pigneto | I saw myself and Lina decide to climb that dark staircase, step by step, floor by floor, until we reached Don Achille's door. I saw that I remembered there was a purple light in the courtyard, and the air was filled with the scent of a spring night. I thought about the day I realized we had begun our friendship.
[1953-05-15 18:01:00] Albergheria | I saw the mothers preparing dinner, but we didn't go home; instead, we were competing with each other. Although I had never spoken to Lina, we were both trying to prove who was braver.
[1953-05-15 18:02:00] Albergheria | I remember Lina putting her arm into the sewer, and I did the same; she jumped down from the window railing at Mrs. Spagnuolo's house, and I did the same; she stuck a rusted French brooch into her palm, and I did as she did. I saw the dark, gaping hole of the sewer, and the white metal tip that left a white gash on her palm. I thought my heart was pounding, I hoped the cockroach wouldn't crawl up, the mouse wouldn't bite me; I was afraid of falling and hurting myself.
[1953-05-15 18:05:00] Borgo | I saw her look at me with her unique, determined squint, then turn her gaze toward the building where Don Achille lived. I know everyone both hates and fears him. I thought I was terrified, and I felt that Don Achille was a monster made of iron, glass, and nettles. I imagined him as a man with a rugged face, breathing hot air from his nose and mouth, and I felt that even looking at him from afar would hurt my eyes, and getting close to him would mean death.
[1953-05-15 18:06:00] Porto | I hesitated for a moment, then finally decided to follow her through the dark doorway. I found Lina sitting on the first step of the first staircase, and then she stood up, and we began to climb upward. I couldn't see anything at first, only smelled old objects and DDT insecticide, and later my eyes adjusted to the darkness. I thought about my futile hope that she might change her mind or forget the matter, but I knew I had to follow her.
[1953-05-15 18:08:00] Porto | I saw us walking along the flaking plastered wall, she in front, me behind. I was trembling. I saw that I felt those steps were higher than the ones in our building. I heard some footsteps or a sound. I found myself caught in a contradiction, unsure whether to get close or put distance between us. I imagined Don Achille appearing with the knife he used to gut chickens, the hallway filled with the smell of fried garlic. I fantasized that his wife would throw me into the frying pan, and he would suck the thoughts out of my brain.
[1953-05-15 18:10:00] Porto | I saw us stopping now and then, I saw her looking up. We stopped for a moment, then Lina continued walking, and I followed behind her. I saw the lights suddenly come on, weak and dusty, with many corners still immersed in darkness. Above me were large gray windows. I didn't hear the sound of doors opening or closing. I thought about wanting Lina to step back, my whole body was sweaty. I wanted to figure out if it was Don Achille who had turned on the light.
[1953-05-15 18:12:00] Porto | I saw us slowly approaching the person we had feared most in those years. When we reached the fourth step of the stairs, Lina stopped to wait for me, she reached out her hand to me. I realized that I was there because she was there. I felt that this act of holding hands completely changed our relationship.

[1953-06-15 11:00:00] Stazione Centrale | I saw myself leaving home to buy bread, clutching the change tightly in my hand. Nino blocked my way and pushed me against the wall. I ran past him. I heard him say, "When we grow up, I'll marry you." He asked if I wanted to date him. I replied, "No, I can't." I saw Nino pale-faced, holding his younger brother Pinocchio. I thought I was moved, and I even wanted to marry him, but I was still in the pain of Tina's disappearance, so I refused. I felt he had chosen the wrong time.
[1954-03-10 09:00:00] Albergheria | I saw Nino's family moving out from the window. I took my hands off my ears and saw copper pots, irons, and other things flying out of Melina's window. I saw an iron fall just a few centimeters away from Nino. I heard Melina's scream and the sound of things being thrown. I heard Pinocchia cry, "Mom, don't do this!" I saw Lydia protecting the child, and Nicola pulling the frightened horse. I saw the iron had left a hole in the ground. I felt weak, and I was filled with guilt for having once refused Nino. I saw Lina looking completely lost.
[1954-05-15 18:30:00] Staircase | I saw that time, and I decided with Lina to climb up that dark staircase. I saw that before me was that dark staircase.
[1954-05-15 18:30:05] Corridor | I saw us climbing one step at a time, layer by layer, upward.
[1954-05-15 18:30:10] Staircase | I saw us walk all the way to Don Achille's house. I thought that was the day we began our friendship.
[1954-05-15 18:30:15] Courtyard | I saw what I remembered: there was a purple light in the courtyard.
[1954-05-15 18:30:20] Courtyard | I see and smell the scent of a spring night in the air.
[1954-05-15 18:30:25] Courtyard | I saw and felt that all the mothers were cooking dinner. I realized it was time to go home for dinner.
[1954-05-15 18:30:30] Courtyard | I saw that we didn't go home right away, but instead kept challenging each other.
[1954-05-15 18:30:35] Courtyard | I saw us competing to see who had the bigger courage. I know that although I and Lina have never spoken a word to each other.
[1954-05-15 18:30:40] School Inside and Outside | I knew this competition had been going on for a while, both inside and outside of school, we were always competing with each other.
[1954-05-15 18:30:45] Storm Drain Entrance | I saw myself reaching my hand, even my whole arm, into the sewer hole. I saw the dark, gaping hole of the sewer.
[1954-05-15 18:30:50] Manhole entrance | I saw it and immediately reached in with my hand. I thought of it, but my heart was pounding.
[1954-05-15 18:30:55] Manhole entrance | I thought I hoped the cockroaches wouldn't crawl up my arm, and that the mice wouldn't bite me.
[1954-05-15 18:31:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's window | I saw Lina climbing up the window of Mrs. Spagnuolo, the woman who lived on the first floor, hanging from the iron bars of the window. I knew that was where the clothesline was tied.
[1954-05-15 18:31:05] Mrs. Spagnuolo's window | I saw her hanging there, swaying her body, then suddenly jumped onto the sidewalk.
[1954-05-15 18:31:10] Mrs. Spanuolo's window | I saw it and immediately did the same. I thought about it, but I was afraid of falling and hurting myself.
[1954-05-15 18:31:15] Street | I saw Lina stick a brooch into her skin. I saw that it was a rust-stained French brooch.
[1954-05-15 18:31:20] Street | I heard her say it was a gift from a fairy. I knew she had picked it up on the way, and she had been keeping the brooch in her pocket all along.
[1954-05-15 18:31:25] Street | I saw the white metal tip making a white cut on her palm. I saw that white metal tip and the white slit.
[1954-05-15 18:31:30] Street | I saw her hand the pin to me, and I did the same as she did.
[1954-05-15 18:31:35] Street | At that moment, she looked at me with a gaze that was uniquely hers. I saw her eyes narrowed, very determined.
[1954-05-15 18:31:40] Street | I saw and then she looked at the building where Don Achille lived.
[1954-05-15 18:31:45] Street | I thought I was frozen with fear because Don Achille was a monster from a fairy tale.
[1954-05-15 18:31:50] Street | I thought to myself that I absolutely couldn't get close to him, couldn't look at him, couldn't speak to him, couldn't spy on him.
[1954-05-15 18:31:55] Street | I thought about pretending that he and his whole family didn't exist.
[1954-05-15 18:32:00] Street | I know that it's not just in my family—everyone feels a mix of hatred and fear towards him. I thought about how I didn't know where this feeling came from.
[1954-05-15 18:32:05] Street | I thought of the way my father spoke about Don Achille, which made me imagine him as a tall man with a rugged face and a very short temper.
[1954-05-15 18:32:10] Street | I thought that, although he was addressed as "Don," the person who bore that title should have been someone calm and serene, a figure of quiet authority.
[1954-05-15 18:32:15] Street | I thought of him as made up of some indescribable materials: iron, glass, and nettle.
[1954-05-15 18:32:20] Street | I saw and felt his hot breath coming out of his nose and mouth. I thought of him, but he was a living person.
[1954-05-15 18:32:25] Street | I thought to myself that even seeing him from afar would hurt my eyes.
[1954-05-15 18:32:30] Street | I thought that if I dared to approach his house, he would certainly kill me.
[1954-05-15 18:32:35] Street | I hesitated for a moment, hoping Lina might change her mind and go back. I know what she wants to do.
[1954-05-15 18:32:40] Street | I thought I had vainly hoped she would forget that thing, but she hadn't.
[1954-05-15 18:32:45] Street | I saw that the streetlights weren't on yet, and the lights in the hallway were also dim.
[1954-05-15 18:32:50] Street | I heard unsettling sounds coming from the house.
[1954-05-15 18:32:55] Main Gate | I saw that to keep up with Lina's pace, I had to leave the pale blue light of the courtyard. I saw the pale blue daylight before me.
[1954-05-15 18:33:00] Inside the gate | I saw myself going into the dark gate. I saw the black door before me.
[1954-05-15 18:33:05] Corridor | I saw that I had finally decided to follow her in. I saw at the beginning, I could see nothing.
[1954-05-15 18:33:10] Corridor | I saw only some old objects, and I smelled the scent of DDT insecticide.
[1954-05-15 18:33:15] Corridor | I saw my eyes finally adjust to the darkness.
[1954-05-15 18:33:20] Corridor | I saw that Lina was sitting on the first step of the first flight of stairs.
[1954-05-15 18:33:25] Corridor | I saw her stand up at that moment, and we began to climb upward.
[1954-05-15 18:33:30] Corridor | I saw us walking along the wall, she ahead of me by two steps, and I following behind.
[1954-05-15 18:33:35] Corridor | I thought I felt conflicted, unsure whether I should catch up to shorten the distance between us or put more space between us.
[1954-05-15 18:33:40] Corridor | I saw us walking with our shoulders against the wall where the plaster was peeling off. I saw and felt the plaster on the walls peeling off.
[1954-05-15 18:33:45] Corridor | I thought to myself at that moment: I had a feeling that those steps were very high, higher than the stairs in our building.
[1954-05-15 18:33:50] Staircase | I saw myself trembling.
[1954-05-15 18:33:55] Corridor | I thought I heard the sound of footsteps, any kind of noise seemed to be Don Achille appearing behind us or coming straight toward us.
[1954-05-15 18:34:00] Corridor | I thought of him holding a long knife, like the kind used to open up chickens.
[1954-05-15 18:34:05] Corridor | I saw and smelled the oily stir-fried garlic scent spreading through the hallway.
[1954-05-15 18:34:10] Corridor | I thought about how the wife of Don Achille, Maria, would throw me into a pot of hot oil, and the children would eat me.
[1954-05-15 18:34:15] Corridor | I thought about how Don Achille would suck out my brain and swallow it, just like my father ate fish heads.
[1954-05-15 18:34:20] Corridor | I saw that we sometimes stopped. I thought to myself that every time, I wished Lina would step back.
[1954-05-15 18:34:25] Corridor | I saw and felt that I was sweating all over. I thought I didn't know how she felt.
[1954-05-15 18:34:30] Corridor | I saw her glancing up occasionally. I thought about it, but I didn't know what she was looking at.

[1954-05-15 18:34:35] Stairwell | I saw the gray window of the stairwell above me.
[1954-05-15 18:34:40] Corridor | I saw that at this moment the lights suddenly came on, but the light was very dim, with dust covering the lamps.
[1954-05-15 18:34:45] Corridor | I saw that there were still many terrible corners immersed in darkness.
[1954-05-15 18:34:50] Corridor | I saw us stop for a moment, trying to figure out if it was Don Achille who had turned on the light.
[1954-05-15 18:34:55] Corridor | I saw, but we heard nothing, no footsteps, no sound of doors opening or closing.
[1954-05-15 18:35:00] Corridor | I saw Lina continue walking forward, and I followed behind her.
[1954-05-15 18:35:05] Corridor | I thought she felt she was doing the right thing, while I had forgotten why I had even been there.
[1954-05-15 18:35:10] Corridor | The one thing I was certain of was that I was there because she was there.
[1954-05-15 18:35:15] Corridor | I saw us slowly approaching the person we had feared the most in those years. I thought about how we went to explore and question our own fears.
[1954-05-15 18:35:20] Corridor | I had just reached the fourth step when Lina surprised me: she stopped and waited for me a moment. I was surprised by her performance.
[1954-05-15 18:35:25] Corridor | I saw that I caught up with her, and she reached out her hand to me.
[1954-05-15 18:35:30] Corridor | I thought that this action had completely changed our relationship.

[1954-05-15 18:50:55] School | I knew Enzo hadn't sent Lina any other gifts.

[1954-05-15 18:51:05] School | I knew that although he was very good at mental arithmetic, he didn't want to study, so the teacher didn't recommend him to take the entrance exam for middle school. I thought he didn't feel sorry at all, but instead felt happy.
[1954-05-15 18:51:10] School/Market | I knew he had enrolled in a technical school, but in reality, he spent every day helping his parents with their work.
[1954-05-15 18:51:15] School/Market | I know he got up very early in the morning, going to the vegetable market with his father, or pulling a cart loaded with vegetables from the fields to sell. His school life came to an end soon.
[1954-05-15 18:51:20] School | I saw the teacher say that we were promising students, capable of continuing our studies. I knew it at the end of fifth grade.
[1954-05-15 18:51:25] School | I saw the teacher calling my parents, Giggia, and Lina's parents one after another to school. I heard that they told them we must continue our studies, and in addition to the primary school graduation exam, we also had to take the entrance exam for middle school.
[1954-05-15 18:51:30] Home | I saw how I had gone to great lengths to have my father, not my mother, meet with the teacher at school.
[1954-05-15 18:51:35] Home | I know my mother limps and has a squint, and most of all, she's always angry; while my father, as the gatekeeper for the city government, knows how to use polite words.
[1954-05-15 18:51:40] Home | I saw that it was my mother who went later. She talked to the teacher, and when she came home, her expression was very gloomy. I thought, but all my calculations had failed.
[1954-05-15 18:51:45] Home | "I heard her say, 'The teacher wants money. She said the exam is difficult, and the kids need tutoring.'" "What's the point of taking these exams?" my father asked.
[1954-05-15 18:51:50] Home | I heard, "Let her study Latin." "Why?" "Because the teacher said she's good at it."
[1954-05-15 18:51:55] Home | I heard, "If she's learning well, why take these paid classes?" "In that case, her life will be easier, but ours will be harder..."
[1954-05-15 18:52:00] Home | I saw them discussing for a long time. At first, my mother opposed it, while my father wasn't very sure.
[1954-05-15 18:52:05] Home | I saw that later, my father became very careful and began to support my schooling, while my mother made some concessions, no longer opposing it as strongly as before.
[1954-05-15 18:52:10] Home | I saw that in the end they decided to let me take the exam, but with a clear understanding that if I wasn't especially outstanding, I would have to drop out immediately.
[1954-05-15 18:52:15] Lina's house | I saw that Lina's parents had decided not to let her continue school. I know that her mother Nunzia wasn't very sure, and she wanted to convince Lina's father.
[1954-05-15 18:52:20] Lina's house | I saw it, but he didn't even leave room for discussion, and he slapped Rino in the face because Rino said it was wrong.
[1954-05-15 18:52:25] School | I saw that Lina's parents didn't even want to talk to the teacher, but later the principal called them, and Nunzia had to go.
[1954-05-15 18:52:30] School | I saw the woman, her face full of terror, reject Oliviero's proposal. I thought the teacher was a bit upset, but I still tried to remain calm.
[1954-05-15 18:52:35] School | I saw the teacher take out Lina's excellent essay, the difficult arithmetic problems she had solved, even her classroom drawings.
[1954-05-15 18:52:40] School | I knew that no matter what Lina painted, the girls in the class loved it, and she skillfully imitated Giotto's style.
[1954-05-15 18:52:45] School | I know the princesses she wrote about are very realistic: their hair, jewelry, clothes, and shoes are things you can't see in books or in the parish cinema.
[1954-05-15 18:52:50] School | After her proposal was completely rejected, Teacher Oliviero lost her patience and pulled Lina's mother to the principal. I thought of her as if she were a student who didn't follow the rules.
[1954-05-15 18:52:55] School | I saw that Nunzia couldn't give in because she hadn't gotten her husband's permission. She kept saying "no" until she, the teacher, and the principal were all exhausted.
[1954-05-15 18:53:00] School | I heard that the next day, when we went to school, Lina said to me in her usual tone: "Either way, I'm going to take the exam."
[1954-05-15 18:53:05] School | I thought about how I believed what she said, and that forbidding her to do anything was pointless, we all knew that.
[1954-05-15 18:53:10] School | I thought she seemed stronger than all of us girls, stronger than Enzo, Alfonso Carracci, Stefano, and even her brother Rino.
[1954-05-15 18:53:15] School | I thought she was stronger than our parents, our teachers, and even the soldiers who could have sent us to prison.
[1954-05-15 18:53:20] School | I know that despite her fragile appearance. I thought of it, but any prohibition would lose its power in front of her.
[1954-05-15 18:53:25] School | I thought she knew how to cross the line, but without truly facing the consequences, and in the end, people would give in.
[1954-05-15 18:53:30] School | I thought that, despite their reluctance, people still had to admire her.
[1954-05-15 18:53:35] Corridor | I knew going to Don Achille's house was forbidden, but she still decided to go, and I followed her.
[1954-05-15 18:53:40] Corridor | I thought it was then, and I believed nothing could stop her; every time she went against the norm, there was always an astonishing result.
[1954-05-15 18:53:45] Corridor | I thought about how we wanted Don Achille to return the doll to us.
[1954-05-15 18:53:50] Corridor | I saw us walking up the stairs. I thought that with every step up the stairs, I had the urge to turn back and run back to the courtyard.
[1954-05-15 18:53:55] Corridor | I saw and felt Lina tightly holding my hand, and I thought with relief: she was doing that because she figured I didn't have the courage to walk all the way to the top floor.
[1954-05-15 18:54:00] Corridor | I thought of that, and she boosted her own courage by holding my hand.
[1954-05-15 18:54:05] Corridor | I saw it that way, so we walked forward side by side. I was on the side next to the wall, and she was on the side with the railing, our hands tightly clasped. I saw and felt my hands were sweaty.
[1954-05-15 18:54:10] Staircase | I saw us climbing the last flight of stairs and arriving at Don Achille's front door. I thought my heart was beating very hard.
[1954-05-15 18:54:15] In front of Don Achille's house | I could hear my own heartbeat from my ears. I thought of it, but I consoled myself by thinking it might be Lina's heartbeat.
[1954-05-15 18:54:20] In front of Don Achille's house | I heard a sound coming from the house. I thought it might be Alfonso Carracci, Stefano, or Pinocchia's voice.
[1954-05-15 18:54:25] At the front door of Don Achille's house | I saw Lina standing silently at the door for a long time before finally ringing the bell.
[1954-05-15 18:54:30] In front of Don Achille's house | I had been waiting for a long time with no sign of movement, and then we heard the sound of slippers — it was Maria who opened the door for us. I saw her wearing a faded green housecoat.
[1954-05-15 18:54:35] At Don Achille's front door | I saw her speaking, and I saw her golden teeth shining brightly.
[1954-05-15 18:54:40] At Don Achille's front door | I was surprised, thinking that we were looking for Alfonso Carracci.
[1954-05-15 18:54:45] At Don Achille's front door | I heard Lina speaking in the dialect: "No, we're looking for Don Achille..." "Speak up, what is it?" "We need to tell him..."
locations: In front of Don Achille's house
At the front door of Don Achille's house

text:
[1954-05-15 18:54:50] At Don Achille's house door | I saw the woman cry out, "Achilles...," and then heard a series of footsteps.
[1954-05-15 18:54:55] At Don Achille's house door | I saw a very strong man coming out of the shadows. He was tall in the upper body but short in the lower part, with long arms that reached to his knees.
[1954-05-15 18:55:00] At Don Achille's front door | I saw him with a cigarette in his mouth, burning, and he asked roughly. "I heard 'Who is it?' 'The cobbler's daughter, and also the daughter of Grego...'"
[1954-05-15 18:55:05] At Don Achille's house door | I saw Don Achille come into the light. I thought this was the first time we had clearly seen him.
[1954-05-15 18:55:10] At Don Achille's house door | I saw that he had no ore on him, nor any shiny glass fragments. His face was flesh-and-blood, long and narrow, with hair hanging over his ears and a bare spot in the middle of his head.
[1954-05-15 18:55:15] At Don Achille's house door | I saw his eyes were bright, with bloodshot veins, his mouth was large, his lips thin, his chin long, with a hollow in the middle.
[1954-05-15 18:55:20] At Don Achille's house door | I thought he was ugly, but not as ugly as I had imagined.
[1954-05-15 18:55:25] At Don Achille's house door | "I'll say it." "About the doll." Lina said. "What doll?" "Our doll." "There's no doll of yours here..."
[1954-05-15 18:55:30] At Don Achille's house door | I heard, "You took our doll from the cellar."
[1954-05-15 18:55:35] At Don Achille's front door | I saw Don Achille turn his head and shout something into the house. I heard, "Pinocchio, did you take the shoemaker's daughter's doll?" "I didn't."
[1954-05-15 18:55:40] At Don Achille's house door | I saw "Alfonso Carracci, did you take it?" and a wave of laughter came from somewhere.
[1954-05-15 18:55:45] At Don Achille's house door | I saw Lina saying very firmly. I heard, "The doll was taken by you, we saw it." I thought about how I didn't know where Lina got her courage.
[1954-05-15 18:55:50] At Don Achille's house door | I saw that, and he fell silent for a moment before asking. I heard, "You said I took it?" "Yes, you put the doll in your black bag."
[1954-05-15 18:55:55] At Don Achille's house door | I saw the man frown when he heard those last words. I saw and felt that he was getting annoyed.
[1954-05-15 18:56:00] At Don Achille's front door | I couldn't believe my eyes; we just stood there, facing Don Achille, and Lina spoke to him that way.
[1954-05-15 18:56:05] At Don Achille's house door | I saw him looking at Lina uneasily. I saw that we could barely make out Alfonso Carracci, Stefano, and Pinocchia behind him, and Maria was setting the table with dishes.
[1954-05-15 18:56:10] At Don Achille's house door | I saw him, he was a bit short, a bit balding, and his limbs weren't very proportionate. I thought I couldn't believe he was just an ordinary man, so I was always on guard, watching for him to change.
[1954-05-15 18:56:15] At Don Achille's house door | I saw Don Achille repeat Lina's words. I heard, "I took your doll, I put the doll in the black bag?" I thought he just didn't understand what that sentence meant.
[1954-05-15 18:56:20] At Don Achille's house door | I thought I felt that he wasn't angry, but suddenly became very painful, as if confirming something he had already known.
[1954-05-15 18:56:25] At Don Achille's house door | I saw him say something in the local dialect, but I didn't understand it. At that moment, Maria called out. I heard, "Achille, the food is ready." "I'm coming right away."
[1954-05-15 18:56:30] At Don Achille's front door | I saw Don Achille reach his big hand into the pocket behind his butt. I thought about how our hands were tightly clasped, and I felt sure he was about to pull out a knife.
[1954-05-15 18:56:35] At Don Achille's house door | I saw him take out a wallet, open it, glance inside, and then give some money to Lina. I thought to myself that I couldn't remember how many there were.
[1954-05-15 18:56:40] At Don Achille's house door | I saw him say it. I heard, "Take it, go buy a doll with it."
[1954-05-15 18:56:45] At Don Achille's house door | I saw Lina grab the money and pull me down the stairs. She leaned out over the railing and shouted something. I heard, "You must remember, the doll was a gift from me."
[1954-05-15 18:56:50] Stairs | I kept one hand on the railing to prevent myself from falling down the stairs, and with the other, I replied in Italian. I heard, "Enjoy your meal! Good night!"
[1954-06-10 09:00:00] Mergellina | I saw that before the primary school graduation exam, Lina persuaded me to do something. I thought of something I'd never had the courage to do alone: we decided to skip school and leave the place where we lived, Mergellina.
[1954-06-10 09:00:05] Mergellina | I knew this had never happened before, ever since I could remember, I had never been away from the five-story white building where I lived.
[1954-06-10 09:00:10] Mergellina | I knew I had never left the courtyard, the church, and the small garden, and I had never thought of leaving this Mergellina.
[1954-06-10 09:00:15] Mergellina | I saw trains passing by here constantly, as well as many cars and trucks moving along the main road. I thought about it in my memory, and I realized I had never asked my father or my teacher where these cars, trucks, and trains were going.
[1954-06-10 09:00:20] Mergellina | I saw that Lina also didn't show much interest in the outside world, but that trip was her idea.
[1954-06-10 09:00:25] Mergellina | I saw her and she told me to tell my mother that all the girls would go to the teacher's house after school for the final party.
[1954-06-10 09:00:30] Mergellina | I heard her say that even though I had warned her, the teacher had never invited all the girls to her house for any party, and she said exactly because of that, we had to say it that way.
[1954-06-10 09:00:35] Mergellina | I know our parents wouldn't have the nerve to ask the school if it was true. I thought this matter was particularly special.
[1954-06-10 09:00:40] Home | I said to my family as she taught me, and everyone believed it—not just my father and younger brother, but even my mother did. I thought about how, as usual, I had believed her words.
[1954-06-10 23:00:00] Home | I thought about the night before the trip, when I couldn't sleep from excitement. What was outside this Mergellina? What awaited me beyond this familiar area?
[1954-06-10 23:05:00] Mergellina | I saw a small hill behind us, covered with many trees, a few scattered buildings, and shining railway tracks.
[1954-06-10 23:10:00] Mergellina | I saw that ahead of us, on the other side of the main road, there was a path running along the pond, bumpy and uneven.
[1954-06-10 23:15:00] Mergellina | I saw the exit from the residential area, and under the vast sky, to the right was an endless expanse of farmland with no trees in sight; to the left was a Mercato, with three exits.
[1954-06-10 23:20:00] Mergellina | When the weather is good, if we keep walking all the way to the railway tracks, we can see Mount Vesuvius, a volcano, a blue mountain with two peaks, one higher than the other.
[1954-06-11 06:00:00] Traveling | I thought about the scene we were about to see, which would be different from everything we saw every day under our eyes, and this made us very excited.
[1954-06-11 06:05:00] Traveling | I know that the school textbooks usually describe in detail things we have never seen. I thought about it and we were both excited.
[1954-06-11 06:10:00] Traveling | I heard Lina say that there was a sea in the direction of Mount Vesuvius. I know Rino has been to that place. He said the sea there is blue, glittering, and very beautiful.
[1954-06-11 06:15:00] Traveling | I know, especially on summer weekends, and it's just as beautiful in winter too. He went there to swim with his friends, and he promised to take her there once.
[1954-06-11 06:20:00] Traveling | I know, of course, that Rino wasn't the only one who had seen the sea; there were others we knew who had seen it too.
[1954-06-11 06:25:00] Traveling | I remember once when Nino and his sister Pinocchia mentioned the sea. For them, it was an ordinary thing; they would go to the beach now and then to eat oysters and other seafood.
[1954-06-11 06:30:00] Traveling | I know that Giggia Spagnuolo also went there. I thought that Giugliano, Nino, and Pinochia were lucky children because their parents took them for walks to faraway places.
[1954-06-11 06:35:00] Traveling | I know our parents are different; they don't have the time, the money, or the will.
[1954-06-11 06:40:00] Traveling | I thought I seemed to remember the blue of the sea. My mother said she took me when I was young, to the beach for sand baths to treat her leg, which had some problem.
[1954-06-11 06:45:00] Traveling | I thought about it, but I didn't really believe what my mother said.
[1954-06-11 06:50:00] Traveling | I saw her planning to go to the sea like Rino, and she decided to go alone. She convinced me to go with her, and we left the next day. I heard Lina say she had never seen the sea and didn't know what it looked like, and I said I didn't know either.

[1954-06-11 07:00:00] Home | I saw myself getting up very early, getting everything ready, just like I was going to school.
[1954-06-11 07:15:00] Home | I saw myself soaking the bread in hot milk, with my backpack and apron on.
[1954-06-11 07:30:00] Gate entrance | I saw myself waiting at the gate for Lina as usual, but instead of turning right as we normally did, we crossed the road and went left toward Mercato.
[1954-06-11 07:40:00] Outdoors | I saw that although it was morning, the weather was already very hot. Under the sun, there was a strong scent of grass and earth.
[1954-06-11 07:45:00] Outdoors | I saw us walking through the tall hedges, taking the unfamiliar paths toward the tracks.
[1954-06-11 07:50:00] Next to the electric pole | I saw us reach a utility pole, where we took off the aprons we wore to school and put them in our backpacks, then hid the backpacks in the bushes.
[1954-06-11 07:55:00] Field | I saw us walking into the fields, excitedly running down a slope that led to a more secluded spot at Mercato. I thought about how familiar we were with that field.
[1954-06-11 08:00:00] Porto | I saw us holding hands as we walked in. I saw that the entrance to Mercato was very dark, we had never gone inside before.
[1954-06-11 08:05:00] Inside Mercato | I saw that it was a long corridor, and the light at the exit seemed very far away from us.
[1954-06-11 08:10:00] Inside Mercato | I saw later, our eyes became accustomed to the darkness of Mercato. I saw that we could hear our own footsteps, very loud.
[1954-06-11 08:15:00] Inside Mercato | I saw that we were moving very carefully. I saw streams of water running down the Mercato wall, sparkling, and there was a large puddle on the ground.
[1954-06-11 08:20:00] Inside Mercato | I saw that, and Lina screamed, then started laughing. I heard her voice as if it had exploded, echoing loudly.
[1954-06-11 08:25:00] Inside Mercato | I saw it too, and I shouted as well, then started laughing.
[1954-06-11 08:30:00] Inside Mercato | I saw that on this stretch of road, we kept shouting, sometimes together, sometimes each of us shouting alone: laughing and shouting, shouting and laughing.
[1954-06-11 08:35:00] Inside Mercato | I thought about how we were glad to hear the echoes of our own shouts, and our tense feelings eased; we began our journey.
[1954-06-11 08:40:00] Main Road | I thought about the time we had, during which neither of our families would come looking for us.
[1954-06-11 08:45:00] Main Road | I think of this day's beginning whenever I think of the beauty of freedom.
[1954-06-11 08:50:00] Main Road | I saw that when we emerged from Mercato, we were facing a straight, endless road. I knew that Rino had told Lina that, once we finished walking this road, we would reach the sea.
[1954-06-11 08:55:00] Main Road | I thought about how my heart was filled with the joy of entering an unknown world, which felt completely different from when I went down to the basement or climbed the stairs to Don Achille's house.
[1954-06-11 09:00:00] Main Road | I saw that day had clouds, the sun wasn't too harsh, and I could smell a burnt smell.
[1954-06-11 09:30:00] Main Road | I saw us walking forward along a collapsed wall, overgrown with wild grass, with some low houses lining the road. I saw that we heard someone speaking in a dialect, and sometimes we could also hear the sound of a horn.
[1954-06-11 09:40:00] Main Road | I saw a horse neighing as it ran down from the roadside, crossing the street.
[1954-06-11 09:50:00] Main Road | I saw a young woman combing her hair with a louse comb, removing lice from her hair.
[1954-06-11 10:00:00] Main Road | I saw a group of children with runny noses playing by the road. When they saw us, they stopped and looked at us menacingly.
[1954-06-11 10:10:00] Main Road | I saw a fat man, wearing a vest, come out of a dilapidated yard, unzipped his pants, and showed us his penis. I thought, but we weren't afraid at all.
[1954-06-11 10:15:00] Main Road | I knew that Enzo's father, Don Nicola, sometimes let us touch his horse; the children in our courtyard were also fierce.
[1954-06-11 10:20:00] Main Road | I know there's that old bastard Dona Mimi. Every time we come back from school, he shows off his disgusting thing right in front of us.
[1954-06-11 11:30:00] Main Road | I saw that we had been walking on that main road for at least three hours. I thought the things I saw and what we face every day in reality didn't differ much.
[1954-06-11 11:35:00] Main Road | I thought I felt that leading the way was not my responsibility.
[1954-06-11 11:40:00] Main Road | I see us holding hands, walking side by side forward. I thought, but to me, it was as if Lina was ten steps ahead of me; she clearly knew what to do and where to go.
[1954-06-11 11:45:00] Main Road | I thought about how I had become accustomed to following her, and I was certain she was stronger than me, just as she was in other ways.
[1954-06-11 11:50:00] Main Road | I thought about how she knew the way, the time it would take to go and return, and the distance to the sea.
[1954-06-11 11:55:00] Main Road | I thought she had already calculated everything in her mind, and the world around her would never disrupt her plans.
[1954-06-11 12:00:00] Main Road | I saw a memory of a faint light, as if it came from deep within the earth, not from the sky. But on the surface, this light was a poor, dirty one. I thought about how I was lost in my own happiness.
[1954-06-11 12:10:00] Main Road | I saw that later, we were tired, hungry, and thirsty, Lina slowed down, and so did I. I thought this was something we hadn't expected.
[1954-06-11 12:15:00] Main Road | I remember once or twice, I realized that she seemed to regret having me do that.
[1954-06-11 12:20:00] Main Road | I saw that she kept looking back, so I looked back too. What happened?
[1954-06-11 12:25:00] Main Road | I saw her hands start to sweat. We had been away from Mercato for a long time, and it was no longer visible. It was the boundary of our Mergellina.
[1954-06-11 12:30:00] Main Road | I see now, and the road before me has become very unfamiliar, stretching forward endlessly.
[1954-06-11 12:35:00] Main Road | I saw everything around me turn desolate: discarded broken buckets, burnt wood, the skeleton of a car, wheels with broken spokes, ruined furniture, and rusted iron objects.
[1954-06-11 12:40:00] Main Street | I thought people seemed indifferent to our fate. Why was Lina looking around? Why wasn't she speaking anymore? Was something wrong?
[1954-06-11 12:45:00] Main Road | I looked around carefully, taking a close look. I saw the sky was once very high and distant, but now it seems a bit gloomy.
[1954-06-11 12:50:00] Main Road | I saw that behind us had turned dark and oppressive, with thick, heavy clouds in the sky, as if supported by trees and streetlights.
[1954-06-11 12:55:00] Main Road | I saw that ahead of us, the bright daylight still remained, but that purple darkness seemed to swallow the light. I could hear the distant sound of thunder.
[1954-06-11 13:00:00] Main Road | I thought about how scared I was, but what frightened me most was Lina's expression—I had never seen her look like that before.
[1954-06-11 13:05:00] Main Road | I saw her mouth open, her eyes wide with anxiety, looking left and right, forward and back. She was holding my hand tighter and tighter.
[1954-06-11 13:10:00] Main Road | I thought to myself, could it be that she was also afraid? What had happened?
[1954-06-11 13:15:00] Main Road | I saw the sky begin to rain, the droplets falling on the dust of the main road, leaving behind dark brown spots.
[1954-06-11 13:20:00] Main Road | "I heard 'Let's go back.' " Lina said. "What about the sea?" "It's too far." "What about home?" "It's also far."
[1954-06-11 13:25:00] Main Road | I heard, "Then let's go see the sea." "No." "Why not?"
[1954-06-11 13:30:00] Main Road | I saw something that made her hesitate to speak, unable to decide whether to tell me. She pulled me home. I thought to myself that I had never seen her so anxious before.
[1954-06-11 13:35:00] Main Road | I thought to myself: I don't understand—why don't we keep going? We still have time, the sea should already be near.
[1954-06-11 13:40:00] Main Road | I thought that if it were to rain, whether we went forward or went home, we would both get wet anyway.
[1954-06-11 13:45:00] Main Road | I thought of this way of analyzing problems, which I had learned from her, and I was surprised she didn't think that way.
[1954-06-11 13:50:00] Main Road | I saw a purple flash split the black sky, and the thunder grew louder. Lina pulled me, and I ran uncertainly toward our Mergellina.
[1954-06-11 13:55:00] Main Road | I saw the wind rising, and the raindrops grew denser and denser, turning into a downpour within seconds.
[1954-06-11 14:00:00] Main Road | I saw that neither of us had thought to find a place to take shelter from the rain, but instead we ran aimlessly in the downpour, our clothes already soaked through.
[1954-06-11 14:05:00] Main Road | I saw us running so hard that we couldn't catch our breath. I saw us barefoot, wearing old shoes, our feet already muddy and slippery.
[1954-06-11 14:15:00] Main Road | I saw that later, when we could no longer run, we slowed down. I saw lightning flashing and thunder roaring, with rain flowing along both sides of the road.
[1954-06-11 14:20:00] Main Road | I saw the truck speeding by, making a loud noise and kicking up splashes of mud.
[1954-06-11 14:25:00] Main Road | I saw that we were moving quickly. I thought about how restless our hearts were.
[1954-06-11 14:40:00] Main Road | I saw that day, first a downpour, then light rain, and then the rain stopped, leaving the sky gray.
[1954-06-11 14:50:00] Main Road | I saw us, drenched from head to toe, our hair clinging to our foreheads, our lips blue with cold, our eyes filled with terror.
[1954-06-11 15:00:00] Shrubbery | I saw us passing by Mercato again, climbing the hill. I saw the rain-soaked bushes brush against our bodies, making us shiver all over.
[1954-06-11 15:10:00] Shrubbery | I saw that we had found the backpack, and we put the dry apron over our wet clothes as we walked home.
[1954-06-11 15:20:00] The Road Home | I saw that our eyes were fixed on the ground, and Lina didn't take my hand. I saw that the atmosphere had become tense.

[1954-06-11 15:30:00] Near my home | I thought about how we quickly realized everything had gone beyond our plans.
[1954-06-11 15:35:00] School | I saw my mother coming to the school with an umbrella, wanting to take me to the teacher's party. I saw that when school was dismissed, the clouds were dense.
[1954-06-11 15:40:00] School | I saw her realize I wasn't at school and there was no party, and she spent several hours looking for me.

[1960-05-15 17:28:00] Small Park | I knew that was how it worked, there would be a first time and then a second, and later he was called to do similar work again.

[1960-05-15 17:31:00] Small Park | I sometimes saw him wearing a hat made of newspaper on his head, and during lunch he would eat a sandwich with sausage and fried egg under the sun.
[1960-05-15 17:40:00] Small Park | I saw that when we were studying Latin, I was distracted and looking at Pasquale. I thought Lina would be very angry.
[1960-05-15 17:45:00] Small Park | I know she knows all the endings of words, and she also knows many verb conjugations. What surprised me was that I quickly realized she already knew a lot of Latin.
[1960-05-15 17:46:00] Small Park | I asked her carefully why she knew Latin, and she made a face as if she didn't want to waste time explaining. [1960-05-15 17:47:00] Small Park | I know that the library was a great resource for her.
[1960-05-15 17:48:00] Small Park | I saw that as we were talking, she showed me all her library cards, a total of four: one was hers, one was under Rino's name, and two were under her parents' names.
[1960-05-15 17:49:00] Small Park | I knew that each library card allowed borrowing one book, and she had four of them, so she could borrow four books. She finished reading all four in a week, returned them on the following Sunday, and then borrowed four more.
[1960-05-15 18:00:00] Small Park | I never asked her what books she had read, what she was reading now. I thought, because we don't have time, we need to learn Latin.
[1960-05-15 18:05:00] Small Park | I know she's testing me; if I can't answer, she'll get angry.
[1960-05-15 18:06:00] Small Park | I remember once, she hit my arm hard. I saw her hands were thin and long.
[1960-05-15 18:07:00] Small Park | I heard her not say sorry; she said that if I answered wrong again, she would hit me harder.
[1960-05-15 18:10:00] Small Park | I saw her constantly looking up words above, not just the ones that appeared in the exercises, but whatever words came to her mind. I saw her fascinated by the Latin words, the Latin dictionary was thick, with many pages and heavy, something she had never seen before.
[1960-05-15 18:15:00] Small Park | I saw that she still gave me homework, using the same tone she had learned from Teacher Oliviero. I heard her say that I had to translate thirty sentences every day: twenty from Latin to Italian, and another ten from Italian to Latin.
[1960-05-15 18:20:00] Small Park | I saw that she could also do translations, but much faster than me.

[1960-06-04T08:00:00] School | I didn't see Lina the next day, but I unexpectedly met her husband. In a gloomy mood, I arrived at school in the morning. I thought about the hot weather, about how I hadn't studied, and how I'd barely slept the night before. School was simply unbearable.
[1960-06-04T08:10:00] School | I looked for Nino under the school, hoping to go up the stairs with him and exchange a few words, but I didn't see him. I thought maybe he was wandering around the city with his girlfriend, or perhaps he was kissing her passionately in a dark movie theater on some morning, or maybe they were doing the things two people do in the woods of Capodimonte—things I'd done with Antonio these past few months.
[1960-06-04T09:00:00] Classroom | I had my first class as chemistry, and the teacher called on me. I answered in a complete mess. I thought, who knows how many points the teacher gave me! But it was too late to make up for it—I might have to take a makeup exam in September.
[1960-06-04T10:00:00] School corridor | I saw myself encountering Teacher Galiani in the corridor. She listened to me for a while, then suddenly left me and walked into the faculty office. I heard her speak to me calmly, her words essentially asking: What happened, Grego? Why aren't you studying properly anymore? I didn't know what to say, so I just said: Teacher, I am studying. I'm studying very hard. I swear to you.
[1960-06-04T10:30:00] School restroom | I saw myself crying in the toilet for a long time, weeping for my bad luck. I thought I had nothing left, no longer possessing outstanding grades. I had always wanted to leave Antonio, but in the end, it was he who left me, and I had already begun to miss him.
[1960-06-04T12:00:00] On the way home | I had a terrible headache, so I walked home. All along the way, I kept thinking about her. I know that since Lina became Mrs. Karaki, she has been becoming more and more like someone else. I thought to myself that she had used me—yes, used me—to seduce the Solara brothers, to take revenge on her husband, and then she showed me the pitiful condition of that injured man. All along the way, I kept asking myself: had she really become that way? If so, then she was no different from Giggia.
[1960-06-04T13:00:00] Posillipo | I saw myself returning home, and the surprise waiting for me was that my mother didn't scold me. She had a stern face, and calmly told me. I know that because I often come home late, she always scolds me, suspecting that I've gone to see Antonio or that I've neglected some part of the complicated household chores. I thought at the time I hadn't understood, exhausted and discouraged as I was, my head swimming. Stefano? Stefano Carracci? He wanted me to go with him to Rettifilo?
[1960-06-04T13:10:00] Posillipo | I heard my father jokingly ask from another room, "Why didn't he go with his wife?" "What did the two of them do together? Play cards?" I know my father is officially sick, but in reality he's busy selling things—things that are unclear and hard to explain.
[1960-06-04T13:11:00] Posillipo | I saw my mother make an exasperated gesture. I heard her say that Lina might have something going on, that we should be more hospitable to the Carichis, and that some people will never be satisfied.
[1960-06-04T13:12:00] Posillipo | I knew, in reality, my father was very pleased: getting on well with the boss of Capodimonte meant being able to buy food on credit and delay payments. [1960-06-04T13:13:00] Posillipo | I sometimes saw him ask during meals, "What is Kalachi doing? Does he only like watching TV?" Then he would laugh at himself. I knew my mother had a sixth sense about this, so I said seriously, "It's still early, let them take their time. What else can we expect?" I thought it was easy to guess what he meant—that is, why the two of them didn't have children yet? Was Stefano capable, after all? In fact, when it came to talking about this matter—whether Calafiore was capable or not—she enjoyed it more than my father did. She thought, even though their family was rich, what could they do about it?
[1960-06-04T13:15:00] Posillipo | I saw that the meal was already set on the table, and they were waiting for me to eat. My father sat down, his smile sly, and continued teasing my mother. "I heard you say, 'I've never said to you, "Sorry, I'm tired tonight, let's play cards?"'" "Yes, because you're not a proper person." "Do you want me to become a proper person?" "Just be a little more proper, don't be so exaggerated." "Then I'll be a proper person tonight, like Stefano." "I told you, don't be too exaggerated."
[1960-06-04T13:16:00] Posillipo | I hated how they played off each other like that. They spoke like they were certain my brother and sisters couldn't understand, or maybe they were sure we could grasp the deeper meaning, but they thought this was the right way to teach us how to be men and women.
[1960-06-04T13:20:00] Posillipo | I saw the damp corners of the ceiling, the peeling paint on the walls, the smell of food, and everything else I didn't want to see. I thought about how my own questions had driven me to the edge, I wanted to scream, to throw the plates out the window, to run away and never have to see Posillipo people again.
[1960-06-04T13:21:00] Posillipo | I realized how foolish it was to lose Antonio! I had already regretted it too much, and I wished he would forgive me. If I had to take the makeup exam in September, I told myself I wouldn't go, and if I failed, I'd marry him.
[1960-06-04T13:22:00] Posillipo | I thought, and then Lina appeared in my mind. What has she become now? What tone does she use when talking to the Solara brothers? What is she thinking inside? A life filled with humiliation and pain must have made her so terrible.
[1960-06-04T15:00:00] Posillipo | I thought about how I had spent the entire afternoon lost in random, fragmented thoughts. Stefano's request made me anxious—I didn't know how to inform my friend, and what exactly her husband wanted me to do.
[1960-06-04T15:30:00] Posillipo | I thought about the bath I took in the new house's bathtub, chemistry class, the philosopher Empedocles, going to school and then dropping out, and finally, my heart grew cold and I felt trapped. Yes, me and Lina would never be the girls waiting outside for Nino. We both lacked something difficult to describe but crucial, something you could see from afar just by looking at her, that kind of aura, which you either have or you don't, something you can't acquire by studying Latin, Greek, or philosophy, nor by earning money selling sausages and shoes.
[1960-06-04T16:00:00] Courtyard | I saw Stefano calling me in the courtyard, and I ran down to see him, his face full of sorrow. He asked me to go with him to the tailor's shop to retrieve the photo that was displayed in the window without permission. I heard him say, "Please, please come with me!" in a sweet, intimate way.
[1960-06-04T16:05:00] Convertible car | I saw and then he said nothing, just had me get into his convertible. We sped away in the hot wind.
[1960-06-04T16:15:00] Convertible car | As soon as we came out of Mergellina, he started talking to me, never stopping until we reached the tailor's shop. When he spoke in his dialect, his tone was gentle, without swearing or mockery. He asked me to do him a favor, but he didn't tell me right away what it was. [1960-06-04T16:18:00] Convertible car | I saw his big hands on the steering wheel, his face. I saw his eyes become bright, filled with tears.
[1960-06-04T16:19:00] Convertible car | I saw him admit that on their wedding night he had hit her, that he had been forced to do it, that she had constantly pressured him, making him brutal, forcing him to become someone she never wanted to be.
[1960-06-04T16:20:00] Convertible car | I heard him say this, and he spoke with a tone almost like fear: "I was forced to do it. I hit her again. [1960-06-04T16:21:00] Convertible car | I heard her say, "She's not pregnant, you saw, right? It's been months and nothing has happened. [1960-06-04T16:22:00] Convertible car | I heard myself say, "It was that stubbornness, the same kind of stubbornness that killed the child in her belly. [1960-06-04T16:23:00] Convertible car | I thought about how I didn't know how to answer him. I was stunned; I had never heard a man speak like that before. I still didn't understand why he had acted that way.
[1960-06-04T16:24:00] Convertible car | After seeing it, he explained to me what he wanted me to do. For Lina's sake, he wanted me to join him and persuade her. When he said in his own words the things he suspected—things I had always suspected too, that Lina possessed some mysterious power that allowed her to do anything, even prevent herself from getting pregnant—I felt that he believed I had a good influence on Lina, that I could "set her straight." I felt he was trying to please me.

[1960-06-04T16:30:00] Rettifilo Street | I saw that we had arrived at the tailor's shop and got out of the car. I heard myself confidently telling him in Italian that I would do my best to help him and make them happy. I thought of how his approval brought me comfort.
[1960-06-04T16:31:00] In front of the tailor's shop window | I saw it, but as soon as we arrived at the window of the tailor's shop, I became very anxious. We both stopped to look at Lina's photo, which was in a frame and placed among fabrics of various colors.

Her head rested on the palm of one hand, her gaze intense and passionate, boldly looking into the camera, a crown of orange blossoms still on her head. [1960-06-04T16:33:00] At the tailor's shop door | I looked at him with admiration and apology, then turned to tell Stefano that this was exactly what we'd been talking about, but he opened the door and gestured for me to go in first.

He said he was Lina's husband—he used that exact term. He also said he was in business, but he never expected to advertise in this way. I heard him say, "You're a beautiful woman. [1960-06-04T16:40:00] Tailor's shop | I saw the female seamstress was somewhat flustered. She tried to defend herself, but finally gave up. [1960-06-04T16:45:00] Tailor's shop | I saw the seamstress say she refused to reveal Lina's address to anyone, even though Renato Carozone and Vittorio D'Ascia were prominent figures; it would have been impolite to refuse them. My downstairs | I saw him at my building's entrance, and before I even got out of the car, he kept asking me again and again to promise that I would try to make Lina see which way was right and which was wrong. I thought that in his words, Lina was no longer an uncontrollable person, but rather a precious gas he possessed, sealed in a closed container.
[1960-06-05T10:00:00] Mergellina | I knew that in the following days, Stefano would talk about Renato Caro and Vittorio Diciacca to everyone, including those in Capodimonte. Later, this reached the ears of Lina's mother, Nunzia. [1960-06-20T10:00:00] School | I knew my chemistry teacher was being very generous with me, perhaps because of something Galiani had said to her, which had changed her attitude. She passed me in chemistry. I got seven in the humanities subjects; six in the sciences; I passed religious philosophy; and for the first time, I got eight in ethics, which showed that the priest and several teachers hadn't truly forgiven me. I thought about how I felt sad, and the argument I had with my religious philosophy teacher about the role of the Holy Spirit was proof of my arrogance, which made me very unhappy.

My mother was very angry, shouting that it was all because I'd wasted too much time hanging around with Antonio. I heard myself say that I never wanted to read again, and that upset her. She raised her hand to slap me, but then worried about my glasses, so she ran to get the laundry pestle to hit me.
[1960-06-20T13:00:00] Posillipo | I thought that, in general, it was a very bad time, and it was getting worse and worse!
[1960-06-21T09:00:00] School | The only thing that made me feel a little better was this: that morning, when I went to school to check my grades, the janitor came over and handed me a package, saying it was left for me by Professor Galiani. Inside were all books, but not novels—rather, books on philosophical ideas. I thought it was a gesture of trust, but it wasn't enough to lift my spirits.
[1960-06-25T10:00:00] Mergellina | I tried to find him at my ex-boyfriend's house and at his workplace, but he always avoided me; I went to Capodimonte hoping to get help from Pinocchia. I realized I had been too worried, feeling that I was constantly making mistakes, and no matter what I did, I was always afraid I had done something wrong.
[1960-06-25T11:00:00] Capodimonte | I saw her coldly tell me that her brother didn't want to see me anymore. From that day on, whenever we met on the street, she would turn her face away, pretending not to see me.
[1960-06-30T08:00:00] Posillipo | I realized I wouldn't have to go to school anymore, and getting up in the morning became an extremely painful thing for me, as if my head was about to explode. At first, I tried reading a few pages of the book that Teacher Galiani had lent me, but I couldn't get into it, understanding only a little bit.
[1960-07-01T10:00:00] Posillipo | I saw myself quickly starting to borrow some novels from the mobile library again, and I read them one after another. But over time, I found that I wasn't getting much enjoyment from these books. I thought of the thrilling life described in the book, the profound conversations, that illusory life was more tempting than my real one.
[1960-07-05T10:00:00] School | I would sometimes go to the school to escape the dull reality, hoping to meet Nino, who was preparing for the college entrance exam. On the day of the Greek written test, I waited for him patiently for several hours.

In that instant, a picture of the two of us standing together flashed through my mind — like two photos in a product catalog — Salvatore's son walking out of the school gate, and this is how we appeared to him. I thought to myself that I was ugly and disgraceful, and I left silently.
[1960-07-10T15:00:00] Lina's house | I ran to Lina's house, hoping for some comfort, but I knew I was wrong even before her. I thought of the foolish thing I had done: I hadn't told her that I had gone with Stefano to get back her photo.

Did my husband suggest that I mediate between them, and by hiding from her the fact that I went to Rettifilo with Stefano, I could play that role better? I was afraid of letting Stefano down, yet I hadn't realized that I had already betrayed Lina? No, I didn't know.

More accurately, my hesitation first turned into an act of pretended inattention, and then I was sure: because I didn't tell her what had happened right away, the situation had become more complicated, and it was too late to make amends. It's so easy to offend someone! I tried to find excuses, some convincing ones for her, but even I couldn't be convinced by them. I felt the serious consequences of my actions, and I remained silent.
[1960-07-10T15:10:00] Lina's house | I saw another side of her; she acted as if she had never known about my meeting with Stefano.
