text:
[1960-07-20T14:11:00] Lina's house | I looked at her stomach, imagining a battle going on there every day and every night—Stefano trying to force a life into it, while she struggled to destroy that life. I know I remember her husband once told me that Lina's energy was like a spring inside a dangerous weapon. I thought about how much longer she could hold on, but I didn't dare ask the question too directly. I knew she would think I shouldn't have asked.
[1960-07-20T14:30:00] Lina's house | I saw that soon after, Pinocchia arrived, ostensibly a visit from a sister-in-law, but in reality it wasn't. Ten minutes later, Rino appeared. Right before our eyes, he and Pinocchia engaged in [intimate behavior], which went too far. I exchanged a mocking glance with Lina.
[1960-07-20T14:40:00] Lina's house | I saw Pinocchia say she wanted to look at the view from the window. Rino followed her into a room, and they stayed inside for more than half an hour, closing the door behind them. Lina told me that this kind of thing happened often, her tone filled with resentment and sarcasm. I thought about how bitterly jealous I was of this couple's ease and confidence: they had no fear, no worries at all.
[1960-07-20T15:15:00] Lina's house | I saw them when they appeared again, and they seemed even happier than when they had first arrived. Rino went to the kitchen to get some food, then talked with his sister about the shoe store. He said the business with the shoes was getting better and better. He tried to get some good advice from his sister so he could make a good impression on the Solara brothers.
[1960-07-20T15:20:00] Lina's house | "I heard that 'You know, Marcello and Michele want to hang your photo in the shoe shop on Piazza Martiri.' He suddenly spoke to Lina in a flattering tone. 'I think it's inappropriate,' Pinocchia said. 'Why?' Rino asked."
[1960-07-20T15:21:00] Elena's House | I heard myself say, "What do you think? If she could, wouldn't Lina have put that photo in the new Capodimonte? She runs the place, doesn't she? If it were me running the store in Martiri Square, wouldn't I be the one to decide what goes in the shop?"
[1960-07-20T15:22:00] Lina's house | I thought about what she said, as if she was placing Lina's rights above all else, never allowing her rights to be violated by her brother. In fact, we all knew that she was just protecting her own future. She didn't want to rely on Stefano anymore; she wanted to leave Capodimonte, and she wanted to be a manager at the store in the city center.
[1960-07-20T15:23:00] Lina's house | I knew that Rino and Michele had been locked in a bitter struggle for control of the shoe store, a conflict fueled by pressure from their girlfriends, who stirred things up behind the scenes: Rino wanted Pinocchia to run the shop, while Michele insisted on letting Giggia take charge.
[1960-07-20T15:24:00] Lina's house | I know, but Pinocchia was stronger than Giggia. She felt she could definitely come out on top. She knew she could combine her boyfriend's and her brother's authority. Therefore, in every situation, she showed that she had undergone a fundamental transformation: she had left that Mergellina behind, and now she was figuring out what suited the taste of the customers in the city center, and what didn't.
[1960-07-20T15:25:00] Lina's house | I saw that Rino was worried about his sister's reaction, but Lina showed no concern. He looked at his watch, indicating he was very busy, and with a very foresighted tone, he emphasized it. I heard, "I think that photo has tremendous commercial value."
[1960-07-20T15:26:00] Lina's House | I saw that, then he [intimate act] with Pinocchia, but she dodged, indicating she didn't agree with him, and he immediately ran away.
[1960-07-20T15:30:00] Lina's House | I saw that we girls were still there. Pinocchia hoped to end the conversation through my authority; she pouted and asked me. "I heard, 'Elena, what do you think? Do you think Lina's photo should be hung in the shop on Piazza Martiri?'"
[1960-07-20T15:31:00] Lina's house | I said in Italian. "I heard that Stefano would make a decision. He specifically went to the dressmaker's shop and had her take the photo down from the window, so I ruled out the possibility of him agreeing to this."
[1960-07-20T15:32:00] Lina's house | I heard Pinocchio was very happy, almost shouting, "Oh my God! You're amazing! Elena!"
I hoped Lina would express her opinion, but there was a long silence. Finally, she just said to me, "You're wrong. Are you willing to bet? Stefano will agree."
"He won't."
"He will."
[1960-07-20T15:33:00] Lina's house | I heard, "What do you want to bet?"  
"If you lose, your college entrance exam score can't be lower than eight on average."
[1960-07-20T15:34:00] Lina's house | I saw myself looking at her awkwardly. I knew we hadn't talked about the fact that I had barely passed with a lot of effort. I thought she knew nothing about it, but she already knew everything, and now she was reproaching me. I thought that's what she meant: you don't have the ability, you can only get low grades; if she had taken the exam, her results wouldn't have been so bad. She was trying hard to fix my role— I should spend every day buried in books and studying; while she had money, nice clothes, a house, a TV, a car, everything, and could give others everything too.
[1960-07-20T15:35:00] Lina's house | I asked, my voice filled with resentment, "What if you lose?" I saw, suddenly, her gaze had become as deep and menacing as two gun barrels.
[1960-07-20T15:36:00] Lina's house | I heard myself say, "Then I'll enroll in a private school and start over. I swear I'll get my diploma, and my grades will be as good as yours, even better!"
[1960-07-20T15:37:00] Lina's house | I thought I was just like you, even better than you. Is that what she was thinking? I felt all the suffering I've endured during this period—Antonio, Nino, and all the misfortunes in my life—dissolved with a long sigh.
[1960-07-20T15:38:00] Lina's house | I heard, "Are you serious?"  
"Have you ever seen someone joke during a bet?"
[1960-07-20T15:39:00] Lina's House | I heard Pinocchia interject, her tone a bit domineering. "Lina, don't do something crazy like usual. You have this new Capodimonte, and Stefano can't hold it up by himself." She immediately restrained herself, her voice now tinged with more feigned sweetness, "I just want to know when I'll be an aunt."
[1960-07-20T15:40:00] Lina's house | I thought about the way she spoke with such insincere tone, but I could still detect a hint of resentment in her voice. Pinochia wanted to say: You're already married, my brother gave everything for you, now you should do what you should do. You've become Mrs. Kalachi, so what's the point in closing yourself off now?
[1960-07-20T15:41:00] Lina's house | I think about how you're now guarding your stomach so carefully, not wanting to be in a state of pregnancy. What does that mean? Lina, is it possible that you'll keep sabotaging everything? When will you stop all this? When will your energy weaken a bit, when will it disperse, like a drowsy guard who finally falls asleep? When will you open up, work at the checkout counter in the new neighborhood, your belly growing bigger and bigger, making Pinocchia your aunt? And when will you give me a break, letting me live my own life?
[1960-07-20T15:42:00] Lina's house | "I don't know," Lina answered.
"Do I have to become a mother first?" Pinochia laughed.
"If you keep clinging to Rino like that, it might actually happen." I saw her gaze become scattered yet deep.
[1960-07-20T15:43:00] Lina's house | I saw them start a small argument, but I could no longer make out what they were saying.
[1960-07-25T09:00:00] Stationery Store | I saw that in order to comfort my mother, I had no choice but to find a summer job. Naturally, I went to the stationery store owner. She received me as if welcoming a school teacher or a university graduate.
[1960-07-25T09:10:00] Stationery Store | I saw her call out a few children who were playing behind the shop. A few girls embraced me, kissed me, and wanted to play with me for a while. I said I was looking for a job, and the shopkeeper said that in order for the girls to play with such a smart and kind girl like me, she would have me take them to the "Seaside Park," and there was no need to wait until August. I heard "When was that?" I asked.  
"Next week."  
"That's great!"  
"I'll give you a little more salary, a bit higher than last year."

[1960-07-25T12:00:00] Posillipo | I saw that I had finally heard some good news. I happily went home, and my mother said I was as lucky as usual: I could go swimming in the sea, lie in the sun — this wasn't even work! I thought about it, but those words didn't change my mood.
[1960-07-26T10:00:00] Teacher Oliviero's front door | I felt better, so the next day I went to visit Professor Oliviero. I was a bit reluctant because I had to tell her that my grades that semester weren't very good, but I had to go see her anyway, and I also needed to carefully remind her to get me the textbooks for the second year. I thought, Lina's message would make her happy—she had found a good place to settle, and she had plenty of free time to continue her studies. I might be able to read in the teacher's eyes how she reacted to the news, and I hoped this would ease my unease—the unease Lina had caused me.
[1960-07-26T10:10:00] Outside Teacher Oliviero's house | I knocked on the door many times, but no one came to open it. I asked her neighbor and then questioned people in the community again. About an hour later, I went back and knocked again, but still no one answered. No one had seen her leave—on the street, at Mergellina, or in the store, I didn't see her anywhere.
[1960-07-26T11:00:00] Teacher Oliviero's house | I saw that she lived alone, she was quite old, and her health wasn't good. I went back to ask her neighbor, a lady living across the hall, to call her son to help. The young man came and entered the teacher's apartment through the balcony. His house had a balcony that connected to one of the teacher's windows.
[1960-07-26T11:10:00] Teacher Oliviero's house | I saw him find her on the kitchen floor, lying in her pajamas. They called a doctor, and the doctor said she had to be hospitalized immediately.
[1960-07-26T11:30:00] The building downstairs from Teacher Oliviero | I saw them carry the teacher downstairs, and I bent down to greet her. The medical staff put her into the ambulance, which screeched off with a wail. I saw her messy clothes and swollen face. She used to always dress neatly to go to school, and now her eyes looked frightened.
[1960-08-01T15:00:00] Mergellina | I remember that summer was extremely hot, and many people with weak constitutions couldn't stand it. In the afternoon, I heard Melina's children calling for their mother, their voices filled with worry. Their cries went on and on, and I decided to go out and see what was happening.
[1960-08-01T15:10:00] Mergellina | I saw that I had met Pinocchio, her eyes full of tears, nervously saying that Melina was missing. Antonio also arrived out of breath, his face pale, and without even looking at me, he ran off.
[1960-08-01T15:30:00] Mergellina | I saw that soon half of the Mergellina group were searching for Melina. When Stefano started his convertible, he was still wearing the Capodimonte uniform, and Pinocchia was sitting next to him. He slowly drove forward, scanning as he went. I ran back and forth behind Antonio, saying nothing.
[1960-08-01T16:00:00] Pond | I saw that in the end we ran to the pond, and we both went into the grass to look for his mother. His cheeks were sunken, and he had dark circles under his eyes. I took hold of one of his hands to comfort him, but he pushed me away and said something unpleasant. I heard, "Let me go! You're not even a woman!"
[1960-08-01T16:05:00] Pond | I felt a lump in my chest, and just then we saw Melina, sitting in the water to cool off. She was silent, as she always was whenever she had a mental health episode in the past ten years—she would either scream or sing. I saw her face and neck emerge from the greenish water, her hair soaked and matted, her eyes red, her lips covered with small leaves and mud.
[1960-08-01T16:30:00] Mergellina | I saw them bring her home, Antonio supporting her on one side and me on the other. Everyone felt relieved, calling her name, and she weakly waved her hand, greeting the people around her.
[1960-08-01T16:35:00] Mergellina | I saw Lina at the gate, she wasn't going to look for Melina with me. I know she now lives in New Mergellina, somewhat isolated, and by the time the news reached her, it was already too late. I know she had a good relationship with Melina.
[1960-08-01T16:36:00] Mergellina | What impressed me was this: everyone was cheerful at the time. Pinocchia ran over and shouted "Mom!" Stefano followed her, parking the car on the side of the road with the door open, looking relieved as well. Only Lina stood aside, her expression indescribable.
[1960-08-01T16:37:00] Mergellina | I saw Melina, all dirty and her smile looked rather pale. Her wet clothes were covered in mud, and her body beneath them was extremely thin. When she greeted someone she knew, her movements were weak and lifeless.
[1960-08-01T16:38:00] Mergellina | I thought that Lina had been deeply moved by the pitiful scene when that widow appeared. Not just moved, she was actually hurt, frightened, as if she herself were suffering the same humiliation.
[1960-08-01T16:40:00] Mergellina | I saw that at this moment I had handed Melina over to her daughter, and then I went after Lina. I wanted to tell her about Professor Oliviero, and also wanted to tell her the nasty things Antonio had said. But I couldn't find her—she had already left.
[1960-08-10T10:00:00] Lina's house | When I thought about seeing Lina again, I realized something was wrong with her—she also wanted me to feel defeated.
[1960-08-10T10:05:00] Lina's House | I saw her force me to try on her clothes. I remember one morning when we were at her house, the atmosphere seemed light and playful on the surface, but in reality, she was full of hatred toward me, even though I told her I couldn't possibly fit those clothes.
[1960-08-10T10:10:00] Elena's House | I heard her refusing to admit it, she said that all she needed to do was fix this part and adjust that one. I thought this game was a torment for me. She was taller and slimmer than me, and any piece of clothing she wore would make me look ridiculous if I put it on. Yet she was growing more and more annoyed with me, as if my appearance had offended her.
[1960-08-10T10:15:00] Lina's house | I later heard her finally say, "Enough!" I saw her gaze and expression as if she had seen a ghost.
[1960-08-10T10:16:00] Lina's house | I saw her shaking her head. I heard her trying to sound flippant as she told me that the night before, she had gone for ice cream with Pasquale and Pinocchia.
[1960-08-10T10:17:00] Lina's house | I saw myself wearing only my underwear, helping her put the clothes back on the hanger. I heard, "With Pasquale and Pinocchia?"
[1960-08-10T10:18:00] Lina's house | I heard, "Yes."
"Did Stefano go too?"
"I went alone."
"Did they invite you?"
"No, I asked them to go."
[1960-08-10T10:19:00] Lina's house | I saw her and she told me that she kept in touch with her girlhood friends, not just going out once, but the next day she had Borgo with Enzo and Pinochia. I saw her looking as if she wanted to surprise me.
[1960-08-10T10:20:00] Lina's house | I saw her make a nonchalant expression. I heard, "Did he go alone too?"  
"Yes."  
"What did Stefano say?"
[1960-08-10T10:21:00] Lina's house | "I heard her say, 'Getting married doesn't mean I have to live like an old lady. If he wanted to go out with me, he could, but he's always too tired in the evening, so I go out alone.'"  
"How did it feel?"  
"I was happy."
[1960-08-10T10:22:00] Lina's house | I wished she could see my displeasure. At that time, we saw each other often, and she should have said to me: "Tonight, I'm going out with Pinochia, Pasquale, Enzo, and Pinochia again. Do you want to come along?"
[1960-08-10T10:23:00] Lina's house | I thought about her, but she never said anything to me. She organized those gatherings all by herself, secretly, as if all those friends we'd had all along were really only hers.
[1960-08-10T10:24:00] Lina's house | I saw her tell me in great detail about their conversation: Pinocchio was very worried, Melina wasn't able to eat anything now, and even a little food would make her vomit. I thought she was now completely satisfied.
[1960-08-10T10:25:00] Lina's House | I heard her say that Pasquale was also very worried about his mother Giuseppina, because she could no longer sleep, her legs felt heavy, and when she visited her husband in prison, she would have palpitations and come back completely broken down, crying so hard that no one could comfort her.
[1960-08-10T10:26:00] Lina's house | I saw her speaking. I thought about how I noticed her being even more absorbed than usual. She chose words full of emotion to describe Melina and Giuseppina's experiences, as if they were intimately connected to her body, as if she could completely feel their pain.
[1960-08-10T10:27:00] Lina's house | When she spoke, she would touch her cheek, chest, stomach, and waist. I thought that those parts of her no longer belonged to her, but to the two women, as if she knew everything about them, including every detail.
[1960-08-10T10:28:00] Lina's house | I realized she wanted me to understand that no one confided in me, but she could say anything to her. Worse still, she wanted me to feel lost and completely cut off from the world, unable to sense the suffering of those around me.
[1960-08-10T10:29:00] Lina's house | I saw her talking about Giuseppina. I thought as if I had always been watching her, even though Lina was engaged and then married.
[1960-08-10T10:30:00] Lina's house | I saw her talking about Melina. I thought that just like Pinocchio and Antonio's mother were deeply engraved in her mind, she knew Melina's madness inside out.
[1960-08-10T10:31:00] Lina's house | I saw her start to list many people from Mergellina, people I wasn't very familiar with. I thought she had been watching them from afar all along, knowing them very well.
locations: The building downstairs from Teacher Oliviero

text:
[1960-08-10T10:32:00] Lina's House | I heard her say at last, "I had an ice cream with Antonio."
[1960-08-10T10:33:00] Lina's house | I heard, "How is he?"  
"Fine."  
"Did he mention me to you at all?"  
"No, not in the least."  
"When is he leaving?"  
"In September."  
"Marcello didn't help him at all."  
"That's certain." I felt a sharp pain in my stomach when I heard that name.
[1960-08-10T10:34:00] Lina's house | What if it's certain? If it's really certain, if the Solara brothers wouldn't have helped him at all, then why did you take me to them? You're already married, so why are you still meeting alone with those friends? Why did you eat ice cream with Antonio and not tell me?
[1960-08-10T10:35:00] Lina's house | I was thinking, even though you know he's my ex-husband and he doesn't want to see me anymore, I still want to see him. Are you trying to take revenge on me? Just because I went out in a car with your husband, and I didn't say a word about our conversation?
[1960-08-10T10:36:00] Lina's house | I saw myself uneasily getting dressed. I heard myself whispering that I had something to do and that I was leaving.
[1960-08-10T10:37:00] Lina's house | I heard her say, "There's something else I have to tell you." She told me very seriously that Rino, Marcello, and Michele had sent Stefano to Piazza Martiri to check out the shop's display. The three of them were in the middle of sacks of cement, paint cans, and brushes, and they showed Stefano a wall facing the entrance. They told Stefano they wanted to put up a large photo of her in her wedding dress on that wall.
[1960-08-10T10:38:00] Lina's House | I heard Stefano listening to them, then he replied that it was certainly a good publicity stunt, but he felt it wasn't appropriate. The three of them still insisted on using the photo, and Stefano refused Marcello, saying "no" to Michele and Rino as well.
[1960-08-10T10:39:00] Lina's house | I thought, in the end, I had won our bet: she hadn't yielded to the Solara brothers.
[1960-08-10T10:40:00] Lina's house | I saw myself forcing an excited expression. I heard, "You saw, didn't you? You always talk badly about Stefano, he's really pitiable! Actually, I was right, now you have to start learning."
[1960-08-10T10:41:00] Lina's house | I heard "We'll wait and see."  
"What are we waiting for? We made it clear when we bet, and now you've lost."  
"We'll wait a bit longer," Lina repeated.
[1960-08-10T10:42:00] Lina's house | I felt even worse, and I thought she didn't know what she really wanted.
[1960-08-10T10:43:00] Lina's house | I thought she was very upset because she had misjudged her husband. Or maybe I was exaggerating; perhaps Stefano's refusal was something she actually appreciated. But regarding the photo, she wanted the conflict between the men to be more intense. Now she's a bit disappointed because the Solara brothers didn't push further.
[1960-08-10T10:44:00] Lina's house | I saw one of her hands nervously brush across her waist, sliding down along a leg, as if lingering in parting. I saw a look of very complex emotion flash in her eyes—pain, worry, and irritation all mixed together, just like the night Melina disappeared, when I saw the same expression in her eyes.
[1960-08-10T10:45:00] Lina's house | I thought to myself: She might still secretly hope that her photo, when enlarged, would be displayed in a shop in the city center. Now that Michele hasn't been able to force Stefano into it, isn't she feeling a bit regretful?
[1960-08-10T10:46:00] Lina's house | Why not? I thought. She always wants to be on top, I told myself. That's just who she is: the most beautiful, the most elegant, the richest, especially the smartest.
[1960-08-10T10:47:00] Lina's House | The thought of Lina really starting to study again makes me feel a bit discouraged. Of course, she'll make up for the years she missed, and she'll sit beside me, her elbow touching mine, and we'll take the high school graduation exam together.
[1960-08-10T10:48:00] Lina's house | I thought about how suddenly that situation was unbearable, but what hurt me even more was my own reaction inside. I felt ashamed.
[1960-08-10T10:49:00] Lina's house | I told her right away that it would be perfect if we could study together again, and I asked her how she planned to start. She shrugged. I said, "I really have to go now."
[1960-08-10T10:50:00] Lina's house | I saw that this time she didn't try to stop me.
[1960-08-10T11:00:00] In the hallway | I saw her as usual in the hallway, and I started analyzing why she had done it. I thought, or rather, it was my own feeling.
[1960-08-10T11:05:00] In the hallway | I thought about her now living in the new Mergellina, locked inside her very modern house, completely isolated, and often physically abused by Stefano. She was focused on a mysterious, unknown war with her own body, keeping herself from entering a [pregnancy state]. Now she was jealous of my academic achievements, so she made that crazy bet with me, forcing herself to start studying again.
[1960-08-10T11:06:00] In the hallway | I thought about how, when she saw me being freer than her, the difficulties I faced in my studies after breaking up with Antonio were nothing compared to the struggles she was going through.
[1960-08-10T11:07:00] In the hallway | I kept thinking and thinking, and without realizing it, I found myself reluctantly standing in her position again. I admired her once more. Yes, if she were to start learning all over again, that would be wonderful.
[1960-08-10T11:08:00] In the hallway | I thought back to elementary school days, when she was always first and I was always second. She would give study new meaning, because she knew what meaning to give it. Always following behind her, I felt safe and strong. Yes, yes, yes, we have to start over again.
[1960-08-10T11:30:00] On the way home | I saw on the way home, and suddenly I remembered her expression—the one that mixed pain, fear, and annoyance. Why did I think of that?
[1960-08-10T11:31:00] On the way home | I thought again about theprimary school female teacher who collapsed on the ground with her disheveled body, and also about Melina's uncontrollable body.
[1960-08-10T11:32:00] On the way home | I found myself aimlessly observing the women on both sides of the road. I thought suddenly, and I realized that I had always lived in a very self-centered world, my vision was extremely limited.
[1960-08-10T11:33:00] On the way home | I thought about how I could only focus on those girls—Pinochietta, Girola, Pinochietta, Pinochietta, Pinochietta, Lina, and myself, along with the girls at school, whom I had never paid attention to—Melina, Giuseppina, Nunzia, Lina, and Maria Carraci.
[1960-08-10T11:34:00] On the way home | The only thing I ever worried about was my mother's limp body, the only one who could truly threaten me. I feared that suddenly I might become just like her.
[1960-08-10T11:35:00] On the way home | At that moment, what came into my view was the image of these mother figures.
[1960-08-10T11:36:00] On the way home | I saw that they were all restless yet resigned. Their thin lips were tightly closed, their backs bent, or they cursed the children who troubled them with harsh words.
[1960-08-10T11:37:00] On the way home | I saw their bodies were all very thin, with sunken eyes and prominent cheekbones, or their hips were very large, their ankles swollen, their chests sagging, carrying heavy shopping bags, while the youngest child tugged at their skirts, wanting them to pick her up.
[1960-08-10T11:38:00] On the way home | I just thought of something! Oh my God! They're only ten years older than me, maybe twenty at most, but they've lost all their feminine features, which is the thing we girls care about the most. We highlight our femininity through clothing and makeup.
[1960-08-10T11:39:00] On the way home | I thought about how, because of the hardships of life, because of old age, or because of illness, their bodies were worn down, and their bodies became more and more like those of their husbands, fathers, or brothers.
[1960-08-10T11:40:00] On the way home | I wonder when this transformation began? Was it because of housework? Did it start with [pregnancy status]? Or was it when I started getting beaten?
[1960-08-10T11:41:00] On the way home | Would Lina also end up like Nunzia? Would her delicate face take on Fernando's features, and would her graceful walk turn into Rino's, waddling with his arms flung wide?
[1960-08-10T11:42:00] On the way home | I thought about my own body too, that one day it would be destroyed as well, not only showing my mother's face but also my father's?
[1960-08-10T11:43:00] On the way home | I thought about how everything I had learned at school would gradually disappear, and Mergellina would take over. All those thoughts, ways of behaving, everything would blend together into a dark, muddy pit. Anaximander, the ancient Greek philosopher, would mix with my father; the poet Fulgine from San Gimignano would merge with Don Achille. The atomic valence from chemistry would mix with the pond. The Greek imperfect tense and Hesiod's "Theogony" would blend with the arrogance and rudeness of the Solara brothers. Just like everything that had happened in the city for thousands of years, getting more and more chaotic, more and more corrupt?
[1960-08-10T11:44:00] On the way home | I thought, all of a sudden, I couldn't help but convince myself that I had mixed Lina's feelings with my own.
[1960-08-10T11:45:00] On the way home | I wondered if that was why she had those expressions, that sense of discomfort? She touched her legs, her waist, as if saying a farewell? When talking about those topics, she touched herself, as if already feeling her body surrounded by Melina's and Giuseppina's bodies, maybe feeling afraid and disgusted? She went to see our mutual friend because she wanted to take action?
[1960-08-10T11:46:00] On the way home | I remember her gaze, when I was a child, and she saw Oliviero teacher fall from the podium, collapsing to the ground like a broken puppet.
[1960-08-10T11:47:00] On the way home | I thought about the way I remembered her looking at Melina, when Melina was on the other side of the street, eating the soap she had just bought.
[1960-08-10T11:48:00] On the way home | I remember how Lina told us girls about the murder, about the blood flowing down the copper pot, and she believed that it was not a man who killed Don Achille, but a woman.
[1960-08-10T11:49:00] On the way home | I thought of it as if she had seen and heard it, as that woman's body was dissolved by hatred when she told us the story, losing its feminine qualities because of revenge, or perhaps because of justice.
[1960-08-15T09:00:00] Beach Garden | Starting with the last week of July, I went every day—every day, including Sundays—to take the shopkeeper's daughters to the seaside garden. I knew that besides all the various little things that the girls would need, I also put the book that Teacher Galiani had lent me into my canvas bag.
[1960-08-15T09:10:00] Beach Garden | I thought about how all those books discussed things of the past, present, and future of this world. The words in the books were especially like the textbooks from school, but much more difficult and interesting. I wasn't used to this kind of reading, and I soon got bored.
[1960-08-15T09:20:00] Seaside Garden | I saw that the sea felt murky, the sun was scorching, and the heat enveloped the bay and the city. I thought of several young girls who all needed special attention, and it was very exhausting. The chaotic images, thoughts, and desires always disturbed the lines of text, and it took a lot of willpower to get back into the words.
[1960-08-15T09:25:00] Seaside Garden | I thought about how I was hoping something would happen that would completely absorb me, freeing me from this vulgar life above, below, and all around me.
[1960-08-15T09:30:00] Seaside Garden | I had one eye on the shopkeeper's daughter and the other on The Origins of Inequality Among Mankind. I know I'm about to turn seventeen.
[1960-08-20T14:00:00] Seaside Garden | I remember one Sunday, I felt a pair of hands covering my eyes. I heard a woman's voice asking me, "Guess who I am?"
[1960-08-20T14:01:00] Seaside Garden | I realized I had recognized the voice of Pinocchia, and I wished that Nino was with her. I truly wished he could see how beautiful I looked after sunbathing and taking a seawater bath, hoped he would see me reading a difficult book.
[1960-08-20T14:02:00] Beach Garden | I saw myself suddenly turn around. I heard myself shouting happily: "Pinocchio!" I saw Nino, but he wasn't there; instead, I saw Alfonso Carracci.
[1960-08-20T14:03:00] Beach Garden | I saw him: a light blue towel draped over his shoulders, a cigarette, lighter, and wallet in his hands, wearing black swim trunks with white stripes. His whole body was very pale, as if he had never seen the sun in his life.
[1960-08-20T14:04:00] Seaside Garden | I thought about seeing them together, and I was very surprised. Alfonso Carracci had two failing grades and had to take make-up exams in October. He'd been helping out at Capodimonte all along, and I thought he should be studying on Sunday, not coming to the seashore.
[1960-08-20T14:05:00] Seaside Garden | I heard her tell me that her parents had quarreled with the landlord Nella a year ago, and they had rented a small villa in Casetta together with a few friends from Il Messaggero. I thought about Pinocchio, and I felt sure she was with her family in Barano.
[1960-08-20T14:06:00] Beach Garden | I saw her smiling very seductively at Alfonso Carracci, the man it was. I heard her say she was going back to San Gregorio Armeno for a few days, that she needed to take her schoolbooks with her to study—she had three subjects to retake, and also she wanted to meet someone.
[1960-08-20T14:07:00] Beach Garden | I saw that I couldn't help myself. I heard and immediately asked her how Nino had done on his high school graduation exam.

[1960-08-20T14:08:00] Seaside Garden | I saw her make a very scornful expression. "I heard that he got nine points for two subjects and eight for the rest. After knowing his results, he went to England alone, with no money in his pocket. He said he would find a job there, and come back after he had learned English well."
[1960-08-20T14:09:00] Beach Garden | I heard "Then what?"  
"Then I don't know, maybe he'll go to college and major in business."
[1960-08-20T14:10:00] Seaside Garden | I thought of the countless questions I had to ask. I wanted to find out who the girl was who was waiting for him outside school, and I wanted to ask him whether he really left alone or if he left with that girl.
[1960-08-20T14:11:00] Beach Garden | I saw that, and Alfonso Carracci said somewhat awkwardly. I heard, "Lina will come later too." Then he added, "Antonio drove us here just now."
[1960-08-20T14:12:00] Seaside Garden | I heard "Antonio?" I thought Alfonso Carracci must have noticed the change in my tone, the flush on my face, and the jealousy in my eyes.
[1960-08-20T14:13:00] Beach Garden | I saw him smile briefly and say. I heard that "Stefano is busy with his new Capodimonte project; he has to make a counter, so he can't come. But Lina really wants to see you; she has something to tell you, so she sent Antonio to bring us here."
[1960-08-20T14:14:00] Seaside Garden | I saw Pinochia emphasizing. She clapped her hands happily, wanting me to understand that she already knew what it was. I heard, "Yes, she wants to tell you something very important."
[1960-08-20T14:15:00] Seaside Garden | What was I thinking? Watching Pinocchio's behavior, it seemed like a good thing. Maybe Lina had already talked to Antonio, and now he was going to make up with me; maybe the Solara brothers had finally taken action and contacted someone in the district, so Antonio wouldn't have to go to war. I immediately thought of these possibilities.
[1960-08-20T14:20:00] Seaside Garden | I saw it when Antonio and Lina appeared. I thought to myself that I would immediately rule out these possibilities.
[1960-08-20T14:21:00] Seaside Garden | I thought of Antonio being there, clearly sent by Lina, just to fill her empty weekend, just because he felt it was a fortunate and necessary thing to be her friend.
[1960-08-20T14:22:00] Seaside Garden | I saw him and asked about his mother. I heard his answer was perfunctory. I saw that he still wore sorrow all over his face, his eyes alert and cold as he greeted me.
[1960-08-20T14:23:00] Beach Garden | I saw him looking around nervously, then quickly jumping into the water with a few girls, who were all happy about Antonio's arrival.
[1960-08-20T14:24:00] Seaside Garden | I saw that as for Lina, she looked pale, her lips untinted, and her eyes full of hostility. I thought I didn't feel like she had anything to tell me.
[1960-08-20T14:25:00] Seaside Garden | I saw her sitting on the concrete platform, flipping through a book I was reading, saying not a word.
[1960-08-20T14:26:00] Beach Garden | I saw Pinocchia feeling embarrassed by the silence, wanting to express her enthusiasm for everything in the world, but her words came out jumbled, and in the end, she went swimming too.
[1960-08-20T14:27:00] Beach Garden | I saw Alfonso Carracci choose a spot as far away from us as possible, and he stayed under the sun, watching the swimmers with intense focus, as if finding it extremely interesting to watch those naked people go in and out of the water.
[1960-08-20T14:30:00] Beach Garden | "I heard, 'Who gave you this book?' Lina asked me."  
"My Latin and Greek teacher."  
"Why didn't you tell me?"  
"I thought you wouldn't be interested."  
"Do you know what interests you, and what doesn't?"
[1960-08-20T14:31:00] Beach Garden | I thought about changing my tone, making it softer, and I wanted to show off a bit.
[1960-08-20T14:32:00] Seaside Garden | I heard myself say, "I'll lend them to you after I finish reading them. These books are the ones the teacher assigned to the students who study well, and Nino reads these too."  
"Who's Nino?"
[1960-08-20T14:33:00] Beach Garden | I wondered if she had said that on purpose? Was she pretending not to remember his name in order to belittle him?
[1960-08-20T14:34:00] Seaside Garden | "I heard that he's the one from the wedding video, the brother of Pinocchia, the son of Nino."  
"The ugly guy you liked?"  
"I already told you, I don't like him anymore, but he's doing something really impressive."  
"What is it?"
[1960-08-20T14:35:00] Seaside Garden | I saw myself repeating Pinocchio's words with great excitement. I heard, "For example, he's in England now: working, traveling, learning English."
[1960-08-20T14:36:00] Beach Garden | I heard myself say to Lina: "Just think, if we could do things like that too—traveling, working as waiters in restaurants to support ourselves, learning English, speaking it better than a native speaker. How great that would be. Why can he do it, but we can't?"
[1960-08-20T14:37:00] Beach Garden | I heard, "He's finished school?"  
"Yes, he has his high school diploma, and then he's going to college to study some very advanced things."  
"Is he a good student?"  
"He's just as good as you."  
"I'm not studying anymore now."  
"Yes, but you lost the bet with me, so now you have to start studying again."
[1960-08-20T14:38:00] Seaside Garden | "I heard 'Come on, Elena.'"
"Stefano doesn't want to?"
"There's a new Capodimonte now, and I have to help manage it."
"You can study at Capodimonte."
"It's not possible."
[1960-08-20T14:39:00] Beach Garden | I heard, "You already promised me, you said we'd graduate together."  
"No."  
"Why?"
[1960-08-20T14:40:00] Seaside Garden | I saw Lina run her fingers back and forth over the book's cover, trying to smooth it out.
[1960-08-20T14:41:00] Seaside Garden | I heard her mutter, "It's so hot." "I've given birth," she said, not waiting for my reaction.
[1960-08-20T14:42:00] Seaside Garden | I saw her put down the book and go to the edge of the concrete platform, then jump into the water without hesitation. She suddenly shouted Antonio's name.
[1960-08-20T14:43:00] Seaside Garden | I saw that at this moment, Antonio was spraying water at Pinochia and several other girls.
[1960-08-20T14:44:00] Beach Garden | I saw her throw her arms open and clumsily splash the water, then she started struggling—she couldn't swim. I heard, "Save me! Anton..."
[1960-08-25T07:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw that in the days to come, Lina was extremely active and energetic, almost fanatical. She started working busily at the newly opened Capodimonte, as if it were the most important thing in the world.
[1960-08-25T07:30:00] Lina's house | I saw her getting up very early in the morning, earlier than Stefano. She was vomiting while making coffee, and after finishing, she immediately started vomiting again.
[1960-08-25T08:00:00] Elena's front door | I saw him become very considerate, wanting to drive her to the store. I heard, but Lina would refuse, saying she wanted to walk, while the weather was still cool, to breathe in the morning fresh air.
[1960-08-25T08:30:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her walking down the empty street, between the newly built houses, all the way to the shop that was still under renovation. She opened the metal shutter, wiped the paint off the floor, and waited for the workers and suppliers to arrive, bringing scales, a slicing machine, and other equipment.
[1960-08-25T09:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her have someone place those things where they belonged, and she even moved the equipment herself to make the layout more reasonable. I saw those tough-looking men and the difficult-to-control boys, all of whom acted obediently in front of her.
[1960-08-25T09:30:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her, already doing the hard work herself before she could finish giving the order. I heard those people would anxiously shout at her: "Mrs. Carraci! I'm coming!" They would all rush over in a panic to help her.
[1960-08-25T14:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I noticed that despite the heat, Lina wasn't very energetic, but she was not only busy managing the new Capodimonte, but sometimes she would also accompany her sister-in-law to the city center, checking out the stores under renovation on Piazza Martiri.
[1960-08-25T14:10:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I knew that everything there was always managed by Michele, and Rino often went to check on it. He felt justified because, on one hand, he was the producer of "Lina" shoes, and on the other, he was Stefano's brother-in-law, and Stefano was a shareholder in the Solara company.
[1960-08-25T14:30:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that Lina was never idle in the shoe store. She inspected the progress, climbed the mason's ladder, looked down from above at the layout of the entire shop, then came down and rearranged the displays.
[1960-08-25T14:40:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I know at first everyone found it unbelievable, but they soon let her do as she pleased. I thought Michele was the most hostile and sarcastic, and he soon realized that Lina's advice was right.
[1960-08-25T14:41:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I heard "Madam." He spoke again, his words laced with their usual sharpness, "Come help me clean the bar too, I'll pay you for it."
locations: Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square

text:
[1960-08-25T16:00:00] Old Capodimonte | I saw that when she had finished causing trouble in her shop on Martiri Square, she started venturing into the old territory of the Carracci family, the original Capodimonte, and she began going there often. I thought about getting involved in the Capodimonte affair, something she had never even considered.
[1960-08-25T16:10:00] Old Capodimonte | I saw her insisting that Stefano keep Alfonso Carracci at home because he needed to study for a make-up exam at the start of the term.
[1960-08-25T16:20:00] Old Capodimonte | I saw her getting Pinocchia and her mother to go often to the shop on Martirini Square, meddling in its affairs. She did a little today and a little tomorrow, completely renovating the old shop inside and out, making it lively and making full use of the space.
[1960-08-25T16:30:00] Old Capodimonte | I knew that soon Maria and Pinocchia's positions in the store were undermined. Pinocchia became very important, and she had Stefano give her a raise.
[1960-08-30T18:00:00] Capodimonte | I returned from the seaside garden as dusk approached, leaving a few girls with the stationery shop owner. Every time I passed by Lina's Capodimonte, I would check on her, see how she was doing, and check if her belly had grown bigger.
[1960-08-30T18:05:00] Capodimonte | I found myself asking about [fertility status]. I heard her either not answer at all or pull me outside the shop, saying some incomprehensible things. I saw her very anxious, and her face didn't look good.
[1960-08-30T18:06:00] Capodimonte | I heard something like, "I don't want to talk about this. It's a sickness. My body feels empty and heavy."
[1960-08-30T18:07:00] Capodimonte | I see, and then she would start talking about the new Capodimonte and the old Capodimonte, as well as the shops in Piazza Martiri, always in that very seductive way. I thought she wanted me to believe these places were magical, that something extraordinary happened there. I was so pitiful, not as good as her.
[1960-08-30T18:08:00] Capodimonte | I thought about it, but I already knew her tricks. I listened to what she said, but I didn't believe a word she said.
[1960-08-30T18:09:00] Capodimonte | I thought that even so, in the end I was still confused by her way of acting both as a servant and a mistress.
[1960-08-30T18:10:00] Capodimonte | I saw Lina talking to me while also speaking to the customers and Pinocchia. Her hands never stopped—opening bags, cutting, weighing, then taking money and giving change.
[1960-08-30T18:11:00] Capodimonte | I saw her fully immersed in the conversation and the actions, exhausting herself completely. I thought I was really engaged in a fierce, boundless struggle, just to forget that burden, that burden she called so discordantly "the inner void."
[1960-08-30T18:12:00] Capodimonte | I saw her go to the checkout counter, taking as much as she wanted. The thing that impressed me the most was her carefree attitude toward money.
[1960-08-30T18:13:00] Capodimonte | I thought of money as that drawer for her, the safe she had imagined in her childhood, which she could open and generously give away to others.
[1960-08-30T18:14:00] Capodimonte | I saw that if there wasn't enough money in the cash register (which rarely happened), she just had to look at Stefano once, and he would instantly become generous again, like in the days of their romance. He would lift up his white coat and pull out a thick wallet from his pants pocket. I heard him ask, "How much?" Lina showed him with her fingers. Her husband would extend his right arm and hand her the money, which she would take with her long, slender hand.
[1960-08-30T18:15:00] Capodimonte | I saw Pinocchio looking at Lina behind the counter, as if she were a movie star in a magazine. I thought, during that time, Antonio's sister must have felt as if she were in a fairy tale, her eyes sparkling every time Lina opened the drawer to give her money.
[1960-08-30T18:16:00] Capodimonte | I saw her husband turn around, and then she easily handed the money to someone else. I know she gave Pinochcia money because Antonio was going to join the army. She gave Pasquale money because he had to pull out three teeth and it was very urgent.
[1960-09-01T08:00:00] Lina's house | I saw that later a midwife came and shaved the child. I knew Lina's baby had been in her womb for more than ten weeks.
[1960-09-01T10:00:00] Capodimonte | At the beginning of September, she still pulled me aside and asked if I wanted to buy books. I heard, "What book?"  
"The textbooks from school, of course, and also the extra ones."
[1960-09-01T10:05:00] Capodimonte | After hearing that, she put money into my pocket. I heard myself telling her that Professor Oliviero hadn't come back from the hospital yet, and I didn't know if she would be able to get me the school textbooks as usual.
[1960-09-01T10:06:00] Capodimonte | I saw myself breaking free, refusing her money. I thought I didn't want to act like a poor relative and ask her for money.
[1960-09-01T10:07:00] Capodimonte | I told her I had to wait until school started. Also, the owner of the stationery shop extended my employment until mid-September, so I could take a few girls to the seaside garden, which would let me earn a little more than expected, and then I could buy books myself. She seemed sorry and insisted that if the teacher couldn't get textbooks, I could come to her.
[1960-09-01T10:10:00] Capodimonte | I thought not only me, but all of our friends found it hard to get used to her generosity.
[1960-09-01T10:15:00] Capodimonte | I know, for example, Pasquale, who didn't want to accept the money for a dentist, feeling humiliated, but in the end he took the money because his face had already distorted, one eye was already red, and ice packs did nothing.
[1960-09-01T10:20:00] Capodimonte | I knew that Antonio was going to accept extra money for Pinochietta, and it made me uncomfortable. He had to convince himself that it was a compensation for Pinochietta, since Stefano had paid her so little before.
[1960-09-01T10:30:00] Capodimonte | I thought about how we had never really seen money, and how we valued even ten lire very much. Even if we found a coin on the road, we would be overjoyed. So Lina's extravagant way of spending money, as if it weren't money at all but just some worthless scraps of copper or paper, was an unforgivable crime.
[1960-09-01T10:35:00] Capodimonte | I watched her do it in silence, not allowing any room for refusal, just like when she was a child and organized games for everyone, assigning roles to each of us. I thought that after she gave me the money, she would quickly change the subject, as if nothing had happened.
[1960-09-02T08:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her the next day, already busy in the new Capodimonte with Pinocchia Peluso. I saw her immersed in the scent of these foods, surrounded by cheese, sausages, bread, salted fish, fresh buffalo milk cheese, ham, and lard, as well as bags full of beans.
[1960-09-05T20:00:00] Capodimonte | I remember one night, Pasquale spoke to me again in that vague way, saying: "Sausages can be sold, shoes can be sold. Lina is still our friend, still on our side, our ally, our companion. She's very rich now, but that's what she deserves."
[1960-09-05T20:05:00] Capodimonte | I heard, "Yes, that's what she deserved. The money wasn't given to her because she was Mrs. Carraci, the future mother of a butcher's son, but because she designed the 'Lina' shoes. Although now everyone seems to have forgotten, we, as her friends, will always remember that."
[1960-09-05T20:10:00] Capodimonte | I thought what he said was all true. In just a few years, so much had happened around Lina. Even though we were only seventeen then, time around us had become like the yellow cream in the pastry machine—thick and sticky.
[1960-09-10 16:00:00] Small Park | I saw the summer end, and as the exams approached, she watched me looking up unfamiliar words in the dictionary. I thought of her face full of confusion.
[1960-09-10 16:05:00] Small Park | I saw myself looking up the unfamiliar words in the order they appeared in the sentence. After checking the vocabulary, I could barely understand the meaning of the sentence.
[1960-09-10 16:06:00] Small Park | I saw her carefully asking me. "I heard, 'Did the Latin teacher make you do this?'"
[1960-09-10 16:07:00] Small Park | I knew the teacher never said anything, she just assigned us homework and didn't tell us how to do it. That was my own way of figuring it out.
[1960-09-10 16:08:00] Small Park | I saw her hesitate for a moment, and she suggested that I say it. I heard, "First, read the entire sentence and find the verb. Once you know the verb's person, you'll understand who the subject is."
[1960-09-10 16:09:00] Small Park | I heard, "After finding the subject, you start looking for the object—if it's a transitive verb, you find the object; if it's not a transitive verb, you look for other complements. Try it..."
[1960-09-10 16:15:00] Small Park | I saw I tried it. I thought that suddenly, translation had become very easy.
[1960-09-10T15:00:00] Beach Garden | I thought about how Lina always carried resentment in her heart, and she had confirmed this herself.
[1960-09-10T15:01:00] Beach Garden | I was surprised to see her appear in the seaside garden. I saw on a Sunday, around three o'clock in the afternoon, the weather was very clear and the sea was calm.
[1960-09-10T15:02:00] Beach Garden | I saw her taking the subway alone, changing buses several times before she got there. She appeared in front of me wearing a swimsuit. I saw that her face was slightly blueish, and there were many pimples on her forehead.
[1960-09-10T15:03:00] Seaside Garden | I heard her say, "Seventeen years of crap!" in her dialect. I saw her, but she looked happy, her eyes filled with self-mockery.
[1960-09-10T15:04:00] Seaside Garden | I knew she had fought with Stefano. Among the daily exchanges with the Solara brothers, issues inevitably arose regarding the shop in Piazza Martiri.
[1960-09-10T15:05:00] Seaside Garden | I knew Michele definitely wanted Giggia to manage the shop. He threatened Rino fiercely because Rino wanted Pinocchia to take over. In the end, Michele and Stefano had a negotiation, and Michele was very stubborn; they almost came to blows.
[1960-09-10T15:06:00] Beach Garden | I know what happened in the end? On the surface, no one came out on top; Giullia and Pina would take over the shop together. But the condition was that Stefano had to change his previous decision.
[1960-09-10T15:07:00] Beach Garden | I couldn't figure it out. "I heard 'What decides?' " I asked.  
"See if you can guess."
[1960-09-10T15:08:00] Beach Garden | I heard Lina say that Michele, still using that joking and disrespectful tone, asked Stefano for a photo of Lina in her wedding dress. This time, her husband gave in.
[1960-09-10T15:09:00] Seaside Garden | "I heard 'Is that true?'  
'Yes, I told you. Just wait. They'll display my photo in the shop. The bet we made—I won, you lost. Now you have to study hard. This year, your grades in every subject must be above eight.' "
[1960-09-10T15:10:00] Beach Garden | I saw that, and her tone changed, becoming very serious. I heard her say that she hadn't come here because of the photo, she had already known that for her husband's bastard of a man, she was just a commodity to be traded. She had come here because of the [pregnancy] situation.
[1960-09-10T15:11:00] Beach Garden | I saw her and we talked for a long time. I saw her very anxious, as if she urgently wanted to crush something with a mortar, and she was very calm.

[1960-09-10T15:12:00] Seaside Garden | "I don't see any sense in it," she said, not hiding her anxiety. "Men put their things inside your body, and you become a meat box with a little person inside. There's already a little person inside me, and that makes me feel sick. I keep throwing up, I can't stand my stomach. I know I should think positively, I know I should be rational, but I can't. I can't find a reason to submit, and I don't feel beautiful at all."
[1960-09-10T15:13:00] Seaside Garden | I heard her add, "I just don't think I can get along with kids. You can, as shown by how you took care of the shopkeeper's daughter. I can't. I was never cut out for this."
[1960-09-10T15:14:00] Beach Garden | I thought about the words she said, and they made me very sad. What could I possibly say to her?
[1960-09-10T15:15:00] Seaside Garden | I saw myself trying to ease her mind, pointing to the daughter of the stationery shop owner who was playing not far away. I heard her say, "You don't know yet if you're up to it, if you have what it takes. You have to try." I said to her, "Stay with them for a while, talk to them."
[1960-09-10T15:16:00] Beach Garden | I saw her smile. Later, she spoke a few words to several girls in an extremely unnatural way, then stepped back and started talking to me. I heard some cruel people say that I've now learned the excessively sweet tone our mother often used.
[1960-09-10T15:17:00] Seaside Garden | I saw him loosen his grip, encourage her, and ask her to try taking care of Linda—the youngest daughter of the stationery store owner.
[1960-09-10T15:18:00] Beach Garden | I heard myself say to her: "Go ahead, play her favorite game with her, drink from the fountain, put your mouth over the spout, or block the opening with your thumb so the water sprays around."
[1960-09-10T15:19:00] Seaside Garden | I saw her reluctantly taking Linda away, holding Linda's hand. I told the two girls who were with me to go see what was happening. I thought that they would be back soon, but they hadn't returned yet. I was a little worried.
[1960-09-10T15:20:00] Seaside Garden | I saw Lina happily wrapped up in Linda's arms, who lifted her and placed her in front of the spout, letting her drink while the water sprayed around her. I saw them all laughing heartily, as if celebrating. I thought, thank goodness, everything was normal.
[1960-09-10T15:21:00] Beach Garden | I saw that the other two girls were also playing with Lina. I sat down at the bar and chose a spot where I could see the four of them, so I could also read for a while. I thought to myself that I felt relieved.
[1960-09-10T15:22:00] Seaside Garden | I saw myself looking at her. I thought about what she would become if she were with her child. Things that she once couldn't stand now might make her happy. Maybe I should tell her that some meaningless things can also be beautiful.
[1960-09-10T15:23:00] Seaside Garden | I thought that was a great-sounding line, and I was sure she would love it. She really was lucky—she already had everything important.
[1960-09-10T15:24:00] Seaside Garden | I tried reading a few lines from Rousseau's book. When I looked up, I saw the problem had occurred—maybe Linda was too close, or maybe a girl pushed Lina, and as a result, Linda slipped from Lina's arms and her chin hit the edge of the washbasin.
[1960-09-10T15:25:00] Beach Garden | I saw myself running out in a panic. I heard Lina, as soon as she saw me, shouting at me in a very childish tone—something I had never heard from her even when she was a child—"It was her sister who made her fall, not me."
[1960-09-10T15:26:00] Seaside Garden | I saw Lina holding Linda in her arms; she was bleeding and crying and shouting. I saw her two older sisters looking elsewhere, their faces not only tense but also strangely smiling, as if the whole thing had nothing to do with them, as if they couldn't hear or see anything.
[1960-09-10T15:27:00] Beach Garden | I saw myself taking Linda from her arms, carrying her with resentment, and washing Linda's face with the showerhead. I saw a scar on her chin, it was horizontal.
[1960-09-10T15:28:00] Beach Garden | I thought I'd never get the money from the stationery shop owner, and my mother would be very angry.
[1960-09-10T15:30:00] Seaside Garden | I ran to the lifeguard at that moment. He first calmed Linda down, and when he used alcohol to disinfect her, she started screaming again. After they put several layers of gauze on her chin, she finally calmed down.
[1960-09-10T15:35:00] Seaside Garden | I saw that I had returned to the cement platform. I thought, after all, there's nothing serious, I'll buy ice cream for the three girls.
[1960-09-10T15:36:00] Seaside Garden | I saw that I had found Lina, who had already left.
[1960-09-11T09:00:00] Stationery Store | I saw the shop owner woman look at Linda's wound, and she didn't seem especially surprised. I heard her say that her daughters had swum too much already and no longer needed me.

[1960-09-20 09:00:00] School | When I saw Elena take the exam, my written test had almost no mistakes, and during the oral exam, I was able to answer all the questions.

[1960-09-20 12:02:00] Outside the school | I thought about how we studied together, and it was she who first suggested it. I felt that inviting her to continue studying with me was a great way to express my happiness and gratitude.
[1960-09-20 12:03:00] Outside the school | I saw her reject me instantly, almost with some irritation. I heard her say that she just wanted to understand the principles of Latin, because those people who were so good all studied Latin.
[1960-09-20 12:04:00] Outside the school | "I heard 'Then what?' 'Now I've figured it out, enough.'"
[1960-09-20 12:05:00] Outside the school | I heard, "Don't you like it?" "It's okay. I need to borrow some books from the library to read."
[1960-09-20 12:06:00] Outside the school | I heard, "Latin?" "Yes."
[1960-09-20 12:07:00] Outside the school | "I heard, 'But there's a lot to learn now.' 'You study for me. If I have difficulties, you have to help me.'"
[1960-09-20 12:08:00] Outside the school | "I heard, 'I'm going to make something with my brother.' 'What thing?'"

"About the photo. If they want to display it, they have to do it my way."  
"What do you mean?"

"I promise you." I thought about how she wanted me to help and support her. I understood that she already had an idea in her mind, one that could help her break free from the oppressive situation she'd been trapped in for so long—a violent release.

"Okay."

[1960-09-28T20:40:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that Lina had placed the photo against the wall, so I had someone move it to the floor. Marcello always showed a bit of shyness when facing Lina; he asked very carefully. I heard, "What do you mean by putting it down?"  
"I'll show you."
[1960-09-28T20:41:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw the Solara brothers place the photo on the floor. Lina frowned, circling around the picture, her eyes narrowed to a slit. [1960-09-28T20:45:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw her looking for something, and she found a black paper package in a corner. She took out a black pair of scissors from it, and also grabbed a box of drafting pushpins from the shelf.
[1960-09-28T20:50:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw her return to the photo with an extremely focused expression, blocking out all the surrounding distractions. [1960-09-28T20:55:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I realized I had been going along with her, just like when we were children. What an exciting moment that was! At that moment, Marcello came to help, and I gave a hand too, propping the easel against the wall. I thought about how I had become happy, and I felt her fingers grip the scissors tightly, moving with determination and ease as she pinned the black strip of paper into place.

I saw Lina's body in the wedding dress, as if cruelly severed: most of her head was gone, her stomach was missing, all that remained was one eye, a hand resting on her chin, and two bright red lips, her body tilted sideways, the lines of her crossed legs, and her shoes.
[1960-09-28T21:02:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I heard Girola couldn't help saying, "I don't want something like this in my shop."  
"I agree!" Pinocchia burst out, "We sell shoes here; customers will run away when they see this weird thing. Rino! Talk to your sister, please."
[1960-09-28T21:03:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Rino pretending not to notice her, instead speaking to Stefano as if everything that was happening was my brother-in-law's fault. I heard, "I've already told you, there's no need to discuss it with her. You just need to ask her yes or no. Haven't you seen what's happening now? It's only making us waste time!"
[1960-09-28T21:04:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that Stefano didn't respond, just stared at the photo leaning against the wall. Clearly, he was looking for a way out. I heard him ask me, "Elena, what do you think?"
[1960-09-28T21:05:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw myself answering in standard Italian. I heard, "I think it's great! Of course, it definitely wouldn't work in our Mergellina, it's not suitable for that environment. But here, it's another story—the photo will grab people's attention, everyone is sure to like it. On Confidenza Street, last week at Confidenza, I saw a painting similar to this one in Rosano Blas's house."
[1960-09-28T21:06:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Giyaola become even more angry after hearing my words. "I heard, 'What do you mean? Are you saying Rosano Blaze knows everything, the two of you know everything, and I and Pinocchia know nothing?'"
[1960-09-28T21:07:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that while Giyola was speaking, she had already started muttering: either this way or not at all. I realized then that my situation was dangerous, but as soon as I looked at Lina, I understood: when we first arrived at the store, if she hadn't tried yet, she would have given in. But now that she had tried, she had created an "unseemly" picture, and at this point, she would not yield even the slightest bit.

Then he said to Lina. "I heard, 'Madam, I like your design. You erased those parts, and I know why—you wanted people to see the legs more clearly, to see how beautiful the shoes on the woman's feet are. It's really great! [1960-09-28T21:11:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Giggia wipe away the tears that had slipped down her face. Pinocchia stared at Rino and her brother Stefano, as if saying: speak up! Stand up for me, don't let this wicked woman step on me. I saw that no one was speaking.

"I just need to add a little color."
[1960-09-28T21:13:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Marcello becoming more and more lost, he whispered, "Coloring? We're opening in three days." Michele laughed. I heard, "If we need to wait, we'll wait. Hurry up and do it, Mrs. — do whatever you want to do."
[1960-09-28T21:14:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that Stefano wanted to make it clear that his wife had to work. I heard, "She still has a new Capodimonte to handle."

We used red or blue pencils to draw the boundary between the parts of the photo that were uncovered and the parts that were covered. I know that in the last few days of September, we were always in the store in the city center, just the two of us and three workers.

[1960-09-29T16:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I thought of how we had forgotten Antonio, Nino, Stefano, the Solara brothers, and my problems with studying, her [pregnancy] body, and the tension between us. Time seemed to have stopped, and we were isolated in a separate space, purely to complete a painting.
[1960-09-30T10:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I thought quickly, I remembered a word Michele once used: "erased." What he said might be true—those black notes made the shoes on the feet in the photo stand out more, become more noticeable.
[1960-09-30T11:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw her drawing with black paper, with green and purple circles on certain parts of her body, using blood-red lines to cut herself. I thought to myself that now I was very sure—she wanted to destroy herself through the pictures, right there in the shop that Solara had bought to display and sell her designed shoes, and she would show this self-destruction to everyone.
[1960-09-30T14:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw her start talking to me about when she first realized she was Mrs. Carraci. I heard her say that in the phrase "the girl from the Karachi family," she saw a locative complement, as if Lina's girl had moved into the Karachi family, and she fell into that name, was absorbed, and then melted.
[1960-09-30T14:10:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I heard her mutter, "It's still like this now." I thought of Lina—Lina had been destroyed, she had lost her shape, she had melted into Stefano's outline, becoming his accessory: Signora Carracci. It was then that I began to see what she had meant on that canvas.
[1960-09-30T17:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I watched until the end, and several workers nervously hung the painting on the wall. We cleaned the store from top to bottom. Lina rearranged the position of the sofa and some decorations.
[1960-09-30T17:30:00] At the shoe store in front of Piazza Martiri | I saw that in the end, both of us reached the door, admiring the result of our work, and she started to laugh. I saw myself intently looking at the top of the canvas, unable to see Lina's full head—only a very realistic eye emerged from where her head should be, surrounded by the blue and red lights of the night.
[1960-10-01 08:00:00] School | I saw that school had started, and I was doing well in all my subjects. I thought about how eager I was for Lina to let me help her study Latin or other subjects. I felt that my efforts to study weren't for school, but for her.
[1960-10-01T15:00:00] Martiri Square | On the day the shoe store opened, Lina came in a convertible. Her husband was driving, and she sat beside him. When she got out of the car, I saw her gaze was hesitant, as if she was worried something bad might happen. I saw her dressed with great care, as if she had stepped out of a fashion magazine.
[1960-10-01T15:05:00] Qianren Street | When she saw me, she immediately left Stefano and pulled me with her to look at the shop windows on the Street of a Thousand.
[1960-10-01T15:10:00] Qianren Street | "I remember the girl in the green dress," she suddenly said, "the one with the cylinder hat?"
[1960-10-01T15:11:00] Qianren Street | I said, "It's just a matter of money, Lina. Everything has changed now. You're much more beautiful than that girl in the green dress." I thought, of course I remember, fear. I understood what she wanted me to say to reassure her.
[1960-10-01T15:12:00] Qianren Street | I thought about it, but it wasn't true—I was lying. There was a kind of malice, an inequality, and now I understood that it was something deeper, something beyond money. The income from the two Capodimontes, plus the shoe workshop, or even the shoe store in the city center couldn't hide our origins.
[1960-10-01T15:30:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that we had returned to the store. Many cars were parked in a messy pile in front of the shop, and the inside was full of people, creating a lively, bustling atmosphere. I watched the entire afternoon celebration, which seemed a bit like a wedding: food, pastries, and a lot of wine.
[1960-10-01T15:35:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Lina's enlarged photo up high. Some people would stop and watch with interest, others would cast doubtful glances, and some even would laugh. I couldn't take my eyes off the photo; it was no longer recognizable as her, but instead had become a terrifying and seductive image—a one-eyed goddess, stretching the foot in her beautiful shoes toward the center of the hall.
[1960-10-01T16:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw in the crowd, and what surprised me most was Alfonso Carracci, who was so lively, happy, and elegant. Lina also looked at him for a long time, looking somewhat uneasy. I heard myself laughing as I said to her, "He's not him anymore."  
"What happened?"  
"I don't know."
[1960-10-01T16:10:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw him come over to us later, speaking in a very confident and elegant manner, praising our handling of the photos. At that moment, he was very at ease, having overcome his shyness in front of my sister-in-law. I heard him say, "I've always known you're a very dangerous person," then he kissed her cheek.
[1960-10-01T16:11:00] The shoe store at Martiri Square | I saw myself looking around anxiously, watching him. Did I think about the danger? What did he see in that portrait that I failed to notice? Alfonso Carracci didn't stop at the surface; he saw something deeper?
[1960-10-01T17:30:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that it was getting dark, and suddenly something outside lit up. The Solara brothers and their grandfather, parents, and every member of their family ran out to see, all of them unusually excited. I saw them come onto the street, at the entrance of the shop, above the window there were a few bright words: Solara.
[1960-10-01T17:31:00] At the shoe store in front of Piazza Martiri | I saw Lina make a scornful face and said to me. I heard, "They also made some concessions in this regard."
[1960-10-01T17:32:00] At the entrance of the shoe store in Piazza Martiri | I saw her push me toward Rino, who looked happier than anyone else. Lina said unhappily. I heard, "If all the shoes were 'Lina' brand, why is the store called Solara?"
[1960-10-01T17:33:00] At the shoe store in front of Piazza Martiri | I saw Rino grab her arm and say softly. I heard, "Lina, why do you always have to ruin the mood? It's so annoying. Do you remember the trouble you got me into here a few years ago? What am I supposed to do now, are you going to cause more trouble? 'Lina' shoes, Solara shop. What do you want to write above the store? Karachi?"
[1960-10-01T17:34:00] The shoe store at the entrance of Martiri Square | I saw Lina shake off his arm and calmly say to him. "I heard you say, 'I'm very calm now, quite calm. What I want to tell you is: don't ask me for anything anymore. What are you doing now? You borrowed money from Signora Solara, didn't you? They made Stefano borrow money too, didn't they? You're all people who owe others money, so you agree to every demand they make? From now on, we'll each take care of ourselves, Rino.'"
[1960-10-01T17:35:00] Martiri Square | I saw her walk away, straight to Michele, looking cheerful and enchanting. I saw her and Michele reach the square, where they circled the stone lions in the square. Her husband's eyes never left her.
[1960-10-01T18:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that at this moment, the store had become empty, and someone had turned off the outside neon sign. I saw the square suddenly grow dark, and the streetlights began to turn on.
[1960-10-01T18:05:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Lina smiling as she left Michele, but when she entered the store, her face was expressionless and very pale. She went into the small bathroom and locked the door behind her.
