[1960-12-20T10:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her full of energy again, pouring a lot of effort into managing the store. I knew that sales had surged on Christmas Eve, and within just a few months, it had already surpassed Mergellina's Capodimonte.
[1960-12-20T20:00:00] Lina's house | I saw Maria often helping at her daughter-in-law's shop instead of her son's. Stefano always had a sour face, partly because he had lost his child, and partly because the business was too busy. I know that Maria's admiration for Lina is growing.
[1960-12-20T20:10:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Pinocchio strictly forbidding her mother from coming to the shop, afraid of embarrassing herself in front of customers. I know that Pinocchio is now working in the shop on Martiri Square.
[1960-12-20T21:00:00] Lina's house | I saw Stefano and Pinocchia always blaming Lina, saying she couldn't even carry a child. Every time, old Mrs. Carracci would step in to defend the young Mrs. Carracci. I heard "She doesn't want children." Stefano complained.
[1960-12-20T21:01:00] Lina's house | "I also think that way," Pinocchia always immediately supported her brother's opinion. "She still wants to be a girl; she doesn't know how to be a wife."
[1960-12-20T21:02:00] Lina's House | I saw Maria scold the two children very severely. I heard her say, "You shouldn't even think about such things, let alone talk about them. Heaven gave us our child, and it will take the child back. I never want to hear you say such foolish things again."
[1960-12-20T21:03:00] Lina's house | I saw my daughter shouting angrily. I heard, "Shut up! You gave the earrings I liked to that annoying woman!"
[1960-12-21T09:00:00] School | I knew their arguments and Lina's reactions soon became the talk of Mergellina, and sometimes even reached my ears. But I didn't pay much attention to these things, because school had started. I thought about it, but the way things unfolded surprised me.
[1960-12-21T10:00:00] School | I thought back to the beginning of the school term, when my studies had always been ahead, as if Antonio's departure, Nino's disappearance, and even Lina's life getting back on track, starting to run Capodimonte, had untangled some knots in my mind.
[1960-12-21T11:00:00] School | I realized that I could clearly and accurately recall what I had learned in my first year of high school, and I could quickly and fluently answer the teacher's questions.
[1960-12-25T10:00:00] School | I saw that, not only that, but Teacher Galiani was also very attentive to me. I thought it might be because she had lost Nino—the most promising of her students—so she turned her attention to me.
[1960-12-28T10:00:00] School | I heard her say that I could join a peace-promoting hike from Lecce to San Gregorio Armeno, which would be meaningful and also beneficial for my growth.
[1960-12-30T09:00:00] Posillipo | I decided to go, but because my mother wanted me to take along a few of my younger brothers, we quarreled and shouted, and in the end, I left late. I thought about it partly out of curiosity, and also because I was worried that if I refused, Professor Galiani might get angry. Another reason was that the hike would pass along the main road near our residence Mergellina, which wouldn't take much effort.
[1960-12-30T10:00:00] Bridge above | I saw myself and several of my brothers arriving at a bridge, and I looked down. I saw the people in the demonstration blocking the road, not letting cars pass. They were all ordinary people, and it didn't look like a real protest at all—more like they were walking around with flags and signs.
[1960-12-30T10:05:00] On the bridge | I wanted to go find Teacher Galiani and have her see me, so I told my younger brothers to wait for me on the bridge. I thought this was a terrible idea.
[1960-12-30T10:10:00] Bridge on | I saw that as soon as I turned around, before I could find the teacher, my younger brothers had already gathered with other boys from Mergellina, throwing stones at the procession and cursing loudly.
[1960-12-30T10:15:00] On the bridge | I saw them and immediately ran back to find them, sweating all over, and took them away. I thought about how worried I was that Teacher Galiani's sharp eyes would see them, recognize them as my brothers.
[1961-01-10T15:00:00] Posillipo | I knew it would end like this, several weeks had passed, and school was about to start a new term, so we needed to buy new books. I thought about showing my mother the list of books I needed, asking her to talk to my father and get money from him, but it was useless because I knew he had no money.
[1961-01-15T15:00:00] Mergellina | I saw her in August or September, I went to the hospital twice. The first time I went, she was asleep. The second time, I found that she had been discharged, but she hadn't gone home. I know that Teacher Oliviero also has no news.
[1961-01-20T16:00:00] Mergellina | I saw in early November, I went to her neighbor to ask. I knew that because her health was poor, she had gone to live with a sister in Potenza, and I didn't know if she would return to San Gregorio Armeno or come back to this Mergellina to continue teaching.
[1961-02-01T10:00:00] School | I realized I had no other choice, so I tried asking Alfonso Carracci if his brother had bought him any books, so I could use them. He was very happy and suggested that we study together. I knew we could study at Lina's house, because since she'd been busy at Capodimonte, her home was empty from seven in the morning until nine at night, and that's how we decided.
[1961-02-15T09:00:00] School | I saw that one morning, Alfonso Carracci reluctantly told me. I heard, "You should go to Capodimonte and find Lina today, she wants to see you." I thought he must know the reason, but Lina made him swear to stay silent, so I could never get the answer out of him.
[1961-02-15T15:00:00] New Capodimonte | I remember that afternoon, I went to Capodimonte. Pinocchia was somewhat conflicted, she showed me a postcard from her boyfriend Enzo Scanno. I didn't know which small town in Piedmont it had come from.
[1961-02-15T15:05:00] New Capodimonte | I saw that Lina had also received a postcard, from Antonio. I thought at first that she had made me run over just to show me the postcard. But she didn't let me see the postcard, nor did she tell me what was written on it.
[1961-02-15T15:10:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her pull me into the room inside the store, excitedly asking me. I heard him say, "Do you remember our bet?" I nodded. "Do you remember that you lost?" I nodded again. "Do you remember that from now on, you can't score lower than eight in any exam?" I nodded once more.
[1961-02-15T15:15:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her pointing to two large packages wrapped in wrapping paper, which were the school textbooks.
[1961-02-15T16:00:00] Posillipo | I saw those books were heavy. I returned home very excited, only to find that the books weren't old. The books that Professor Oliviero had previously found for me were all secondhand, usually smelling terrible. I saw that the book Lina had given me was a new one, still smelling of ink, and among these books there were also some dictionaries: "Zingarelli," "Rossi," and "Caronci-Giorgi," all of which the teacher had never managed to get.
[1961-02-15T16:10:00] Posillipo | I saw her suddenly start crying when she saw me opening the books' packaging. I know that no matter what happens to me, my mother always says something contemptuous.
[1961-02-15T16:11:00] Posillipo | I saw myself running to her immediately and touching her arm with my hand. I was surprised and a bit frightened by her unusual behavior. It was hard to say what had moved her: maybe it was the generosity of the owner of Capodimonte, or perhaps her helplessness in the face of poverty—I didn't know.
[1961-02-15T16:15:00] Posillipo | I saw her calm down quickly, muttering a few words I didn't catch, then she went back to her own business.
locations: Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square

text:
[1961-02-15T17:00:00] My small room | I know that in the small room where I and my younger brothers lived, there was a small table made by piecing together different pieces of wood, covered with many insect holes. I usually did my homework at that table.
[1961-02-15T17:10:00] My small room | I saw myself placing all the books on the table, watching them neatly lined up against the wall. I thought of it and suddenly felt full of energy.
[1961-03-01T15:00:00] School | I saw time rushing by, and I returned the books that Teacher Galiani had lent me during the summer. She lent me other books, which were even more difficult to understand.
[1961-03-05T10:00:00] Posillipo | I saw that I read these books very carefully every Sunday, but I didn't understand much. I read line by line, turning the pages. I thought about it, but those long, complex sentences annoyed me—I couldn't figure out what the words really meant.
[1961-03-10T20:00:00] Posillipo | I spent my entire sophomore year studying while reading these difficult books. I thought about how I found it hard, but I was satisfied, feeling that all the efforts were worth it.
[1961-03-15T10:00:00] School | I remember one day when Teacher Galiani asked me, "Grego, which newspaper are you reading?"
[1961-03-15T10:01:00] School | I felt extremely embarrassed thinking about this, just like I had felt that time at Lina's wedding when I was talking with Nino. Professor Galiani naturally assumed that I also read the newspaper at home, but in the environment where I lived, reading the newspaper was not a normal thing to do.
[1961-03-15T10:02:00] School | I tried desperately to recall what newspaper Pasquale, as a communist, was reading, but I couldn't remember anything. I thought about how I could tell her that my father never bought newspapers, and I had never read a newspaper. I felt I couldn't bring myself to say it.
[1961-03-15T10:03:00] School | At that moment, I remembered Donato Nino reading the newspaper on the beach of Vomero, and I remembered that he had written an article for Il Messaggero, so I replied. I heard, "I read Il Messaggero."
[1961-03-15T10:04:00] School | From that day on, she started showing me the newspapers she had read. She would buy two newspapers, sometimes three, and during school dismissal, she would give me one. I saw my teacher's face break into a slightly mocking smile.
[1961-03-15T12:00:00] On the way home | I saw myself thanking her. I thought about the way home, and I felt unusually heavy, which was yet another homework assignment for me.
[1961-03-20T19:00:00] Posillipo | At first, I used to leave the newspaper lying around the house, planning to read it after finishing my homework, but by evening, I found the newspaper was gone. I know my father has taken over the newspaper; he reads it in bed, or in the bathroom.
[1961-03-21T23:00:00] Posillipo | I saw and so I changed my "strategy," hiding the newspaper between the pages of my textbook, only taking it out at night when everyone was asleep.
[1961-03-25T23:30:00] Posillipo | I flipped through my columns one by one, not out of personal interest, but out of duty, just like schoolwork. I know that sometimes the teacher gives me L'Unità, and sometimes Il Messaggero or Corriere della Sera. I thought about it, but I felt both of these newspapers were hard for me to understand. It was like reading a series of comic books and picking up one in the middle without knowing what had happened before. I hope that the parts I don't understand today, if I keep at it, I'll eventually be able to understand them.
[1961-04-01 10:00:00] Home | I saw that year, my chest, thighs, and buttocks became increasingly full. I thought to myself that I felt like I was rising like pizza dough.
[1961-04-01T14:00:00] New Capodimonte | I sometimes ran home right after school, finished my homework, and then went to meet her at the new Capodimonte. I know that during that time, I met Lina very few times.
[1961-04-01T14:10:00] New Capodimonte | I see myself eating a sandwich hungrily, and I'll say some sentences in standard Italian that I've learned from books or from Professor Galiani's newspaper. I told her I was hungry, and she immediately made me a sandwich with lots of meat and cheese inside.
[1961-04-01T14:15:00] New Capodimonte | I heard myself saying the cruel things that happened in the Nazi concentration camps, and what people could have done now. I also mentioned the threat of nuclear war to human peace. In short, we have tamed nature with the tools we have invented, but now our tools have become even more terrifying than nature itself. I spoke about the need for a civilization that fights against human suffering, and how we must eliminate the suffering humanity endures.
[1961-04-01T14:16:00] New Capodimonte | I heard that religion would disappear from people's consciousness, and we would build a world where everyone is equal, without class differences, and people would have a more scientific and rational understanding of society and life. I thought about all the things I said to her. On one hand, I wanted to show her that I had a chance to get an eight in every subject. On the other hand, I didn't really know what to say to her, and another reason was that I hoped she would challenge me, so we could have discussions like before.
[1961-04-01T14:20:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her, but she hardly said anything; sometimes she seemed a bit embarrassed, as if she didn't understand what I was saying. Or she would say a few words, and end with expressions like: she started talking about where Don Achille's money came from, and the money of the Solara family. I know that sometimes I said these things in front of Pinocchia, and Pinocchia quickly expressed her agreement. I thought about why she brought up the issue again.
[1961-04-01T14:25:00] New Capodimonte | When a customer came in to buy something, she immediately stopped talking, became very polite and attentive, quickly cut the item, weighed it, and took the money.
[1961-04-10T15:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw once when she looked into an open drawer, staring at the money inside, and her expression looked very bad. I heard her say, "All this money was earned by me and Pinocchia through hard work, but none of it is mine, Elena. This money belongs to Stefano. Stefano's money came from his father. Without Don Achille's money made through the black market and usury—those hidden under the mattress—there would be no shop, no cobbler's workshop."
[1961-04-10T15:01:00] New Capodimonte | I heard, "Not only that, Stefano, Rino, and even my father—without the Solara family's connections and the money they lent, they wouldn't have sold a single pair of shoes. The Solaras are also loan sharks. You can see my current situation, can't you?"
[1961-04-10T15:02:00] New Capodimonte | "I know all that is in the past," I said to her, bringing up the conclusion we had reached when she was engaged to Stefano, "What you're talking about is over. We are different from those people." I thought she had spoken clearly, but I didn't understand what purpose her words served.
[1961-04-10T15:03:00] New Capodimonte | I heard her say to me, "I don't like the things I've done, and I don't like the things I'm doing now." I thought of these words, which had originally been hers, but she wasn't very sure about them now. I remember this sentence very clearly; at the time, she had spoken it in dialect.
[1961-04-10T15:05:00] New Capodimonte | I thought she might have started seeing Pasquale again, because he's always had that kind of attitude. I thought their friendship was growing stronger, because Pasquale was now engaged to Pina, the salesgirl from the old Capodimonte, and Pasquale was Pina's brother. Now Pina was running the new Capodimonte with her.
[1961-04-10T15:30:00] Piazza del Plebiscito | I wasn't happy when I left Capodimonte. I thought about how I was struggling very hard to suppress a complex I'd had since childhood, a painful feeling—back then, Lina and Pinochia became friends, and they started to exclude me.

[1961-04-10T23:00:00] Posillipo | I saw myself calm down only after studying late into the night.
[1961-04-15 15:00:00] Small Park | I saw that on a Sunday, I had arranged to meet Girolamo Spagnuolo in the small park.
[1961-04-15 15:05:00] Small Park | I saw the Solara brothers driving up, Marcello, the older one, behind the wheel, and his brother Michele sitting next to him. They parked the car beside me.
[1961-04-15 15:06:00] Small Park | I saw the two brothers, both handsome, with dark, shiny hair and white teeth when they smiled. I thought of them, but between the two, I preferred Marcello; he looked like Ettore—the character in the illustrations of our Iliad textbook.
[1961-04-15 15:07:00] Small Park | I saw them following me all the time. I was walking on the sidewalk, and they were on the road, sitting in that "Fiat 1100" car.
[1961-04-15 15:08:00] Small Park | I heard, "Have you ever ridden in a car?" "No."
[1961-04-15 15:09:00] Small Park | "I heard, 'Come up, we'll give you a ride.' 'My father won't agree.'"
[1961-04-15 15:10:00] Small Park | I heard, "We won't tell him. When will you ever get a chance to ride in such a fancy car again?"
[1961-04-15 15:11:00] Small Park | I saw it, but I kept saying "No," and quickened my pace toward the small park. I thought, never, I thought.
[1961-04-15 15:12:00] Small Park | I saw their car speed off, and in the blink of an eye, it disappeared behind the buildings under construction.
[1961-04-15 15:13:00] Small Park | I thought about how I had refused them, because if my father found out I had gotten into their car, even though he was a gentle, good man who loved me very much, he would surely have beaten me to death.
[1961-04-15 15:14:00] Small Park | I thought of my two younger brothers, Peppe and Gianni, who, even though they were very young, would feel obligated to kill the Solara brothers once they grew up.
[1961-04-15 15:15:00] Small Park | I knew there were no written rules, but everyone knew how things worked, including the Solara brothers.
[1961-04-15 15:20:00] Small Park | I have to say, they've always been very polite, they just invited me into the car. I know that later, in front of Pinocchia, they weren't so polite anymore.
[1961-04-15 15:21:00] Small Park | I knew Pinocchia was the crazy widow—the eldest daughter of Melina Antonio, the widow who had made a fool of herself when Nino moved away.
[1961-04-15 15:22:00] Small Park | I saw Pinocchia when she was fourteen. On Sundays, she would secretly put on lipstick, betraying her mother. Her legs were long and straight, her chest larger than mine, giving her a mature and beautiful appearance.
[1961-04-15 15:25:00] Street | I saw the Solara brothers saying disgusting things to her. Michele grabbed one of her arms and opened the car door, pulling her inside.
[1961-04-15 16:30:00] Street | An hour later, I saw them return Pinocchio to her place. She seemed a bit angry, but she was also smiling.
[1961-04-15T23:00:00] Posillipo | I was reading Il Messaggero one night when, too tired, my eyes were about to close. Suddenly, I jolted awake as if struck by electricity. I came across an unsigned short review that was about the shoe store in Piazza Martiri, and the article praised the wooden panels that I and Lina had created together. I found it almost unbelievable.
[1961-04-15T23:05:00] Posillipo | I read it again and again. I remember a few lines now: in a shoe store on Piazza Martiri, there was an artistic creation that mixed text and color. Unfortunately, the two girls who ran the store wouldn't tell me the name of the artist who made it. But in any case, he was certainly an avant-garde artist. With a pure, unique power that seemed almost divine, he revealed an intense, inner sorrow through his images, and it was very expressive.
[1961-04-15T23:10:00] Posillipo | I know there were many other praise-filled words that extolled the entire shoe store, saying it was a significant manifestation of the vitality of San Gregorio Armeno's business in recent years.
[1961-04-16 10:00:00] Street | I told Antonio, Pinocchia's brother, that I had seen the Solara brothers force Pinocchia into a car. I know he works as a mechanic in the Glacio workshop.
[1961-04-16 10:05:00] Street | I know that Antonio works very hard, is disciplined, and is also shy. I realized that his father's early death and his mother's madness had deeply wounded him.
[1961-04-16 17:00:00] At the entrance of Capodimonte | I saw him not telling his relatives and friends, but going alone to the door of Solara's bar to wait for Marcello and Michele.
[1961-04-16 17:10:00] At the entrance of Capodimonte | As soon as the two brothers appeared, he didn't say a word and immediately attacked.
[1961-04-16 17:15:00] At the entrance of Capodimonte | I saw the first few minutes, and he was on top, but then the father of the Solara brothers and a bartender came out, and the four of them teamed up, beating Antonio until he was covered in blood.
[1961-04-16 17:16:00] At the entrance of Capodimonte | I saw that at this moment, neither the people passing by nor the customers in the bar made any move to help him.
[1961-04-16T07:00:00] Posillipo | I saw that I had not slept all night.
[1961-04-16T14:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her the day after school ended, and I immediately ran to find Lina. I knew the store was empty—Pinocchia had gone home to take care of her mother, Giuseppina was sick, and Lina was on the phone with a supplier from the countryside, complaining that he hadn't delivered the water buffalo mozzarella or fresh cheese. I wasn't exactly sure.
[1961-04-16T14:05:00] New Capodimonte | I saw and heard her shouting and swearing a lot. I thought about it and was very shocked. I was thinking that the person on the other end of the phone might be an old man who would get angry and send his son to take revenge. I thought, why did she have to make such a big deal out of it.
[1961-04-16T14:10:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her hang up the phone and let out a contemptuous sigh, then explained to me. I heard, "If I didn't say it that way, they wouldn't listen to me."
[1961-04-16T14:15:00] New Capodimonte | I saw myself showing her the newspaper, and she glanced at it carelessly. I heard, "I've already seen it." I knew she explained that it was Michele's idea, as usual, he never discussed anything with anyone.
[1961-04-16T14:20:00] New Capodimonte | "I see," she said, walking to the checkout counter and pulling open the drawer. She took out some clippings and handed them to me.
[1961-04-16T14:25:00] New Capodimonte | I knew those articles were also talking about the shops in Martirano Square. There was a short piece published in Il Messaggero that lavishly praised the Solara brothers, but said nothing at all about the chalkboard.
[1961-04-16T14:30:00] New Capodimonte | I know there was another article published in the "San Gregorio Armeno Evening News," spanning three columns, which praised the store as if it were a palace. The article used an extremely exaggerated written style to describe the store's atmosphere, praising its interior decoration, luxurious lighting, and especially the shoes. It also praised the two elegant, gentle, and polite girls, meaning Miss Gigia Spagnuolo and Miss Giuseppina Caracci.
[1961-04-16T14:35:00] New Capodimonte | I know that the painting was only mentioned at the end of the article, and not much was said about it. It was described as a vulgar piece, an incongruous note in this elegant and luxurious setting.
[1961-04-16T14:40:00] New Capodimonte | I heard Lina ask me in a teasing tone, "Did you see the signature below?" I knew the article on Il Messaggero was signed with the abbreviation D.S, and the one at the end of the article in San Gregorio Armeno Evening Paper was signed Donato Nino—the father of Nino.
[1961-04-16T14:41:00] New Capodimonte | I heard, "Yes."
"What do you think?"
"What can I say?"
"You should say, 'Like father, like son.'"
[1961-04-16T14:45:00] New Capodimonte | I saw her smile, but it wasn't happy at all. She explained that the "Lina" shoes and the Solara shoe store were becoming more successful every day, so Michele decided to expand his influence. He was giving gifts everywhere, and because of this, the newspapers in this city were all talking positively about the Solara shoe store.
[1961-04-16T14:50:00] New Capodimonte | I heard her say to me, none of the words in these articles were true. I thought about it and it made me very sad. I felt she shouldn't have belittled those newspapers. I had worked so hard reading them, even sacrificing my sleep.
[1961-04-16T14:51:00] New Capodimonte | I didn't like how she emphasized Nino's relationship with the authors of the two articles, linking Nino to his father—a man who wrote flashy, fake pieces. Was that necessary?
[1961-04-20 16:00:00] Courtyard | I know that when it comes to this matter, we girls have split into two factions. Girolama Spagnuolo and Camilla Peluso support the Solara brothers because they're good-looking and have a car.
[1961-04-20 16:05:00] Courtyard | I found myself, in front of these two friends, leaning towards Solara, pretending to be very impressed by them. I thought about my hesitation.
[1961-04-20 16:10:00] Yard | I thought they were really handsome, something we found hard to resist. We imagined ourselves sitting in a car, sitting next to one of them.

[1961-04-20 16:15:00] Courtyard | I thought about how terrible their performance was in front of Pinocchia. Antonio wasn't very handsome, not like the Solara brothers who were muscular and went to the gym every day, but he had the courage to challenge them.
[1961-04-20 16:20:00] Courtyard | I saw Lina expressing her opinion without hesitation, and she thought the same way I did. So, in front of Lina, I also spoke my true thoughts.
[1961-04-20 16:25:00] Courtyard | I remember once, we had a very heated discussion. I thought maybe because she didn't develop as well as we did, she didn't know the pleasure and fear of being noticed by the Solara brothers.
[1961-04-20 16:30:00] Courtyard | I saw her even paler than usual. She said that if something like what happened to Pinochia had happened to her, she wouldn't have troubled her father and her brother Rino; she would have dealt with the two brothers herself.
[1961-04-20 16:31:00] Courtyard | "I heard 'Marcello and Michele don't even look at you.' Girolama Spagnuolo said.
[1961-04-20 16:32:00] Courtyard | I saw that we thought Lina would be angry, but she said seriously. I heard, "That's best."
[1961-04-25 15:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her, still as thin as before, but very firm. I looked at her hands in astonishment: in a short time, her hands would become like her brother Rino's and her father's, with thick, yellow calluses on their fingers.
[1961-04-25 15:05:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that she had also started doing some work, threading needles, unsewing, applying glue, and hemming. She was now handling Fernando's tools almost as skillfully as her brother. I knew that although no one was forcing her—working in the shop wasn't her job.
[1961-05-01 10:00:00] Unknown | I knew that's why she stopped asking me about Latin that year.
[1961-05-01T10:00:00] Mergellina | I knew that, because of the praise in the newspaper, Solara's shoe shop and the "Lina" shoes soon became well known. Since the newspaper mentioned the names of Giggia and Pinochia, both of them took every opportunity to show off.
[1961-05-01T12:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I knew that the store's success didn't ease their relationship. Each of them felt she was the key to the store's success and saw the other as a stumbling block to its further development. But they were united in one thing: Lina's photo was a disgrace.
[1961-05-01T13:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw how they treated those who came out of curiosity to look at the photos. They cut out the articles from Il Messaggero and Il Messaggero, put them in frames, and hung them up.
[1961-05-15 15:00:00] Unknown | I later heard her tell me her thoughts, but they had nothing to do with books: she wanted to convince her father to make the new shoes, but Fernando didn't even want to talk about it.
[1961-05-15 15:05:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard my father tell her that making handmade shoes had no future. Now there were many machines, those machines were expensive and required a lot of money, but the money wasn't in the bank—it was with loan sharks. The Lina family didn't have that kind of money.
[1961-05-15 15:10:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that she still stuck to her own opinion, and said a lot of good things to my father. I heard, "Dad, no one makes shoes as well as you do."
[1961-05-15 15:15:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw him say. I heard that, despite the fact, nowadays all the shoes are factory-made, mass-produced, and cost very little.
[1961-05-15 15:20:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I'd heard he'd worked in the factory and knew just how bad those shoes were that ended up on the market, but there was nothing we could do—people who wanted new shoes no longer went to the local cobblers, but instead bought them from stores in the Rettifilo district.
[1961-05-15 15:25:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard that even if you make the shoes properly, they still won't sell, it's a waste of effort and you'll end up losing money.
[1961-05-15T10:00:00] Mergellina | I knew that from Christmas to Carnival, the Solara and Calogero families made a lot of money. Especially Stefano, who was relieved. The new and old Capodimonte both brought in good profits, the "Lina" handcrafted shoe workshop was working at full capacity, and there was also the shop above Martiri Square. I thought this confirmed what he had always expected: Lina's shoes, designed in her early years, were not only selling well in the Rettifilo district, Via Favia, and Via Garibaldi, but had also gained the approval of the wealthy.
[1961-05-20 14:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that Lina wasn't being swayed by her father as usual; she pulled Rino to her side. I know that at first, her brother was on father's side because he found Lina annoying; after all, he was the real expert at making shoes. Now Lina doesn't talk about studying anymore, but instead gives orders about work.
[1961-05-25 14:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that later, he was gradually persuaded by his sister's tempting prospects in the shoe business, and began arguing with Fernando, frequently talking back, saying the same things that Lina had said.
[1961-05-25 14:05:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "We should at least try." "No way."
[1961-05-25 14:06:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Have you seen the car from the Solara family? Have you seen how successful the Mask Loc 013 business is for the Carracci family?"
[1961-05-25 14:07:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "I saw the woman who ran the sewing supply store wanted to open a ready-to-wear shop, but she gave up later. I also saw Glacio's repair shop, because of his foolish son, Ma's steps were longer than his legs."
[1961-05-25 14:08:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard, 'But the Solara family's shop is getting bigger and bigger.' 'Mind your own business and don't worry about the Solaras.'"
[1961-05-25 14:09:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "A new neighborhood is going to be built next to the railway." "What's that got to do with us?"
[1961-05-25 14:10:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Dad, those people made money, and now they want to spend it."
[1961-05-25 14:11:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard him say, 'People spend money on food because they have to eat every day. Shoes can't be eaten; secondly, if shoes break, you can have them repaired and wear them for twenty years. At present, our job is to repair shoes, we don't do anything else.'"
[1961-05-25 14:20:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I really like Rino because he has always been very polite to me, but sometimes he can also summon courage and be very firm, which even makes his father a little afraid.
[1961-05-25 14:25:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that at any time, anywhere, he was always supporting his sister. I thought about how jealous I was of Lina having such a brother, so firmly supporting her.
[1961-05-25 14:30:00] Home | I sometimes think the difference between me and her is that I only have a younger brother, so no one encouraged me or opposed my mother, allowing me to think for myself; while Lina could rely on Rino, who would protect his sister in front of anyone, and no matter what she thought, her older brother would always support her.
[1961-05-25 14:35:00] Home | You could say that, but I think Fernando made sense, and I agreed more with his point of view. When I discussed this with Lina, I found that she thought the same way.
[1961-06-01 15:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I remember once she showed me a drawing, a design for shoes that she and her brother had drawn together, both men's and women's shoes.
[1961-06-01 15:05:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw the design sketches, which were very beautiful, drawn on grid paper, with rich details and precise colors. I saw that she had examined those shoes from close up, the ones that didn't belong to our world, and after seeing them, she drew them.
[1961-06-01 15:10:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I realized that the shoes were actually her design, every detail was her imagination, just like the princesses she drew when she was in elementary school. I know the shoes she painted; they look very ordinary, but they don't look like the shoes sold at Mergellina at all, not even the ones on the actresses' feet in the photo novel.
[1961-06-01 15:15:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Do you like it?" "These shoes are elegant."
[1961-06-01 15:16:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Rino says these shoes are hard to make." "Will he make them then?"
[1961-06-01 15:17:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "He said he was sure he could do it." "What about your father?"
[1961-06-01 15:18:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "He certainly can do it." "Then you do it."
[1961-06-01 15:19:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard, 'Dad doesn't want to do it.'" "Why?"
[1961-06-01 15:20:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard him say, "I can play around, but he and Rino can't waste their time following me."
[1961-06-01 15:21:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard 'What do you mean?' 'It means that if we actually go through with it, it'll take time and money.'"
[1961-06-01 15:25:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that, she showed me the account she had carefully calculated for Rino.
[1961-06-01 15:30:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her trying to find out how much it would cost to make these shoes, and finally she stopped, folding up those crumpled pages.
[1961-06-01 15:31:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard her tell me that her father was right, it was a waste of time.
[1961-06-01 15:32:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard, 'So what are you going to do?' 'We still have to try.'"
[1961-06-01 15:33:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Fernando will get angry." "If we don't even try, everything will stay the same."
[1961-06-01 15:35:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that she wanted to change the situation, but it was still the same topic. I heard that we were supposed to go from poor to rich, from having nothing to having everything.
[1961-06-01 15:36:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I mentioned to her our previous plan: to get rich by writing novels, like the author of Little Women. I know I'm still stuck here, still care a lot, and still studying Latin for this goal.
[1961-06-01 15:37:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I know that deep down I believe that, although she no longer goes to school and is now focused on making shoes, she has borrowed so many books from Professor Ferraro's mobile library. I thought it was about writing a novel together and making a lot of money.
[1961-06-01 15:38:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw and heard my words, and she shrugged. I thought of putting on an indifferent expression.
[1961-06-01 15:39:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that her thoughts about Little Women had changed, and she explained to me that now, to truly become rich, one had to do business. I heard they could make a pair of shoes first and show them to her father, demonstrating how beautiful and comfortable they were.
[1961-06-01 15:40:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard that once Fernando was convinced, production could start: two pairs today, four pairs tomorrow, thirty pairs a month, four hundred pairs a year. Soon she would be able to build a shoe factory—Lina Factory—with her father, Rino, her mother, and a few brothers, employing at least fifty workers, making shoes with machines.
[1961-06-01 15:41:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "A shoe factory?" "Yes."
[1961-06-01 15:42:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw how she spoke about the factory with confidence. I saw her sketch the image of a factory before me, speaking in her usual tone, in Italian.
[1961-06-01 15:43:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard that the "Lina" brand will be stamped on the upper part of the shoes, and they will produce a "Lina" product line. The designs are all beautiful and elegant. She said that when you wear "Lina" shoes, they are so comfortable and beautiful that you don't want to take them off even when going to bed at night.
[1961-06-01 15:45:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that we all were laughing. I thought the idea was interesting.
[1961-06-01 15:46:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Lina stop at last. I thought, as if realizing we were just joking, just like many years ago when we put Tina and Nuo in the cellar vent and played with the dolls together.
[1961-06-01 15:47:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her say to me that she was eager to explain: it was a very concrete and feasible thing. I thought of her acting like a little adult, and later, this pretense of maturity became one of her main characteristics in my eyes.
[1961-06-01 15:48:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard, 'Do you know why the Solara brothers think they are the masters of this Mergellina?' 'Because they act like bullies.'"
[1961-06-01 15:49:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "No, because they're rich." "Do you really think so?"
[1961-06-01 15:50:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard, 'Of course, you saw it? They never bother Pinocchio Caracci.' 'Indeed.'"
[1961-06-01 15:51:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Do you know why they treated Pinocchio that way?" "No."
[1961-06-01 15:52:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard her say, "Because Pinocchio has no father, she helps Melina clean the hallway and stairs, and her brother Antonio isn't much help either. So we have to earn money ourselves, more than the Solaras. We have to make it clear to those two brothers that we're not to be messed with."
[1961-06-01 15:55:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her show me a very sharp leather knife, which she had taken from her father's shop.
[1961-06-01 15:56:00] Shoemaker's Shop | "I heard her say, 'They won't touch me because I'm ugly and I haven't started my period yet, but they'll harass you. If something happens, tell me.'"
[1961-06-01 15:57:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I looked at her, very confused. I thought about how we were only thirteen years old, didn't understand anything, didn't know about the law, justice, or state institutions.
[1961-06-01 15:58:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought about how we were just imitating what we had seen and heard since childhood, but we never really knew for sure: wasn't justice always gained through fighting?
[1961-06-01 15:59:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I know that Peruzzo killed Don Achille, right?

text:
[1961-06-01 16:30:00] Home | I thought about going home, and I realized that the last things she said proved she cared about me, which made me feel very happy.
[1961-06-01T10:00:00] Outskirts | Starting from the second year, I saw that some imitation "Lina" shoes had already appeared in the display windows of shoe stores in the suburbs. I knew those shoes were basically identical to the ones Lina designed, just with slight modifications to the decoration on the upper part. Michele immediately stopped the sale of the counterfeit versions through protest and intimidation, and the matter was settled, but it didn't end there.
[1961-06-15T20:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw one evening when Michele gathered his brother Marcello, the Carraccis, Rino, of course Girolama and Pinocchia, to a meeting in the store on Martiri Square. I knew that what was unexpected was that Stefano came alone, and Lina didn't come, saying she was very tired and apologized sincerely.
[1961-06-15T20:10:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I heard Michele say that Lina wasn't coming, so what the hell were we talking about? I knew that the Solara brothers were very upset about Lina's absence. These words annoyed Giggia.
[1961-06-15T20:20:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw it, but Rino immediately intervened. He announced that he and his father had been considering it for a long time and planned to introduce some new designs at the exhibition in Arezzo in September. I know, but it's obvious he's lying.
[1961-06-15T20:30:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Michele, who didn't believe what he was saying, becoming even more restless. He said that now they needed to launch some truly creative products, not just ordinary ones. He said this to Stefano in the end. I heard, "Your wife is indispensable, you have to ask her to come."
[1961-06-15T20:31:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Piazza Martiri | I saw Stefano speak in an unexpectedly firm tone. I heard, "My wife has been busy all day in Capodimonte. She's going to rest at home tonight. She has to take care of me."
[1961-06-15T20:32:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Michele make an ugly face, which for a few seconds ruined his good-looking face, he said. I heard, "Well, then, see if she can spare some time and take care of us too."
[1961-06-15T21:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I knew that everyone was in a bad mood that night when they left, especially Pinochiazza and Giggia. For different reasons, both of them were extremely angry. They couldn't stand how Michele valued Lina so much, and over the next few days, this irritation gradually turned into a bad mood. They even started arguing over the smallest things.
[1961-07-15T15:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | One afternoon, during a routine conflict, Giggia slapped Pinocchia. Pinocchia complained about it to Rino. I know that things eventually escalated, I think it was in March, there was an accident, but I don't remember the details.
[1961-07-15T15:30:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Rino act like a boss as he entered the store, harshly reprimanding Giyaola. Giyaola reacted very strongly, and Rino became even more exaggerated, threatening to fire her. I thought of Rino, who must have been feeling full of himself and full of confidence during that period.
[1961-07-15T15:35:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | "I heard him say to Giggia, 'Starting tomorrow, you go back and continue stuffing cream into the pastries.'"
[1961-07-15T16:00:00] Martiri Square | I saw that after a while, Michele appeared, smiling as he pulled Rino out of the shop and into the square, letting him take a look at the store's sign. "I heard 'My friend,' he said, 'this shop is called Solara. You have no right to come into my shop and tell my girlfriend: I'm going to fire you.'"
[1961-07-15T16:05:00] Elena's shoe store at Martiri Square | I saw Rino remind him that everything in the store belonged to his brother-in-law, and the shoes were made by his own hands, so he had equal say in the matter. At that moment, Giggia and Pina felt they had their boyfriends to back them up, and they started shouting at each other.
[1961-07-15T16:10:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw two young men rush back into the shop, trying to get them to quiet down, but it was impossible. Michele gradually lost patience and started shouting that he would fire both of them.
[1961-07-15T16:11:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that, and not only that, he also said he wanted Lina to manage the shoe store. I thought of Lina? Managing this shop? The two girls fell silent at once, and even Rino was stunned by the idea.
[1961-07-15T16:15:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw them start discussing this shocking idea. Giyao, Pinocchia, and Rino joined forces against Michele. I heard, "What does it have to do with her? What use is Lina to you? We've made a lot of money; you shouldn't have anything to complain about. The shoes are all my work. She was just a girl back then; what could she have designed?"
[1961-07-15T16:20:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that suddenly, the board— the one with the black strips, color blocks, and photos— let out a dull sound and then suddenly caught fire, the flames rising high. I saw it like a patient struggling to breathe.
[1961-07-15T16:21:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that when the fire started, Pinocchia was facing away from the photo. The flames came up behind her, as if possessed, crackling and burning the ends of her hair.
[1961-07-15T16:22:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw Rino act quickly and put out the fire for her. I thought that if it weren't for him, her entire head of hair would have been burned off.
[1961-07-16T10:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I knew Rino and Michele both believed the fire was caused by Giggia, because sometimes she smoked secretly and had a small lighter. I thought, following Rino's words, that Geyao La had done it on purpose: everyone was busy arguing, and she set the painting board on fire. The board was covered with paper, glue, and paint, and it caught fire immediately.
[1961-07-16T11:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I need to be careful with Michele: everyone knows Giullara keeps playing with her little lighter, and maybe when they were arguing fiercely, she accidentally set the painting board on fire.
[1961-07-16T12:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Piazza Martiri | I saw it, but no matter which version you took, Giullara couldn't stand it. She spoke in a provocative tone, saying it was Lina's own fault, that the shattered photo had been set on fire by herself. I heard the words: "It's like the devil, in order to tempt a saint into sin, takes on the form of a woman to seduce them. And when those saints call upon God, the devil transforms into fire."
[1961-07-16T12:05:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw that, in order to confirm her statement, she also said that Pinocchia had said her sister-in-law had the ability to prevent herself from [being pregnant], and if she failed, she also had the ability to refuse God's gift—[causing a miscarriage].
[1961-07-20T15:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw Michele start to frequently visit the new Mergellina's Capodimonte, and the rumors grew more intense. He usually stayed there for a long time, always joking around with Lina and Pinocchia.
[1961-07-20T15:10:00] New Capodimonte | I thought that Pinocchia believed Michele had come to see her, and she was worried someone might tell Enzo, who was currently serving in Piedmont, but at the same time she felt proud, and grew even more flirtatious.
[1961-07-20T15:20:00] New Capodimonte | I saw Lina constantly making fun of Michele, and she had also heard the rumors about Michele's girlfriend. I heard, "You'd better not stay here, we're all witches, and we're dangerous."
[1961-07-25T16:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw it, but during that time, whenever I went to see Lina, I never saw her happy. Every time, she would talk about everything with a fake tone, with sarcastic remarks and [intimate gestures].
[1961-07-25T16:05:00] New Capodimonte | I heard about Xiao Xi Michele? He likes to hurt people? she said. Not at all! If he touched me, I'd catch fire. I was always the one who hurts people. I saw a blue mark on her arm, the result of Stefano's passionate touch. Her eyes were red and swollen, but not from sadness—they were tears of joy.
[1961-08-01T10:00:00] Mergellina | I thought that, in the end, everyone agreed. Giggia was completely convinced: Lina was a witch, she had enchanted her boyfriend, which was why he had sent her to run the store in Piazza Martiri.
[1961-08-01T11:00:00] Elena's Shoe Store at Martiri Square | I saw her determined to talk to Pinocchia, and in the end, they united and began to fight back. I thought about how for several days, when she went to work, she felt both jealous and desperate.
[1961-08-01T12:00:00] Lina's house | I saw Pinocchia shouting at her brother, yelling at Stefano for being happy even though he was wearing a green hat. She also attacked Rino—the boyfriend—saying he wasn't really the boss, but just Michele's lackey.
[1961-08-10T20:00:00] Below the bar | I saw that one evening, Stefano and Rino were waiting for Michele under the bar, and they had a brief, careless conversation. I knew the main idea was: stop bothering Lina, you're just wasting her time, she has work to do.
[1961-08-10T20:05:00] Below the bar | I saw Michele immediately understand the meaning of the words, and he said coldly. I heard, "What the hell do you want to say?"  
"If you don't understand, it's because you don't want to understand."  
"No, my friend, it's you who haven't figured out our business needs. If you don't want to understand, then I'll have to find another way."
[1961-08-10T20:06:00] Below the bar | "I heard 'that means?'" Stefano asked.  
"My wife wasted it in Capodimonte."  
"What does that mean?"  
"What she can do in the Martiri Square in a month, my sister and Giugliara together couldn't do in a hundred years."
[1961-08-10T20:07:00] Below the bar | "I heard, 'Speak clearly.'"  
"Lina should make a decision, Strega! She should take on the responsibility, she should design the products, she should start working on the new shoes right away."
[1961-08-10T20:30:00] Below the bar | I watched them discuss it like that, finally untangling the complex web of relationships and reaching an agreement. I knew that Stefano had firmly ruled out the possibility of his wife working at Martiri Square. The new Capodimonte was doing very well, and moving Lina away from there was definitely not a good idea. But he agreed to have Lina design some new shoe models as soon as possible, at least the winter collection.
[1961-08-10T20:40:00] Below the bar | I saw Michele say it was foolish not to let Lina run the shoe store in the city center. He said that by the end of summer, she had to start designing new shoes, his tone laced with a threat. The conversation ended like that.
[1961-08-10T20:41:00] Below the bar | "I insist that the style has to be very unique," Michele emphasized. "You have to stress that to her."  
"She'll do what she likes, as usual."  
"If she'd listen to me, I could give her some suggestions," Michele said.  
"No need for that."
[1961-08-20T14:00:00] Capodimonte | I saw that not long after the conversation, one day when I came out of school, the weather had already become very hot, and I felt very tired, so I went to find Lina. These are things she told me herself.
[1961-08-20T14:05:00] Capodimonte | I was relieved to see that there was only her in Capodimonte. She said she couldn't design anything, not even a pair of sandals, or rather, flip-flops. I heard, "They'll be angry."  
"What can I do?"  
"It's all money, Lina."  
"Their money is already more than enough."
[1961-08-20T14:10:00] Capodimonte | I thought she was, as usual, stubborn. That's just how she is—when someone asks her to focus on something, she immediately loses interest. But I soon realized it wasn't a matter of personality, not even because she disliked her husband, Rino, or the Solara brothers, or perhaps because of the political discussions she had with Pasquale and Pinochia. It was something deeper.
[1961-08-20T14:15:00] Capodimonte | I saw her expression was serious, and she spoke slowly. "I heard, 'Right now, there's nothing in my mind.'"
"Have you tried it?"
"I've tried. I'm not the same person I was at twelve anymore."
[1961-08-20T14:16:00] Capodimonte | I realized that in her mind, the shoes had only appeared once, and after that, they never came back. The game was over, and she couldn't start it again. She even found the smell of leather repulsive now. The things she used to do had become something she had forgotten.
[1961-08-20T14:17:00] Capodimonte | I know, and everything has changed. The small workshop where Fernando used to work has undergone a complete transformation; it now contains three workbenches and three machines. I thought her father had somehow gotten smaller, and he no longer argued with his older son at all, just bent over his work.
[1961-08-20T14:18:00] Capodimonte | I thought that her feelings had gradually grown cold too. Before, when her mother passed by Capodimonte, Lina would still fill her basket with things, giving some gifts to her few younger brothers, as if they were still poor and starving. Now, she no longer felt any connection with Rino. Their relationship had been broken, severed. She no longer felt he needed her help and protection.
[1961-08-20T14:19:00] Capodimonte | I thought about the motives that had once inspired her imagination, and the soil that had once produced those shoes had now become dry.
[1961-08-20T14:20:00] Capodimonte | I saw her suddenly say that even if she never went to school again, she could do so many things, as if she were showing it off to me. Finally, she laughed a bit nervously, glanced at me, and tried to see my reaction.
[1961-08-20T14:21:00] Capodimonte | I thought about how I hadn't answered her, and I was so excited I couldn't speak. Was this what Lina was like? Wouldn't she, like me, bury herself in study? The thoughts that arose in her mind, the designs for shoes, the things she wrote down and said out loud, the very complex plans, the crazy ideas—were they all just to show off to me? She no longer had that motivation, so now she's lost? Even her artistic handling of that wedding photo, she can't do it again now? Everything about her is just a coincidence, the product of chaos?
[1961-08-20T14:25:00] Capodimonte | I saw, I felt, my tightly coiled heart loosening up. She ran her fingers across her forehead, a gesture she often made. I softened when I saw her sparkling eyes and fragile smile. I thought about it, but this state lasted only a short time.
[1961-08-20T14:26:00] Capodimonte | I saw her say regretfully. I heard, "I've always had to prove that I'm the best."
[1961-08-20T14:27:00] Capodimonte | "I heard him say, 'When this place first opened, Stefano taught me how to cheat on the scale. I told him, 'You're a liar! A thief! That's how you make your money!' But in the end, I couldn't resist the temptation. Not only did I learn his tricks right away, but I even found a better way and showed it to him. My mind is always coming up with new ideas: I've deceived all of you, I cheated on the scale, I played all sorts of tricks, I deceived the whole Mergellina. Don't believe me, Elena! Don't believe what I say or what I do." I saw that she was somewhat gloomy, and then I said.
[1961-08-20T14:28:00] Capodimonte | I felt uncomfortable, and in just a few seconds, I already didn't know what she really wanted. Why was she telling me this now? I didn't understand. Was she saying it on purpose, or had those words just slipped out without her realizing? Was it to strengthen our friendship—that was her real intention—so she had spoken impulsively?

[1961-08-20T14:29:00] Capodimonte | I saw that she quickly denied the feeling, and she felt it was necessary to do so. I heard, "You see, I'm the same with Stefano as I am with you. I do good and bad things with everyone."
[1961-08-20T14:30:00] Capodimonte | I saw her long fingers interlaced, clenched tightly as she asked me. "I heard her say, 'You know, Girola said my photo caught fire on its own.'"  
"That's just the nonsense Girola says. She's angry at you."
[1961-08-20T14:31:00] Capodimonte | I saw her smile, which sounded a bit nervous, and then she suddenly changed her mood. I heard her say, "I feel pain here, something is swollen behind my eyes. Have you seen those knives? They're all very sharp, I just sharpened them. When I cut sausages, I always think: how much blood can a person's body hold? If you put too much in a container, it will crack or produce sparks and then burn down. I'm glad that wedding photo was burned. Burn down this marriage, the shop, the shoes, the Solara brothers—everything should be burned."
[1961-08-20T14:35:00] Capodimonte | I saw that I had made her quiet, and she nodded. I thought to myself that I understood—no matter how she struggled, resisted, or tried to do anything, she could not free herself from that situation. From the day she got married, she had fallen into a misfortune that grew heavier and heavier, suffocating her, and this made me feel painful for her.
[1961-08-20T14:36:00] Capodimonte | I heard, "You should try to be quiet."  
"You have to help me."  
"How can I help you?"  
"You have to be with me."  
"I am with you."  
"It's not real. I told you all my secrets, even the worst ones, but you never told me anything."  
"You're wrong. You're the only one I've ever been open with."
