[1962-08-06 09:30:00] Street | I saw I told Pasquale. I heard that we all knew an extraordinary man: Donato seemed completely controlled by his wife Lydia, but he was actually a poet.
[1962-08-06 09:35:00] Street | I saw that his tragic love story was unfolding right before our eyes. I heard that it was a person we all knew well, Melina, who inspired him.
[1962-08-06 09:40:00] Street | I felt extremely excited, my heart was pounding, but I realized that when it came to this topic, Pasquale couldn't keep up with my thoughts. He just agreed to avoid going against me.
[1962-08-06 09:45:00] Street | I saw that after a while, he started changing the subject, asking me about Lina. I heard how she's doing at school? How is she as a person? Are we still friends or not, and so on.
[1962-08-06 09:50:00] Street | I was enthusiastically talking all the way. I thought I would be happy to answer his question, the first time someone had ever asked me about our friendship.
[1962-08-06 09:55:00] Street | I tried to downplay my relationship with Lina, suppressing many loud expressions and exclamations. I thought about how I had never before felt the need to find the right words to talk about our friendship, until now.
[1962-08-06 10:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw the cobbler's shop, and we were still talking about the subject. I know Fernando has gone home to take a nap.
[1962-08-06 10:05:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Lina and Rino sitting face to face, both looking down at something with expressions of dissatisfaction. I saw their faces were full of gloom.
[1962-08-06 10:06:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw them through the glass door and immediately put everything away.
[1962-08-06 10:10:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw myself giving Professor Ferraro's prize to Lina.
[1962-08-06 10:15:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that at this moment, Pasquale and his friend Rino were joking around, opening the book he had won in front of him, teasing him. I heard, "After you finish reading The Dead Bruges, tell me if you like it. If it's well written, I'll read it too."
[1962-08-06 10:16:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw the two of them laughing, whispering about Bruges. I heard, of course, something utterly disgusting.
[1962-08-06 10:17:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that even though Pasquale was joking with Rino, he secretly glanced at Lina. I thought to myself that I had noticed it.
[1962-08-06 10:18:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I wondered why he looked at her that way? What was he searching for? What did he see? That meaningful glance, Lina hadn't even noticed.
[1962-08-06 10:19:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw him drag Pasquale into the street, as if trying to prevent us from hearing their joke. I thought that Rino had noticed it more than me, and in fact, he hated the way his friends looked at my sister.
[1962-08-06 10:20:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw myself accompanying Lina to the room at the back of the shop, and I tried hard to watch her. I thought about what it was that had caught Pasquale's attention in her.
[1962-08-06 10:21:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her still as the frail little girl: bony, pale, her only attraction possibly her big eyes and the slight rise and fall of her chest. I thought she was still the same as ever.
[1962-08-06 10:22:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her put those books among her own books, old shoes, and some crumpled notebooks.
[1962-08-06 10:25:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that I had mentioned Melina's mental health issues to her. What I want, above all, is to convey my excitement to her.
[1962-08-06 10:26:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard myself finally say that we knew someone who had just published a book—Donato Nino.
[1962-08-06 10:27:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw myself speaking to her in standard Italian. "I heard, 'Think about it, his son Nino went to the same school as us, and Nino's family got rich.'"
[1962-08-06 10:28:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her make a hesitant smile, full of doubt. I heard her say, "You mean this book?"
[1962-08-06 10:29:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her reach out and show me the book by Nino.
[1962-08-06 10:30:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I knew the book was given to her by Melina's eldest son, Antonio, who didn't want his mother to see it.
[1962-08-06 10:31:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw the book I had taken and looked at it carefully. I saw that the title of this poetry collection was Clear Proof, the cover was red, and the design showed a radiant sun atop a mountain.
[1962-08-06 10:32:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw the cover of the poetry collection, which was inscribed with the name Donato Nino. I thought about how excited I was.
[1962-08-06 10:33:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw myself opening the book and reading aloud the dedication on it. I heard, "To Melina, who inspired me. Donato, San Gregorio Armeno, June 12, 1958."
[1962-08-06 10:34:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I said, "Nino will have a car, even more beautiful than the Sorrento brothers' car." I felt excited, a tingling sensation ran down my neck, spreading all the way to the ends of my hair.
[1962-08-06 10:35:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Lina looking at me with her usual gaze, fixed on the book in my hand.
[1962-08-06 10:36:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard her mutter, "Whatever is going to happen, we'll find out soon enough." She said, "So far, these poems have only brought disaster."
[1962-08-06 10:37:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Why?" "Nino didn't have the courage to come to Melina himself; he sent her this book."
[1962-08-06 10:38:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard, "Isn't this a beautiful thing?" "Who knows? Now Melina is waiting for him. If Nino doesn't come, she'll suffer even more than before."
[1962-08-06 10:40:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw my eyes on her pale skin. I saw that her face was very smooth, not a single pimple in sight. I thought of such a brilliant analysis!
[1962-08-06 10:41:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw the delicate contours of her lips and ears as I looked at her. I thought so. I suppose she's changed, not just physically, but her way of expressing herself has changed too.
[1962-08-06 10:42:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought that, in today's terms, she could not only explain something clearly in a tone I was familiar with, but even more clearly than when I was a child.
[1962-08-06 10:43:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that now, by listing facts, she naturally enhanced their weight, and with just a few sentences, she heightened the impact of the situation. I thought, and happily realized that when she expressed her opinions, I felt I also had the ability to speak like that.
[1962-08-06 10:44:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I tried it and the effect was very good. I thought happily to myself, this is the difference between me and Camilla and the other girls: I can talk with her passionately and respond to her.
[1962-08-06 10:45:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw how strong her hands were! How graceful her movements and her gaze were! I thought to myself, sighing.
[1962-08-06 10:50:00] Shoemaker's Shop | When Lina and I were talking and analyzing love, the pleasure of our conversation suddenly stopped because I had a very ugly thought. I suddenly realized that I had been wrong.
[1962-08-06 10:51:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought of the mason Pasquale, the son of a killer, who had brought me here not for me, but for her, just to have a chance to see her.
[1962-08-06 10:55:00] Shoemaker's Shop | The moment I think about it, I suddenly can't catch my breath.
[1962-08-06 11:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw two young men come in from outside and interrupted our conversation.
[1962-08-06 11:01:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Pasquale smiling as he confessed. I heard that when he came out from the construction site, he didn't tell the foreman, and he had to go back to work immediately.
[1962-08-06 11:02:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that he was still staring at Lina, almost as if he couldn't help himself. I thought about what he said, and maybe it was meant to imply that: I risked being fired just to see you.
[1962-08-06 11:03:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw it all, and then he said to Rino. I heard, "Sunday, we're all going to Giggia's house, and Elena is coming too. Are you going?"
[1962-08-06 11:04:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Rino answer. I heard, "Sunday is still a long way off, we'll think about it."
[1962-08-06 11:05:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Pasquale glance at Lina again, but Lina didn't notice at all.
[1962-08-06 11:06:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I watched until the end, and he didn't even ask if I wanted to go with him before leaving quickly.
[1962-08-06 11:07:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Pasquale glance at Lina again, but Lina didn't notice at all. In the end, he didn't even ask if I wanted to go with him before leaving quickly. "I heard, 'Sunday is still far away, we'll think about it.' Rino answered."
[1962-08-06 11:10:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I felt very uncomfortable and anxious. I thought about how I kept running my fingers over my reddening cheeks, but once I became aware of it, I forced myself not to do so.
[1962-08-06 11:15:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw Rino pull something out from under the workbench, and he examined it uneasily. I knew that was what they had been busy with before we arrived.
[1962-08-06 11:20:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I tried again to talk to Lina about books and love.
[1962-08-06 11:25:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw us talking freely about Nino, about Melina's wild love, and about the role of the book. What do you think is happening now?
[1962-08-06 11:26:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought about how much passion could be rekindled in that woman's heart just by looking at the book's cover, its title, and the name on it—without even reading its contents!
[1962-08-06 11:30:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that we were talking so intensely that eventually Rino lost his patience and shouted at us. I heard, "Have you two had enough? Lina, let's see how we're going to do this. Dad will be back in a minute, and then we'll be stuck doing nothing!"
[1962-08-06 11:35:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I stopped talking, and I took a look at what he was doing. I saw that it was a wooden last, surrounded by a chaotic mess of soles, strips of leather, thick pieces of leather, knives, various sizes of awls, and other tools.
[1962-08-06 11:36:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I heard Lina say to me that she and Rino were trying to make a pair of travel shoes for a man.
[1962-08-06 11:37:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her brother get anxious very quickly, and he made me swear on my sister Elena's life that I would never tell anyone about this. I knew they were working behind Fernando's back, and Rino got some leather through a friend who did odd jobs at the "Casanova" leather factory.
[1962-08-06 11:38:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I know they use some scattered moments, five minutes today and ten minutes tomorrow, to make the shoes, because they couldn't convince their father to help them.
[1962-08-06 11:39:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I know it's not just that—every time they mentioned the matter, Fernando would become furious and tell Lina to go home immediately, saying he didn't want to see her in the shop anymore.
[1962-08-06 11:40:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I know he also threatened to kill Rino, saying that he was already nineteen years old and still so unreasonable, not respecting his father at all.
[1962-08-06 11:45:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I saw that I was pretending to be interested in their secret operation. I know that, even though both siblings regarded me as their confidant, even though I could only be a witness to this matter. I thought that later, I felt regretful.
[1962-08-06 11:50:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought of Lina walking alone along this road, accomplishing great things. What saddened me most was this: after we had passionately discussed poetry and love, she saw me off at the door, and yet she found a pair of shoes more interesting than love?
[1962-08-06 11:51:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought about how our conversations about Nino and Melina were so fascinating. What I couldn't believe was that when she talked about the pile of skins and tools, she immediately forgot about the woman who had suffered for love, while I still couldn't get her out of my mind.
[1962-08-06 11:52:00] Shoemaker's Shop | What does making shoes have to do with me?
[1962-08-06 11:53:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought about my heart, my eyes, still experiencing the passion of love, that broken fidelity, and the love song written into a book. It felt like the time when I and she read a novel together in the shop, and on a weekend watched a tragic film in the church cinema.

[1962-08-06 11:54:00] Outside the Shoemaker's Shop | I saw her look confused, as if she didn't know what to say. Finally, she uttered a disjointed sentence. I heard, "Last week, my period came."
[1962-08-06 11:55:00] The door of the cobbler's shop | I saw that even though Rino didn't call her, she went in.
[1962-08-06 12:00:00] Shoemaker's Shop | The mismatched emotions I saw caused me pain, and I had to leave. I thought about how she preferred the adventure on her shoes rather than our conversation; because she was independent, while I needed her; because she had a world she could throw herself into.
[1962-08-06 12:01:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought about how it was Pasquale, a man older than us, not a boy, and he must have found other opportunities to see her, to flirt with her, to secretly become her boyfriend, to be intimate with her, to touch her, just like any other couple.
[1962-08-06 12:02:00] Shoemaker's Shop | I thought, in the end, now I feel that I am becoming increasingly unnecessary for her.
[1962-08-06 12:05:00] The shoemaker's shop door | I said suddenly, I'm going to high school, as if to drive away my inner discomfort at the time, to emphasize my worth, and my irreplaceable position in her life. I thought about how I told her at the shop's entrance, by which time I had already reached the road.
[1962-08-06 12:06:00] The door of the cobbler's shop | I told her that the decision had been imposed on my parents by Professor Oliviero, and she also said she would get textbooks for me to use at school, as well as some free old books.
[1962-08-06 12:07:00] Outside the cobbler's shop | I thought that way because I wanted her to realize: I am unique, even if she might get rich with Rino making shoes, she would never be able to do without me, just like I could never do without her.
[1962-08-06 12:08:00] At the shoemaker's shop door | I saw her looking at me uneasily. I heard her ask, "What is high school?"
[1962-08-06 12:09:00] The shoemaker's shop door | I heard, "It's the school you go to after finishing middle school." "What are you going to high school for?" "To study, of course."
[1962-08-06 12:10:00] Outside the cobbler's shop | "I heard, 'What are you learning?' 'Latin.' 'Just that?'"
[1962-08-06 12:11:00] At the shoemaker's shop door | I heard, "Still studying Greek?" "Greek?" "Yes."
[1962-08-06 12:12:00] At the shoemaker's shop door | I saw her look very confused, as if she didn't know what to say. Finally, she said something that made no sense. I heard, "Last week, my period came."
[1962-08-06 12:13:00] At the shoemaker's shop door | I saw that even though Rino didn't call her, she went inside.
[1962-08-06 12:15:00] Street | I thought that she was also bleeding, the secret movement inside her body, first happening to me, then spreading to her like an earthquake wave, changing her, and it had already begun to change her.
[1962-08-06 12:16:00] Street | I thought, and I thought that Pasquale had discovered this earlier than me. It might not just be him—maybe other boys had noticed it too.
[1962-08-06 12:17:00] Street | I thought about the fact that I was going to high school, and the glamour of it quickly faded.
[1962-08-10 10:00:00] Home | I've been thinking about this for several days, wondering about the changes that might have happened to Lina, whether she might have become as beautiful as Pinocchia, Giggia, or Carmela.
[1962-08-10 10:05:00] Home | I saw myself returning home and looking at my reflection in the mirror. I wondered if I was really that ugly. Would she become ugly like me? What would she turn into, anyway?
[1962-08-12 15:00:00] Home | I saw myself beginning to dress up.
[1962-08-12 15:30:00] Street | I remember a Sunday afternoon when I walked from the main road to the small park, dressed in my usual holiday clothes: a sky-blue dress with a large square neckline, and my mother's silver bracelet on my wrist.
[1962-08-12 15:40:00] Small Park | I saw Lina. I saw her as usual, her dark hair in disarray, wearing an old, faded dress. I thought I felt a very secret joy.
[1962-08-12 15:41:00] Small Park | I thought she was no different from usual, still that neurotic, thin girl.
[1962-08-12 15:42:00] Small Park | I know she was once very small, but now she's almost as tall as me, maybe just a centimeter shorter. I thought she had grown a bit taller.
[1962-08-12 15:43:00] Small Park | I wondered where exactly her changes had been. At that time, my chest was already big, already shaped like that of a mature woman.
[1962-08-12 15:50:00] Small Park | I saw us walking all the way to the small park, then back again, and then once more into the park.
[1962-08-12 15:51:00] Small Park | I knew the time was still early, and there was no usual Sunday noise yet; the vendors selling fried peanuts, walnuts, and broad beans had not arrived yet.
[1962-08-12 15:55:00] Small Park | I saw Lina ask me carefully about high school. I didn't know much, so I exaggerated and told her everything I knew.
[1962-08-12 15:56:00] Small Park | I thought about how I wanted to arouse her curiosity, to make her long to know about my life outside, to involve her in my experiences, to make her feel that she was losing a part of me, just as I feared losing her.
[1962-08-12 16:00:00] Small Park | I saw myself walking on the side of the road, and her on the other side. When I spoke, she listened very carefully.
[1962-08-12 16:05:00] Small Park | I saw later that the Solara brothers' "Fiat 1100" pulled up, driven by Michele, with Marcello sitting beside him.
[1962-08-12 16:06:00] Small Park | I saw Marcello start making humorous remarks to us, teasing us. I heard, to be precise, not just what was said to me, but to both me and Lina.
[1962-08-12 16:07:00] Small Park | I saw him singing like that in his dialect. I heard such a beautiful lady! You keep walking back and forth, aren't you tired? Look! San Gregorio Armeno is that big, it's the most beautiful city in the world, as beautiful as you. Come up here! In half an hour, we'll send you back.
[1962-08-12 16:08:00] Small Park | I thought I shouldn't have done it. I should have pretended not to see him and Michele, not to see the car. I should have kept walking, continued talking to Lina, and ignored him.
[1962-08-12 16:09:00] Small Park | I saw it, but to prove to myself that I was charming and lucky, I was about to go to the school that the wealthy attended, where I would meet other boys with more beautiful cars.
[1962-08-12 16:10:00] Small Park | I saw myself turn around and say in Italian. I heard, "Thank you, but we can't..."
[1962-08-12 16:11:00] Small Park | I saw that at that moment, Marcello extended a hand. I thought that although he was tall, he was already a fully developed man.
[1962-08-12 16:12:00] Small Park | I saw his five fingers sticking out of the car window, grabbing my arm. I saw it, but I saw that the hand was broad, with short fingers.
[1962-08-12 16:13:00] Small Park | I saw him saying. I heard, "Michele, stop the car for a second. Look, the concierge's daughter is wearing such a beautiful bracelet!"
[1962-08-12 16:14:00] Small Park | I saw the car stop. Marcello grabbed my wrist, twisting my arm and taking the bracelet from my hand.
[1962-08-12 16:15:00] Small Park | I saw the bracelet lying on the road between the car and the sidewalk, broken.
[1962-08-12 16:16:00] Small Park | I saw "Oh my God! Look what you've done!" and I thought of my mother, so I screamed. "I'm not in a hurry," he said as he opened the car door and got out, "Now I'll fix it for you."
[1962-08-12 16:17:00] Small Park | I saw him about to reach out and grab my arm again, trying to act more familiar, to calm me down. I thought he was pleasant and courteous.
[1962-08-12 16:18:00] Small Park | At that moment, Lina suddenly came over—she pushed Marcello into the car and pressed a leather-cutting knife against his throat. I saw that her height was only half of Marcello's.
[1962-08-12 16:19:00] Small Park | I saw her speak in a slow, unhurried way, using the local dialect. I heard, "If you dare touch her again, I'll show you what will happen."
[1962-08-12 16:20:00] Small Park | I saw Marcello motionless, stunned.
[1962-08-12 16:21:00] Small Park | I saw Michele quickly get out of the car and he said with certainty. I heard, "Marcello, what can that little slut do to you? She doesn't have the guts."
[1962-08-12 16:22:00] Small Park | "I'm coming," Lina said, "you come here, so you can see if I have the guts or not."
[1962-08-12 16:23:00] Small Park | I saw Michele lingering around the car. At that moment, I started crying.
[1962-08-12 16:24:00] Small Park | I saw from my angle that the knife had already cut Marcello's skin, leaving a small wound from which a thread of blood flowed.
[1962-08-12 16:25:00] Small Park | I saw Lina standing next to Marcello, as if there was a dangerous insect on his face, and she was trying to brush it away. I remember the scene very clearly in my mind: it was still very hot, and there were few people on the street.
[1962-08-12 16:26:00] Small Park | I remember clearly what happened; at that moment, her attitude was very clear: she would have no hesitation in cutting Marcello's throat.
[1962-08-12 16:27:00] Small Park | I saw that Michele had also realized it.
[1962-08-12 16:28:00] Small Park | "I see. You're pretty good," he said, still calm, almost humorous. He returned to his car. "I heard, 'Come on! Marcello, apologize to the two ladies, let's go.'"
[1962-08-12 16:29:00] Small Park | I saw Lina slowly lower the knife from Marcello's neck. I saw him smile shyly, his eyes a little flustered.
[1962-08-12 16:30:00] Small Park | I heard "Wait a minute," he said. I heard him kneeling on the sidewalk in front of me, as if offering an apology through the greatest possible humility.
[1962-08-12 16:31:00] Small Park | I saw him fumble underneath the car and found the bracelet.
[1962-08-12 16:32:00] Small Park | I saw him look at it carefully, tightening the silver ring with his fingernail, and fixed the bracelet.
[1962-08-12 16:33:00] Small Park | I saw him hand me the bracelet, but his eyes were on Lina. I heard him say, "I'm sorry."
[1962-08-12 16:34:00] Small Park | I saw and then got into the car and left.
[1962-08-12 16:35:00] Small Park | I saw what I said. I heard, "I was crying not because I was afraid, but because of the bracelet."

text:
[1962-08-15 08:00:00] Home | I remember one morning, my father took me out. I knew that summer, the boundary of Mergellina was slowly dissolving.
[1962-08-15 08:05:00] Street | I saw that I had to go register for high school. I thought he wanted to take this opportunity to make me figure out which bus to take and which route to follow to the new school I was supposed to go to in October.
[1962-08-15 08:10:00] Street | I saw that it was a very clear day, with a breeze and excellent weather.
[1962-08-15 08:15:00] Street | I thought about how I felt deeply cherished, and my feelings for my father quickly turned into admiration.
[1962-08-15 08:20:00] Street | I saw that he knew where to take the subway, the tram, and the bus. I thought about how familiar he was with this vast city.
[1962-08-15 08:30:00] Street | I saw him being friendly on the way. I thought it was a very composed form of courtesy; he never behaved that way at home.
[1962-08-15 09:00:00] On the bus | I saw that in the bus and the office, he could get along with anyone. I thought about how he always made it known that he worked at the city hall, that he could help speed up procedures and open some doors.
[1962-08-15 09:30:00] Train Station | I saw us spending a day together, the first time in my life. I thought I had never felt that before.
[1962-08-15 09:35:00] Train Station | I saw that he was paying attention to me. I thought that, in just a few hours, he was going to pass on to me everything he had learned in life that was useful.
[1962-08-15 09:40:00] Train Station | I saw him showing me the Garibaldi Square and the train station under construction.
[1962-08-15 09:41:00] Train Station | I heard him say that the train station would be built very advanced, so even the Japanese would come here to study its structure and then build an exact copy back home, especially the columns, which were very beautiful.
[1962-08-15 09:42:00] Train Station | I saw it, but he confessed to me that he preferred the old train station because it was more emotional. I heard there's nothing we can do about it. San Gregorio Armeno has always been like this: split apart, break down, then rebuild again. Money flows, creating opportunities for work.
[1962-08-15 10:00:00] Street | I saw him take me to Garibaldi Street, all the way to where I had to go to school.
[1962-08-15 10:10:00] School | I saw him chatting warmly with the secretary, and his tone was always likable. I thought that at our Mergellina and at home, he would hide that tone.
[1962-08-15 10:15:00] School | I saw him showing off my grades in front of a custodian, and at school he also found an acquaintance, someone from the same faction.
[1962-08-15 10:16:00] School | I saw and heard him constantly saying "Is everything okay?" or "We can only do our best."
[1962-08-15 11:00:00] City area | I took him to see Piazza Carlo III, the homes of the poor, the botanical garden, Via Flora, and the museum.
[1962-08-15 12:00:00] City center | I saw him take me to Constantinople Street, then to the Port of Alba, Dante Square, and the Toledo district.
[1962-08-15 12:10:00] Downtown | I saw my mind full of names. I saw the bustling sounds of cars and people on the road, the rich colors, and the festive atmosphere around me.
[1962-08-15 12:15:00] City center | I tried very hard to write down everything I saw, so I could tell Lina about it when I got back.
[1962-08-15 12:30:00] Downtown | I saw my father chatting humorously with a pizza maker, and he bought me a hot, cheesy pizza. He also got me a golden peach from the fruit stand.
[1962-08-15 12:35:00] City center | I wondered if it was possible that only our Mergellina was filled with violence, while other parts of the city were radiant and peaceful?
[1962-08-15 13:00:00] City Hall | I saw him take me to the municipal building where he worked.
[1962-08-15 13:05:00] City Hall | I heard him say that everything there was new, the trees had all been cut down, and the old houses had been torn down: now look how spacious it is, the only old thing is the Azzurro Castle, delicate and beautiful. Governor Azzurro, two real men were your father and him.
[1962-08-15 13:10:00] City Hall | I saw us walking toward the government building; he greeted this one and that one, he knew so many people.
[1962-08-15 13:15:00] City Hall | I saw that he was especially familiar with some people, and he introduced me to them. I've heard it said countless times that I got a nine in Italian at school, and also a nine in Latin.
[1962-08-15 13:20:00] City Hall | I saw that he hardly spoke to anyone else. I just heard him say, "Well, yes, I'll do as you say."
[1962-08-15 13:25:00] City Hall | I saw it all, and then he announced that he wanted me to take a close look at Mount Vesuvius and the sea.

[1963-07-22T09:11:20] Beach | I've been thinking about this all week, and every night before I go to sleep, I imagine what will happen over the weekend.

[1963-07-22T09:11:30] Beach | I saw myself smiling and saying something. "I heard, 'Lina, what should I know? Are married women happy?'"

[1963-07-22T14:30:00] Beach | I saw Pinocchia's mood getting clearly worse, she was saying more and more irrational things, sometimes saying she thought they wouldn't come after all, other times lamenting that we couldn't waste time waiting for them.
[1963-07-22T15:00:00] Beach | I saw the two boys arrive on time, still carrying their cold drinks.
[1963-07-22T15:10:00] Beach | I saw her acting irritable. She said she felt tired, but a few minutes later her mood seemed to get worse. She changed her mind and sighed, saying she was going to buy a coconut.
[1963-07-22T15:30:00] Beach | I saw that as for Lina, she did something I really disliked. Throughout the whole week, she never mentioned the book I lent her, and I had almost forgotten all about it.

"Kind of."

"That's not the same thing."  
"I know, but it's better than never seeing it at all."
[1963-07-22T15:30:15] Beach | I saw that at that moment, she took out the book I had given her, Beckett's collection of plays, and showed it to Nino, asking him. I heard, "Have you read this book?"
[1963-07-22T15:30:20] Beach | I saw Nino take the book, look at it carefully, then uncomfortably admit. I heard, "No."  
"So you aren't all-knowing after all."  
"Yes."  
"You should take a look at this book."

Now she made these people and things come alive before our eyes.
[1963-07-22T15:35:05] Beach | I saw her say that we didn't have to wait for nuclear war to break out, as if in that book, the nuclear war had already happened.

[1963-07-22T15:40:05] Beach | I saw her explaining to us why there was nothing in Winny's life, nothing at all. Her movements were empty, her mind was empty. Not a single day, not even the days before, was extraordinary.

[1963-07-22T15:45:05] Beach | I saw her say that Dan Rooney was blind, but he didn't feel regretful, because not seeing made his life better. One day, he thought, if he had become deaf and mute, would his life be even more like real life—a pure life, a life that was only life.
[1963-07-22T15:46:00] Beach | I heard Nino ask, "Why do you like this character?"  
"I don't know if I really like him now."  
"Isn't he arousing your curiosity?"
[1963-07-22T15:46:05] Beach | "I heard, 'He made me think of a lot—meaning, if you couldn't see, couldn't hear, and even lost your language, what would life be like? What does that even mean?'"
"Maybe it was just a strategy."
[1963-07-22T15:46:10] Beach | I heard him say, "No, it's not some kind of strategy. It makes you think of a lot of things—this isn't just a way of expressing something."
[1963-07-22T15:47:00] Beach | I saw that Nino was silent, he just looked at the book's cover as if trying to carefully recognize it. I heard him ask, "Have you finished reading it?"  
"Yes."  
"Can I borrow it to take a look?"

[1963-07-22T15:47:10] Beach | I thought of Nino, who once said—though I don't remember exactly—that he wasn't really interested in literature. He read other kinds of books. I gave the Beckett to Lina precisely because I knew I would never get a chance to talk to him about it.

"Did you read it?" he asked me.

"Then show it to me after you finish."
[1963-07-22T15:47:30] Beach | "I heard 'If you're really that interested,' " I immediately said, "then read first."
[1963-07-22T15:48:00] Beach | I saw Nino thanking me, he used his fingernail to scrape off the corpse of a mosquito from the cover, and said to Lina. I heard, "I can finish this book in one night, and tomorrow we can talk about it."
[1963-07-22T15:48:05] Beach | I heard, "Tomorrow isn't possible, we can't meet tomorrow."  
"Why?"  
"Tomorrow I'll be with my husband."  
"Oh."

[1963-07-22T15:48:15] Beach | I saw him, but he suddenly became very impatient and said. I heard, "I won't be able to come tomorrow. Bruno's parents are here, I have to go stay in Barano, and I won't be back until Monday."
[1963-07-22T15:48:20] Beach | I thought of Balano? Monday? I hope he'll tell me to meet him at the Maronti beach.
[1963-07-22T15:48:25] Beach | I saw it all, and he never invited me. I thought about him, but he was distracted, probably still thinking about Dan Rooney—the character didn't want to just be blind, he also wanted to become deaf and mute.

[1963-07-22T18:05:00] On the way home | I felt my mood gradually brighten. I didn't think Nino had just said he was going to Balano on a whim—he wanted me to know where he was, to take the initiative and go find him in Balano. That's just the way he is.
[1963-07-22T18:05:05] On the way home | I felt relieved when I thought about it—I realized he needed to be followed, and I decided to get up early tomorrow morning to find him.

After [her reproductive state], not only did her body become rounder, but her personality seemed to have lost some of its sharp edges. The only person whose mood remained terrible was Pinocchia, but for some reason, her face grew darker and darker that day.
[1963-07-22T18:15:00] On the way home | I saw myself suddenly ask her. I heard, "Did Bruno say something unpleasant to you?"  
"No, he didn't."  
"What happened?"

"Are you feeling unwell?"
"I'm not feeling unwell. I don't even know myself what's wrong with me."

[1963-07-24 09:00:00] Malonto Beach | I saw the next day, and I set aside all my fear and doubt. I took a towel and a book and walked toward Maronti Beach.
[1963-07-24 09:20:00] Malongti Beach | I thought to myself that the road was long, and I didn't meet anyone going up or down.
[1963-07-24 09:30:00] Malongdi Beach | I saw the beach as if it had no end, empty and vast, with large grains of sand that squeaked with every step I took.
[1963-07-24 09:30:10] Malongti Beach | I saw the sea emitting a strong odor, along with a dry, monotonous sound.
[1963-07-24 09:30:20] Malongdi Beach | I saw that I had been standing there for a long time. I saw before me a vast expanse of water.
[1963-07-24 09:30:30] Malonto Beach | I saw her later sitting helplessly on the towel.
[1963-07-24 09:35:00] Malonto Beach | I saw it to the end, then I stood up and got my feet wet.
[1963-07-24 09:35:10] Malonto Beach | I think about how I lived in a city like San Gregorio Armeno, yet I never once thought of going for a swim. But that's exactly what happened.
[1963-07-24 09:36:00] Malonto Beach | I watched myself carefully stepping forward, letting the water flow over my ankles, then my thighs. Finally, I lost my balance and fell into the water.
[1963-07-24 09:36:10] Malongti Beach | I saw myself struggling in fear, drinking some seawater, and then returning to the surface to breathe air.
[1963-07-24 09:36:20] Malonti Beach | I saw what I had discovered, and I naturally moved my arms and legs, rising up. I thought, so I am able to swim.
[1963-07-24 09:36:30] Malonto Beach | I thought about how my mother really brought me to the sea when I was very young, and while she had her sand baths, I learned to swim.
[1963-07-24 09:36:40] Malongdi Beach | I thought I suddenly saw her, younger then, not so ugly.
[1963-07-24 09:36:50] Malonto Beach | I saw, or rather, I thought I saw her sitting on the beach, sunburned in the noon sun.
[1963-07-24 09:37:00] Malongdi Beach | I saw that I remembered her wearing a white flowered dress, the good leg covered by the skirt all the way to her knees, while the faulty leg was buried under the scorching sand.
[1963-07-24T10:00:00] Beach | I knew that from that moment on, for the entire following week, it felt completely natural for the two boys to come looking for us at ten in the morning.
[1963-07-24T19:00:00] Beach | I saw us staying on the beach until the sun set. I heard until we said, "We should go, otherwise Nunzia will get angry." They also took the opportunity to say they needed to go back and study for a while.
[1963-07-25T15:00:00] Beach | I saw that if Bruno joked with Lina, calling her Mrs. Karachi, she would punch his shoulder and then run after him. I thought about how close we had become.
[1963-07-25T15:10:00] Beach | I saw that if he paid a lot of attention to Pinocchia because she was pregnant, Pinocchia would let him put his hand on her shoulder. I heard him say, "Let's go, I want a soda."
[1963-07-25T15:20:00] Beach | I saw that as for Nino, he now often took my hand and put one arm over my shoulder and the other over Lina's, catching her index finger and thumb with his hand.
[1963-07-25T16:00:00] Beach | I saw that in the end, the five of us became cheerful and easily happy companions. I thought about how the boundaries between us were disappearing.
[1963-07-25T16:10:00] Beach | I watched us play all sorts of games, and whoever lost had to be punished. I know that usually the person who gets punished has to kiss someone, but that kind of playful intimate gesture.
[1963-07-25T16:15:00] Beach | I know, for example: Bruno wants to kiss Lina's feet covered in sand, Nino wants to kiss my hands, cheeks, forehead, ears, or hit the back of my ears.
[1963-07-25T16:30:00] Beach | I saw that we were still playing the ball game, and Lina was very good at it, as was Nino. I know, but the most energetic and fun-loving person is Bruno; he and Pinocchia always win.
[1963-07-25T16:35:00] Beach | I saw that no matter whether they were playing with me and Lina, or Lina and Nino, or Nino and me, they always won. I thought about how we all had reached an unspoken agreement in front of Pinocchio.
[1963-07-25T16:40:00] Beach | I watched her running, rushing, rolling in the sand, completely forgetting her condition. We quickly ended the game, letting her win, just to calm her down.
[1963-07-25T16:45:00] Beach | I saw Bruno kindly persuade her to sit down, then he called out. I heard, "Pinochia scores, great!"
[1963-07-25T17:00:00] Beach | I saw it like that, day by day, a kind of happiness began to spread. I used to be annoyed when Lina borrowed my books, but now I don't mind at all—I even think it's a beautiful thing.
[1963-07-25T17:30:00] Beach | When we were discussing, Lina started to express her own ideas, and Nino was listening carefully, as if he couldn't find anything to argue against, which also made me feel good. I thought that what made me so happy was that, in those situations, he would suddenly stop talking to her and start discussing with me instead, as if doing so helped him regain his own thoughts.
[1963-07-26T15:00:00] Beach | I remember once when Lina talked about the book she had read about Hiroshima, something similar happened.
[1963-07-26T15:05:00] Beach | I know the discussion sparked by that book was very intense. I thought about how, because I knew Nino was critical of America, he didn't like the military base they had established in San Gregorio Armeno, but he was also deeply attracted by their way of life. He said he wanted to study it.
[1963-07-26T15:10:00] Beach | I felt hurt when Lina said that the atomic bombing of Japan by the United States was a crime, even more serious than a military crime, and had little to do with war anymore—it was an attack on dignity.
[1963-07-26T15:15:00] Beach | I saw him speak very carefully. I heard, "Do you remember the Pearl Harbor incident?"
[1963-07-26T15:20:00] Beach | I didn't know what the Pearl Harbor incident was, but I found out that Lina did.
[1963-07-26T15:25:00] Beach | I saw her telling Nino that the nature of the Pearl Harbor incident and the Hiroshima incident were completely different and couldn't be compared. Pearl Harbor was a very despicable military operation, but Hiroshima was a very foolish and terrible act of revenge, even worse than revenge—it was a Nazi massacre.
[1963-07-26T15:30:00] Beach | I saw her conclude with that. I heard him say, "Americans should be sent to a military tribunal as the most despicable war criminals. The terrible things they did were only meant to scare the people who are still alive and make them completely submit."
[1963-07-26T15:35:00] Beach | I saw that in this heated discussion, Nino didn't retaliate but instead fell into a troubled silence. I thought, and then he spoke to me as if Lina wasn't even there.
[1963-07-26T15:40:00] Beach | I saw him say that the incident itself was not driven by cruelty or revenge, but to end that brutal war once and for all, precisely through this new type of weapon that would end all wars.
[1963-07-26T15:45:00] Beach | I saw him speaking in a low voice, his eyes locked on mine, as if he cared only for my approval. I thought it was a very beautiful moment.
[1963-07-26T15:50:00] Beach | I was so excited at that moment that tears burst from my eyes and I could hardly hold them back. I thought he was very handsome at that moment.
[1963-07-26T19:00:00] Beach | I saw that Friday had come again, a very hot day, and we spent most of our time in the water. I thought, suddenly I felt something was broken.
[1963-07-26T19:30:00] On the way home | I saw us on the way home, just said goodbye to two young men, and the sun was about to set. I saw the blue sky covered with red clouds.
[1963-07-26T19:35:00] On the way home | After a few hours of high emotion, Pinocchia suddenly became quiet. She threw her bag on the ground and sat by the roadside, shouting angrily — a very quiet shout, almost like a groan.
[1963-07-26T19:40:00] On the way home | I saw Lina squint her eyes, staring at her sister-in-law. I thought of it as if I were looking at something extremely ugly, something she couldn't bear to face.
[1963-07-26T19:45:00] On the way home | I saw myself approaching her with some concern and asked. I heard, "Pinocchio, what's wrong? Are you feeling unwell?"  
"I can't stand this wet swimsuit."  
"But our swimsuits are all wet too."
[1963-07-26T19:50:00] On the way home | I heard, "I can't stand it anymore!"
"Take your time, get up, we're leaving. Aren't you hungry?"
"Don't tell me to take my time! When you say that, it really gets on my nerves. I can't stand you anymore, Elena, and your 'take your time' nonsense."
[1963-07-26T19:55:00] On the way home | I saw her start to cry, patting her thigh as she wept.
[1963-07-26T20:00:00] On the way home | I saw that Lina hadn't waited for us; she had already walked away alone. I thought to myself that she made this decision not because she was annoyed or indifferent, but because of some deeper, more intense reason—so intense that it seemed to burn her just by being near us.
[1963-07-26T20:05:00] On the way home | I saw myself helping Pinocchia stand up and holding her bag.

[1963-07-26T21:00:00] Renting House | I saw that Pinocchio gradually calmed down, but that night she kept a sour face, as if we had done something wrong to her.
[1963-07-26T21:30:00] Renting house | I saw that later she wasn't even polite to Nunzia, saying the noodles were poorly cooked. Lina sighed and then launched into a torrent of insults in the local dialect.
[1963-07-26T22:00:00] Renting house | I saw the night when Pinocchia decided to sleep in my room.
[1963-07-26T23:00:00] Rentals | I saw that she was sleeping uneasily. I saw two people staying in such a small room that they couldn't even catch their breath, their clothes soaked through with sweat.
[1963-07-27 10:00:00] Barano | I saw that the sea and sunlight quickly erased the marks of my acne from my face. I was red all over from the sun, and also got darker.
[1963-07-27T04:00:00] Renting House | I saw that I later had to open the window, but I was immediately surrounded by mosquitoes. I thought about it so much that I couldn't sleep at all, and as soon as it was light, I got up.
[1963-07-27T05:00:00] Renting House | I saw three or four mosquito bites on my face, making me feel utterly ashamed to go out. I thought my mood was also very bad now.
[1963-07-27T05:10:00] Renting House | I saw myself going to the kitchen, and Nunzia was already washing our clothes.
[1963-07-27T05:15:00] Renting House | I saw that Lina had also gotten up; she had already drunk her milk and was looking at another one of my books. I thought about when she might have taken it.
[1963-07-27T05:20:00] Renting House | I saw her look at me with a scrutinizing gaze the moment I came in. She made an innocent expression and asked me a question that surprised me. I heard, "How is Pinocchio?"  
"I don't know."
[1963-07-27T05:25:00] Renting House | I heard, "You're angry?"  
"Yes, I didn't sleep all night. Look at my face."  
"I don't see it."  
"That's because you can't see anything at all."
[1963-07-27T05:30:00] Renting House | I heard, "Nino and Bruno will also be invisible."  
"What does that have to do with them?"  
"Are you really concerned about Nino?"  
"I've told you a hundred times, I don't care about him."
[1963-07-27T05:35:00] Renting House | I heard, "Don't get excited."  
"I'm perfectly calm."  
"We have to be careful with Pinocchia."  
"You have to be careful with her. She's your sister-in-law, not mine."  
"Are you angry?"  
"Yes, yes, yes."
[1963-07-27T09:00:00] On the way to the beach | I saw us walking nervously toward the beach. I saw that the day was even hotter than the previous one, and our bad moods seemed to spread like an infection, infecting all of us.
[1963-07-27T09:10:00] On the way to the beach | I saw that on the way, Pinocchia realized she had forgotten her towel and had another fit.
[1963-07-27T09:15:00] On the way to the beach | I saw Lina walking forward with her head down, not even bothering to look back. "I'll go get it," I volunteered.  
"No, I want to go home. I don't want to go to the beach anymore."
[1963-07-27T09:20:00] On the way to the beach | I heard, "Do you feel unwell?"  
"I'm fine."  
"Then why?"  
"Look at my stomach."
[1963-07-27T09:25:00] On the way to the beach | I looked at her stomach and, without thinking, said. "I heard, 'What about me? Look at my face, it's been bitten by mosquitoes so bad.'"
[1963-07-27T09:30:00] On the way to the beach | I saw her start shouting, then she quickened her pace and caught up with Lina. I heard her say to me, "You're an idiot!"
[1963-07-27T10:00:00] Beach | I saw that we had reached the beach, and she immediately apologized to me, saying, "You're so honest, so proper," which made me very angry. I heard, "I'm very honest?"
"I wanted to say you're good."
"I'm not good at all."
[1963-07-27T10:05:00] Beach | I saw Lina staring at the sea in the direction of Mergellina, trying not to be affected by us. Finally, she said coldly. I heard, "Stop it, they're coming."
[1963-07-27T10:10:00] Beach | I saw Pinocchio mutter, "Your guest has arrived." Suddenly, her voice softened. She applied lipstick to her lips, even though she had already put on plenty.
[1963-07-27T10:15:00] Beach | I thought about the two boys' feelings, which were even worse than ours.
[1963-07-27T10:20:00] Beach | I saw Nino speaking to Lina in a mocking tone. I heard, "Tonight, your husbands are all coming, right?"  
"Of course."  
"What fun things are you going to do?"  
"We'll eat, drink, and then go to sleep."
[1963-07-27T10:25:00] Beach | I heard, "What about tomorrow?"  
"Tomorrow we eat, drink, then go to sleep."  
"Will they be there on Sunday night?"  
"No, on Sunday we eat, drink, and only take a nap in the afternoon."
[1963-07-27T10:30:00] Beach | I saw that I had hidden my self-mocking tone, and I forced myself to speak. I heard, "I'm free. I don't eat or drink, I don't sleep."
[1963-07-27T10:35:00] Beach | I saw Nino looking at me as if he'd just noticed a problem he'd never seen before. He touched my right cheekbone with one hand, where a mosquito had bitten me and it was swollen more noticeably than the rest.
[1963-07-27T10:40:00] Beach | I saw him speaking to me very seriously. I heard, "Well, let's meet here tomorrow morning at seven o'clock, then we'll go hiking together. After that, we'll stay by the sea until late. What do you think?"
[1963-07-27T10:45:00] Beach | I felt a wave of joy surging through my veins, and I said quite relieved. "I heard, 'Okay, seven o'clock in the morning, I'll bring the food.'"
[1963-07-27T10:50:00] Beach | I saw Pinocchio looking somewhat dejected and asking. "I heard, 'What about us?'"
[1963-07-27T10:55:00] Beach | I saw him mutter something. I heard, "You have husbands." I thought about how, when he said the word "husband," it was as if he were talking about a toad, a venomous snake, and a spider.
[1963-07-27T11:00:00] Beach | I saw Pinocchio stand up suddenly after hearing those words and start walking toward the seashore.
[1963-07-27T11:05:00] Beach | I saw myself making an excuse for her. I heard, "She's been a bit too sensitive lately. It's because of her [childbearing condition], she usually isn't like this."
[1963-07-27T11:10:00] Beach | I saw Bruno speaking again in his patient tone. I heard, "I'll go with her to buy a coconut."
[1963-07-27T11:15:00] Beach | I saw our eyes following him as he walked steadily across the sand. He moved with ease, as if the scorching sand beneath his feet wasn't even there. I saw that he was small in stature but solid, with a broad chest and strong thighs.
[1963-07-27T11:20:00] Beach | "I saw Lina say as Bruno and Pinocchia walked toward the beach." I heard, "Let's go swimming."
[1963-07-27T11:30:00] Beach | I saw the three of us walking toward the sea, me in the middle, with the two of them on either side.
[1963-07-27T11:35:00] Beach | I saw Nino say to me, "We'll meet at seven o'clock tomorrow morning." I found it hard to describe my feelings at that moment, a sudden sense of victory.
[1963-07-27T11:35:05] Beach | I thought, of course, I felt sorry for Pinocchio's fickle mood, but that sorrow was very slight and had no real impact on my cheerful mood.
[1963-07-27T11:35:10] Beach | I thought about how I finally felt satisfied with myself, and a long, exciting weekend was waiting for me; at that moment, I felt proud to be there, being with the most important person in my life, someone who even my parents and my brothers and sisters couldn't compare to.
[1963-07-27T11:40:00] Beach | I saw myself holding both of their hands and letting out a happy cry, pulling them into the cold, crashing sea water.
[1963-07-27T11:41:00] Beach | I saw us, as one, plunge into the sea.
locations: On the way to the beach

text:
[1963-07-27T11:42:00] Sea | I saw that once we entered the water, we let go of each other's hands. I thought about how I've never liked the cold sea water wetting my hair, and the feeling of the seawater on my scalp and in my ears.
[1963-07-27T11:43:00] Sea | I saw myself rising to the surface, shaking off the water.
[1963-07-27T11:45:00] Sea | I saw them already swimming, so I started swimming too to keep up. I immediately realized it was a very difficult thing to do.
[1963-07-27T11:46:00] Sea | I saw that I couldn't swim straight ahead. My head was underwater, and I could still calmly move my arms, but my right arm was stronger than my left, so I always drifted off course. Plus, I was also worried about swallowing water.
[1963-07-27T11:50:00] Sea | I thought about how I tried to keep up with them. I was nearsighted, but I still hoped I could always see them. I thought they would stop.
[1963-07-27T11:55:00] Sea | I saw my heart beating fast, then I slowed down until it finally stopped, floating on the water, watching them swim confidently one after another toward the distance.
[1963-07-27T12:00:00] Sea | I saw that, perhaps, they had swum too far, and I had too. At the time, I had been seized by a sudden impulse, and I swam farther than my usual safe line. Normally, from that line, I could swim back to shore with just two strokes.
[1963-07-27T12:05:00] Sea | I saw that Lina had never crossed that line either, but now she was competing with Nino. I knew that despite her lack of experience, she didn't back down, and she swam farther and farther away from him.
[1963-07-27T12:10:00] Sea | I thought about it, worrying: What if she lost her strength? What if she felt unwell? Nino is a good swimmer; he would help Lina, but what if he cramp up? What if he couldn't hold on either?
[1963-07-27T12:15:00] Sea | I looked around, the waves pushed me to the left. I couldn't wait here for them, I should go back to the shore.
[1963-07-27T12:15:05] Sea | I looked down. The sky-blue had turned into a deep blue, and the color below grew darker and darker, like night, even though the sun was shining on the sea, which shimmered with glints of white, as if connected to the horizon. I thought that was really a mistake.
[1963-07-27T12:15:10] Sea | I thought I felt a deep chasm beneath my feet, without any solid ground, like a death trap that could spring up at any moment, piercing me, catching me, tearing me apart, dragging me into the depths of the sea.
[1963-07-27T12:20:00] Sea | I forced myself to calm down and shouted, "Lina!" I saw it, but I wasn't wearing my glasses, so I couldn't see anything. All I saw was a vast expanse of white sea.
[1963-07-27T12:25:00] Sea | I was thinking about my outing with Nino the next day as I swam back slowly, floating on my back, moving my arms and legs, until I reached the shore.
[1963-07-27T12:30:00] Beach | I saw myself sitting in the shallow water, straining to look at their dark heads far out on the sea, like two buoys. I felt a sense of relief.
[1963-07-27T12:35:00] Beach | I saw that Lina was not only fine, but she had also caught up with Nino, swimming just as fast as he did. I thought how enthusiastic, exaggerated, and brave she was.
[1963-07-27T12:40:00] Beach | I saw myself stand up and walk over to Bruno, who was sitting next to us. "I heard 'Where's Pinocchio?' I asked."
[1963-07-27T12:40:05] Beach | I saw him smile shyly. I heard, "She's gone." I thought that he was trying to hide his sadness.
[1963-07-27T12:40:10] Beach | I heard, "Where did she go?"  
"She went home. She said she wanted to pack her luggage."  
"Luggage?"  
"She wants to leave here. She can't stay away from her husband for so long."
[1963-07-27T12:50:00] Beach | I saw myself taking my things, and I made him watch Nino, especially watching Lina. I ran back all wet, wanting to see what was wrong with Pinocchio.
[1963-07-27T14:00:00] Rentals | I knew it was a terrible afternoon, and the situation got even worse by nightfall. I saw Pinocchia really packing her suitcase, and Nunzia couldn't calm her down.
[1963-07-27T14:10:00] Rentals | "I don't want you to worry," Nunzia said calmly, "Rino can wash his own underpants, he can cook, and his father is at home, plus other friends. He won't think you're here just for your own pleasure. He understands you're here to rest, to have a beautiful and healthy baby."
[1963-07-27T14:15:00] Renting house | "I heard, 'Come on! Let me help you put things away. I've never taken a vacation before, but now thanks to God, we have money. But we can't waste it. It's not a sin to enjoy ourselves, and your financial situation allows for it. Pinocchio, my daughter!"
[1963-07-27T14:20:00] Rentals | I heard, "Rino has been working for a whole week, he's very tired now, and he's coming right away. Don't let him see you like this. You know him, he gets worried easily, and when he gets worried, he gets angry. And what happens when he gets angry?"
[1963-07-27T14:25:00] Rentals | I heard, "You want to go back to him, he's already left, he'll be with you soon, now you've met, you should be happy together. Now you look like this, it'll make everyone unhappy. Do you think that's good?"
[1963-07-27T14:30:00] Rentals | I saw Nunzia pleading with all her might, but Pinocchia wouldn't listen at all.
[1963-07-27T14:40:00] Renting House | At that point, I also joined the effort to persuade her. Eventually, we took the items out of her luggage, she put them back in, and she kept shouting. When she finally calmed down, we started all over again.
[1963-07-27T15:00:00] Renting House | I saw Lina come back later. She leaned against the door frame, frowning as she looked at us. A long wrinkle appeared on her forehead, and she just stood there, watching Pinocchio's confused state.
[1963-07-27T15:05:00] Rentals | I saw her nod. "I'm okay, right?" I asked.  
"You're swimming so well now."  
She said nothing.
[1963-07-27T15:10:00] Renting House | I know her sister-in-law once again was insisting on leaving, saying goodbye to this place, and regretting all the things she hadn't done, sighing for her husband Rino. She contradictory said she couldn't bear to leave the sea, the scent of the garden, and the beach. I thought about the expression on her face, which looked both happy and sad. It was clear that Pinocchio's stubborn mischief had finally become more than she could stand.
[1963-07-27T15:15:00] Rentals | I saw that although Lina said nothing, she didn't utter her usual cruel and mocking words. Finally, she coldly spit out a single sentence. I heard, "They're coming soon." I thought it wasn't about asking everyone to return to normal emotions, but more like announcing an urgent matter that threatened everyone.
[1963-07-27T15:20:00] Rentals | At that moment, Pinocchia completely broke down. She threw herself onto the suitcase that had already been closed.
[1963-07-27T15:30:00] Renting House | I saw Lina make a face, then went back to get herself ready. She didn't take long and came back, tying her black hair up. I saw her wearing a very tight red dress.
[1963-07-27T16:00:00] Renting House | I saw her be the first to hear the sound of the "Lametta" motorcycle, stick her head out of the window, and greet someone with enthusiasm, then speak to Pinocchia in a tone full of contempt, very seriously. I heard, "You'd better go wash your face and change out of that wet swimsuit."
[1963-07-27T16:05:00] Rentals | I saw Pinocchia looking at her, but she showed no reaction. I thought about how the two girls quickly exchanged something between them, a secret projection of their emotions, tiny molecules emitted from the depths of their hearts that left them broken and wounded. It was the trembling within that long second.
[1963-07-27T16:05:05] Renting House | I saw that I had captured it, I didn't understand exactly what it was, but they did, they understood each other, they shared an unspoken understanding. I thought that Pinocchia knew that Lina understood her situation, and she realized that Lina wanted to help her, even if it was laced with contempt, so she did what Lina told her to.

[1963-07-27T16:30:00] Rentals | I saw Stefano and Rino burst in immediately.
[1963-07-27T16:35:00] Renting House | I saw Lina being even more affectionate than the previous week; she embraced Stefano and let him embrace her.
[1963-07-27T16:40:00] Apartment for Rent | I saw Stefano pull a small box from his pocket. When she opened it and saw a gold chain with a heart-shaped pendant, she let out a cry of joy.
[1963-07-27T16:50:00] Apartment for Rent | I saw, of course, that Rino had also brought a small gift for Pinocchia, and Pinocchia did her best to act as excited as Lina. I thought of her, but she still couldn't hide her pain and vulnerability.
[1963-07-27T16:55:00] Rentals | I saw Rino's affectionate gestures, his embraces, and the gifts, which made her hastily conceal her true feelings, restoring her to the image of a happy wife. I thought of it, but only for a brief moment.
[1963-07-27T17:00:00] Rentals | I saw her lips begin to tremble, her tears gushed forth like a fountain, and she spoke in a voice choked with sobs. I heard, "I've already packed my luggage. I don't want to stay here for another minute. I just want to be with you."
[1963-07-27T17:05:00] Renting House | I saw Rino smiling, and this intense love moved him deeply. I heard him say, "I just want to be with you."
[1963-07-27T17:05:05] Rentals | I thought that in the end, he understood that his wife wasn't just telling him how much she missed him—she was saying she really wanted to leave, that she had already made up her mind, and she expressed her resolve to go through that unbearable crying.
[1963-07-27T17:10:00] Rentals | I saw them close the door and start discussing, but their discussion was short.
[1963-07-27T17:15:00] Apartment for Rent | I saw Rino come back to us, shouting at his mother. "I heard, 'Mom, I want to know what happened.'"
