[1963-08-10T21:01:35] Apartment for Rent | I saw that although I was very scared, I felt I couldn't just sit there. I grabbed the door handle and shook it. I pounded on the wooden door, begging. I heard, "Stefano, please! This isn't true, let her go. Stefano, don't hurt her."
[1963-08-10T21:01:40] Renting House | I saw him, but he was already completely lost in his anger. I heard him shouting that he wanted to know the truth because Lina wasn't speaking. I thought of something worse: it sounded like she wasn't even in the room. For a while, I thought he was talking to himself, slapping his own face, breaking things.
[1963-08-10T21:02:00] Rentals | I saw myself running down the stairs and said to Nunzia. I heard, "I'll go get the landlord." I thought about asking the landlord if he had another key, or maybe finding the landlord's nephew, a strong man who might be able to break the door open.
[1963-08-10T21:02:05] Apartment rental downstairs | I saw, but it was all in vain. I knocked on the door for a while, but the landlord wasn't there. I thought that if she were here, she wouldn't have opened the door either.
[1963-08-10T21:02:10] Apartment rental downstairs | At that moment, Stefano's scream was so loud it seemed to break through the walls, reaching the street, the reeds, and even the sea beyond. I saw, but it seemed no one else heard his cries, because no one nearby stuck their head out, and no one noticed.
[1963-08-10T21:02:15] Renting House | I could only hear Nunzia's plea, which was quieter than Stefano's voice. She threatened that if Stefano hit her daughter, she would tell Fernando and Rino, who would really kill him.
[1963-08-10T21:03:00] Rentals | I saw myself running back, but didn't know what to do. I threw my entire body weight against the door. I heard myself say that I had called the police, that they were coming right away.
[1963-08-10T21:03:05] Renting House | I saw that Lina hadn't said a word, so I kept shouting. I heard, "Lina, are you okay? Please, Lina, tell me how you're doing."
[1963-08-10T21:03:10] Renting house | I realized then that we finally heard her voice, but she wasn't speaking to us—she was coldly addressing her husband. I heard, "Do you want to know the truth? Yes, I held hands with Nino's son and went swimming. We swam out to deep water, and we [intimate act], touching each other. Yes, I let him do it a hundred times, so I found out you're just a piece of dog shit, worthless, all you want are those disgusting things, it really makes me want to throw up. How's that? Are you happy now?"
[1963-08-10T21:03:15] Apartment for Rent | I saw that after Lina spoke, Stefano said nothing more. I stopped banging on the door, and Nunzia stopped crying. I saw silence, only silence, and outside sounds became clear—cars passing by, distant voices, even the sound of a hen flapping its wings.
[1963-08-10T21:05:00] Rentals | I saw that after a few minutes, Stefano started speaking, but his voice was low, and we could hardly hear what he was saying. I heard him say a few broken, short sentences: "Let me see how you're doing." "Be good, don't act like this." I thought I understood that he was trying to calm himself down.
[1963-08-10T21:05:05] Rentals | I thought about Lina's confession, which was almost unbearable for him. He believed she was lying on purpose, and he felt she had said it just to hurt him, an exaggerated statement like a heavy punch that would knock him down instantly.
[1963-08-10T21:05:10] Renting House | I thought about it, but Lina's words sounded too terrifying to me, just like Stefano's punches and kicks. I sensed that beneath his gentle and polite appearance, there was a kind of violence that frightened me. At the same time, I couldn't stand Lina's courage—she spoke the truth so boldly, as if it were a lie.
[1963-08-10T21:05:15] Renting House | I thought about every word she said to Stefano, which made him regain his reason, but left me in pain. He thought it was a lie, but I knew: it was the truth!
[1963-08-10T21:10:00] Rentals | I saw when Capodimonte's boss's voice became clearer. I thought that the worst moments, which both I and Nunzia had feared, had already passed. Don Achille had withdrawn from his son, Stefano had returned to normal, becoming once again the gentle, easygoing Stefano.
[1963-08-11T05:00:00] Renting House | I saw that the door wasn't open, the key wouldn't turn, and the door lock finally moved only when morning came. I saw Stefano's voice become very sad, as if it were a low, pleading request.
[1963-08-11T05:30:00] Renting House | I saw myself and Nunzia waiting outside for several hours, we kept each other company and encouraged each other, speaking in quiet voices, just like the people inside.
[1963-08-11T05:35:00] Rentals | I saw Nunzia whisper something, and I just naturally believed her, whispering back. "I heard, 'If I told Rino about this, he'd kill Stefano, he'd definitely kill him.'"
"Please, don't tell him."
[1963-08-11T05:40:00] Renting House | I thought, but at the same time I thought: After Lina got married, Rino and Fernando never touched her again, but ever since she was born, they had beaten her whenever they wanted.
[1963-08-11T05:45:00] Apartment for Rent | I saw myself sighing. I thought, and then I thought again: all men are the same, only Nino is an exception, but my resentment grew stronger and stronger. Now it was clear—Lina would take Nino for herself, even though she was already married. They would escape this disgusting reality together, but I would never be able to get free.

[1963-08-11T06:00:00] Rentals | I saw that it was just beginning to get light, and Stefano came out of the bedroom, but Lina didn't. He said. I heard, "You two, pack your belongings, we're leaving."
[1963-08-11T06:05:00] Renting House | I saw Nunzia's face full of anger, and couldn't help pointing at the things he had broken, saying that these would have to be compensated to the landlord. I heard him say, "This house's rent was paid by me. Your vacation was paid for by me, everything you have—your husband, your son—all their money came from me. So shut up and pack your things and leave." I thought of the words Nunzia had screamed before, etched into his mind, and he felt an urgent need to refute them.
[1963-08-11T06:30:00] Rentals | I saw Nunzia remain silent, and after a while, Lina came out of the room. I saw her wearing a long-sleeved yellow dress and big glasses, like those worn by movie stars.
[1963-08-11T07:00:00] Port | I saw that she didn't speak to us, didn't speak at the port, didn't speak on the motorboat, and not even when we reached our Mergellina.
[1963-08-11T09:00:00] Mergellina | I saw her go straight home with her husband, without even saying hello.
[1963-08-11T10:00:00] My home | I thought, as for me, from that moment on, I decided to live only for myself. Since returning to San Gregorio Armeno, I've been doing just that, and I've made the decision to cut ties with Lina.
[1963-08-12T09:00:00] My home | I saw that I didn't go back to Lina, nor did I go back to Nino.
[1963-08-12T20:00:00] My home | I saw myself silently enduring my mother's scolding, saying that I went to Vomero to enjoy myself, without considering that the family needed money. When I heard my mother curse me in front of him, my father would immediately join in: "You've grown up, you should be responsible now, you need to earn money for the family, we really need money." I thought that although my father kept praising my healthy skin tone and golden hair, he hadn't stopped talking about me either.
[1963-08-13T09:00:00] My home | I should have asked Lina for the money she'd promised me, since I took her to Vomero, but I'd already made up my mind not to see her again, so I didn't go to ask for the money. I thought about making money, and it was really urgent, especially after Stefano said those cruel things to Nunzia (in a way, those words were also meant for me).
[1963-08-13T10:00:00] Mergellina | I remember once I ran into Alfonso Carracci and had him tell Lina that I'd already gotten the books for the school year, so she didn't need to worry about it. I thought that for the same reason, I would never again accept her buying my school textbooks as I had before.
[1963-08-16T09:00:00] Bookstore | After the Feast of the Assumption of Mary on August fifteenth, I went again to the bookstore on Via Mezzocannone. I thought it was because I was a well-behaved and hardworking salesgirl, and on the other hand, because of my appearance, I looked much more beautiful after sunbathing by the sea. The bookstore owner first refused, but then let me go back to work there.
[1963-08-16T09:10:00] Bookstore | I saw him, but he asked me to continue working there after the school started. I had to go in the afternoon, and I had to stay for the entire textbook sales season at the school. I agreed to his request.
[1963-08-20T15:00:00] Bookstore | I saw myself starting work at the bookstore, greeting the teachers who came to sell their books, as well as students bringing in old books to sell for even less money. I knew the teacher's bag contained books given by the publisher, which could be obtained for just a few lira. I think of each day, and each day feels long.
[1963-08-25T23:00:00] My home | I thought about how for a whole week I was extremely anxious because my period didn't come, and I was afraid that Nino had made me pregnant. I was so desperate.
[1963-08-26T03:00:00] My home | I couldn't sleep all night, I didn't seek any advice or comfort from anyone, I kept everything hidden inside me. I thought that on the surface I was solemn, but inside I was panicking.
[1963-08-30T17:00:00] Bookstore | I finally saw the bloodstain one afternoon in the dirty restroom of the bookstore. I thought that was one of the few happy moments I had during that time. For me, this period seemed like a symbol, completely erasing Nino's violation of my body.
[1963-09-01 10:00:00] At the shoe repair shop door | I saw Stefano park the car in front of the shoemaker's shop, get out and open the door for me. He extended his hand to help me down.
[1963-09-01 10:00:10] Outside the shoe repair shop | I saw him completely ignoring Lina; she got down from behind on her own.
[1963-09-01 10:00:20] Outside the shoe repair shop | I saw him standing in front of the window with me, Rino and Fernando inside the shop, casting us curious glances. I thought I saw a flicker of irritation in their expressions.
[1963-09-01 10:00:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Lina catch up with us. Stefano opened the shop door, let me go in first, then he went in himself, without letting Lina go in first.
[1963-09-01 10:00:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw how he was very polite to Fernando and his son, asking if he could see the shoes. Rino hurriedly ran to get them.
[1963-09-01 10:00:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him look at it carefully and praised it. I heard, "These shoes are light and durable, the design is very nice, what do you think, Rino."
[1963-09-01 10:01:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "It's very beautiful." I thought to myself, I'm very embarrassed to say.
[1963-09-01 10:01:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard him say to Fernando, "Your daughter said that the three of you took a long time to make it, and you want to continue making other styles, and also women's ones."
[1963-09-01 10:01:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino looking at his sister in surprise. I heard, "Yes."
[1963-09-01 10:01:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Fernando saying uneasily as well. I heard, "Yes, but not right away."
[1963-09-01 10:01:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Do you have any blueprints that I can take a look at first?"
[1963-09-01 10:01:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino say something to his sister, slightly changing his tone because he was afraid of being refused. I heard, "You go get the blueprint."
[1963-09-01 10:02:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Lina go without resistance to the back of the shop, and when she returned, she handed some blueprints to her brother. I thought that would surprise him.
[1963-09-01 10:02:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino hand the blueprint over to Stefano. I knew those were all the design sketches Lina had drawn two years ago.
[1963-09-01 10:02:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano showing me a pair of women's shoes with high heels. He asked. I heard, "Would you buy shoes in this style?"
[1963-09-01 10:02:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Yes."
[1963-09-01 10:02:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him look at the blueprint again. He was sitting on a stool, and had taken off his shoe from his right foot. I heard, "What a big pair of shoes!"
[1963-09-01 10:02:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino tell a lie. I heard, "Forty-three, but it's almost like a forty-four."
[1963-09-01 10:03:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Lina kneeling in front of Stefano, using a shoe horn to help him put on his new shoes. I thought of this, and it once again surprised us.
[1963-09-01 10:03:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw and then she took off his other shoe and put the other one on his foot as well.
[1963-09-01 10:03:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that up until then, Stefano had been acting very smoothly and confidently. I thought about it, but I saw that at that moment he was clearly uneasy.
[1963-09-01 10:03:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him waiting for Lina to stand up, then he sat again for a few more seconds to catch his breath, and finally he stood up and took a few steps.
[1963-09-01 10:03:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard him say, "These shoes are tight."
[1963-09-01 10:03:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino's face turn pale instantly. I thought I saw his disappointment.
[1963-09-01 10:04:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "We can make it wider with a last." Fernando inserted. I thought I detected uncertainty in his tone.
[1963-09-01 10:04:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano looking at me and asked. I heard, "How do I look in it?"
[1963-09-01 10:04:20] Shoe Repair Shop | "I heard 'Very good.' I said."
[1963-09-01 10:04:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Then I'll buy it."
[1963-09-01 10:04:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Fernando expressionless, while Rino's face turned from gloomy to bright.
[1963-09-01 10:04:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "You see, Stefano, these are special 'Lina' shoes, very expensive."
[1963-09-01 10:05:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano smiling, speaking in a very gentle tone. I heard, "If it wasn't the special 'Lina' shoes, would you have bought them? When will you get them done?"
[1963-09-01 10:05:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino looking at his father. I saw a face glowing with excitement.
[1963-09-01 10:05:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard Fernando say, "We put the shoes on the machine, at least three days." I thought, but it was obvious that he could have said ten days, twenty days, even a month--he needed time to adjust to this unexpected new situation.
[1963-09-01 10:05:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "That's great, you guys give me a friend's price, I'll come pick up the shoes in three days."
[1963-09-01 10:05:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him fold up the design drawings and put them in his pocket. We all watched him nervously.
[1963-09-01 10:05:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him shake hands with Fernando and Rino at last, then head toward the door.
[1963-09-01 10:06:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "blueprints." Lina said coldly.
[1963-09-01 10:06:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano ask in a very polite manner, but before Lina could answer, he opened the door and let me go out first, then followed me out himself. I heard, "Can I return it to you in three days?"
locations: At the shoe repair shop door

text:
[1963-09-01 10:06:30] In the car | I saw that I was already sitting in the car, sitting next to him.
[1963-09-01 10:06:40] Inside the car | I saw that at this point Lina caught up with me, and she said angrily. I heard, "Do you think my father is a fool, my brother is a fool?"
[1963-09-01 10:06:50] Car interior | I heard, "What do you want to say?"
[1963-09-01 10:07:00] In the car | I heard, "If you think you can fool my family and me, you're wrong."
[1963-09-01 10:07:10] Car interior | "I'm angry! I'm not Marcello."
[1963-09-01 10:07:20] In the car | I heard, "Then who are you?"
[1963-09-01 10:07:30] In the car | I heard him say, "A businessman. I've never seen the shoes you designed, not the ones I'm seeing now, but all of them."
[1963-09-01 10:07:40] Car interior | "I heard 'that is to say?'"
[1963-09-01 10:07:50] In the car | I heard, "That is to say, I need to think. See you in three days."
[1963-09-01 10:08:00] Car interior | I saw Lina staring at him, as if trying to read his thoughts, and she didn't leave the car.
[1963-09-01 10:08:10] Car interior | I heard her say the one thing I never had the courage to say: "You see, Marcello has tried every way to buy me, but no one can buy me."
[1963-09-01 10:08:20] Car interior | I saw Stefano looking into her eyes. I thought it was a very long second.
[1963-09-01 10:08:30] Car interior | I heard, "If I can't make a hundred lire, I won't spend a single lire."
[1963-09-01 10:09:00] In the car | I saw him start the engine, and we set off. I thought then that I was now certain: this roundabout way was an agreement reached after many meetings and conversations.
[1963-09-01 10:09:10] Car interior | I heard myself say in a low voice in Italian: "Stefano, please, could you stop at the corner? If my mother sees me sitting in your car, she'll definitely tear my face off."
[1963-09-01T09:00:00] Main Street of Maizhuokangna | I saw him, but he didn't appear on Via Mazzini or at Mergellina. I thought about early September, and I figured Nino should have already returned from Vomero. I felt afraid, but I also hoped he would show up and say hello.
[1963-09-05T10:00:00] Mergellina | I only caught a vague glimpse of Lina a couple of times. Once on a Sunday, she was sitting next to her husband as Stefano drove by at high speed. I thought about how just a few seconds were enough to make me angry. What had happened? How had she solved those problems?
[1963-09-05T10:05:00] Mergellina | I thought about how she still had everything she once had: a car, Stefano, a house with a bathroom, phone, and TV, nice clothes, and a wealthy life. And who knew what schemes were brewing in her mind besides that.
[1963-09-05T10:10:00] Mergellina | I know what kind of person she is; even if Nino abandons her, she will never abandon Nino. But I immediately suppressed this thought, because I wanted to keep my promise to myself: I would live my own life, keep them out of it, and no longer suffer over it.
[1963-09-05T16:00:00] New Capodimonte | I saw it on an afternoon in early September, just as she was about to make up her mind to leave, when Nino appeared at the door. I saw Nino appear at the entrance of Capodimonte, which was crowded with people, his beard unshaven and completely drunk.
[1963-09-05T16:01:00] New Capodimonte | I saw Pinocchia about to chase away this hobo-like young man, but Lina stopped her, pulling Nino away with a firm and cold voice. I heard her say, "I'll go." to Pinocchia.
[1963-09-05T16:02:00] New Capodimonte | I knew that Pinocchia Peluso certainly didn't recognize it as Nino's son, because in her eyes, the Nino of that time was a complete stranger with [mental health issues], entirely different from the boy who had gone to elementary school with them. I thought Lina would act immediately, as always, a woman who could solve any problem.
[1963-09-05T16:03:00] New Capodimonte | I saw the walls covered with goods disappear, the streets became unfamiliar, and the new buildings with pale exteriors also vanished. I thought, but in reality, at that time she didn't even know where she was, especially she couldn't sense the danger she was facing.
[1963-09-05T16:04:00] On the street | I thought of Nino! Nino! Nino! All she felt was joy and desire.
[1963-09-05T16:05:00] Street | I saw him appear in front of her, finally appearing before her again. Every feature on his body clearly showed that he had suffered great pain, and the pain was still continuing. I thought about how he was searching for Lina, how he longed for her too.
[1963-09-05T16:06:00] Street | I saw her still on the street, and he wanted to grab her desperately, kiss her intimately.
[1963-09-05T16:10:00] Lina's house | I saw Lina pull him into her house. I thought that she considered it the safest place; passersby? She could no longer see them; neighbors? She completely ignored them.
[1963-09-05T16:15:00] Lina's house | I saw her just shut the door, and then they started having sex without any hesitation. I thought she just wanted to get Nino right away, to merge with him instantly.
[1963-09-05T16:30:00] Lina's house | I saw the Mergellina, the neighbors, Capodimonte, the street, the sound of the railway, and Stefano and Pinocchia probably waiting anxiously for her; all these began to slowly return to her mind. I thought that even when everything had calmed down, that desire remained very strong.
[1963-09-05T16:31:00] Lina's house | I thought she clearly understood that these matters, like items that needed to be sorted out as soon as possible, would get them into trouble. If they weren't careful, these chaotic issues would collapse all at once.
[1963-09-05T16:35:00] Lina's house | I saw Nino scold her, saying that she hadn't even said goodbye when she left, then he tightly embraced her and wanted her.
[1963-09-05T16:36:00] Lina's house | I saw him wanting to take her away immediately, but he didn't know where to go; she said she was willing, she was willing. I thought both of them were crazy.
[1963-09-05T16:40:00] Lina's house | I saw the chandelier above them like a threat. I thought that unlike Nino, Lina now felt time slipping away, each second rushing by, and the risk of being discovered was increasing.
[1963-09-05T16:41:00] Lina's house | I saw her and Nino lying on the floor, staring up at the chandelier hanging from the ceiling. I thought back to the beginning, when all she wanted was to have Nino right away, no matter what. She started calculating how she could keep holding on to him tightly, without worrying about the chandelier falling from the ceiling or the floor cracking. She leaned one way, Nino the other, separating them forever.
[1963-09-05T16:45:00] Lina's house | I heard, "Go away." "No." "Are you crazy?" "Yes." "Please, go."
[1963-09-05T17:00:00] Lina's house | I saw her convince him to leave. She waited for Pinocchia to scold her, for the neighbors to gossip, for Stefano to come from another Capodimonte and hit her. I thought about it, but nothing happened, and she sighed with relief.
[1963-09-06T10:00:00] Mergellina | I saw later that she gave Pinocchia a raise, became even more attentive to her husband, and came up with every excuse to meet Nino secretly.
[1963-09-10 10:00:00] Mergellina | I know that Lina's life changed in September, and the process wasn't simple, but it did undergo a fundamental transformation.
[1963-09-10 10:00:10] Mergellina | I thought, as for me, I came back from Ischia and fell in love with Nino, my body had been defiled by his father's lips and hands.
[1963-09-10 10:00:20] Mergellina | I thought the excitement and fear intertwined deep within me should have made me weep day and night, but within just a few hours, my emotions had already been adjusted.
[1963-09-10 10:00:30] Mergellina | I thought about how I had set aside Nino's voice, his father's beard, and Vomero was beginning to fade, disappearing into a secret corner of my mind.
[1963-09-10 10:00:40] Mergellina | I thought about how my mind was full of things that had happened to Lina.

[1963-09-10T09:00:00] Bookstore | I saw that for this purpose, I began a form of self-mental training, reacting to her presence as little as possible. I thought about how I had learned to control and mute my own emotions.
[1963-09-10T10:00:00] Bookstore | I would calmly push away the bookstore owner's hand if he reached for me; if the customers who came to sell books were rude, I would remain composed and do what needed to be done; even in front of my mother, I could speak softly and gently.
[1963-09-10T11:00:00] Bookstore | I thought to myself every day: This is my fate, I must submit to destiny, accept reality. I was born in this city, speak this dialect, have no money, give what I can give, gain what I can gain, endure what I must endure.
[1963-09-12 10:00:00] Capodimonte | Three days after we went for a drive in our shiny convertible, Lina often went to Stefano's Capodimonte, claiming she needed to do some shopping, and each time she asked me to go with her.
[1963-09-12 10:00:10] Capodimonte | I thought about how I always felt uneasy, worried that Marcello might get angry, but at the same time I was happy with my role, because I could listen to her thoughts wholeheartedly and offer her advice.
[1963-09-12 10:00:20] Capodimonte | I realized I was an accomplice in this play, the one Stefano apparently focused on.
[1963-09-12 10:00:30] Capodimonte | I thought we were all just girls, believing we had no guile, acting purely from the facts—Marcello, Stefano, the shoes—we approached everything with our usual passion, feeling we could control everything.
[1963-09-12 10:00:40] Capodimonte | I said, "I told him that way." She assumed, expecting me to suggest a small change. I said, "No, you should tell him that way."
[1963-09-12 10:00:50] Capodimonte | I saw them, and then she and Stefano began to talk closely in a corner behind the counter.
[1963-09-12 10:01:00] Capodimonte | At this point, Alfonso Carracci would chat with me for a while, while Pinocchia impatiently attended to the customers.
[1963-09-12 10:01:10] Capodimonte | I saw Maria at the checkout counter, nervously watching her eldest son, who had become careless about his work, causing the neighbors to gossip.
[1963-09-13 10:00:00] Street | I thought, of course, we both acted on a whim.
[1963-09-13 10:00:10] Street | I thought about those days of back and forth, when I was always trying to figure out what Lina was thinking, so I could go along with her and help her achieve her goals.
[1963-09-13 10:00:20] Street | I thought at first that she just wanted to make some money for her father and brother, selling the only pair of shoes made by the "Lina" shop at a high price to Stefano.
[1963-09-13 10:00:30] Street | I thought about it, but I quickly realized her goal was to use this young Capodimonte boss to get rid of Marcello.
[1963-09-13 10:00:40] Street | I got a definite answer on this one time when I asked her. I heard, "Which of the two do you prefer?"
[1963-09-13 10:00:50] Street | I saw her shrug. I heard, "I've never liked Marcello, he makes me sick."
[1963-09-13 10:01:00] Street | I heard, "You were engaged to Stefano just to kick Marcello out of your house?"
[1963-09-13 10:01:10] Street | I saw her think for a moment and then nod.
[1963-09-13 10:02:00] Street | I thought that from that moment on, our sense of ultimate goal was: through various means, to eliminate Marcello from her life.
[1963-09-13 10:02:10] Street | I thought about other things by chance, we were only directing the course of events, sometimes truly manipulating them — at least that's how we saw it. But in reality, it was always Stefano who took action.
[1963-09-14 10:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | Three days later, I saw Stefano arrive at the shop very punctually to buy those shoes, even though they were too tight for him.
[1963-09-14 10:00:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Lina and her father nervously asking for twenty-five thousand lira, but they were already prepared to lower the price to ten thousand lira.
[1963-09-14 10:00:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him not blink an eye and added another two million lira to buy Lina's blueprints.
[1963-09-14 10:00:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him say he really liked those drawings and wanted to put them in a frame.
[1963-09-14 10:00:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "Should we put it in a frame?" Rino asked.
[1963-09-14 10:00:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "Yes."
[1963-09-14 10:01:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Like a painter's work?"
[1963-09-14 10:01:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Yes."
[1963-09-14 10:01:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Did you tell my sister that you also want to buy her drawings?"
[1963-09-14 10:01:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "He said."
[1963-09-15T10:00:00] Mergellina | I knew that at the beginning, the biggest problem wasn't the rumors, but the boy she deeply loved. I thought of him grabbing her without restraint, kissing her, biting her, entering her, as if he longed to do this for a lifetime, his lips pressing against her, entering her body.
[1963-09-15T10:05:00] Mergellina | When I saw that he couldn't stand being apart, he turned to alcohol to numb himself. He stopped studying and smoked constantly. I felt scared thinking about him, scared that she would disappear again; it seemed as though, for him, nothing else in the world existed besides the two of them. If he spoke, it was always with jealousy, saying he couldn't stand her continuing to live with her husband.
[1963-09-15T10:10:00] Mergellina | "I've given up everything," he muttered, exhausted. "What about you? Don't you want to give up anything?" "What are you going to do?" she asked.
[1963-09-15T10:15:00] Mergellina | I saw Nino say nothing, as if he didn't understand what she was asking, or perhaps he was about to get angry, as if the question had made him upset. I heard him say, desperately, "You don't want me anymore!"
[1963-09-15T10:20:00] Mergellina | I saw it, but Lina wanted him, she wanted him, and after getting him, she still wanted more. I thought of her, but she wanted him to keep studying, to still ignite her thoughts as he had when in Vomero.
[1963-09-16 10:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that Stefano didn't stop there. In the following days, he appeared again at the cobbler's shop.
[1963-09-16 10:00:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him tell the father and son that he had also rented the store next to their shop.
[1963-09-16 10:00:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard him say, "That's it for now. If one day you need to expand your shop, just let me know."
[1963-09-16 12:00:00] Lina's house | I saw that in Lina's house, they discussed quietly for a long time, analyzing the meaning of "expand."
[1963-09-16 12:10:00] Lina's house | I saw it to the end, and when Lina saw that they had no clue, she said. I heard, "He's suggesting that you turn the shoe repair shop into a workshop producing 'Lina' brand shoes."
[1963-09-16 12:10:10] Lina's house | I saw Rino ask very carefully. I heard, "Where does the money come from?"
[1963-09-16 12:10:20] Lina's house | "I heard 'He took the money.'"
[1963-09-16 12:10:30] Lina's House | "I heard you say 'he told you'?" Fernando asked suspiciously, unable to believe it. Nunzia immediately asked the same thing.
[1963-09-16 12:10:40] Lina's House | I saw "He was talking to both of you," Lina said, pointing at my father and brother.
[1963-09-16 12:10:50] Lina's house | I heard, "Does he know that handmade shoes are expensive?"
[1963-09-16 12:11:00] Lina's house | I heard, "You've sold it to him at a high price, and he already knows."
[1963-09-16 12:11:10] Lina's House | I heard, "What if it doesn't sell?"
[1963-09-16 12:11:20] Lina's house | I heard, "You wasted your effort, and he lost money."
[1963-09-16 12:11:30] Lina's House | I heard, "That's it?"

[1963-09-16 12:11:40] Lina's house | I heard, "That's it."
[1963-09-16 20:30:00] Lina's house | I could see that everyone in the family was very excited those days. I knew Marcello had become secondary—when he came for dinner at 8:30, the meal wasn't even ready yet.
[1963-09-16 20:45:00] Lina's house | I often saw him sitting in front of the TV with Melina and Pinocchia, while Lina's whole family talked in another room.
[1963-09-18 10:00:00] Street | I saw it all naturally; the most fervent one was Rino, who had regained his energy, his face glowing with vitality, and he was completely happy, just like when he first became a close friend of the Solara brothers.
[1963-09-18 10:00:10] Street | I saw it like that, and he began to become friends with Stefano, Alfonso Carracci, Pinocchia, and even Mrs. Maria.
[1963-09-20 10:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano go to the shoe shop again, and Fernando finally came clean. After a brief discussion, they reached an oral agreement in the end.
[1963-09-20 10:00:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I knew the basic principle was: Stefano would cover all the expenses, Lina and her son would first make the shoes that Lina and Rino had already made, then other styles, and the profits would be split equally.
[1963-09-20 10:00:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him take out the pieces of paper from his pocket and show them to them one by one.
[1963-09-20 10:00:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard him say, "You make this style, this one, and this one," but he added, "I hope you won't take two years to make a pair of shoes like last time."
[1963-09-20 10:00:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Fernando awkwardly explaining. I heard, "My daughter is a girl, and Rino hasn't fully mastered the craft yet."
[1963-09-20 10:00:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano politely shake his head.
[1963-09-20 10:01:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "This time, don't let Lina get involved, you should find workers."
[1963-09-20 10:01:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard "Who pays the workers?" Fernando asked. I heard, "Let me pay. You pick two or three workers; you can decide who to choose yourself."
[1963-09-20 10:01:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Fernando's face turn red as soon as he mentioned hiring people, and he became so excited that he was almost incoherent.
[1963-09-20 10:01:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino nearby, looking at my father with some contempt.
[1963-09-20 10:01:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Fernando say that he had learned the craft from his father, who was really a good man.
[1963-09-20 10:01:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him say that the machines at the Cassoria factory were really hard to work with back then.
[1963-09-20 10:02:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him say that the biggest mistake of his life was marrying Nunzia, who spent money recklessly and was lazy and gluttonous.
[1963-09-20 10:02:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I thought that if he had married Ines, the woman he loved when he was young—a very capable woman—then he might now have his own business, better than the Campanile shoe factory, perhaps with a whole line of products displayed overseas.
[1963-09-20 10:02:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him say that he had already conceived of a pair of very beautiful shoes, perfect in every way.
[1963-09-20 10:02:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I thought that if Stefano hadn't been so fascinated by Lina's messy sketches, they could have already started making the shoes he designed, and who knows how many pairs they might have sold.
[1963-09-20 10:02:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano listening patiently, and he reiterated that he just wanted to see the designs Lina had created.
[1963-09-20 10:03:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino take his sister's blueprint, look at it carefully, and ask Stefano with a slight sneer. I heard, "You're going to put these blueprints in frames and hang them where?"
[1963-09-20 10:03:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Hang it here."
[1963-09-20 10:03:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that Rino didn't say anything else. I saw him looking at his father, and suddenly his face grew dark again.
[1963-09-20 10:03:30] Shoe Repair Shop | "I've heard, 'Has my sister agreed?'" he asked.
[1963-09-20 10:03:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano smile slightly.
[1963-09-20 10:03:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "If your sister doesn't agree, who would dare to do that?"
[1963-09-20 10:04:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him stand up, shake hands tightly with Fernando, then head toward the door.
[1963-09-20 10:04:10] At the shoe repair shop door | I saw Rino accompanying Stefano out, and suddenly he felt a surge of worry as the Capodimonte boss was heading toward his red sports car.
[1963-09-20 10:04:20] Outside the shoe repair shop | I saw Rino shouting something at the door. I heard, "The shoes made, the brand is still 'Lina'!"
[1963-09-20 10:04:30] At the shoe repair shop door | I saw Stefano didn't look back, and made a gesture saying. I heard someone say, "The shoes designed by the girl from Lina's family must be 'Lina' brand."
[1963-09-20 20:30:00] Lina's house | I said that night, before going out with Pasquale and Antonio. I heard, "Marcello, have you seen the car Stefano bought?"
[1963-09-20 20:30:10] Lina's house | I saw that the TV was on, and Marcello was still lost in his sorrow, not responding.
[1963-09-20 20:30:20] Lina's house | I saw Rino take out a comb from his pocket, comb his hair, and then put the comb down.
[1963-09-20 20:30:30] Lina's house | I saw him saying happily. I heard, "You know, he spent forty-five thousand lira to buy the shoes we made."
[1963-09-20 20:30:40] Lina's house | I saw Marcello answer, and suddenly Melina laughed. I heard, "That means he has money to spend." I wondered whether it was because of the TV program or because of the thing Marcello had said.
[1963-09-20T10:00:00] Mergellina | I saw the gifted girl from elementary school, the little girl who had fascinated Oliviero, the one who had written The Blue Fairy, once again showing new energy. I knew it was Nino, who found the little girl in a dark corner and pulled her out.
[1963-09-20T10:05:00] Mergellina | I thought of that girl, who now wished he would regain his strength and return to who he had been before—a young scholar who had helped her grow, who had made her shed the identity of Mrs. Carraci.
[1963-09-25 20:00:00] Lina's house | Since then, every night, Rino always found various ways to provoke Marcello, and the atmosphere at home grew increasingly tense.
[1963-09-25 20:00:10] Lina's house | Every time Solara came, Nunzia always greeted him warmly, while Lina would disappear, saying she was tired and then went to sleep.
[1963-09-28 20:30:00] Lina's house | I saw one night that Marcello was very depressed and said to Nunzia. "I heard, 'As soon as I arrived, your daughter went to sleep. So what am I here for?'"
[1963-09-28 20:30:10] Lina's house | I saw that he hoped Nunzia would comfort him with a few words, say something encouraging to give him the courage to win Lina's love, but Nunzia didn't know how to answer him.
[1963-09-28 20:30:20] Lina's house | I saw him ask in a low voice. I heard, "Is she starting to like someone else?"
[1963-09-28 20:30:30] Lina's house | I heard "No."
[1963-09-28 20:30:40] Lina's House | I heard, "I know she often buys things from Stefano's store."
[1963-09-28 20:30:50] Lina's House | "I heard, 'My child, then where should she buy food?'"
[1963-09-28 20:31:00] Lina's house | I saw Marcello stop speaking and lower his eyes.
[1963-09-28 20:31:10] Lina's house | I heard, "Someone saw her get into the boss's car, Capodimonte."
[1963-09-28 20:31:20] Lina's House | I heard, "Elena is also in the car, and Stefano is chasing the concierge's daughter."
[1963-09-28 20:31:30] Lina's house | I heard, "I think Elena isn't a good companion for your daughter. Tell Lina not to see her anymore."
locations: At the shoe repair shop door

text:
[1963-10-01 16:00:00] Street | I wondered if I wasn't a good companion? Shouldn't Lina stop meeting me? When my friend told me about Marcello's request, I completely took Stefano's side.
[1963-10-01 16:05:00] Street | I found myself starting to speak well of him, mentioning specific things, saying he was very determined and very rich. I heard myself saying to her at the end, and as I spoke those words, I realized that the wealth we had dreamed of as children was changing again.
[1963-10-01 16:10:00] Street | I knew that as children, we used to imagine: publishing a book like Little Women would bring us wealth and reputation, along with a safe full of gold coins, and a crowd of servants in uniforms waiting to serve us in our castle. I thought those imaginations had completely faded away.
[1963-10-01 16:10:10] Street | I thought that maybe, for us now, money was like cement—it could reinforce my life, prevent our lives and those of our dearest from collapsing together, and this feeling was growing stronger.
[1963-10-01 16:10:20] Street | I thought that the most fundamental characteristic of wealth had begun to take shape gradually, becoming part of daily life, becoming business and negotiations.
[1963-10-01 16:10:30] Street | I thought about the wealth of adolescence, the naive and fantastical images, those shoes that no one had ever seen, which later concretely manifested as Rino's dissatisfaction and irritability, his desire to spend money like a wealthy man.
[1963-10-01 16:10:40] Street | I thought of wealth as the television, Marcello's noodles, and the ring, things he wanted to use to buy a feeling.
[1963-10-01 16:10:50] Street | I thought of how, in the end, wealth was embodied in that young, polite Stefano, who made a living selling sausages and had a red convertible.
[1963-10-01 16:11:00] Street | I thought about how he didn't even blink when he spent forty-five thousand lira. He put the blueprints in frames, and besides selling cheese, he also wanted to get into the shoe business.
[1963-10-01 16:11:10] Street | I thought about how he invested in leather, hired people, as if he were absolutely certain he could open up a new era of peace and prosperity.
[1963-10-01 16:11:20] Street | I thought that this was the manifestation of wealth in daily life, devoid of any brilliance or glory.
[1963-10-01 16:12:00] Street | I saw and heard Lina repeating the words, she laughed, and finally added. I heard, "He's very rich, and he's also cute, kind-hearted."
[1963-10-01 16:12:10] Street | I said right away that I felt the same, that was a quality Marcello didn't have, and that was another reason to stand with Stefano. I thought, but the two adjectives Lina used confused me. I felt it meant that the radiant imaginations of our childhood had come to an end: castles, safes.
[1963-10-01 16:12:20] Street | I realized I had understood, and these fantasies would no longer be connected to Lina or my life; we would never again lie together writing a story like "Little Women."
[1963-10-01 16:12:30] Street | I thought of wealth, which had taken the form of Stefano, a young man in an oily shirt.
[1963-10-01 16:12:40] Street | I thought of wealth, which was taking on a shape, a smell, and a sound, revealing itself as friendly and charming—a familiar man, the eldest son of Don Achille.
[1963-10-01 16:12:50] Street | I thought about it and felt very excited.
[1963-10-01 16:13:00] Street | "I heard, 'No matter what, he once wanted to pierce your tongue.' I said."
[1963-10-01 16:13:10] Street | I saw her respond with emotion, her voice very sweet, a tone I had never heard before. I heard, "At that time, he was still a child."
[1963-10-01 16:13:20] Street | I realized then that things had gone beyond what she had told me.
[1963-10-01T08:30:00] School | I didn't realize I had entered my senior year until I saw the school starting on October 1st and walked into the classroom. I thought about how I had already turned eighteen, and although my academic journey had been unusually long, it was almost over, which was better.
[1963-10-01T10:00:00] Mergellina | I saw that, bit by bit, she succeeded; whatever the reason, he had started studying again. I thought about how I didn't know how things had changed, but Nino must have realized it. In order not to lose Lina, he couldn't just be a crazy lover. Maybe he simply realized that passion had emptied his mind.
[1963-10-01T10:05:00] Mergellina | I know Lina is satisfied with this: he is slowly regaining his normal self, becoming the boy she met at Vomero again, which is also important for Nino. I thought about how she not only once again had Nino, but also his words, his thoughts.
[1963-10-01T10:10:00] Mergellina | I saw Nino buying a lot of books to read. He read Adam Smith, Joyce, but found them all rather dull. He wanted Lina to read them with him, and when they met, he wanted to talk about those books, but he never managed to do it. I know, but they don't meet often.
[1963-10-05 10:00:00] Street | I thought that in the days to come, everything would become even clearer. I heard Lina speak of Stefano, and her tone seemed to have beautified him.
[1963-10-05 10:00:10] Street | I thought about how I had been adapting to the alliance they were forming, avoiding being left out.
[1963-10-05 10:00:20] Street | I thought about how we had spent several hours plotting together—just the two of us, or maybe the three of us—so that people, feelings, and events would go according to our wishes.
[1963-10-05T15:00:00] Mergellina | I saw myself talking a lot with Alfonso Carracci about what we could do after graduation, and he, like me, wasn't really sure about the options after college. I thought we would attend some job interviews, so he just said it off the top of his head, but in reality, he wasn't even sure what a job interview was.
[1963-10-05T15:05:00] Mergellina | I heard us say "apply" and get a job. I thought, but for us, the concept of applying for a job was vague: were we supposed to take a written test? Would there be an interview? Would that really get us a position? A salary?
[1963-10-05T15:10:00] Mergellina | I saw Alfonso Carracci and he told me he wanted to get married, no matter what position he obtained; once he had a job, he would marry immediately. I heard, "With Pinocchio."  
"Of course!"
[1963-10-05T15:15:00] Mergellina | I remember asking about Nino a few times, but he didn't seem to like Nino, and they didn't even exchange greetings. I heard him say that Nino was ugly, his whole body loose and crooked. I thought about how he never understood what I liked about Nino.
[1963-10-05T15:20:00] Mergellina | I thought Pinocchio was very beautiful, and he quickly added, fearing I might be upset. I heard, "You're very beautiful too."
[1963-10-05T15:25:00] Mergellina | I know he's very fond of looking good and likes to dress well. He pays a lot of attention to his appearance, always shaving his beard neatly. He buys clothes and goes to the gym almost every day.
[1963-10-05T15:30:00] Mergellina | I saw him and he told me he was happy working in the store on Martiri Square, which wasn't like Capodimonte. I heard him say, "In the shoe store, you can dress elegantly, you must dress elegantly. You can speak Italian, everyone who goes there is polite and has been to school."
[1963-10-05T15:35:00] Mergellina | I saw that there, when you kneel half-kneeling before the male and female guests, helping them put on their shoes, you can be very graceful, like a knight in love at court, but now he can't stay in the shop anymore. I heard "Why?"  
"Ah."
[1963-10-05T15:40:00] Mergellina | I saw that at first he didn't explain carefully, and I didn't pry either. Later, he told me. I know that Pinocchio has been staying mostly at home these days because she doesn't want to exert herself; her belly has gotten bigger.
[1963-10-05T15:45:00] Mergellina | I knew, obviously, that after the child was born, she had even less time to work. In theory, this should have cleared his path, since the Solara brothers were satisfied with him; perhaps he could have started working there right after high school. I thought that there was no way it could happen now, and suddenly Lina appeared.
[1963-10-05T15:50:00] Mergellina | I heard, "What does that have to do with her?" I thought of just hearing her name, and my stomach would twist painfully.
[1963-10-05T15:55:00] Mergellina | I know from Alfonso Carracci that after Lina came back from her vacation by the sea, she went completely crazy. She still couldn't [have a child], and swimming in the sea hadn't helped.
[1963-10-05T16:00:00] Mergellina | I saw Alfonso Carracci list a series of her [mental health issues]. I know once, she broke all the flowerpots on the balcony. She said she was going to Capodimonte, but she left Pinocchia alone there. She herself wandered around the streets, and in the evening, Stefano woke up and found her not in bed—she was moving around the room, reading and writing.
[1963-10-05T16:05:00] Mergellina | I know that later she suddenly calmed down, or rather, she used all her abilities to destroy Stefano's life. Her only goal was to get Stefano to hire Giyao La to work at the new Capodimonte, so she could take care of the store in Piazza Martiri.
[1963-10-05T16:10:00] Mergellina | I said, I was very surprised by what I saw. I heard, "Michele has always wanted her to work there, but she didn't want to."
[1963-10-05T16:15:00] Mergellina | I heard, "That's how it was, but she changed her mind. Now she's determined to go there no matter what. The only obstacle is Stefano, but you know, my brother always does whatever she says."
[1963-10-05T16:20:00] Mergellina | I saw that I didn't ask any other questions. I thought to myself that I didn't want to get involved with Lina's affairs again, and I wondered in confusion: What was she thinking? Why had she suddenly decided to work in the city center?

[1963-10-10 09:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw a worker come into the shop next to the shoe repair stand, and he tore down the wall between the two shops.
[1963-10-10 10:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that the whole workshop had been rearranged, with three country apprentices from Melito.
[1963-10-10 10:10:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw they hardly spoke, huddled in a corner continuing to replace the soles of customers' shoes.
[1963-10-10 10:10:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw other spaces being used by Fernando to place small worktables, shelves, tools, and wooden molds of various sizes.
[1963-10-10 10:10:20] Shoe Repair Shop | What astonished me was that this incredibly thin man, who had always been dissatisfied with reality, suddenly became full of energy and started planning to start a business.
[1963-10-10T11:00:00] Capodimonte | I saw Pinocchia frowning as she looked at Lina. I know Pinocchio is getting more and more confused now. She doesn't understand what's so urgent about Lina's business. She always comes up with one excuse or another and disappears for several hours.
[1963-10-10T11:05:00] Capodimonte | Even when Capodimonte was at its busiest, Lina always let her handle the customers alone, as if she couldn't see or hear anything, completely immersed in her book, fully focused on writing in her notebook.
[1963-10-10T11:10:00] Capodimonte | I saw that only when you called her name did her gaze lift from the book, her fingertip brushing her lips. I heard, "Lina! Please, help me!" She said, "Okay!"
[1963-10-15 10:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | On the very day their new job was about to start, Stefano showed up.
[1963-10-15 10:00:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him take a package wrapped in paper. Everyone, including Fernando, stood up as if someone was coming to inspect us.
[1963-10-15 10:00:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano open the package, which contained several small paintings of the same size, framed in brown.
[1963-10-15 10:00:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that it was a page from Lina's notebook, now framed under glass, like a precious artifact.
[1963-10-15 10:01:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw him ask Fernando to hang the design drawings on the wall, and Fernando muttered something.
[1963-10-15 10:01:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano having Rino and a few apprentices nail the nails into the wall.
[1963-10-15 10:02:00] Shoe Repair Shop | After I saw those blueprints hanging on the wall, Stefano gave the three apprentices some money to go get coffee.
[1963-10-15 10:03:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that only Stefano and the cobbler father and son were left in the shop. He whispered that he wanted to marry Lina.
[1963-10-15 10:03:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw the shop fall into an unbearable silence.
[1963-10-15 10:03:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Rino smile slightly, as if he had already known the outcome, Fernando said in a very faint voice. I heard, "Stefano, Lina is Marcello's fiancée."
[1963-10-15 10:03:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "But your daughter doesn't know about this."
[1963-10-15 10:03:40] Shoe Repair Shop | "I heard 'Dad, what did you say?' Rino inserted himself at this moment, saying it very happily. I heard, "You have to tell the truth. You and Mom let that bastard come to the house every day. Lina never accepted him. Lina just didn't like him at all."
[1963-10-15 10:03:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Fernando glare fiercely at his son. Stefano looked around and said very politely. I heard, "Now our work has begun, don't spoil the good mood. All I ask of you, Don Fernando, is that you let your daughter decide for herself."
[1963-10-15 10:04:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "If she chooses Marcello, I'll step back. I love her very much. If she can be happy with someone else, I'll withdraw, and we'll just remain as we were before."
[1963-10-15 10:04:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "If she chose me and accepted me, I wouldn't be polite—I'd make her marry me."
[1963-10-15 10:04:20] Shoe Repair Shop | "I'm asking you, are you threatening me?" Fernando said. I thought I detected a gentle, somewhat helpless tone in his voice.
[1963-10-15 10:04:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "It's not a threat, I'm just begging you, do a good deed for your daughter."
[1963-10-15 10:04:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "I know how to treat her well."
[1963-10-15 10:04:50] Shoe Repair Shop | I heard, "Yes, but she knows better than you do."
[1963-10-15 10:05:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw that, at that moment, Stefano stood up and opened the door to call me. I heard "Elena!"
[1963-10-15 10:05:10] Outside the shoe repair shop | I saw myself and Lina waiting outside together. We went in, feeling like the central figures in this whole thing. I thought about how I liked this feeling, that we had finally seen things come to a clear conclusion.
[1963-10-15 10:05:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I thought about how I was extremely excited and nervous at that time.
[1963-10-15 10:05:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Stefano say to Lina. I heard, "In front of your father, I want to tell you: I love you more than my own life. Will you marry me?"
[1963-10-15 10:05:40] Shoe Repair Shop | I saw Lina answer very seriously. I heard, "I do."

I thought about how she felt that Enzo was tired of everything, including her, which made her even angrier; now he was locked in his own world, roaring like a wild beast—roaring inside, but silent on the outside. Pinocchia could no longer stand him, especially because when the subject of that bad woman came up, he would get somewhat agitated.

[1963-11-20 10:00:10] School | I realized then that apologizing to the priest wasn't enough—I needed to gain his trust, as well as that of other teachers who shared his views.
[1963-11-20 10:00:20] School | I saw that I effortlessly separated what I said from who I was. [1963-11-20 10:00:40] School | I thought that in just a few days, I felt as if I and Nino had become the two most promising students in this run-down high school.

[1963-11-20T10:05:00] Mergellina | I saw her say bad things about Lina to everyone, sharp-tongued and unashamed, but she was especially angry with Antonio and Pasquale. I heard her say, "She tricked all of you, you men." She said, "Because she knows your psychology, she's just a prostitute."
[1963-11-20T10:10:00] Mergellina | I saw her speaking like that, full of anger, as if Antonio and Pasquale represented all men, and all men were the same; she would curse her own brother because he wasn't on her side. [1963-11-20T10:20:00] Mergellina | I saw that Bambino would only become more ruthless and unyielding in his words, never letting him off the hook at any time. I knew that Pasquale, in order to have a calmer life, had to make a concession on the issue of Lina; otherwise, they might break up.

[1963-11-20T22:15:00] Flegrey District | I thought: I haven't graduated yet, I don't have a job; if I don't want to waste my life, I need to work twice as hard; but now I'm with a married woman who's pregnant, and every morning she throws up, disrupting my routine.
[1963-11-23T10:00:00] Flegrey District | I saw how he feltpainful when he found out that Il Messaggero would not publish his article.
[1963-11-23T10:05:00] Flegrey District | I saw Lina comfort him and suggest that he submit the article to another newspaper. I heard her add at the end, "I'll call and ask tomorrow."

[1963-11-23T10:11:00] Flegrey District | I heard, "That's really the case, I'm not an idiot, you only get me into trouble." "What do you want to say?" "I shouldn't have listened to you." "What exactly did I do?"

[1963-11-23T10:12:00] District of Flegrey | "I heard, 'You've messed up my mind. Because you're like a drop of water: drip, drip, drip! You don't let go if everything doesn't go your way.' [1963-11-23T10:13:00] Flegrey District | I heard, "Lina, let's be straight about this. Choose something you like, go back and sell shoes, sell sausages, but don't think you can become someone else and drag me in too."
[1963-11-23T10:14:00] Flegrey District | I know they have been living together for twenty-three days. I thought of them as if the gods had wrapped them in a mist, hiding them from the world, letting them enjoy each other undisturbed.
[1963-11-23T10:15:00] Flegrey District | I saw these words hurting her deep inside, and I said to Nino. I heard "Get out!"
[1963-11-23T10:16:00] Flegrey District | I saw him angrily throw his coat over his sweater and slam the door as he left.
[1963-11-23T10:30:00] Flegrey District | I saw his books, his notes, and his razor and soap here. I thought of Lina sitting on the bed, thinking: He'll be back here in ten minutes.
[1963-11-23T10:40:00] Flegrey District | I saw her crying in the end. I wondered how I could have thought about living with him, about helping him? It was my fault. I freed my mind, and I made him write things he shouldn't have.

I heard him say either he leaves home or stays, but he shouldn't just casually leave for a month without even saying goodbye. He comes back only to get money, as if the money were his own.
[1963-11-23T12:30:00] Nino's house | I saw Nino slip into his room, and he stayed there for a long time. [1963-11-23T12:35:00] Nino's House | I thought to myself: For example, right now, I can't wait to return to her, constantly touching her, taking on my responsibility; but reason tells me that what I did today, when I was completely disappointed, was right—Lina and I aren't compatible!
[1963-11-23T12:40:00] Nino's house | I thought about Lina's pregnancy, the child in her belly frightened me; I should go find Bruno and ask him for some money, I should leave San Gregorio Armeno like Elena did, to study somewhere else.
[1963-11-23T23:59:00] Flegrey District | I saw her lying in bed waiting. She had waited all night, but Nino didn't come back until the next day—and he never came back at all.
[1963-11-24T20:00:00] Nino's house | I thought about him all night, and the whole next day. On one hand, I felt I really couldn't do without Lina, but on the other hand, I was scared, because I remembered her rude and shameless behavior, her ignorant cleverness, and her thoughts—bold ideas, ones I didn't know how she came up with.
[1963-11-24T21:00:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw that he was having trouble controlling himself; that night he called Bruno and said he wanted to go out to find him. I saw that it was raining.

[1963-11-24T21:10:00] Mergellina | I thought about how she had given up her old life, something he could never understand; he hit Nino to take his revenge, because he really hated Nino—a worthless pretty boy, a frail, thin figure who had managed to make both of us girls, past and present, so completely infatuated.
[1963-11-24T21:30:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw him run to the bus stop and get on the bus before it started moving, but suddenly he changed his mind and got off at Garibaldi Square.
[1963-11-24T22:00:00] On the way to the Flagray District | I saw him take the subway to the Flegre district. I thought about how he was eager to embrace Lina, to take her right there, the moment he walked in the door, against the wall at the entrance—this was the most urgent thing, and the rest could wait.
[1963-11-24T22:15:00] Flagray District Street | I saw him walking swiftly through the rain, not noticing that someone was coming straight toward him. I saw that the sky was very dark.
[1963-11-24T22:16:00] Flagray District Street | I saw him get violently pushed, thrown to the ground, and then the man began to kick and punch him relentlessly.
[1963-11-24T22:17:00] Flagray District Street | I saw the person hitting him speaking to him constantly, but there was no anger in his voice. I heard, "Leave her, never see her again, never touch her again. Say quickly: I'm leaving her, I'll never see her again, never touch her again. You bastard! You scum! You like it? Ah! You like messing with other people's wives. Say it: I'm sorry, I'm leaving her."
[1963-11-24T22:18:00] Flagray District Street | I saw Nino obediently saying those words, but the man who was beating him didn't stop. I thought it was not so much because of the pain as because of fear that he lost consciousness.
[1963-11-25T10:00:00] Mergellina | I knew that Antonio was the one who beat Nino, but about this matter, he didn't utter a single word to his boss.
[1963-11-25T10:05:00] Mergellina | I saw Michele ask him if he had found Nino's son, and he said he had. I heard when Michele asked anxiously, following this lead, whether they had found Lina, and he said no.
[1963-11-25T10:10:00] Mergellina | I heard Michele ask him if he had any news about Lina, and he said Lina still hadn't been found. The only thing that was absolutely certain was that Nino's son had absolutely nothing to do with Mrs. Carracci.

[1963-11-25T15:10:00] Mergellina | I heard him not mention Nino, he just said he'd found Lina and that she needed help. "What are we supposed to do for her?" Pasquale said in an annoyed tone.

[1963-11-25T15:13:00] Mergellina | I heard, "I'm no one, I just finished a job." "Good, what do you want us to do now?" "I didn't tell Michele that I found her."

I heard his future brother-in-law Pasquale say that Lina left her husband and everything else, and eventually left the Solara shoe store, because she realized marrying Stefano had been a mistake, and she was right to do so, of course he wouldn't go and get her back.
[1963-11-25T15:16:00] Mergellina | At that moment, I saw Antonio getting a bit excited. "I heard 'You want to leave her alone in the Fratelli district?' " Antonio asked uneasily, "alone, and without any money?"
[1963-11-25T15:17:00] Mergellina | "I heard, 'Why, are we rich people? Lina is an adult, she knows how to live. She made this choice, and she always has her own reasons. We shouldn't bother her.' 'Every time we need help, she always steps in.'"

[1963-11-26T09:10:00] Mergellina | I know, but his personality is very reserved, making it hard to guess what kind of person he really is; from Pinochia, I learned that he was studying in secret, hoping to obtain a certificate in industrial management through self-taught exams.

[1963-11-26T09:20:00] House in the Flegrey District | I saw him find the path and the gate, he climbed the stairs and knocked on the door with great determination.
[1963-11-26T10:00:00] Flagray District House | I saw that after ten minutes, after an hour, and even the next day, Nino didn't return and had vanished without a trace. I knew Lina's mood had turned terrible; she didn't feel abandoned, but rather insulted.
[1963-11-26T10:10:00] Flagray District House | I know that she herself also admitted she wasn't suitable for Nino, but she couldn't stand it: he disappeared from her life just twenty-three days later, in a way that was unbearable and certainly confirmed it.

[1963-11-26T11:00:00] Flagray District House | I thought of her, and my heart ached. She thought of Nino—the Nino she loved, the Nino who loved her, the one who made her suffer these pains.
[1963-11-26T11:10:00] Flagray District House | I saw the house suddenly reveal its true face—it was a very dilapidated house, and through its walls I could hear the noise of the entire city; she smelled a terrible odor, saw cockroaches crawling in under the door, and noticed mold spots forming on the ceiling. I thought of how she first felt the experience of her childhood once again seizing her—not the imaginative, dreamy childhood, but that sorrowful, brutal one, filled with threats and violence.
[1963-11-26T11:20:00] House in the Flegrey District | I thought of her, but suddenly she realized that the fantasy she had always turned to for comfort—the dream of becoming rich—had already vanished from her mind.
[1963-11-26T11:30:00] Flagray District House | I know that the poverty she endured in the Frazione district was even darker than the one I experienced in our Mergellina during childhood. Despite her situation being worsened by her [pregnancy status], and despite the fact that she had spent all her money within just a few days. I thought about how she had realized that wealth was not a reward, nor a bargaining chip; for her, it had lost any meaning.
[1963-11-26T11:40:00] House in the Flegrey District | I know that safe we dreamed of as children, filled with gold coins and jewels, was later replaced by the dirty, smelly money—those were the coins in the drawer where she worked at Capodimonte, or the money in the colorful metal boxes in the shoe store on Piazza Martiri. I realized this fantasy had already lost its power and no longer held any allure for her.
[1963-11-26T11:50:00] Flagray District House | I realized that her possession of money and material things had completely disappointed her; she wanted nothing from herself, and nothing for the child in her belly.
[1963-11-26T12:00:00] Flagray District House | I thought that for her, wealth had meant having Nino, and now that Nino was gone, she felt poor, a kind of poverty money could not erase.
[1963-11-26T12:10:00] Flagray District House | I thought about her current situation, which could not be compensated by anything—she had made too many mistakes since childhood, and all of them led to this final mistake: she believed that Nino's son couldn't do without her, and she couldn't do without him either. Their fates would be different, but they would always love each other, and nothing else would be needed besides their love.
[1963-11-26T12:20:00] Flagray District House | I realized I had been wrong, and I decided never to go out again, never to look for him, never to eat anything again, just to wait until my consciousness faded away, slowly disappearing along with my child. I thought of her, until her mind was completely empty, not even a single thing left to make her furious, meaning she would completely give up on herself!
[1963-11-26T12:30:00] Flagray District House | I was watching when someone knocked on the door.
[1963-11-26T12:31:00] House in the Flegrey District | I thought it was Nino, so I opened the door, but it was Enzo instead. I thought of seeing Enzo, and she wasn't disappointed.
[1963-11-26T12:32:00] Flagray District House | I thought about how she was expecting him to bring her some fruit, just like many years ago, when they were children, during the competition organized by the principal and Teacher Oliviero, when he had been defeated and then hit Lina on the forehead with a stone.
[1963-11-26T12:33:00] House in the Flegrey District | I saw her laughing, and Enzo thought her laughter was a sick reaction.
[1963-11-26T12:35:00] Flagray District House | I saw him come in, but out of respect, I left the door open. He didn't want the neighbors to think she was a prostitute.
[1963-11-26T12:36:00] Elena's House in Flegrey District | I saw him look around, see her defeated state, and though he hadn't yet realized the thing that wasn't yet apparent—she was pregnant—but he guessed that she really needed help.
[1963-11-26T12:37:00] House in the Flegrey District | I saw him still speaking in that serious way, without any emotion, before she stopped laughing, he said. I heard, "Let's go." "Where to?" "Back to your husband."
locations: On the way to the Flagray District
