[1963-11-26T12:39:00] Flagray District House | I heard, "I'm not leaving." "Then I'll stay with you." "Forever?" "Until you make a decision."
[1963-11-26T12:40:00] Flagray District House | I heard, "Work?" "Tired of it." "Where's Pinocchio?" "You're more important."
[1963-11-26T12:41:00] House in the Flegrey District | I saw him start to speak in a low voice, but he kept his distance from her. I heard, "I'll tell her, and she'll leave you." "I'll tell her myself, I've already made up my mind."
[1963-11-26T12:42:00] House in the Flegrey District | I saw her respond to him in a very improper tone, laughing as she spoke. I thought, as they say, not a single word is true; they are talking about worlds, people, and emotions that have been gone for a long time.
[1963-11-26T12:45:00] Flagray District House | I saw Enzo realize it. He was silent for a moment, then he walked around the room, found Lina's suitcase, and started taking things from the drawers and wardrobe and putting them into the suitcase.
[1963-11-26T12:50:00] Flagray District House | I saw Lina letting him do all those things. I thought that because she felt Enzo in front of her wasn't a real person at all, but more like a shadow, just like in a movie, and even though he was speaking, it was only the effect of light.
[1963-11-26T12:55:00] Flagray District House | I saw him finish packing his luggage and then approach her. He said something that surprised her, in that cold but forceful way he had. "I heard 'Lina, I love you, I've loved you since we were little. But I've never told you because you're beautiful and smart, while I'm short and ugly, too small to be worthy of you.'"
[1963-11-26T12:56:00] House in the Flegrey District | I heard, "Now, go back to your husband. I don't know why you left him, and I don't want to know. All I know is that you can't stay here, you shouldn't live in this terrible environment."
[1963-11-26T12:57:00] Flagray District House | "I heard, 'I'll walk with you to your building's entrance and wait for you. If he treats you badly, I'll go up and kill him; if he doesn't hit you and is happy you're back, then it's okay. We've made an agreement: if you can't get along with your husband, I'll take you back and bring you away. Okay?'"
[1963-11-26T12:58:00] Flagray District House | I saw Lina stop smiling, she squinted her eyes, it was the first time she had listened to him so intently.
[1963-11-26T13:00:00] Elena's House in Flegrey District | I knew that by then, the connection between Lina and him was very weak, but whenever I was there, I always felt amazed. I thought there was something hard to explain between them, a vague thing that had existed since childhood; I felt she trusted Enzo, and she saw him as a reliable person.
[1963-11-26T13:05:00] Flagray District House | I saw her hesitate when Enzo picked up his luggage and walked toward the open door, then followed him.
[1963-11-26T20:00:00] Lina's building downstairs | I saw the night Enzo walked Lina home, and he was really waiting under Lina and Stefano's window. I thought that if Stefano hit her, I would most likely go up and kill Stefano.
[1963-11-26T20:10:00] Lina's house | I saw that Stefano didn't hit her; the opposite happened. I saw that a clean, neat, and comfortable house was waiting for her.
[1963-11-26T20:15:00] Lina's house | I saw his reaction as if his wife had really gone to Borgo and stayed with me for a while, even though there was no evidence that it had actually happened.
[1963-11-26T20:20:00] Lina's house | I saw Lina, she didn't use that excuse, nor did she come up with any other.
[1963-11-27T08:00:00] Lina's house | I saw her reluctantly say to Stefano the next morning when I got up. I heard, "I've given birth."
[1963-11-27T08:01:00] Lina's house | I saw Stefano was very happy; when she spoke her second sentence, he laughed, as if it was a genuine joy from within. I heard, "The child isn't yours."
[1963-11-27T08:02:00] Lina's house | I saw her repeat the sentence two or three times, her voice growing increasingly angry. She also clenched her fists and hit Stefano. He came over to comfort her, [intimate gesture]. I heard a soft voice say, "Don't do this, Lina! Don't do this, don't do this, I'm so happy. I know I've been bad to you, let's not fight now, don't say these things to me."
[1963-11-27T08:03:00] Lina's house | I saw happiness in his eyes, tears of joy.
[1963-11-27T08:05:00] Lina's House | I had always known that Lina understood people lied to protect themselves from the pain of the truth, but what surprised her was that her husband could deceive himself with such a cheerful attitude.
[1963-11-27T08:10:00] Lina's House | I saw her, but she no longer cared—didn't care about Stefano, didn't care about herself. After repeating several times, "The child isn't yours," she sank into the numbness and sluggishness of pregnancy.
[1963-11-27T08:15:00] Lina's house | I thought to myself, Stefano doesn't want to suffer now, okay! Let him feel whatever he wants to feel. If he doesn't want to suffer now, then let him suffer later.
[1963-11-27T10:00:00] Lina's house | I saw her start to say what she wanted to do and what she didn't want to do. I thought she no longer wanted to work at the store on Martirini Square, nor in Capodimonte; she didn't want to see anyone, not relatives or friends, especially the Solara brothers; she wanted to stay home and be a full-time wife and mother.
[1963-11-27T10:10:00] Lina's house | I saw that he agreed. I thought he wouldn't be able to hold out for more than a few days, and Lina would change her mind.
[1963-12-01 10:00:00] Posillipo | I was thinking about the argument I told you about, just to explain how that year passed.
[1963-12-01 10:00:10] Posillipo | I thought I should explain the atmosphere surrounding Lina's choices, especially the attitudes of the men who had once been infatuated with her or had confessed their love to her.
[1963-12-01 10:00:20] Posillipo | I thought about how they had loved her, longed for her, and it was very likely they still did.
[1963-12-01 10:00:30] Posillipo | I thought that no matter what the situation, I would defend Lina, and I liked doing it, liked speaking about it in that pedantic, authoritative tone.
[1963-12-01 10:00:40] Posillipo | I thought about it, but I also knew that I was quite willing to tell the story of what had happened before, even exaggerating it, saying how Lina had been manipulating Stefano's actions behind the scenes.
[1963-12-01 10:00:50] Posillipo | I thought about how to tell the story of how we gradually solved that problem, like solving a math equation, until we arrived at this result: settling ourselves, taking care of my brother, and beginning to realize the plan for the shoe factory.
[1963-12-01T08:00:00] On the street | I saw that up until that time, Pasquale often yelled at his girlfriend and sister, saying they had forgotten the favors Lina had done for them. I want to point out one thing: the matter didn't end there.
[1963-12-01T08:05:00] Street | I didn't realize until one morning when I saw Lina sitting in Michele's "Juliet" sports car. I saw our friend heavily made up, dressed like a high-class prostitute, as Michele drove her to Martiri Square.
[1963-12-01T08:10:00] Street | I thought about how Pasquale had admitted he no longer understood the situation. Lina didn't have to worry about making a living; why had she sold herself to a man like him?!
[1963-12-01T10:00:00] Lina's house | I saw, but in fact, Lina stayed at home all along. I thought about how she didn't care at all about Stefano's business, nor about her brother and father's shoe factory, nor about what happened to her husband and her own relatives.
[1963-12-05 10:00:00] School | A few weeks later, when Nino saw me, he got straight to the point, using his usual gloomy tone, and asked me to write a half-page report detailing my conflict with the priest.
[1963-12-05 10:00:10] School | I heard, "What's it for?"
[1963-12-05 10:00:20] School | I heard him say that he was editing a small magazine called "San Gregorio Armeno: The Poor Man's Hotel." I know he mentioned it at the editorial office, and several editors told him that if he could write a brief summary, they might try to include it in the next issue of the magazine.
[1963-12-05 10:00:30] School | I saw him glance at the magazine for me. I saw it was a booklet of about fifty pages, with a dark gray cover. The table of contents included his name and an article of his titled "Miserable Data."
[1963-12-05 10:00:40] School | I thought of this, and I thought of his father, who had read the article published in the newspaper with a satisfied and self-satisfied expression on the beach at Maronti.
[1963-12-05 10:00:50] School | "I also write poetry?" I asked him.
[1963-12-05 10:01:00] School | I saw him look at me with contempt and deny it. I immediately agreed with him. I heard, "Okay, I'll try."
[1963-12-05 14:00:00] Street | I rushed home, extremely excited, feeling my mind was full of sentences I wanted to write.
[1963-12-05 14:10:00] Street | I told Alfonso Carracci in great detail about my thoughts as I was on the way. I heard him expressing his concern for me, and he repeatedly told me not to write anything.
[1963-12-05 14:10:10] Street | I heard, "Will they write down your name?"
[1963-12-05 14:10:20] Street | I heard, "Yes."
[1963-12-05 14:10:30] Street | I heard, "Rino, the priest will be angry, he'll make you fail the exam, he'll have the chemistry teacher and the math teacher join him on the same side."
[1963-12-05 14:15:00] Street | I thought his anxiety had infected me, and I lost my confidence.
[1963-12-05 14:20:00] Street | I thought that once we parted, once my small article quickly appeared in a magazine, printed with my name, I could show it to Lina, my parents, and Professor Oliviero and Professor Ferraro. Still, I decided to write the article. After finishing it, I would make amends.
[1963-12-05 14:20:10] Street | I felt exhilarated at the thought of receiving applause from those people I admired, like Teacher Galiani and Nino.
[1963-12-05 14:20:20] Street | I thought about joining forces with them to oppose the outdated people—Father, the chemistry teacher, and the math teacher—but in their eyes, I also needed to behave well in order to gain their appreciation and respect.

[1963-12-05 16:00:00] Outside the shoe repair shop | I saw the shop of Fernando. I thought of a victorious happiness, because I had also contributed to making it happen.
[1963-12-05 16:00:10] Outside the shoe repair shop | I had never seen a sign on this shop before, but now there's a metal plate on the broken door, and it says: "Lina."
[1963-12-05 16:00:20] In front of the shoe repair shop | I saw Fernando, Rino, and the other three apprentices working from morning until night at the table, stitching edges, hammering, and polishing.
[1963-12-05 16:00:30] Door of the shoe repair shop | I know everyone knows that Fernando thought those shoes, especially the women's ones, couldn't be made according to Lina's designs—they were just a girl's fanciful imagination.
[1963-12-05 16:00:40] At the shoe repair shop door | I know everyone knows that Stefano went to the shop. He calmly said that the shoes he would make would be just like those on the drawings, and that's why he hung up the drawings.
[1963-12-05 16:01:00] Outside the shoe repair shop | When I passed by the shop, I just glanced inside and quickly walked away. I thought of the blueprints hanging on the wall, which had deeply imprinted themselves in my mind.
[1963-12-05 16:01:10] At the shoe repair shop door | I thought to myself: For Lina, those drawings were her fantasies, unrelated to money or selling herself. All the work being done was the final result of her delirium, a reflection of Stefano's love for her.
[1963-12-05 16:01:20] At the shoe repair shop door | I thought she was lucky because she was deeply loved, she could be herself, and she had creativity.
[1963-12-05 16:10:00] Posillipo | I saw that I had found some very concise and meaningful sentences, trying to clearly state my position, arguing with reason and dignity, and using many very obscure words.
[1963-12-05 16:15:00] Posillipo | I saw myself writing: "If God is everywhere, why does He still need the Holy Spirit to spread His presence?"
[1963-12-05 16:30:00] Posillipo | I saw that half a page was soon filled, and I had only finished the introduction. What should I do with the rest?
[1963-12-05 17:00:00] Posillipo | I saw myself rewriting again, slowing down, starting from the most basic elements, hunching over and trying several times. The final result was basically satisfactory.
[1963-12-05 17:30:00] Posillipo | I went to preview the next day's lessons.
[1963-12-05 18:00:00] Posillipo | I thought about it, but less than half an hour later, I started having some doubts again. I felt I needed someone else's confirmation. Who could help me look at the article I wrote and give their opinion?
[1963-12-05 18:00:10] Posillipo | I thought of my mother? My brothers? Antonio? They certainly couldn't do it. The only one was Lina.
[1963-12-05 18:00:20] Posillipo | I thought about it, but going to see her would mean acknowledging her authority. In fact, I was the one who now had the knowledge.
[1963-12-05 18:00:30] Posillipo | I thought about starting, and I was very reluctant to go find her. I was afraid she'd see the half page I'd written, and dismiss me with just a few short sentences.
[1963-12-05 18:00:40] Posillipo | I realized that what I was really afraid of was that she would change my mind with just a few words, pushing my thoughts to extremes and breaking the balance I had carefully written on that half page.
[1963-12-05 18:10:00] Lina's house | I ended up running to her, hoping to find her.
[1963-12-05 18:15:00] Lina's House | I saw her at her parents' house, and I told her about Nino, handing her the notebook.
[1963-12-05 18:15:10] Lina's House | I saw her looking at the page unwillingly, as if the words on it would hurt her eyes.
[1963-12-05 18:15:20] Lina's house | I saw someone like Alfonso Carracci, and she asked me. I heard, "They'll put your name on it?"
[1963-12-05 18:15:30] Lina's house | I saw myself nodding.
[1963-12-05 18:15:40] Lina's house | I heard, "Write Elena Greco?"
[1963-12-05 18:15:50] Lina's house | I heard, "Yes."
[1963-12-05 18:16:00] Lina's house | I saw her hand the notebook to me. I heard, "I can't tell you whether it's good or bad."
[1963-12-05 18:16:10] Lina's house | I heard, "Please, I beg you."
[1963-12-05 18:16:20] Lina's house | I heard, "Don't do this, I don't have that ability."
[1963-12-05 18:16:30] Lina's House | I saw that I had to insist again and again. I said to her—despite the fact that I knew full well it wasn't the truth. I heard myself say, "If she doesn't like it, if she refuses to read the article, I won't have it printed by Nino."
[1963-12-05 18:20:00] Lina's house | I watched until the end, she read the article, and she was completely absorbed, as if carrying a very heavy burden.
[1963-12-05 18:20:10] Lina's house | I thought she was making a painful effort to free the old Lina deep inside herself—the Lina who read, wrote, painted, designed, and was quick-witted.
[1963-12-05 18:25:00] Lina's house | I saw her finish reading the article, as if she had relaxed.
[1963-12-05 18:25:10] Lina's house | I heard, "May I edit it?"
[1963-12-05 18:25:20] Lina's house | I heard, "Of course you can."
[1963-12-05 18:26:00] Lina's house | I saw her delete many words, even entire sentences.
[1963-12-05 18:26:10] Lina's house | "I heard, 'May I move the sentence's position?'"
[1963-12-05 18:26:20] Lina's house | I heard, "Yes."
[1963-12-05 18:27:00] Lina's House | I saw her circle a sentence with a curve and move it to the top of the page.
[1963-12-05 18:27:10] Lina's House | I heard, "Can I copy the article onto another sheet of paper?"
[1963-12-05 18:27:20] Lina's house | I heard, "I'll copy it myself."
[1963-12-05 18:27:30] Lina's house | I heard, "Let me do it."
[1963-12-05 18:30:00] Lina's house | I watched her write for a while, and then she returned the notebook to me and said. I heard, "You're really amazing, no wonder they all gave you a ten."
[1963-12-05 18:30:10] Lina's house | I saw that in the end her tone became harsh, and she said. I heard, "I never want to see anything you've written again." I thought I sensed no sarcasm in her tone; it was a sincere compliment.
[1963-12-05 18:30:20] Lina's house | "I heard 'Why?'"
[1963-12-05 18:30:30] Lina's house | I saw her thinking.
[1963-12-05 18:30:40] Lina's house | I saw her tap her head with her finger and then laugh. I heard, "Because it will give me a headache."
[1963-12-05 19:00:00] Posillipo | I saw myself happily returning home, and in order not to disturb the others in the house, I locked myself in the bathroom and studied until 3 a.m. before going to sleep.
[1963-12-05T10:00:00] Martiri Square Store | I saw, as usual, Lina completely unaware of the hostility around her, she threw herself into her new job.
[1963-12-05T10:05:00] Martiri Square Store | I saw that soon, the store's sales shot up; she placed books among the shoes—books she had read. I saw people go to the shop not only to spend money but also to exchange a few words with that very beautiful, lively, and witty young woman.
[1963-12-05T10:10:00] Martiri Square Store | I saw her lips move, saying some nice words, and she even handed me some chocolate. I know the people who come here are wives and daughters of lawyers or engineers, reporters from Il Messaggero, and playboys of all ages lingering in the club.
[1963-12-05T10:15:00] Martiri Square Store | I thought that for them, it seemed Lina wasn't eager to sell them "Lina" or "Sorola" shoes; she just wanted them to sit on the sofa or armchair and chat for a while.
[1963-12-06 06:30:00] Posillipo | I forced myself to get up at 6:30 in the morning and started copying the article.
[1963-12-06 06:35:00] Posillipo | I looked at Lina's beautiful cursive writing, which had already taken shape in her elementary school days. I thought about her handwriting, which was very different from mine. My writing had become neater and smaller.
[1963-12-06 06:40:00] Posillipo | I thought about the sentences on that page—they were really all mine, but clearer now—those parts that had been deleted, the changes in the order of the sentences, and the additions, all made my expression more effective.
[1963-12-06 06:40:10] Posillipo | I thought of her handwriting, which gave me a feeling: as if I had escaped from myself, now running ahead by a hundred meters, full of energy, very harmonious, possessing the strength and coordination that the me following behind lacked.
[1963-12-06 06:45:00] Posillipo | I thought about how I had decided to keep Lina's handwriting and stop copying it myself.
locations: In front of the shoe repair shop
Door of the shoe repair shop
At the shoe repair shop door

text:
[1963-12-06 10:00:00] School | I saw myself handing the article to Nino. I thought that what I wanted was to preserve her handwriting in my language, a visible trace.
[1963-12-06 10:05:00] School | I saw him blink several times as he read the article. Finally, he said with a hint of sadness. I heard, "Professor Galiani is right."
[1963-12-06 10:05:10] School | "I heard 'What did she say?'"
[1963-12-06 10:05:20] School | I heard, "You write better than I do."
[1963-12-06 10:05:30] School | I felt very embarrassed and said it wasn't true, but he repeated the words again, then turned and left without even saying goodbye.
[1963-12-06 10:05:40] School | I saw that he didn't even tell me when the magazine would come out or how to get it, and I didn't have the courage to ask him.
[1963-12-06 10:05:50] School | When I saw him leave, I recognized in his distant figure the way his father walked. I felt a strong aversion to his attitude.
[1963-12-10 10:00:00] School | I thought about how this meeting would end like this, how we were once again both wrong.
[1963-12-10 10:00:10] School | I thought about how Nino had been avoiding me for several days, as if the fact that my article was better than his was a mistake, a crime. I felt really angry.
[1963-12-10 16:00:00] Street | I saw that when we found time to meet, she talked about her life. I thought she was satisfied with her transformation, as if, aside from marriage, a house, and children, she could no longer see anything else, nor did she want to.
[1963-12-10 16:00:10] Street | I thought I felt sad. She seemed to have become sweet, all her previous harshness was gone.
[1963-12-10T10:00:00] Lina's house | I remember once when Rino came, he was very anxious and restless, and Lina received him.
[1963-12-10T10:15:00] Lina's house | I saw how she reacted when her brother told her about the Solara brothers' actions, and it made him angry. I know that Lina's shoes are slowly being taken off the market, and now the shoe workshop is in trouble. Stefano is always preoccupied with his own affairs and no longer invests.
[1963-12-10T10:30:00] Lina's house | I saw her say to him when he finally fell silent. I heard, "Rino, you're the older brother, you're older than me. You have a wife and a son. Please! Live your own life, don't always come looking for me."
[1963-12-10T10:45:00] Lina's house | I saw Rino was very sad after hearing that; he left dejectedly. I thought to myself before leaving: everyone is getting richer and richer, but not him. Because his sister doesn't care about her own family, nor about Lina's family; now she only thinks about the Carichis. He is now losing everything he has so hard-earned.
[1963-12-10T11:00:00] Martiri Square Store | The only obstacle I saw was Michele. He often showed up at the store during work hours, clumsy and intrusive. He would speak in his sarcastic tone, saying things that had double meanings, and when he got to that point, he would lean in and kiss her. "I heard, 'You've married the wrong man, Lina! My eyes are sharp: look, how good you are at dealing with people, that's useful for us. If we work together, in a few years, the entire San Gregorio Armeno will be ours, and we can do whatever we want.'"
[1963-12-10T11:05:00] Martiri Square Store | I saw Lina push him away, but he didn't get discouraged; he would still smile. I heard, "Well, I'll wait." "You can wait anywhere you like, but not here," she replied, "if you keep waiting here, I'll leave for Capodimonte tomorrow."
[1963-12-15 10:00:00] Street | I later heard a lot of rumors about her from Giggia Spagnuolo.
[1963-12-15 10:00:10] Street | I saw Geyao La speaking in the local dialect, full of contempt, as she said to me. I heard, "Now, your friend has become a princess. At that time, Marcello went to her house, and she played the flute for him every night. Did Stefano know about that?"
[1963-12-15 10:00:20] Street | I thought about how I pretended to ignore the meaning of "blowing the flute," but in fact, I knew that word since I was very young. It sounded extremely unpleasant, carrying a sense of humiliation.
[1963-12-15 10:00:30] Street | I heard, "This isn't real."
[1963-12-15 10:00:40] Street | I heard, "Marcello said that."
[1963-12-15 10:00:50] Street | I heard, "He's lying."
[1963-12-15 10:01:00] Street | "I heard, 'Is that so? Then his brother is lying too?'"
[1963-12-15 10:01:10] Street | I heard, "Is it Michele who told you?"
[1963-12-15 10:01:20] Street | I heard, "Yes."
[1963-12-15 10:01:30] Street | I thought to myself that I hoped those rumors would not reach Stefano's ears.
[1963-12-15T13:00:00] Martiri Square Store | I noticed that Michele came less often, so Nino came more. I know that during the months he spent at Martiri Square, he finally had time to be with Lina every day for three hours, except on Sundays and holidays—and for them, that was almost unbearable.
[1963-12-15T13:05:00] Martiri Square Store | At one o'clock, the clerk would lower the metal shutters three quarters of the way and then leave. Nino would go in through the small door of the restroom and leave at four o'clock before the clerk returned.
[1963-12-15T13:10:00] Martiri Square Store | I remember only a few times when something unexpected happened. Twice, Michele and Giggia came, and once it got really tense—Stefano suddenly showed up. I knew that Nino had slipped into the toilet and then left through the small door leading to the courtyard.
[1963-12-15T15:00:00] Lina's House | I saw even Michele lowering himself to come and see her. At first, he came twice a day, but only when he was sure Stefano wasn't home.
[1963-12-15T15:10:00] Lina's house | I saw her, but she never opened the door. She sat silently in the kitchen, holding her breath.
[1963-12-15T15:20:00] Lina's house | I saw that once, he could no longer stand the treatment, and before leaving, he shouted from the street. I heard, "Do you think you're someone important? You whore! We had an agreement, and you didn't stick to it."
[1963-12-18 13:00:00] At the school gate | I saw one day, after school, when his sister Pinocchia appeared. She seemed to have come to tell Nino something. I know it's been a long time since we met at Vomero.
[1963-12-18 13:00:10] At the school gate | I saw her run downstairs immediately, being very friendly toward me. She said she was sorry I hadn't gone back to Balano in the summer.
[1963-12-18 13:00:20] At the school gate | I saw myself walking with Alfonso Carracci back then, and I introduced him to her.
[1963-12-18 13:05:00] Street | I saw that her brother had already left, but she insisted on walking with us for a while. She first told us about the pain of love she had suffered.
[1963-12-18 13:10:00] Street | When I finished, she realized that I and Alfonso Carracci weren't a couple, so she stopped talking to me and instead, in her usual way, started speaking intimately with Alfonso Carracci.
[1963-12-19 10:00:00] School | I saw that the next day, Nino started circling around me again, but just seeing him made me feel annoyed. I thought that after she got home, she would tell her brother that there was nothing between me and Alfonso Carracci.
[1963-12-19 10:00:10] School | I thought, despite his hatred for his father, was he really as foolish as his father? Did he think everyone was dying to meet him, to love him? Was he so full of himself that he couldn't stand anyone being better than him?
[1963-12-20 13:00:00] At the school gate | I saw that I had asked Antonio to pick me up at school, and he arrived immediately as I had requested. I thought that on one hand he was confused, and on the other hand, he was grateful that I had let him come.
[1963-12-20 13:00:10] At the school gate | I saw myself grabbing his hand in front of everyone, our fingers entwined. I thought the thing that would surprise him the most was this.
[1963-12-20 13:00:20] At the school gate | I thought about how I had always refused to walk with him, both inside and outside of Mergellina, because it made me feel like a child, walking with my father.
[1963-12-20 13:00:30] At the school gate | I saw that, and that's exactly what I did. I knew Nino had seen us.
[1963-12-20 13:00:40] At the school gate | I wanted him to know who I was: my writing was better than his, I would publish my own articles where he did, and I studied well at school, better than him.
[1963-12-20 13:00:50] At the school gate | I thought of the man I had, this was my man, so I wouldn't follow him like a loyal little dog, trailing behind his back.
[1963-12-20 16:00:00] Street | I thought, every time I came back from school, I wanted to say: Maybe, before something bad happens, I should tell Lina.
[1963-12-20 16:00:10] Street | I thought about it, but I was afraid she'd get angry, because, given her upbringing, according to her personality, she would definitely go looking for Marcello with a knife.

[1963-12-20T13:00:00] At the school gate | I saw her until Christmas Eve, once at the school gate, she stopped me and we walked a ways together. She came straight to the point and asked me what had happened to Nino. I heard her say, "I know nothing at all." I replied to her.  
"Tell me the truth."  
"That's the truth."
[1963-12-20T13:05:00] At the school gate | I know that later I found out, after that summer, he never showed up again, and neither she nor her daughter ever saw him again.
[1963-12-20T13:10:00] At the school gate | I saw Galiani, as a mother, speaking with resentment. I heard, "He broke up with Nadezhda in a very bad way. He sent her a few lines from Vomero, which made her very upset."
[1963-12-20T13:10:05] At the school gate | I saw that in the end she managed to control her emotions and spoke in her teacher's tone. I heard, "Well, that's just how it is. You're all kids, and pain helps you grow."
[1963-12-20T13:15:00] At the school gate | I saw myself nodding, then she asked me. I heard, "Has he left you too?"
[1963-12-20T13:15:05] At the school gate | "I heard 'me?'"
"Didn't you see her at Vomero?"
"Yes, but nothing happened between us." I saw my face turn red.
[1963-12-20T13:20:00] At the school gate | I saw that I had strongly refuted the possibility, and I said I could meet Nadia face to face and tell her that nothing had ever happened between me and Nino, and never would. "I heard 'Really?'"
"Absolutely not."
"Nadia is certain that Nino left her because of you."
[1963-12-20T13:25:00] At the school gate | I saw Teacher Galiani and she was happy, assuring me that she would tell Nadezhda. I didn't mention Lina, not only because I had already decided to do my own thing, but also because bringing her up would inevitably plunge me into pain.
[1963-12-20T13:30:00] At the school gate | I tried not to bring up these things anymore, but Teacher Galiani mentioned Nino again. I knew there were several different versions about Nino; some said he hadn't taken the fall exams at all, and that he had already stopped going to school.
[1963-12-20T13:35:00] At the school gate | I know someone who swore that one afternoon on Via Alemanni, she saw him alone, completely drunk, swaying as he walked and drinking from a bottle.
[1963-12-20T13:40:00] At the school gate | I heard her conclude that perhaps it was because many people didn't like Nino, so someone was inclined to speak ill of him. But if that were really the case, it would be a great pity. "I heard 'I think it's definitely not true,' I said."  
"Hope so. That boy, you just can't rely on him at all."
[1963-12-20T13:45:00] At the school gate | I heard, "Indeed."
"He's excellent."
"Yes."
"If you find out what he's up to, let me know."
[1963-12-20T14:00:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I saw her and then we parted ways. I ran to give a Greek lesson to a high school girl living in Margaret Park, but I was received politely. I thought about it, but my thoughts were hard to calm down.
[1963-12-20T14:10:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I saw that in the somewhat dim large room, there were many luxurious furnishings. The floor was covered with a carpet whose pattern depicted scenes of hunting, along with old photographs of high-ranking officers, and various symbols showcasing the authority and wealth of this family. I thought about all this and it made my fourteen-year-old student mentally and physically sluggish, and I found it unbearable as well.
[1963-12-20T14:30:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I realized that, in the circumstances, I had to be very careful with my word choices and verb conjugations. I thought of how I kept recalling the image of Nino as described by Professor Galiani: wearing an old, worn-out coat, a crumpled tie, walking with long legs that stumbled awkwardly, holding an empty bottle, and then smashing it against a rock on the roadside after drinking from it.
[1963-12-20T15:00:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I wondered what happened between him and Lina after Vomero? Perhaps everything was completely different from what I had expected. It was obvious that she regretted it, everything was over, and she had returned to her old life.
[1963-12-20T15:10:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I thought about it, but Nino could never go back to the past. He had turned from a young scholar who could provide detailed answers to everything in the world into a decadent, abandoned man, because his love for the boss of Capodimonte had ended in failure.
[1963-12-20T16:00:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I thought to myself that when I met Alfonso Carracci, I would ask him if there was any news about Nino. I wanted to go find Pinocchia and get information about her brother, but I forced myself to push him out of my mind.
[1963-12-20T16:10:00] Margaret Park Student's Home | I thought this would pass. I thought, did he look for me? No. Did Lina look for me? No. Why should I worry about him, and about her? When have they ever worried about me? I'll just keep going to class and follow my own path.
[1963-12-22 10:00:00] Street | I decided to tell her the gossip I'd heard, so she could prepare for whatever might happen, but I found out she already knew about it.
[1963-12-22 10:00:10] Street | I thought not only that, but she knew much better what it meant to play the flute.
[1963-12-22 10:00:20] Street | I realized, she said in a very clear way, that she would never do that for any man, she found it disgusting, let alone Marcello.
[1963-12-22 10:00:30] Street | I saw her at the end and she told me that all those words had reached Stefano's ears.
[1963-12-22 10:00:40] Street | I know he asked Lina about what their relationship was during the time Marcello went to her house.
[1963-12-22 10:00:50] Street | I saw her answering very angrily. I heard, "There's no relation at all! Are you crazy?"
[1963-12-22 10:01:00] Street | I saw Stefano immediately say that he believed Lina, that he had never doubted her, and that he had only asked the question to let her know that Marcello was spreading rumors about her.

[1964-08-30T17:01:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her trying to ask Alfonso Carracci, asking him if Pinocchia knew when her brother would return from Vomero. I thought about it, but she was worried that her brother-in-law might tell her husband, so she didn't ask.

[1964-08-30T17:03:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about how desperate she was, even to the point of wanting to take a boat to Vomero.
[1964-08-31T20:00:00] My home | At the end of August, I realized I had made a lot of money, totaling seventy-seven thousand lira. I gave fifty thousand lira to my mother.
[1964-08-31T20:05:00] My kitchen | I saw her almost snatch the money from my hands and hide it in her bra. I saw her reaction was very exaggerated, as if we weren't in our own kitchen, but on the street. I thought about how she was worried the money might be stolen.
[1964-08-31T20:10:00] My home | I saw that I had left myself two million lira, and I hid the money.
[1964-09-01 10:00:00] Mergellina | I thought about it for a while, but I never found the right moment to talk to him.
[1964-09-01 10:00:10] Mergellina | I saw he was worried because Melina's condition usually worsened in the heat. I thought about how this deterioration would become very obvious in late August.
[1964-09-01 10:00:20] Mergellina | I saw her again and thought of Nino—the one she called Donato. I heard her say she saw Donato, that he had come back for her, and none of the children could calm her down.
[1964-09-01 10:00:30] Mergellina | I felt sad thinking about it, because if Nino really appeared on Mergellina's street, he would be looking for me, not for Melina.
[1964-09-01 23:00:00] My room | I saw at night, sometimes I would suddenly wake up. I thought he had somehow crawled in through the window and was staying in my room.
[1964-09-01 23:30:00] My room | I thought about it until I finally calmed down, and I told myself he might be in Balano, on vacation at the Maronti beach, instead of here, where the weather was so hot and everywhere full of flies and dust.
[1964-09-01T20:00:00] My home | I didn't tell the people from Posillipo that I was going to Borgo for an exam until the day before I left. "I said, 'If they accept me, I'll go to school and it won't cost my family a penny.'"
[1964-09-01T20:01:00] My home | I saw myself speaking in Italian, saying it firmly. I thought that speaking in dialect would make these words less meaningful, as if my father, mother, and younger brother and sister shouldn't, and couldn't, understand what I was doing.
[1964-09-01T20:02:00] My home | I saw that they were actually uncomfortable when I said these things to them. I thought that in their eyes, I was no longer myself, but a stranger who had come to visit at the wrong time.
[1964-09-01T20:05:00] My home | I saw him until my father said, then he went to sleep. I heard, "Do whatever you want, but remember, we can't help you." My younger sister asked if she could go with me.
[1964-09-02T06:00:00] My home | I said nothing to my mother, but before leaving, she put five thousand lire on the table for me.
[1964-09-02T06:05:00] My home | I stared at the money for a long time, I didn't touch it. I thought about how it was as if I were going to take that money and waste it, doing something reckless.
[1964-09-02T06:10:00] My home | I saw it through, and still managed to break through my psychological barrier; I took the money. I thought to myself: This is my money!
[1964-09-02T07:00:00] On the train | I know I'm leaving San Gregorio Armeno for the first time, leaving the Campania region. I thought about how I had come to fear everything: I was afraid of taking the wrong train, afraid of needing to urinate but not finding a restroom, worried that if it got dark, I'd get lost in an unfamiliar city, worried about being robbed.
[1964-09-02T08:00:00] On the train | I saw that, just like my mother, I had put all my money in my bra. I thought about it for several hours, spending them in a state of anxious uncertainty, yet I also felt strangely free.
[1964-09-03 09:00:00] Street | I was out getting something when I heard someone calling me. I turned around.
[1964-09-03 09:00:10] Street | I didn't recognize him at first, but then I looked more carefully. I saw his black beard, his tanned, sharply defined face, and his thin lips.
[1964-09-03 09:00:20] Street | I took a step back, and he followed.
[1964-09-03 09:00:30] Street | I heard him say that he hadn't found me at Balano's house, at Nella's, and he was sad.
[1964-09-03 09:00:40] Street | I heard him say that he had been thinking of me all along, and that he didn't know how to live without me.
[1964-09-03 09:00:50] Street | I heard him say that for our love, he would write many poems and read them to me.
[1964-09-03 09:01:00] Street | I heard him say he wanted to see me, to talk to me without any restraint. If I refused him, he would [tragic event].
[1964-09-03 09:01:10] Street | I saw myself stop, and I said to him word by word. I heard him say, "Please don't bother me anymore. I already have a boyfriend. I don't want to see him again."
[1964-09-03 09:01:20] Street | I saw him getting really frustrated, and he muttered that he would wait for me forever, that every noon he would be waiting for me at the entrance to the main road Mercato. I heard myself shake my head firmly and say, "I will never go there."
[1964-09-03 09:01:30] Street | I saw him coming toward me to [intimate act], so I took a step back. I thought of a face full of hatred.
[1964-09-03 09:01:40] Street | I saw him give a helpless smile and whisper. I heard, "You are very talented, very sensitive. I will bring you some of my favorite poems."
[1964-09-03 09:01:50] Street | I saw it and then turned and walked away.
[1964-09-03 10:00:00] Street | I thought about how terrified I was, not knowing what to do. I decided to seek help from Antonio.
[1964-09-03 20:00:00] By the pond | I heard that night, by the pond, I told him, she was right—Donato Nino was hanging around in this Mergellina, he stopped me on the way and told me to tell Melina that he would be waiting for her, that every day at noon he would be waiting for her at the entrance of Mercato.
[1964-09-03 20:00:10] By the pond | I saw Antonio's face grow dark. I heard him say in a low voice, "What should I do?"
[1964-09-03 20:00:20] By the pond | I heard myself say to him that I would go with him to the meeting, and that we would clear things up with Nino and talk about his mother's current health condition.
[1964-09-03T09:00:00] Borgo | I knew the teacher with the sky-blue hair hadn't told me that this exam would be harder than the high school graduation exam, especially Latin, which was absolutely impossible for me, but that was just the tip of the iceberg. I thought I felt everything was getting better—except for the exams; each exam was a cruel test of my abilities.
[1964-09-03T10:00:00] Exam Room 004 | I saw myself becoming hesitant and stammering, I often pretended to know the answer but couldn't get it out.

[1964-09-03T11:00:00] Exam Room Borgo | I heard him say, "Miss, when you write an essay, you're not really arguing—you're just talking nonsense. I see you're boldly discussing some issues, but you completely ignore the structure an article should have." I saw that my Chinese teacher's attitude toward me was terrible, as if my voice also annoyed him.
[1964-09-03T11:05:00] Exam Room 004 | I saw that the teacher had noticed it too. He looked at me with a mocking expression and told me to talk about the books I'd read recently. I thought I felt depressed, my confidence completely gone. I imagined that what he had said was about the work of some Italian writer, but I hadn't understood it at the time.
[1964-09-03T11:10:00] Exam Room 004 | I saw myself clinging to something that flashed through my mind—only Samuel Beckett's Dan Rooney, which I had read on Cetrara Beach, and I began to speak. I know that the blind man Dan Rooney, even though he was already blind, still wanted to become deaf and mute...
[1964-09-03T11:15:00] Exam Room Borgo | I saw him cut me off quickly and hand me over to the history teacher. I saw the teacher's mocking expression, and I gradually became uneasy and confused.
[1964-09-03T12:00:00] Exam Room 004 | I saw the history teacher asking me a series of detailed questions. I thought the situation hadn't improved at all. In the end, I had never felt as ignorant as I did then. Even in the years when I was studying the worst and performing the worst on exams, my situation had never been so desperate.
[1964-09-03T12:15:00] Exam Room Borgo | I could answer all the questions, but in a very general way; as soon as he asked me a more specific question, I couldn't answer.
[1964-09-03T12:20:00] Exam Room 004 | I heard him say, full of disgust, "Other than school textbooks, have you never read anything else?" I replied, "I studied the concept of the nation-state."
[1964-09-03T12:21:00] Exam Room 004 | I heard him say, "Let's see how much you understood." He listened carefully to me for a few minutes, then suddenly told me to stop. I heard, "Do you remember the author of the book?" "Federico Cappo." I thought about how I had said a lot of foolish things.
[1964-09-03T13:00:00] Borgo | I saw that I had been crying for a long time. I thought, feeling that because of my recklessness, I had personally thrown away my future.
[1964-09-03T13:05:00] Borgo | I thought, then I thought again: it was foolish of me to be so desperate. I knew all along that I was never really outstanding; Lina was truly outstanding, and Nino too. I was just vain, and now I've been punished for it.
[1964-09-04 02:00:00] Posillipo | I thought about it all night and couldn't sleep because I was so worried.
[1964-09-04 12:00:00] Mercato | I saw that the next day we went to Mercato.
[1964-09-04 12:00:10] Mercato | I saw Antonio say nothing, walking slowly and calmly. I thought I sensed his heavy mood, his steps growing slower and slower.
[1964-09-04 12:00:20] Mercato | I thought, on one hand, he was very angry; on the other hand, he felt extremely uncomfortable.
[1964-09-04 12:00:30] Mercato | I thought, angry with myself: He had been willing to challenge the Solara brothers for his sister, for Lina, but now he had become timid. Donato Nino was an important and respected figure in his eyes.
[1964-09-04 12:00:40] Mercato | I saw and felt his shyness, which made me more determined. I really wanted to shake him. I thought of shouting at him: "You've never written a book, but you're far better than that man!"
[1964-09-04 12:00:50] Mercato | I saw it, but I just held his arm.
[1964-09-04 12:01:00] Mercato | I saw Nino spotting us from afar and wanted to vanish immediately into the darkness of Mercato.
[1964-09-04 12:01:10] Mercato | I heard myself calling out to him: "Mr. Nino."
[1964-09-04 12:01:20] Mercato | I saw him reluctantly turn around.
[1964-09-04 12:01:30] Mercato | I heard, "I don't know, do you remember Antonio? He was Mrs. Melina's oldest son." I knew I was addressing him with respect, and in our circumstances at that time, this wasn't very common.
[1964-09-04 12:01:40] Mercato | I heard Nino speaking in a feigned voice, full of emotion: "Of course I remember. Hello, Antonio."
[1964-09-04 12:01:50] Mercato | I heard, "He's my boyfriend."
[1964-09-04 12:02:00] Mercato | I heard, "Ah! Very good."
[1964-09-04 12:02:10] Mercato | I heard, "We've talked a lot already, now let him speak to you."
[1964-09-04 12:02:20] Mercato | I saw Antonio understand that it was his turn to speak, his face very pale and his expression very tense.
[1964-09-04 12:02:30] Mercato | I heard him speak in standard Italian, struggling to say: "It's a pleasure to meet you, Mr. Nino. I can't forget all that you did for my family after my father died."
[1964-09-04 12:02:40] Mercato | I heard, "I especially want to thank you for arranging for me to work at Mr. Gherasio's garage, where I learned a trade."
[1964-09-04 12:02:50] Mercato | I heard, "Tell him about your mother." I thought to myself, I was very impatient and reminded him.
[1964-09-04 12:03:00] Mercato | I saw that he was also upset, and he gestured for me to be quiet. I heard him continue: "But you don't live in this neighborhood anymore. You don't understand the situation. Just hearing your name would drive my mother crazy. If she saw you again, even once, she'd end up in the asylum."
[1964-09-04 12:03:10] Mercato | I saw Nino looking a bit flustered. I heard, "Antonio, my child, I never meant to hurt your mother. You mentioned it yourself, how much I care about you all. Actually, I just wanted to help her, and your whole family."
[1964-09-04 12:03:20] Mercato | I heard, "So, if you're going to continue helping her, don't look for her anymore, don't send her books, don't let her see you in this Mergellina."
[1964-09-04 12:03:30] Mercato | "I can't ask you for that. You can't stop me from seeing the place I'm attached to." Nino said in a heated voice, laced with insincere emotion.
[1964-09-04 12:03:40] Mercato | I thought of that tone, and it made me angry. I knew that tone well—back in Balano, on the beach at Maronti, he often used it. It was a soft, sticky tone.
[1964-09-04 12:03:50] Mercato | I thought he saw himself as a man with depth, someone who had written a book of poetry and published articles in the newspaper; he thought he should speak in that kind of tone.
[1964-09-04 12:04:00] Mercato | I was about to speak, but to my surprise, Antonio spoke first.
[1964-09-04 12:04:10] Mercato | I saw him shrug his shoulders, lower his head, and stretch out a hand, pushing Donato Nino's chest with his strong fingers.
[1964-09-04 12:04:20] Mercato | I heard him speak in the local dialect: "I won't stop you. But I assure you, if you make my mother lose the last of her sanity, I'll make sure you never want to see this damn place again!"
[1964-09-04 12:04:30] Mercato | I saw Nino turn very pale.
[1964-09-04 12:04:40] Mercato | "I see," he said hurriedly, "I understand, thank you."
[1964-09-04 12:04:50] Mercato | I saw him turn and walk quickly toward the train station.
[1964-09-04 12:05:00] Mercato | I saw myself holding Antonio's arm, proud of his efforts, but I noticed he was trembling.
[1964-09-04 12:05:10] Mercato | I thought about what I thought--perhaps it was the first time I had ever thought, from childhood on, first his father's death, then work, and after his mother's breakdown, the burden that fell upon his shoulders.
[1964-09-04 12:05:20] Mercato | I saw myself lovingly pulling him away. I thought to myself that I had set another deadline—I would break up with him after Lina got married.

[1964-09-05T10:00:00] Borgo | I saw that I would have my own room, my own bed that wouldn't have to be set up at night and taken down in the morning, and a desk along with all the books I needed. I knew, but in reality, I passed the exam later.
[1964-09-05T10:05:00] Borgo | I knew I—Elena Greco, daughter of a building superintendent—would finally be free of this Mergellina at nineteen, I was leavin gSan Gregorio Armeno, all alone!
[1964-09-15 10:00:00] Mergellina | I know that wedding is unforgettable for everyone in the neighborhood. The preparation for the wedding and the long, meticulous, and contentious creation of "Lina" shoes were intertwined, as if, for different reasons, both things were always difficult to complete.
[1964-09-15 10:00:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I knew that, in addition to everything else, this wedding would have a big impact on the shoe shop. Fernando and Rino had been working hard to make the new shoes, and up until then, they hadn't made any money from it.
[1964-09-15 10:00:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I know that they also have to be busy with countless other small tasks, those that can bring immediate profit, because they are in urgent need of money.
[1964-09-15 10:00:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I knew they would raise a considerable amount of money for Lina's dowry, in addition to covering the costs of the wedding banquet.
[1964-09-15 10:00:40] Lina's house | I know they tried every possible way not to appear too poor at that moment, and the result was that for several months, the atmosphere in Lina's house remained tense.
[1964-09-15 10:00:50] Lina's house | I know that Nunzia has been stitching bed linens day and night, and Fernando has been complaining, sighing, full of regret, saying how happy his previous times were, when in his little shop he was a king, with a pin in his mouth, calmly applying glue, sewing, and hammering.
[1964-09-20 16:00:00] Lina's house | I know that the only happy couple is the newlyweds.
[1964-09-20 16:00:10] Lina's house | I know there were only two small conflicts between them. The first was about their future house. Stefano wanted to buy a place in the new neighborhood, while Lina preferred an apartment in the old building.
[1964-09-20 16:00:20] Lina's House | I know they discussed it. The Mergellina house was big, but the lighting was bad and the view wasn't good either. Most of the houses at Mergellina were like that.
[1964-09-20 16:00:30] New Community | I knew the new apartment was a bit small, but there was a huge bathtub in it, just like the one in the "Santoor" bathroom ad, and there was also a bidet. The windows faced Mount Vesuvius.
[1964-09-20 16:00:40] New Community | I know that from a distance, under the misty sky, Mount Vesuvius is just a dim silhouette, and only a hundred meters away from the house, the shiny iron tracks are constantly filled with trains coming and going.
[1964-09-20 16:00:50] New Community | I knew Stefano was fascinated by the new neighborhood, with its polished floors and white walls, and Lina quickly gave in.
[1964-09-20 16:01:00] New Community | I don't need to say anything else—she'll own her own house before she's seventeen, with hot water flowing from the taps, and the house won't be rented, it'll be hers to buy.
[1964-09-20 16:01:10] Lina's house | I know that the second conflict arose over the honeymoon trip. Stefano suggested going to Venice, and Lina proposed a route she liked, which had an important impact on her later life; she never wanted to be far away from San Gregorio Armeno.
[1964-09-20 16:01:20] Lina's house | I knew she suggested going to Vomero, or maybe Vomero, saying the Amalfi Coast was also an option—those were places she'd never been to, and her fiancé immediately agreed.
[1964-09-30 16:00:00] Shoe Repair Shop | I know the rest are all small issues, all caused by the difference in their family backgrounds.
[1964-09-30 16:00:10] Shoe Repair Shop | I know, for example, that after Stefano went to Lina's workshop, things always ended up like this: when he saw Lina again, he would scold Fernando and Rino a bit, sometimes saying harsh things, which made her feel bad and she would defend them.
[1964-09-30 16:00:20] Shoe Repair Shop | I knew he would shake his head in frustration, beginning to feel that too much money was being spent on shoes, with no return yet in sight.
[1964-09-30 16:00:30] Shoe Repair Shop | I knew that when summer was about to end, the conflict between him and Lina's father escalated. He set a deadline for Lina, her father, and a few apprentices, saying that by November he wanted to see the initial results, at least the winter shoe designs, both men's and women's, displayed in the window before Christmas.
[1964-09-30 16:00:40] Lina's house | I know that in the end, he was also very frustrated, and he couldn't help but say to Lina that Rino only wanted money and never thought about working. Lina defended her brother, but Stefano refuted her, and finally Lina lost her temper. Then Stefano immediately gave in.
[1964-09-30 20:00:00] The rooftop of the old house | I saw him take out the first pair of shoes he had made, the ones he had never worn after buying them. They were a very precious token in their love story.
[1964-09-30 20:00:10] The rooftop of the old house | I saw him touching the shoes and sniffing them with his nose. I heard her say, deeply moved, that through these shoes he could feel and see the image of Lina's little hands working together with her brother.
[1964-09-30 20:00:20] The rooftop of the old house | I saw them then, standing on the rooftop of the old house. I know it's the place where they had the fireworks competition with the Solara brothers.
[1964-09-30 20:00:30] The rooftop of the old house | I saw him take her hand, pressing each finger one by one in a tender way. I heard him say that he would never again allow these hands to do hard work.
[1964-10-01 10:00:00] New House | When I told her about Stefano's act of love, Lina was happy. These were the things she said to me when she took me to visit their new home.
[1964-10-01 10:00:10] New House | I saw the house and it was really great: the tile floor gleamed, the bathtub was perfect for bubble baths, the dining room and bedroom were furnished with carved wooden furniture, and there was even a refrigerator and a telephone.
[1964-10-01 10:00:20] New House | I was so excited that I wrote down her phone number. I thought about how we were both born and grew up in small houses, without our own rooms, not even a place to study. I still live in the small house where I was born, but she does not.
[1964-10-01 10:00:30] New Room Balcony | I saw that we had arrived at the balcony. I saw the balcony facing the railway and Mount Vesuvius.
[1964-10-01 10:00:40] New Room Balcony | I heard myself asking her carefully, "Will you come here alone with Stefano?"
[1964-10-01 10:00:50] New Room Balcony | I heard, "Sometimes it does."
[1964-10-01 10:01:00] New Room Balcony | I heard, "What's going to happen?"
[1964-10-01 10:01:10] New Room Balcony | I saw her looking at me as if she didn't understand a word I said. I heard, "What do you mean by that?"
[1964-10-01 10:01:20] New Room Balcony | I heard, "Did you [intimate things]?" I thought I felt a bit embarrassed.
[1964-10-01 10:01:30] New Room Balcony | I heard, "Sometimes it does."
[1964-10-01 10:01:40] New Room Balcony | "I heard 'And then?'"
[1964-10-01 10:01:50] New Room Balcony | I heard, "There's no 'then,' we're not even married yet."
[1964-10-01 10:02:00] New Room Balcony | I thought I was getting confused: they had so much freedom, but nothing really happened—how was that possible? There were so many rumors about her in the neighborhood, and the Solara brothers had even revealed some indecent details, yet they just went on with [intimate acts]?
[1964-10-01 10:02:10] New Room Balcony | I heard, "He doesn't ask you?"
[1964-10-01 10:02:20] New Room Balcony | I heard, "Why, did Antonio ask you to?"
[1964-10-01 10:02:30] New Room Balcony | I heard, "Yes."
[1964-10-01 10:02:40] New Room Balcony | I heard, "He doesn't ask me. We agreed, first we have to get married."
[1964-10-01 10:02:50] New Room Balcony | I thought my question had surprised her, just as her answer had surprised me. So she didn't give anything to Stefano, even though they went out alone in the car, even though they were about to get married and already had a fully renovated house, the mattress on their bed was still unopened.
[1964-10-01 10:03:00] New Room Balcony | I thought about it, but the subject of marriage had never even been mentioned, and my experience had long since gone beyond just [intimate acts].
[1964-10-01 10:03:10] New Room Balcony | I saw her ask me—purely out of curiosity—whether I had given Antonio what he wanted. I couldn't bring myself to tell her the truth, so I said there wasn't any.
[1964-10-01 10:03:20] New Room Balcony | I saw that she looked happy about the answer.
locations: The rooftop of the old house

text:
[1964-10-05 10:00:00] By the pond | I knew our dates by the pond became less frequent because school was coming up.
[1964-10-05 10:00:10] Posillipo | I thought about my classes and homework, and I was sure Lina would exclude me from the wedding preparations, as she had gotten used to me disappearing for a while after school started.
[1964-10-05 10:00:20] Capodimonte | I know, but this time is different—Lina's relationship with Pinocchio has become more tense, not just about clothes, hats, scarves, or jewelry anymore.
[1964-10-08 10:00:00] Capodimonte | I once saw Pinocchio clearly tell Lina's brother in front of Lina. I heard that his future wife will work in Capodimonte, either starting immediately or after the honeymoon. She should work like everyone else, just like Alfonso Carracci, who always helped out in the store whenever school was out.
[1964-10-08 10:00:10] Capodimonte | I heard that if his fiancée doesn't work, then she won't work either. I knew that Pinocchio's mother was openly supporting her daughter this time.
[1964-10-08 10:00:20] Capodimonte | I saw Lina not blink at all; she could start working right away, whatever the Caracci family wanted her to do, she could begin the next day.
[1964-10-08 10:00:30] Capodimonte | I thought of this answer as the way Lina used to speak, and even though she tried to use a calm and gentle tone, it still revealed an unyielding arrogance and a sneer at those who provoked her, which only further angered Pinocchia.
[1964-10-08 10:00:40] Capodimonte | I thought it was obvious that, in the eyes of the mother and daughter, the cobbler's daughter was a witch, come to take over their home. She wouldn't lift a finger to earn money, but she spent it like water. She had the men in the family completely under her spell, making them act unjustly toward their own blood relatives—his own sister, even his mother.
[1964-10-08 10:00:50] Capodimonte | I saw that Stefano still had the same attitude as before, not answering immediately but waiting for his sister to finish venting her anger. I thought that, in the end, the issue of Lina and her role in this small family business had never really come up.
[1964-10-08 10:01:00] Capodimonte | I heard him say calmly that it was better for Pinocchio to be working at Capodimonte than to help his fiancée prepare for the wedding.
[1964-10-08 10:01:10] Capodimonte | "I no longer have a place here?" my sister asked immediately.
[1964-10-08 10:01:20] Capodimonte | I heard, "No need. From tomorrow on, I'll have Melina's daughter Pinocchia take over your job."
[1964-10-08 10:01:30] Capodimonte | "I guess she suggested it, didn't she?" Pinochia shouted, pointing at Lina.
[1964-10-08 10:01:40] Capodimonte | I heard, "That's none of your business."
[1964-10-08 10:01:50] Capodimonte | "I heard it, Mom, did you hear what he said? He thinks he's the master here, the only master!"
[1964-10-08 10:02:00] Capodimonte | I saw Maria finally stand up from the stool behind the counter and say to her son. I heard, "You're also going to find someone to take my place, I'm tired and don't want to work hard anymore." I saw that what followed was an unbearable silence.
[1964-10-08 10:02:10] Capodimonte | At that moment, Stefano made a concession, he said slowly. I heard, "Let's be quiet. I'm not the owner. Actually, this Capodimonte isn't just my own affair—it involves all of us. We need to make a decision."
[1964-10-08 10:02:20] Capodimonte | "I heard, 'Pinocchio, do you need work? No. Mom, do you need to sit behind the counter every day? No.'"

[1965-03-12 12:20:30] In Pasquale's car | I thought about being with them, and I realized that all the things I had learned in my daily life were of no use. I had to restrain myself and lower myself to fit in with them.
