[1967-03-15T21:05:00] Mergellina | I thought to myself that I felt as if I had returned to the stage of being with Antonio, even though they were very different. Going out at night with Pietro's son excited me, and I could draw strength from him.
[1967-03-20T10:00:00] Borgo | I sometimes wanted to find a public phone and call Lina. I wanted to tell her that I now have a new boyfriend, and I'm almost certain our graduation thesis will be published, turned into a book.
[1967-03-20T10:05:00] Borgo | I thought of telling her that we both could end up teaching at the university, because her sister Mariarosa was already teaching there at twenty-four.
[1967-03-20T10:10:00] Borgo | I wanted to tell her: Lina, you're right. If you learn something from a young age, you'll be confident in every aspect when you grow up, as if you were born knowing it. But in the end, I gave up.
[1967-03-20T10:15:00] Borgo | Why did I call her? Just to silently listen to what was happening in her life? If she were to listen to me, what would I tell her?
[1967-03-20T10:20:00] Borgo | I thought to myself that I clearly knew that whatever had happened to Pietro would never happen to me.
[1967-03-20T10:25:00] Borgo | I saw the two of us sitting together in the dark alley, on the grass. I thought, especially knowing that he would disappear from my life like Franco Mari. Anyway, it was probably good that it ended this way, because I didn't love him, just so I wouldn't be so scared.
[1967-03-20T15:00:00] Staircase landing | I saw him for the last time when he met his wife, shouting at her angrily. I heard, "You're a disgrace to your family. Your mother doesn't even want to see you anymore."
[1967-03-20T15:05:00] Stair landing | I heard, "That's because they don't understand what kind of life I and you are living." "I treat you like a queen." "I'd rather be a beggar."
[1967-03-20T15:10:00] Stair Landing | "I heard, 'If you [become pregnant], you must [abort], because officially you're still my wife. I don't want a child born to you who would take my name.'"
[1967-03-20T15:15:00] Stair landing | I heard, "I won't have any other children." "Why? Have you already decided not to bother?" "Go to hell."
[1967-03-20T15:20:00] Stair landing | I heard, "I've already greeted you." "In any case, little Rino isn't your son, but he still takes your name."
[1967-03-20T15:25:00] Stair landing | I heard, "You bitch, if you keep saying things like that, it's really over. I'll never want to see you again, nor him."
[1967-03-20T15:30:00] Stair landing | I realized that, in truth, he had always been certain that little Rino was his son. But he was pretending, driven by an opportunistic thought—he preferred to live a quiet life, and he wanted to keep himself from the emotional turmoil Lina caused.
[1967-04-01T20:00:00] Mercato | I saw Lina carefully describe to Enzo her husband's visit, and Enzo would listen very attentively, rarely offering any comments.
[1967-04-01T20:05:00] Mercato | I know he's a man of few words; he never told Lina anything about his work, what he did in the factory, whether he was happy or not.
[1967-04-01T20:10:00] Mercato | I watched as she finished dinner, played with the children for a while, and listened to Lina talk. I know he left home at six in the morning and came back at seven in the evening.
[1967-04-01T20:15:00] Mercato | I saw that whenever Lina said the child needed something, the next day he would find a way to get the money needed.
[1967-04-01T20:20:00] Mercato | I saw him looking at her, and he never once told her she should go to Stefano for money, to support the child, he never once told her she should get a job. I thought that his only reason for living was to come home at night and sit in the kitchen with her, listening to her talk.
[1967-04-01T21:00:00] Mercato | I saw him stand up at last and lock himself in the bedroom. I heard the words "Good night."
[1967-04-10T21:00:00] Hidden Place | I saw our only commonality was our mutual affection in the darkness when it got dark. I thought he would rub against me and pant, but he didn't ask for anything more.
[1967-04-20T10:00:00] Dormitory Borgo | I felt so oppressed that for a while I couldn't continue writing my thesis. I looked at the lines of text on the page, but I couldn't make sense of a single word.
[1967-04-20T10:10:00] Dormitory Borgo | I saw myself lying in bed, staring at the ceiling, thinking about what to do. I thought that in the end, I would give in, and after graduation, I would return to my birthplace, back to that Mergellina, and teach at a secondary school.
[1967-04-20T10:15:00] Dormitory 004 | I wanted to be a middle school teacher, yes, higher in rank than Teacher Oliviero, on par with Teacher Galiani, or perhaps just slightly lower, like Teacher Greco.
[1967-04-20T10:20:00] Dormitory Borgo | I thought that in Mergellina, everyone would see me as an important person, the daughter of a gatekeeper, who was eager to learn from a young age and eventually succeeded in her studies.
[1967-04-20T10:25:00] Dormitory Borgo | I realized that only after becoming familiar with Borgo, after meeting those important professors, after meeting Pietro, Mariarosa, and their father, did I clearly understand that I couldn't go very far.
[1967-04-20T10:30:00] Dormitory Borgo | I thought about the great effort I had made, the many hopes and beautiful moments I had experienced, and I would always cherish the wonderful time I spent with Franco Mari.
[1967-04-20T10:35:00] Dormitory Borgo | I think back to those years, to those happy times, and how wonderful it was being with him. At the time, I didn't realize how important he was. Now, I'm becoming more and more depressed.
[1967-04-20T10:40:00] Dormitory Borgo | I saw rain, snow, and cold days, the breath of spring along the Arno Riverbank, the city's flower-filled paths, and the warmth passed on to us. We went together to choose clothes and glasses, and he took great interest in improving me.
[1967-04-20T10:45:00] Dormitory Borgo | I know we're in Paris, on this exciting trip abroad, in cafés, politics, literature. Although the working class is gradually coming to terms with reality, a revolution is about to come. I thought of him, of his room at night, his body.
[1967-04-20T10:50:00] Dormitory Borgo | I saw that everything had ended, and I lay anxiously on my small bed, unable to fall asleep as I tossed and turned. I thought to myself, maybe I was just deceiving myself—were things really that good?
[1967-04-20T10:55:00] Dormitory 004 | I thought I clearly knew that at that time, I also felt ashamed, uncomfortable, humiliated, and nauseated. I accepted, endured, and forced myself to do so.
[1967-04-20T11:00:00] Dormitory Borgo | I thought even the happiest moments couldn't stand up to close scrutiny. Wasn't it possible that everything was just an illusion?!
[1967-04-20T11:05:00] Dormitory Borgo | I thought it was likely that whatever had happened in the darkness of Maronti Beach would soon spread to Franco Mari, even to Pietro, and I didn't want to remember any of it.
[1967-05-01T10:00:00] Borgo | I noticed that for a while, I saw Pietro less often. I made up an excuse that my thesis was behind schedule and I feared I wouldn't be able to finish on time.
[1967-05-05T09:00:00] Dormitory 004 | I saw that one morning, I bought a grid notebook and started writing about things that happened to me in Balano in the third person, and also wrote about things that happened in Vomero in the third person.
[1967-05-05T09:05:00] Dormitory Borgo | I saw the end, where I told about San Gregorio Armeno and my life in Mergellina, and I changed the names of people, places, and the background of the story.
[1967-05-05T09:10:00] Dormitory Borgo | I thought about how the protagonist's life concealed a dark force, an entity that had welded the surrounding world to her body, glowing with the color of a blowtorch's flame, a purplish-blue tip. Every thing she liked would spark and burst forth, but soon fall to the ground, turning into gray clumps that meant nothing.
[1967-05-15T16:00:00] St. John Street | I saw later that Lina met a man who would have a great impact on her life. One afternoon, she left the child in the care of the female neighbor and went out alone.
[1967-05-15T16:05:00] St. John Street | I saw her hear the sound of car horns behind her, and someone was waving at her from the car window. I saw that it was a very luxurious car.

[1967-05-15T16:10:00] Saint John Street | I saw "Lina."
[1967-05-15T16:15:00] St. John Street | I saw her look at the man very carefully. I thought she recognized it as Bruno Socavo's—Nino's friend's wolf-like face.
[1967-05-15T16:20:00] Saint John Street | I heard him ask, "What are you doing here?" "I live here," I said.
[1967-05-15T16:25:00] Saint John Street | I know that at the time, she didn't talk much about her own life. In those days, these things were hard to explain. She didn't mention Nino, and Bruno didn't either.
[1967-05-15T16:30:00] St. John Street | I saw her ask if Bruno had graduated from university, and he just said he had decided not to continue his studies.
[1967-05-15T16:35:00] Saint John Street | I heard, "Are you married?" "No."
[1967-05-15T16:40:00] Saint John Street | I heard, "Do you have a girlfriend?" "Sometimes I do, sometimes I don't."
[1967-05-15T16:45:00] Saint John Street | I heard, "What are you doing?" "Nothing much, someone is working for me."
[1967-05-15T16:50:00] Saint John Street | I saw her almost jokingly ask him. I heard, "Can you find me a job?"
[1967-05-15T16:55:00] St. John Street | "I heard, 'Getting you a job? Do you really need it?' 'I want to work.'"
[1967-05-15T17:00:00] St. John Street | I heard, "Do you want to be sausage and ham?" "Why not?"
[1967-05-15T17:05:00] Saint John Street | I heard, "Where's your husband?" "I don't have a husband anymore, but I have a son to raise."
[1967-05-15T17:10:00] St. John Street | I saw Bruno looking at her closely, trying to figure out if she was joking. He was confused and just replied evasively. I heard, "That's not much of a job."
[1967-05-15T17:15:00] Café | I saw him invite Lina into the café and continue talking about his own things. I know, and then he talked about the many problems that can arise between a couple. His mother had been constantly arguing with his father, and recently he'd become obsessed with a married woman, but she dumped him.
[1967-05-15T17:45:00] Café | I saw that in the end Lina said she was leaving, and Bruno asked her. I heard, "You really left your husband? You really have a child?" "Yes."
[1967-05-15T17:50:00] Café | I saw him frowning and writing something on a napkin. I heard, "You go find this man, he'll be there starting at eight in the morning. Have him look at this."
[1967-05-15T17:55:00] Café | I saw Lina smile awkwardly. I heard, "This napkin?" "Yes." "That's enough?"
[1967-05-15T18:00:00] Café | I saw and heard the mocking tone in her voice, and he nodded, suddenly becoming shy, muttering something under his breath. I heard, "That was a very beautiful summer."
[1967-05-15T18:05:00] Café | I heard her say, "It's the same for me too."
[1967-05-25T10:00:00] Dormitory Borgo | I saw that I had spent twenty days writing this story, and during that time I hadn't met anyone, only going out to eat.
[1967-05-25T10:05:00] Dormitory 004 | I read what I had written again at the end, and I didn't like it at all, so I put it down. I thought I had calmed down a bit, as if that feeling of shame had shifted from me onto the notebook.
[1967-05-25T10:10:00] Borgo | I saw myself back in my daily life, I quickly finished my paper, and then met with Pietro.
[1967-06-15T10:00:00] Borgo | I was moved by his friendliness and the encouragement he gave me.
[1967-06-20T10:00:00] Borgo | When I saw him graduate, everyone came, including many of his parents' friends from Borgo. I thought, to my surprise, that I no longer felt any hostility toward everything Pietro was facing, nor toward his life plan.
[1967-06-20T10:05:00] Borgo | I saw the opposite, and I was happy he was so lucky. I was very grateful to his family for inviting me to their celebration, especially Mariarosa, who took such good care of me. I thought about how we had passionately discussed the provisional government established by the Greek Fascist.
[1967-07-05T10:00:00] Borgo | I saw that I was in the second batch of graduation defenses, and I didn't tell my parents. I thought about how I was worried that my mother felt obligated to come celebrate for me.
[1967-07-05T10:05:00] Borgo | I saw myself wearing the clothes Franco Mari bought for me to attend the defense. I thought that the dress was acceptable, and after a long time, I finally felt satisfied with myself.
[1967-07-05T10:10:00] Borgo | I know that by the time I was twenty-three, I had already graduated from university with a degree in literature, and I graduated with a perfect score of 110 out of 100.
[1967-07-05T10:15:00] Borgo | I know my father only went to the fifth grade of elementary school, and my mother only reached the second grade. As far as I know, none of my ancestors ever seriously studied or wrote. I thought to myself that I had really done something remarkable.
[1967-07-05T13:00:00] Borgo | I saw that Pietro had also come to celebrate with me, besides a few of the girls in our class. I saw that I remembered the day was very hot.
[1967-07-05T17:00:00] Dormitory Borgo | I had attended the school's ceremony and rituals, and I returned to my room to rest for a while, putting down my thesis.
[1967-07-05T18:00:00] Dormitory 004 | I saw him waiting for me downstairs; he wanted to take me to dinner.
[1967-07-05T18:05:00] Dormitory Borgo | I looked at myself in the mirror and felt beautiful. I took the book that contained the story and stuffed it into my bag.
[1967-07-05T19:00:00] Restaurant | I know that was Pietro's first time taking me to a restaurant. Franco Mari used to take me there often; he taught me where to place the utensils and glasses.
[1967-07-05T19:05:00] Restaurant | I heard Pietro ask me, "Are we boyfriend and girlfriend?"
[1967-07-05T19:10:00] Restaurant | I saw myself smiling and saying, "I don't know." I heard him take a box from his pocket and hand it to me, whispering, "For the past year, I've thought of myself as your boyfriend. If you don't feel the same way, just think of it as a graduation gift."
[1967-07-05T19:15:00] Restaurant | I saw myself tearing open the package, revealing a green box inside which was a ring with a small diamond. I heard "Very beautiful." I said.
[1967-07-05T19:20:00] Restaurant | I tried it on and found that the size fit perfectly. I thought of Stefano's engagement ring for Lina, which was much more luxurious than this one.
[1967-07-05T19:25:00] Restaurant | I know, but it was the first piece of jewelry I had ever received. Franco Mari had given me many things, but never any jewelry. The only jewelry I owned was my mother's silver bracelet.
[1967-07-05T19:30:00] Restaurant | I saw what I said to him. I heard, "We are boyfriend and girlfriend."
[1967-07-05T19:35:00] Restaurant | I saw and then leaned over the table, [intimate gesture] his lips.
[1967-07-05T19:40:00] Restaurant | I saw him turn red and he spoke in a low voice. "I heard, 'I have one more gift.'"
[1967-07-05T19:45:00] Restaurant | I saw him give me an envelope, which contained a manuscript of his thesis. I thought, how fast he is! I even found it very pleasant to think so.
[1967-07-05T19:50:00] Restaurant | "I have a little gift for you," I said. "What?"
[1967-07-05T19:55:00] Restaurant | I heard, "Something insignificant, but I don't know what to give you that truly belongs to me."
[1967-07-05T20:00:00] Restaurant | I saw myself taking the notebook out of my bag and handing it to him.
[1967-07-05T20:05:00] Restaurant | "I heard 'it's a novel,' I said, 'the only version, the only attempt, I'll never write again.'"
[1967-07-05T20:10:00] Restaurant | I saw myself smiling as I added. I heard, "There are a few more daring passages inside."
[1967-07-05T20:15:00] Restaurant | I saw that he seemed a bit uneasy and thanked me, then placed the notebook on the table. I thought about how I would soon regret giving him that notebook.
[1967-07-05T20:20:00] Restaurant | I knew I thought: He was a serious student with a good family background, about to publish a paper on the worship of Dionysus, and this book would launch his career, and it was handwritten, not typed on a typewriter. I realized I was wrong, and I shouldn't have put him in an awkward situation with a story.
[1967-07-05T20:25:00] Restaurant | I told him I would attend the job interview for the kindergarten teacher position and that I would return to San Gregorio Armeno. I said our relationship would face great challenges, me in a southern city, him in a northern one. I thought, but even in this situation, I didn't feel uncomfortable. He was he, and I was me.
[1967-07-05T20:30:00] Restaurant | I saw that Pietro was very serious, his mind was made up.
[1967-07-05T20:35:00] Restaurant | I saw him explain his plans to me: he needed two years to establish himself at a university, and then he would marry me.
[1967-07-05T20:40:00] Restaurant | I saw that he had even set a date: September 1969.

[1967-07-05T20:45:00] Outside the Restaurant | I reminded him jokingly as we left the restaurant. I heard, "Where's my gift?"
[1967-07-05T20:50:00] Outside the restaurant | I didn't react at first when I saw him, then I ran back to get it.
[1967-07-05T21:30:00] On the banks of the Arno River | I saw that we had been walking for a long time. We [intimate gesture], by the Arno River, and he embraced me tightly.
[1967-07-05T21:35:00] On the Arno River | I saw myself asking him if he wanted to sneak into my room, my tone a bit serious and a bit playful.
[1967-07-05T21:40:00] On the banks of the Arno River | I saw him shaking his head, then he began to passionately embrace me.
[1967-07-05T21:45:00] On the Arno River | I thought to myself that, even though he and Antonio were separated by the entire library, they were very similar.
[1967-07-20T10:00:00] Mergellina | I thought about returning to my life at San Gregorio Armeno, that feeling was like someone carrying a broken umbrella in a strong wind, and the umbrella snapped shut above my head.
[1967-07-20T10:05:00] Mergellina | I saw myself returning to Mergellina in the height of summer. I thought about wanting to find a job right away, but my status as a college graduate made it impossible for me to go out and wander around as I had before, taking on odd jobs.
[1967-07-20T10:10:00] Mergellina | I thought on the other hand, I didn't have any money, and I was too ashamed to ask my parents for it, they had already made great sacrifices for me.
[1967-07-20T10:15:00] Mergellina | I found myself becoming anxious very quickly, everything annoyed me—the streets, the main roads, the small parks, and those ugly houses. Even though at first, every blade of grass, every scent moved me.
[1967-07-20T10:20:00] Mergellina | I thought, what would I do if Pietro had chosen someone else, if I couldn't pass the exam? I couldn't stay here forever, with these people.
[1967-07-20T10:25:00] Mergellina | I know that my parents and my brothers and sisters are proud of me, and I can feel it. I wondered what they would do with the fact that I had graduated, why I had come back, and how they would act in front of the neighbors, pretending that I was the pride of the whole family.
[1967-07-20T10:30:00] Mergellina | I thought, if I really think about it, I've only added to their burden. I've made this small house even more crowded, and setting up a bed at night has become a problem. I've caused them trouble in their daily lives.
[1967-07-20T10:35:00] Mergellina | I spent all day reading, standing, or sitting in a corner, moving from one place to another like a useless statue devoted to study, a very proud and troubled person, someone no one should disturb. I thought about it, but undoubtedly, they were all wondering one thing: what was she planning to do?
[1967-07-20T10:40:00] The Old Library | I saw my mother could no longer hold back, and she asked me about my boyfriend. Actually, I had never mentioned him, she deduced it from the ring on my hand.
[1967-07-20T10:45:00] Mergellina | I could see she wanted to know what my boyfriend did for a living, how much he earned, and when he would come to our house to ask for my hand in marriage. I also wondered where we would live after I got married.
[1967-07-20T10:50:00] Mergellina | I told her, at the beginning, some information: he was a university teacher, but didn't have a salary yet, couldn't earn any money, he was about to publish a book, other teachers thought it was a very important book, we would get married in a couple of years, his parents lived in Genoa, and we might live in that city or in the city where he worked.
[1967-07-20T10:55:00] Mergellina | I still ask her the same question whenever I see her. I thought, but by the way she looked at me, I felt she hadn't heard a word I said—she had too many preconceived notions.
[1967-07-20T11:00:00] Mergellina | I saw her become as irritable as usual. She could no longer curse at me the way she used to before. She tried hard to control her irritation, perhaps because she felt she had no more reason to be upset with me. I thought about how I was engaged to a man who had never even proposed to me, a man living far away, who taught but didn't earn much, who would publish a book but wasn't well known.
[1967-07-20T11:05:00] Mergellina | I realized that, in reality, language itself had become something foreign. I expressed myself in a language too complex for her, even though I tried to speak in the dialect. When I found out she didn't understand, I simplified my words, but those simplified sentences felt unnatural and chaotic.
[1967-07-20T11:10:00] Mergellina | I saw people on the road, in the stores, in the stairwells of the houses, looking at me with a mixture of respect and disdain. Behind my back, they all called me the "Borgo woman." I thought about how I had tried so hard to erase my San Gregorio Armeno accent, but it hadn't convinced Borgo, yet my accent was something my mother, father, my brothers and sisters, even the whole Mergellina, could sense.
[1967-07-25T10:00:00] Mergellina | I saw that during that time, I wrote some very long letters to Pietro, and his replies to me were even longer.
[1967-07-25T10:05:00] Mergellina | I thought at first that he would mention the notebook I showed him, but later I even forgot about it myself.
[1967-07-25T10:10:00] Mergellina | I saw that in our letters we never talked about any specific things, and I still keep those letters to this day: there were no useful details in them to reconstruct daily life at the time, like the price of a loaf of bread, or a movie ticket, or how much the concierge or teacher earned in a month.
[1967-07-25T10:15:00] Mergellina | As far as I know, we all focused on discussing a book he had read, or an interesting article about our field of study, the things he or I was thinking about, and also on student movements and some new avant-garde issues—I didn't understand these, but he did.
[1967-07-25T10:20:00] Mergellina | I saw that he wrote to me: "I would like to write a small book using the words on those discarded sheets of paper—the ones you wrote a paragraph on, then thought unsatisfactory and threw into the waste basket."
[1967-07-25T10:25:00] Mergellina | I saw "I'm collecting these materials, and I want to print them just as they are, keeping the torn marks, the lines drawn casually on the draft, the places where it was interrupted, and the traces of being folded randomly. Maybe this is the only possible literature we have now."
[1967-07-25T10:30:00] Mergellina | The last sentence really shook me. I doubted it, and I remember thinking at the time that he was trying to tell me in this way that he had read the notebook I had given him, the story I had given him, and that he thought it was an out-of-place work.
[1967-08-01T14:00:00] Mergellina | I saw that during those weeks, the weather remained consistently hot. I thought of the body that had made me study tirelessly for years, and I felt completely exhausted, with no strength left.
[1967-08-01T15:00:00] Mergellina | I searched everywhere for news about Professor Oliviero, hoping she was still alive so I could see her. I thought about how I could make her satisfied through my academic achievements, in order to gain a little bit of energy.
[1967-08-01T15:05:00] Mergellina | I learned from my sister that the teacher's sister came to take her to live in Potenza.
[1967-08-01T15:10:00] Mergellina | I thought about how lonely I felt, and I began to miss Lina. I thought about how completely different our lives were, and I wanted to go find her, to see just how far apart we really were.
[1967-08-01T15:15:00] Mergellina | I saw her, but I didn't do anything. I just casually mentioned her to the people at Mergellina, wanting to know what people thought of her, what gossip they spread.
[1967-08-05T10:00:00] Mergellina | I went to find Antonio first, but he wasn't in Mergellina. They said he might have stayed in Germany. I know some people say he married a very beautiful German woman, a tall, voluptuous, genuine blonde with blue eyes, and they had twins.
locations: On the banks of the Arno River

text:
[1967-08-05T11:00:00] Martiri Square | I went to chat with Alfonso Carracci, and I often went to his store in Piazza Martiri.
[1967-08-05T11:05:00] Shoe Store | I saw him becoming increasingly handsome, handsome like a Spanish nobleman. He spoke very refined Italian, interwoven with some pleasant regional dialect words.
[1967-08-05T11:10:00] Shoe Store | I knew that the Soleara shoe store was doing well under his care, his salary satisfied him, and he had rented an apartment in the Tappa district. He didn't miss our Mergellina, his brothers and sisters, or the oily smell in Capodimonte at all.
[1967-08-05T11:15:00] Shoe Store | I saw, "Next year I'll be married." When he told me, he wasn't full of passion.
[1967-08-05T11:20:00] Shoe Store | I knew his relationship with Pinocchia had always been stable, and now he needed to take the final step.
[1967-08-05T11:25:00] Shoe Store | I sometimes go out with them, and they fit well together. I know she's not as talkative as she used to be. Now she speaks carefully, especially avoiding anything that might offend Alfonso Carracci.
[1967-08-05T11:30:00] Shoe Store | I had never asked her about her father, mother, or brothers and sisters, and I had never asked about Nino either. She never mentioned him either, as if Nino had completely disappeared from her life.
[1967-08-06T10:00:00] Mergellina | I saw myself meeting Pasquale and his sister Pinocchia as well. I know that Pasquale is still working as a bricklayer, sometimes at San Gregorio Armeno, sometimes in the suburbs. Pinocchia is still working in the new Capodimonte.
[1967-08-06T10:05:00] Mergellina | I learned quickly that they all had new relationships. I knew that Pasquale was secretly dating the older daughter of the department store owner, a girl who was still very young; Pinochia was seeing a clerk at the gas station on the main road, a man in his forties who was very kind and deeply loved her.
[1967-08-07T10:00:00] Pinocchio's House | I saw myself going to Pinocchio. I thought I was already beginning to forget her.

[1967-12-16T17:50:00] At the factory gate | I was glad she was happy that I praised her child, and she also spoke well of the female neighbor. But when she mentioned Enzo, she became radiant and talkative.
[1967-12-16T17:55:00] At the factory gate | I saw her say it. I heard, "He's very nice, has a good temper, is fearless, very smart, and studies hard in the evening. He knows a lot."
[1967-12-16T18:00:00] At the factory gate | I had never heard her speak like that about anyone, I asked. I heard, "What is he learning?"
[1967-12-16T18:05:00] At the factory gate | I heard "math." "Enzo?"
[1967-12-16T18:10:00] At the factory gate | "I heard, 'Yes. He read an article about IBM System, or maybe he saw an advertisement—I don't remember—which made him obsessed with IBM System.'"
[1967-12-16T18:15:00] At the factory gate | "I heard him say that IBM System wasn't like the ones we see in movies, it had a lot of colored lights and made a beeping sound when turned on. He said IBM System was a language." "A language?"
[1967-12-16T18:20:00] At the factory gate | I saw the look in her eyes, which seemed very sharp, as if she understood this language very well.
[1967-12-16T18:25:00] At the factory gate | I saw her say. I heard, "It's not the language we write novels in."
[1967-12-16T18:30:00] At the factory gate | I heard her laugh after she said those words. The thing that troubled me was the way she dismissed the language of novels, and even more troubling was that.
[1967-12-16T18:35:00] At the factory gate | I heard her say, "They're all programming languages. After the kids go to sleep, Enzo will start studying them."
[1967-12-16T18:40:00] At the factory gate | I saw her lips were dry, cracked from the cold, and her face was full of exhaustion and weariness.
[1967-12-16T18:45:00] At the factory gate | I saw that, despite everything, she still said it with pride. I heard, "He has started studying."
[1967-12-16T18:50:00] At the factory gate | I thought to myself that I understood, even though she used the third person singular, I knew it wasn't just Enzo who had taken an interest in that thing.
[1967-12-16T18:55:00] At the factory gate | I heard, "He studies, but what do you do?" "I keep him company while he studies. He gets tired easily; if he studies alone, he falls asleep right away."
[1967-12-16T19:00:00] At the factory gate | I heard, "We'll have a lot of fun studying together. One of us asks a question, the other answers. Do you know what a chart is?"
[1967-12-16T19:05:00] At the factory gate | I saw myself shaking my head, and her eyes narrowed into a slit. She let go of my arm and tried to pull me into the world she was now obsessed with.

[1967-12-16T19:10:00] Factory courtyard | I smelled the fire in the courtyard, mixed with the odors of animal fat, meat, and tendons, and also the smell of Lina's thick coat and blue overall. Her hands were cracked, her hair was messy, and there wasn't a trace of makeup on her pale face.
[1967-12-16T19:15:00] Factory courtyard | I saw her regain her vitality, full of energy.
[1967-12-16T19:20:00] Factory Yard | I saw her reduce everything to an alternating sequence of true and false. She mentioned Boolean algebra and other things, all of which were completely unknown to me. I thought that, despite everything, her language still fascinated me.
[1967-12-16T19:25:00] Factory courtyard | I thought of the time when she spoke, and I seemed to see her, on a night in that dilapidated house, with the child sleeping in another room.
[1967-12-16T19:30:00] Factory Yard | I saw Enzo sitting on the bed, his face full of exhaustion after a long day at the electric locomotive factory.
[1967-12-16T19:35:00] Factory courtyard | I saw her, either picking meat all day around the pot, or after working all day in the freezing cold of minus twenty degrees, sitting on the quilt with him.
[1967-12-16T19:40:00] Factory courtyard | I saw the two of them in a blinding light, both of them sacrificing their sleep. I heard their voices, as they did chart exercises, trained themselves, eliminated everything unnecessary in the world, simplified their daily actions, and represented everything through just two real values—0 and 1.
[1967-12-16T19:45:00] Factory courtyard | I thought of that humble room, where they spoke in profound words, whispering softly so as not to wake little Rino.
[1967-12-16T19:50:00] Factory courtyard | I thought about how I had arrived there full of pride, confident and full of emotion, mainly wanting to show her what she had lost and what I had gained.
[1967-12-16T19:55:00] Factory courtyard | I thought that when I appeared, she had already realized it. Now, she was risking a conflict with her coworkers and possible punishment. Her approach was to explain to me that I hadn't won anything, that there was nothing to win in this world.
[1967-12-16T20:00:00] Factory courtyard | I thought about how her life was filled with all sorts of things, good or bad, heart-stopping events that were no less intense than everything I had experienced. Time just passed meaninglessly, and the occasional meeting was beautiful, just to hear another person's crazy thoughts and the echo of those thoughts in someone else's mind.
[1967-12-16T20:05:00] Factory Yard | I asked, "Do you like living with him?" "Yes."
[1967-12-16T20:10:00] Factory courtyard | I saw her make a face, pretending to be happy. I heard, "Will you [be pregnant]?"
[1967-12-16T20:15:00] Factory Yard | "I heard, 'We're not together.' 'Not together?"
[1967-12-16T20:20:00] Factory Yard | "I don't have any ideas," I said. "What about him?"
[1967-12-16T20:25:00] Factory courtyard | "I heard, 'He's waiting for me.' 'Maybe you think he's like an older brother.'"
[1967-12-16T20:30:00] Factory Yard | I heard, "No, I like him." "Then what's going on?" "I don't know."
[1967-12-16T20:35:00] Factory courtyard | I saw us stop in front of the bonfire, and she pointed at the guard. I heard, "You should be careful with that person."
[1967-12-16T20:40:00] Factory courtyard | I heard, "When you go out, he'll say you stole the sausage, make an excuse to search you, just to feel you up."
[1967-12-16T20:45:00] Factory courtyard | I saw us embrace for a moment, then she kissed my cheek.
[1967-12-16T20:50:00] Factory courtyard | I told her I would look for her again, I didn't want to lose her, and I said it sincerely. I heard her smile slightly and whisper, "Yes, I don't want to lose you either."
[1967-12-16T20:55:00] Factory courtyard | I saw that her voice was also sincere.
[1967-12-16T21:00:00] At the factory gate | I saw her and left very excitedly, but inside I felt it was hard to leave her.
[1967-12-16T21:05:00] At the factory gate | I thought again that, just like before, I felt that without her, nothing truly important could happen in my life. Yet I still felt I had to escape from here as soon as possible, just to avoid smelling that greasy scent of hers again.
[1967-12-16T21:10:00] At the factory gate | After taking a few quick steps, I still couldn't help but turn back and wave to her.
[1967-12-16T21:15:00] Factory courtyard | I saw her stop in front of the pile of firewood. She flipped through The Blue Fairy, and suddenly threw it into the fire. I saw her in that outfit, and couldn't tell she was a woman.
[1967-12-20T10:00:00] Home | I knew I never told her what was in my book, nor when it would be published.
[1967-12-20T10:05:00] Home | I knew I hadn't even told her about my fiancé Pietro, or our plan to get married in two years.
[1967-12-20T10:10:00] Home | I thought about how her life had deeply affected me, and it took me several days to recover. I clearly felt my own reality, and she completely brought me back to myself — which self was really mine?
[1967-12-20T10:15:00] Home | I saw that the manuscript had one hundred and thirty-nine pages, printed on thick paper, and the words I had written in my notebook were now set in type. I thought about it, and it made me feel strange and unfamiliar.
[1967-12-20T10:20:00] Home | I saw that I had spent several hours re-reading and revising this book.
[1967-12-20T10:25:00] Home | I saw that the weather outside was very cold, and the wind was coming in through the cracks in the door and the windows.
[1967-12-20T10:30:00] Home | I saw myself sitting at the kitchen table, and Gianni and Elisa were also studying at that same table.
[1967-12-20T10:35:00] Home | I saw my mother moving about us with careful, delicate movements, afraid of disturbing us. I thought to myself that it was something that surprised me.

[1968-04-01 20:41:00] Court Road Conference Site | I saw Pasquale finish speaking, and at that moment, a girl spoke up—she was the first among the few women present to speak. I thought this made Lina even more annoyed: first, because she spoke as if she were reading from a book; second, because she mentioned Lina several times, calling her Comrade Lina; the third reason was that she knew the girl—she was Nadia, the daughter of Professor Galiani, Nino's former girlfriend, the girl who had written love letters to Nino on Ischia.
[1968-04-01 20:41:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I thought at first she was worried that Nadezhda would recognize her, but the girl kept looking at her while talking, showing no sign of recognition. Besides, how could she possibly recognize Lina? Who knew how many parties of wealthy people she had attended; her mind must be full of people.
[1968-04-01 20:42:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I thought about it, but a few years ago, Lina had only one chance, that gathering left a deep impression on her.
[1968-04-01 20:42:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I thought of how clearly she remembered: the house was on Vittorio Emanuele Street, she had seen Nino, and those young men from good families, the books, the paintings, and the pain she felt, as well as her terrible situation at that time.
[1968-04-01 20:43:00] Court Road Conference Site | I saw Nadia still talking, but Lina could no longer stand it and got up, leaving with Gennaro.
[1968-04-01 20:43:30] Outside the Conference Venue at Court Road | I thought she had a pain inside her, which made her stomach churn, but she couldn't find a way to release it.
[1968-04-01 20:50:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw that after a while, she returned to the hall, and she decided to speak about her experience instead of acting as if she didn't matter.
[1968-04-01 20:55:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw that now a curly-haired young man was talking about the Italian metallurgy industry and payment according to work, and he spoke very thoroughly.
[1968-04-01 21:00:00] Court Road Conference Site | I saw Lina wait for him to finish. She ignored Enzo's anxious glance and asked to speak.
[1968-04-01 21:05:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw her talking for a long time, speaking in standard Italian, while Gennaro kept squirming in her arms.
[1968-04-01 21:05:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw her speaking slowly at first, then her voice grew louder and louder, perhaps too loud in the silence around us.
[1968-04-01 21:06:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard her jokingly say that she didn't have the slightest idea what the working class was, only knowing the men and women workers at the place where she worked. She said there was absolutely nothing worth learning in these people besides their poverty.
[1968-04-01 21:06:30] Court Road Conference Site | "Can you imagine?" she asked. "What's it like to spend eight hours a day with water up to your waist, soaking in the water used to boil big sausages?"
[1968-04-01 21:07:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard that when they took the bones out, her hands were all cut up. Can you imagine?
[1968-04-01 21:07:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard that when you go in and out of the ice warehouse in twenty degrees below zero, you earn ten lira an hour—ten lira—as a frostbite allowance. Can you imagine?
[1968-04-01 21:08:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I wondered, if you could imagine, what you could possibly learn from people who are forced to live this way?
[1968-04-01 21:08:30] Court Road Conference Site | I heard the female workers being touched on the buttocks by the foreman or other colleagues, but they didn't dare say a word.
[1968-04-01 21:09:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard that if the boss's son has a need, you have to go with him to the storage room. That's what his father or grandfather started doing. Before taking advantage of you, the boss's son would also give you an inspiring dialogue about how excited he was by the smell of sausage.
[1968-04-01 21:09:30] Court Road Conference Site | I heard that in the factory, both men and women are searched. At the exit, there's a "detector." If it turns red instead of green, it means you have sausage or fat sausage on you.
[1968-04-01 21:10:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard that the "detector" was controlled by the guard, who was the boss's right-hand man. Sometimes when the red light went on, it wasn't because someone was stealing, but because a pretty, shy girl walked by, and the guard wanted to tease her a little.
[1968-04-01 21:10:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard that this is the situation where I'll be working. The union people have never been able to get inside. These workers are just pitiful people, risking their lives under the boss's control and oppression. The boss's law is: I pay you, so I own you. I own your life, your family, everything around you. If you don't do what I say, I'll destroy you.
[1968-04-01 21:11:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw that at first, no one said a word. Finally, the others kept quoting what Lina had said.
[1968-04-01 21:15:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw Nadia come over and embrace her, saying a lot of flattery: "You're so beautiful! You're amazing! You spoke so well!" I heard her thanking Lina and saying very seriously, "You've shown me how much work we still have to do."
[1968-04-01 21:15:30] Court Road Conference Site | I thought that although Nadya's tone was high and her manner solemn, Lina still saw her as the little girl she had known years ago, the girl who was with Nino, even more childish than she had been back then.
[1968-04-01 21:16:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I wondered what her son with Nino was doing at that moment? Were they dancing, talking, rubbing against each other, [intimate acts]? She couldn't imagine it.
[1968-04-01 21:16:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I thought, of course, that Nadia was beautiful back then, unforgettable. Now, her appearance seems even more pure, so innocent, so fragile, so considerate of others' pain, as if she could truly feel the workers' suffering. This empathy seemed unbearable for her.
[1968-04-01 21:17:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard, "Are you coming back?"
[1968-04-01 21:17:05] Court Road Conference Site | "I have a child."
[1968-04-01 21:17:10] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard, "You need to keep coming to the events, we need you."
[1968-04-01 21:17:15] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw Lina shaking her head uncomfortably, and she repeated it to Nadia. I heard, "I have a child."
[1968-04-01 21:17:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw her point Gennaro out to Nadia and say something to Gennaro. I heard, "Say hello to this lady, tell her you can read and write, let her listen to how well you speak."
[1968-04-01 21:18:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I saw Gennaro holding Lina around the neck, blocking her face. Nadia was nodding and smiling, but Lina didn't see her.
[1968-04-01 21:18:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I heard her say to Nadia, "I have a child, I work eight hours a day, not counting overtime. People in my situation always just want to go to sleep as soon as they get off work."
[1968-04-01 21:19:00] Court Road Conference Site | I thought that in the end, she was exhausted, and she felt she had exposed herself too much in front of others.
[1968-04-01 21:19:30] Court Road Conference Venue | I suppose so, they're all good people. Although they understand those abstract things very well, they may not be familiar with the specific situation.
[1968-04-01 21:20:00] Court Road Conference Venue | I know—Lina thought, but didn't say—what it's like to live a life of wealth and good intentions, something you can't even begin to imagine the real meaning of poverty.
locations: Outside the Conference Venue at Court Road

text:
[1968-04-01 21:30:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about going out onto the street, and the feeling of discomfort she had felt became even stronger.
[1968-04-01 21:30:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about how, as they walked toward the car, Pasquale and Enzo seemed somewhat gloomy, and I felt my words had hurt them.
[1968-04-01 21:31:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw Pasquale gently pull her arm, an action he had never taken before, and I knew he was trying to close the distance between them.
[1968-04-01 21:31:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I heard him ask, "Are you really working under those conditions?"
[1968-04-01 21:32:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw that this physical contact annoyed her, so she pulled away his hand and asked him back. I heard, "How do you work, the two of you? How do you work?"
[1968-04-01 21:32:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw that they didn't answer. I thought about how tired they must be, and this was something everyone clearly knew.
[1968-04-01 21:33:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought that at least Enzo would see, in the factory, how some female workers were worn down by hard labor, humiliated, and burdened with housework, and that they weren't any easier off than Lina.
[1968-04-01 21:33:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought of the two men, both wearing gloomy expressions because of her work situation, and they couldn't stand it.
[1968-04-01 21:34:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought that for these men, it was necessary to hide everything.
[1968-04-01 21:34:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about how they would prefer not to know anything, how they would rather pretend that the things the bosses did in the factory would miraculously never happen to the women they cared about—that was the mindset they'd had since childhood. They should protect their women, a responsibility they couldn't escape even if it meant being killed.
[1968-04-01 21:35:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about their silence, which made Lina even more angry.
[1968-04-01 21:35:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I heard her say, "Fuck them!" She said, "You, and others."
[1968-04-01 21:40:00] On Pasquale's car | I saw them get into the car and head to Stazione Centrale; we only exchanged a few casual words along the way.
[1968-04-01 22:00:00] Lina's house downstairs | I saw Pasquale drop them off downstairs, and Pasquale spoke seriously to Lina. I heard there's nothing to say, you're still the best.
[1968-04-01 22:05:00] Lina's building downstairs | I saw and then he drove back to Mergellina.
[1968-04-01 22:10:00] Lina's house downstairs | I saw Enzo holding a sleeping child in his arms, his face dark as he muttered something under his breath. "I heard, 'Why have you never told me? Did someone touch you at the factory?'"
[1968-04-01 22:10:30] Lina's building downstairs | I saw that they were all tired, so Lina decided to calm him down and said to him. I heard, "They won't do anything to me."
[1968-04-01T10:00:00] Home | I saw that the book was published in the spring. I thought it was more important than my graduation from university; it gave me a new identity.
[1968-04-01T10:05:00] Home | I showed my new book to my mother, my father, and my brothers and sisters. They looked at it silently, but no one turned the pages to read its contents.
[1968-04-01T10:10:00] Home | I saw them with a smile full of disbelief. I thought of how someone like Labor Office was facing a fake document.
[1968-04-01T10:15:00] Home | I saw what my father said. I heard, "This is my family name."
[1968-04-01T10:20:00] Home | I saw it, but when he said it, he didn't sound very satisfied. I thought, as if suddenly he wasn't proud of me, but rather had discovered that I had stolen money from his pocket.
[1968-04-05 07:00:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I saw Lina arrive at work early in the morning, and because there was so much to do, she was flustered and rushed. I knew that the problem would arise a few days later.
[1968-04-05 07:00:30] Sokavo Meat Factory | I saw that the weather was very cold. I thought about how she had been coughing for several days, and she felt like she had a cold.
[1968-04-05 07:01:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Gate | I saw her at the factory gate, where she saw a few boys. I thought she might be a student skipping class.
[1968-04-05 07:01:30] Sokavo Meat Factory entrance | I saw one of them greet her warmly and hand her a typeset booklet, instead of just giving her a flyer as before.
[1968-04-05 07:02:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Gate | I saw her greet the boy as well, her gaze a bit anxious. I know that Lina saw him at the party congress on the way to the court.
[1968-04-05 07:02:30] Front of Sokaowo Meat Factory | I saw her put the brochure into her coat pocket, and when she passed by the guard Philip, she didn't even look at him.
[1968-04-05 07:03:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Gate | I heard Philip shouting at her at that moment: "Hey! At least say hello, we've never even said 'good morning' to each other."
[1968-04-05 10:00:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I saw her still working as hard as before, and in that phase she was working in the deboning area. I thought about how she had forgotten the boy she met at the door.
[1968-04-05 13:00:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | When I saw her bringing her lunchbox to the factory courtyard for lunch, she was looking for a corner to eat. At that moment, Philip saw her and left his booth, walking toward her.
[1968-04-05 13:00:30] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | I know he's a man in his fifties, short and heavyset. He has a lecherous side that makes people sick, but sometimes he also likes to be friendly and familiar. Recently, he had a son, and he gets easily moved. He often takes out his son's photo from his wallet and shows it to everyone.
[1968-04-05 13:01:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | I saw the man pull out a brochure from his jacket pocket and say, with a threatening tone, in a harsh way. I thought Lina saw him coming and expected him to show her the photo of his son, but that wasn't what happened.
[1968-04-05 13:01:30] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | "I heard you, Seru! Listen carefully: if what's written here is something you told those rotten people, you're in big trouble, you understand?"
[1968-04-05 13:02:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Courtyard | I saw her say coldly. I heard, "I don't know what the hell you're talking about, I'm going to eat."
[1968-04-05 13:02:30] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | I saw Philip angrily throw the brochure into her face and say. I heard, "You don't know, do you? You'll see for yourself. The people here have always been very friendly, there's no real conflict. Only someone like you, a bitch, would go around talking about this outside."
[1968-04-05 13:03:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Courtyard | "I can turn on the alarm whenever I want? I touched those female workers? As the head of the family, a man with children, how could I do something like that? You'll see, I'll tell Boss Bruno, and you'll pay for it. You dirty woman, I really want to tear your face apart."
[1968-04-05 13:03:30] Sokavo Meat Factory Courtyard | I saw him say that, then he turned and walked back to the booth.
[1968-04-05 13:10:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | I watched Lina calmly finish her lunch. She picked up the brochure and saw its overly dramatic title: "San Gregorio Armeno and the Living Conditions of Workers in the Suburbs."
[1968-04-05 13:15:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | I saw her flip through it and noticed there was an entire page filled with Via Caracciolo.
[1968-04-05 13:15:30] Sokavo Meat Factory Yard | I thought of how she had seen every word she had spoken at the meeting on the way to court.

[1968-04-05 13:20:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I saw her act as if nothing had happened, dropping the brochure on the ground without looking back at the doorman, and walked straight into the factory to start working.
[1968-04-05 13:25:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I thought about it, but she was filled with anger toward the person who had caused her so much trouble without even informing her beforehand. That little saint, Nadia—this article must be hers! The writing was overly sentimental, the tone manipulative—clearly her work.
[1968-04-05 13:30:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I saw Lina holding a knife, working on the cold meats. I thought of that nauseating smell, which made her anger even more intense.
[1968-04-05 13:35:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I thought about how she must feel the hostility from her colleagues, both men and women, all showing the same attitude. They had worked together for a long time, and they all knew they were being exploited, but no one said a word.
[1968-04-05 13:40:00] Sokavo Meat Factory | I wondered who had exposed the matter here? They all unquestionably believed it was her. Because she was the only one who had shown this attitude from the beginning: willing to work hard and even risk her life, but never to be humiliated.
[1968-04-05 16:00:00] Bruno's Office | I saw that afternoon, Bruno appeared, and not long after, he sent someone to call her. I saw his face was even redder than usual, and he was holding that brochure.
[1968-04-05 16:05:00] Bruno's Office | I heard, "You did this, didn't you?" "No." "Tell me the truth, Lina! Are you also getting involved in the chaos outside?" "I told you, it wasn't me."
[1968-04-05 16:05:30] Bruno's Office | I heard, "Ah, you don't? No one here has the ability, nor the nerve, to come up with these lies." "Maybe it was some employee who said it." "An employee is even less likely."
[1968-04-05 16:06:00] Bruno's Office | I saw him sigh, as if he were really certain it was her. I heard him say, "What do you want me to do? Birds sing, should I make them stop? Everyone says it's your fault."
[1968-04-05 16:06:30] Bruno's Office | "I gave you a job, and you joined the union. I said nothing. If it had been my father, he would have kicked you out right away. Okay, in the drying room, I did something stupid, but I apologized to you. You can't say I forced you."
[1968-04-05 16:07:00] Bruno's Office | "I heard, 'Why are you saying these things now? Are you taking revenge? You've defamed my factory, you've written it down in black and white, saying I took the female workers to the drying room. Are you crazy? What do I have to do with those female workers? I really regret helping you.'"
[1968-04-05 16:07:30] Bruno's Office | I heard, "Help me? I work my fingers to the bone every day, and that's all you give me. Rather than saying you're helping me, maybe I'm the one helping you."
[1968-04-05 16:08:00] Bruno's Office | I heard, "Did you see? You're talking just like those bastards, the way you spoke to them. You wrote these things, so admit it." "I didn't write anything."
[1968-04-05 16:08:30] Bruno's Office | I saw Bruno snort and glance at the book in front of him. I thought she understood, but he hesitated, unsure of what to do: should he threaten her with a harsher tone, fire her, or step back and find out if there were other similar actions being planned?
[1968-04-05 16:09:00] Bruno's Office | I saw that she had made up her mind. She spoke in a low voice—though reluctant, she still forced a flattering expression, suppressing the vivid memories of his invasion—she said three compromising words. I heard, "You have to believe me. I have a child at home. I really didn't do it."
[1968-04-05 16:09:30] Bruno's Office | I saw him nod, muttering something discontentedly. I heard, "Do you know what you're forcing me to do?" "No, I don't want to know."
[1968-04-05 16:10:00] Bruno's Office | I heard, "I still have to tell you. If it was your friend who did it, tell them: if they dare to cause trouble in front of the factory again, I'll beat them so badly they won't want to come back. As for you, be careful: if you keep talking, the rope will break."
[1968-04-05 18:00:00] Sokavo Meat Factory entrance | I know, but that day didn't end there. When Lina passed by the booth on her way out, the alarm went off.
[1968-04-05 18:00:30] Front of Soka Wo Meat Factory | I know it's still the same old routine—every day, the gatekeeper selects three or four victims, those shy girls who lower their eyes and let him touch them, and those women who smile and say, "Hurry up, if you want to touch, go ahead, I have to go cook dinner."
[1968-04-05 18:01:00] Front of Soka Wo Meat Factory | I saw this time Philip blocked Lina, and the doorman came out of the small house. I saw that the weather was very cold, and the wind was strong.
[1968-04-05 18:01:30] Front of Soka Wo Meat Factory | I saw Lina trembling as she said. I heard, "If you dare so much as touch a single finger of mine, either I'll kill you myself, or I'll have someone else do it."
[1968-04-05 18:02:00] Sokavo Meat Factory entrance | I saw Philip's face was dark and gloomy. He pointed to a table next to the booth, which had always been there. I heard, "Take the things out of your pocket and put them on top of this."
[1968-04-05 18:02:30] Front of Soka Wo Meat Factory | I saw a fresh sausage in Lina's pocket, and she took it out. I saw her touch the soft meat inside the intestine.
[1968-04-05 18:03:00] Sokavo Meat Factory entrance | I saw her suddenly laugh and say. I heard, "You're all crap, all of you are the same."
[1968-04-05 18:05:00] Front of Soka Wo Meat Factory | I saw Philip scold her, threatening to report her for stealing, to deduct her salary, and to fine her. She retaliated against Philip. I thought about how Bruno never showed up when the incident happened, even though he was always at the factory, his car still parked in the yard. Lina felt that from that moment on, her situation would only get worse.
[1968-04-05 19:00:00] At Lina's home | I saw her return home, more exhausted than usual. She was harsh with Gennaro because the child wanted to stay at the neighbor's house. She began preparing dinner.
[1968-04-05 21:00:00] Lina's house | I saw her tell Enzo she couldn't study the correspondence course with him, and then she went to sleep in an intimate way.
[1968-04-05 21:30:00] At Lina's house | I saw that her body still wouldn't warm up. She got up, put on a sweater over her nightgown, and then lay back down again.
[1968-04-05 22:00:00] At Lina's house | I thought there was no direct reason for it, but her heart suddenly jumped to her throat, beating so hard that she felt it was someone else's heart.
[1968-04-05 22:00:30] Lina's house | I knew she had experienced such symptoms before, along with other hallucinations—eleven years later, in 1980, she would call this sensation "the dissolution of boundaries"—but this time, it was stronger than any previous occurrence.
[1968-04-05 22:01:00] At Lina's house | I thought, especially, that this was the first time she was alone, with no one around, and before, these symptoms had occurred because of one reason or another.
[1968-04-05 22:01:30] Lina's house | I thought about how she realized, amid her waves of fear, that she wasn't alone. From her uncontrollable mind came the people she had met and the voices she had heard that day.
[1968-04-05 22:02:00] Lina's house | I thought of those people floating around in the room—the gatekeeper, the laborer, Nadia, the two boys I met at the meeting, Bruno who appeared in the drying room—like a silent film, their movements all fast, the red light of the alarm flashing rapidly, including Philip, who snatched the sausage from her hand and loudly threatened her, all moving as if fast-forwarded.
[1968-04-05 22:02:30] Lina's house | I saw that there was no one else in the room besides Gennaro; the child was lying on the small bed next to him, breathing steadily. I thought all of this was a trick of the mind, that there were no other real people or voices, but this didn't calm her down—it only made her more afraid.
[1968-04-05 22:03:00] At Lina's house | I thought of her heart pounding so violently that it seemed to push everything around her apart, making the tight interlocking of things loosen. Even the walls of the room seemed less solid. Her heart pounded fiercely against the bed beneath her, as if it might crack the plaster on the walls or loosen her skull, perhaps even harm the child.
[1968-04-05 22:03:30] Lina's house | Yes, I thought, maybe he would be destroyed like a celluloid doll, his chest, belly, and brain would split open, exposing his internal organs. She thought: I should stay away from him. The closer I get to him, the more likely I am to hurt him.
[1968-04-05 22:04:00] Lina's house | I know, but she remembered another child who had left her—the child who had never even formed in her womb, the son of Stefano, the one I had expelled from my body, at least that's what Pinocchia and Giggia said behind my back.
[1968-04-05 22:04:30] At Lina's house | I thought maybe it was true, and I had deliberately pushed him out of my body. Up until now, I hadn't accomplished anything. Why should I keep those broken pieces?
[1968-04-05 22:05:00] At Lina's house | I saw her get up again from the bed and sit on the edge of it. I saw her covered in sticky cold sweat, and she felt it was like cold oil.
[1968-04-05 22:05:30] At Lina's house | I saw her place her bare feet on the edge of Gennaro's bed and gently push them forward, trying to move him a little, but not too far away. I thought of the child by my side, and I worried about hurting him.
[1968-04-05 22:06:00] Lina's house | I saw her taking small steps toward the kitchen, leaning against the furniture, leaning against the wall, but she kept looking back over her shoulder. I thought about the floor sinking in and taking Gennaro with it.
[1968-04-05 22:06:30] At Lina's house | I saw her take some water from the faucet and splash it on her face. Suddenly, her heart stopped, and her whole body lurched forward as if there had been a sudden brake.
locations: Front of Soka Wo Meat Factory

text:
[1968-04-05 22:07:00] Lina's house | I saw it end, and the surrounding world began to rejoin, her body gradually restored. She wiped her face. Now she was trembling. I thought of how exhausted she was, so much that the walls around her seemed to spin, and she feared she might faint.
[1968-04-05 22:07:30] Lina's house | I thought: I should go find Enzo. I need to get warm. I want to get into his bed, to embrace him from behind as he sleeps, and fall asleep. But she gave up.
[1968-04-05 22:08:00] Lina's house | I thought of her, of the fawning smile on her face—that expression she made when speaking to Bruno: "You have to believe me. I have kids at home. I really didn't do it."
[1968-04-05 22:08:30] Lina's house | I thought that although she felt disgusted, it was a natural reaction of a woman's body—a kind of feminine allure, perhaps even seductive. She felt ashamed: how could she have acted that way, said those words, knowing what Sokolov had done to her in the drying room?
[1968-04-05 22:09:00] At Lina's home | I just thought of it! Like a docile little beast, clinging to those men—this isn't what she wants to do! It can't go on like this anymore!
[1968-04-05 22:09:30] At Lina's house | I knew that in the past, for different reasons, she had done things like this, sometimes without realizing it, and she had ended up in such situations with Stefano, Nino, Solara, or even with Enzo, but she no longer wanted to go through that again.
[1968-04-05 22:10:00] Lina's house | I thought about how she, too, was imagining those scenes: the gatekeeper, her coworkers, those students, the unrelenting expectations that Soca had for her. In the collision with these people and situations, she felt exhausted, on the verge of breaking down.
[1968-04-05T10:00:00] Home | A few days later, I saw the initial comments, and I anxiously scrolled through them. Any slight criticism hurt me deeply.
[1968-04-05T10:05:00] Home | I saw myself reading those exaggerated praises out loud to the Posillipo person. I saw my father's face brighten.
[1968-04-05T10:10:00] Home | I saw Elena joking. I heard, "You should sign your name as Elena, Elena sounds terrible."
[1968-04-06 06:00:00] Lina's house | I saw her wake up, and she realized she had a fever. She took some aspirin and still went to work.
[1968-04-06 06:30:00] On the way to the factory | I saw that it wasn't yet fully light, with a faint blue glow outlining the low buildings around me, as well as the grass growing in the mud puddles and the trash by the roadside.
[1968-04-06 06:40:00] On the way to the factory | I saw her just as she reached the dirt path leading to the factory. When she rounded the puddles, she noticed there were four students there this time. Two of them she had seen the day before, the third was about the same age as them, and the fourth was a boy around twenty years old, very strong and definitely overweight.
[1968-04-06 06:40:30] Sokavo Meat Factory Gate | I saw them putting up slogans on the factory wall, calling on workers to join the fight, and they also distributed flyers with the same message. I know that if the day before, those male and female workers had taken the flyers out of curiosity or politeness, but now most of them just kept their heads down and hurried by. Even if they took the leaflets, they would immediately crumple them up and throw them away.
[1968-04-06 06:41:00] Sokavo Meat Factory Gate | I thought about how Lina got annoyed when she saw those students already there, conducting political work as punctually as if they were at work, which was even more annoying than her own job. This feeling later turned into hostility.
[1968-04-06 06:41:30] Sokavo Meat Factory entrance | I saw one of the boys who had appeared the day before recognize her, holding a large stack of flyers, and run toward her enthusiastically to ask. I heard, "Comrade, everything all right?"
[1968-04-06 06:42:00] Sokavo Meat Factory entrance | I saw Lina didn't look at him. I thought of her sore throat, the pulsing at her temples.

I've also published two articles on L'Unità about the working conditions of women in factories in the Campania region; the editors have been very satisfied, and the publisher has been urging me to write a new novel. I thought, after all, I have a lot of my own things to do. I've already invested a lot of energy in Lina, and I can't always revolve around her messy affairs.
[1968-05-15 14:00:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I bought a beige suit at Porto, encouraged by Adele Airota, intending to wear it at the wedding. I knew the outfit suited me well; the top was form-fitting and the bottom was a short skirt. I thought of Lina when I tried on this dress, of her luxurious wedding gown, and of the photo of her displayed in the window of the Rettifilo district. This contrast made me feel completely different from her, as if her wedding and mine belonged to entirely separate worlds.
[1968-05-15 15:00:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I told her before that I wouldn't get married in a church, that I wouldn't wear a traditional wedding dress. I knew that Pietro only invited some close relatives to the wedding.
[1968-05-15 15:01:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her asking me, but she didn't show much interest. I heard, "Why?" "What do you mean, why?" "Why didn't you get married in the church?" "We aren't believers."
[1968-05-15 15:02:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her mention the little article we wrote together when we were children. "I heard, 'That God's finger, the Holy Spirit?' 'I'm growing up.'"
[1968-05-15 15:03:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I heard, "You should at least throw a party and invite your friends." "Pietro doesn't want to." "You're not even inviting me?" "Are you coming?"
[1968-05-15 15:04:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her shake her head and smile. I heard, "No."
