text:
[1968-05-15T15:00:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw in the bookstore at Porto, where I first met one of my readers. I knew I would soon find out that this meeting had been organized by Adele Airota-Pietro, who was overseeing the promotion of the book remotely and had even come specially from Genoa to Porto.
[1968-05-15T16:00:00] Pigneto | I saw her pass by the hotel where I was staying, and she spent the entire afternoon with me, trying to calm me down. I thought about how my hands kept shaking, and I found it hard to control myself. I felt a bitter taste in my mouth.
[1968-05-15T16:05:00] Pigneto | I kept thinking especially about how angry I was at Pietro, because he was busy with something else at Borgo and didn't come to Porto.
[1968-05-15T17:00:00] Mask Loc 005 Hotel | I saw Mariarosa at Porto before the signing session. She came over to greet me warmly and congratulated me, then had to leave because she had something else to attend to.
[1968-05-15T18:00:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | When I went to the bookstore, I was extremely nervous.
[1968-05-15T18:05:00] BOOKSTORE_LOC_005 | I saw that the lecture hall was full of people, so I lowered my head and went in. I thought I was going to pass out from excitement.
[1968-05-15T18:10:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Adele Airota greeting many people present, all of whom were her friends and acquaintances. I knew she was sitting in the front row, giving me encouraging looks, and she occasionally spoke with a woman behind her, around her own age.
[1968-05-15T18:15:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I knew that up until then, I had only spoken in public twice, both times under Franco Mari's insistence. The audience was his six or seven classmates, all of whom smiled and showed understanding.
[1968-05-15T18:20:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw that this time was completely different; I had to face forty-something unfamiliar faces. I saw that they were all refined, cultured people. They looked at me silently, but their eyes were not very friendly. Most of them had to be there because of Pietro's family.
[1968-05-15T18:25:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought about wanting to get up and run away.
[1968-05-15T18:30:00] Bookstore | I saw it at that moment, but the ceremony had already begun. A senior critic—a university professor who was once very influential—spoke highly of the book.
[1968-05-15T18:35:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought about what he had said, but I hadn't heard a single word—my mind was only on what I wanted to say.
[1968-05-15T18:40:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw myself hunched over in my seat. I thought about my stomachache, and the whole world disappeared into a chaos. I couldn't find that authority within myself that could restore order.
[1968-05-15T18:45:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw it, but I still pretended to be at ease. When it was my turn to speak, I didn't even know what I was saying—I just wanted to break the silence.
[1968-05-15T18:50:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I realized I had made too many gestures, showing off my literary accomplishments and knowledge of classical culture too much. I saw that the hall was silent in the end.
[1968-05-15T18:55:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I wondered how the people facing me were viewing me. What was the professor sitting beside me thinking about my dialogue? Adele Airota, beneath her delicate feminine appearance, had she already regretted supporting me?
[1968-05-15T19:00:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw that when I looked at her, I immediately realized I was gazing at her with a pleading look, longing for her approval. It made me feel very ashamed to think about it.
[1968-05-15T19:05:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | At that moment, the professor sitting beside me touched my arm, as if to calm me down. He then invited the people present to ask questions.
[1968-05-15T19:10:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw many people awkwardly staring at their knees and the floor.
[1968-05-15T19:15:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw the first person to speak was a man with thick glasses, older in age. Everyone present knew who he was, except me. I knew just from hearing his voice that Adele Airota made an impatient face.
[1968-05-15T19:20:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw that man talking at length about the decline of the publishing industry, saying that what is published now is all about making money rather than literary value; critics and the supplement sections of newspapers also follow the trend, driven by profit.
[1968-05-15T19:25:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I finally mentioned my book at the end, starting with a rather mocking tone, then bringing up those more daring passages, and he clearly used a hostile tone.
[1968-05-15T19:30:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw my face turn red all of a sudden. I didn't answer his question, but instead spoke vaguely, drifting far off the subject.
[1968-05-15T19:35:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I stopped speaking in the end, staring at the table with great embarrassment.
[1968-05-15T19:40:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw the critic smiling and encouraging me with his eyes. I thought he wanted me to keep talking.
[1968-05-15T19:45:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him ask dryly when he realized I didn't want to go on. I heard, "Is there anything else?"
[1968-05-15T19:50:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw someone raising their hand at the end of the hall. I heard, "Please speak."
[1968-05-15T19:55:00] Bookstore | I saw a very tall young man, with long, messy hair and a thick, dark beard.
[1968-05-15T20:00:00] BOOKSTORE_LOC_005 | I saw him speak about the person who had just spoken in a very contemptuous tone, and he also casually mocked the kind professor sitting beside me, saying. I heard her say, "We live in a very narrow and closed-off country, where people only complain at any given moment, but no one can rise up, take charge, rebuild the country, and get everything running again."
[1968-05-15T20:05:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw it through to the end, and he began praising the modernity in my novel. I thought to myself that I recognized it, it was Nino! Nino!
[1969-04-10 19:00:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw the man with thick glasses, who mocked me and my book in front of everyone. I know it was a night more than forty years ago, in a library.
[1969-04-10 19:00:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw myself trembling all over, and I answered him incoherently.
[1969-04-10 19:01:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw later, Nino suddenly popped up. I saw him with a thick black beard on his face.
[1969-04-10 19:01:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him speak to the guy who had been talking behind my back in a very harsh manner. I thought to myself that I had barely recognized him at all.
[1969-04-10 19:02:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I had been silently calling his name—Nino, Nino—in my heart ever since that moment. I thought about how long it had been since I'd seen him, maybe four or five years— I felt cold all over, but my face was burning hot.
[1969-04-10 19:02:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | After Nino finished speaking, the man raised his hand to ask a question. I realized clearly that he was angry, but I was too excited and my mind was too confused to understand immediately why he was angry.
[1969-04-10 19:03:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought, but I realized that Nino's remarks had shifted the topic from literature to politics, and he had done so in a very domineering, almost disrespectful way.
[1969-04-10 19:03:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought back to that time, when I hadn't paid much attention to what they were saying, because I was consumed by guilt. I couldn't forgive myself for not being able to control that confrontational situation, for being incoherent in front of people who were very cultured, even though I usually had a good way with words.
[1969-04-10 19:04:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I knew that in high school, I had been in a situation that was against me, and back then, I had chosen to imitate Teacher Galiani as much as possible, using her tone and language.
[1969-04-10 19:04:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I knew that, but when Borgo arrived, facing a more aggressive opponent, Galiani's role as a female model no longer worked. I thought of Franco Mari, Pietro, all the outstanding students, of course also the excellent teachers at the Normal School. They expressed themselves in a very complicated way, they wrote very carefully, they had strong analytical abilities and clear logic. I felt that none of these were things that Professor Galiani had.
[1969-04-10 19:05:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | At that moment, I began training myself, I wanted to be like them. I thought to myself that sometimes I feel capable, I feel I can use my own language, overcome all the discomforts I face in this world, and control my emotions, avoiding hasty, careless expressions.
[1969-04-10 19:05:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought that, in the end, I had mastered a way of speaking and writing, using carefully chosen words, steady, thoughtful, and tightly focused sentences, as well as a clean, formal, and refined style, which often left my opponents dialogueless.
[1969-04-10 19:06:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought that night would go the way I hoped, but things didn't turn out that way.
[1969-04-10 19:06:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I know that first, Adele Airota and her friends interpreted the novel, but later, that man with thick glasses made me feel shy. I thought about how I had been cast back into my original form, once again the girl from the slums, the daughter of a doorman, speaking with a southern accent, amazed at how far I had come, and how I had managed to play the role of a young, cultured female writer there.
[1969-04-10 19:07:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | In the end, I lost my confidence, and my expression became confused, incoherent.
[1969-04-10 19:07:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought of Nino's appearance, which made me lose all control. His defense of me once again confirmed my defeat. Suddenly, I lost the ability to speak.
[1969-04-10 19:08:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I know we all came from the same background, and we both worked very hard to master that refined language. I thought about how I had discovered that Nino could use that language with such ease, not only refuting the man before him effortlessly, but also, when he felt it necessary, occasionally adding other elements into that refined Italian.

[1969-04-10 19:08:30] Bookstore Porto | I thought of him, speaking in a carefree and scornful tone, making people feel that the old professor's way of talking was somewhat ridiculous.
[1969-04-10 19:09:00] Bookstore Porto | I saw the result, I saw the old professor about to speak. I thought to myself: He must be really angry right now. He criticized my book before, and now he's surely going to judge me even more harshly, humiliating me and belittling Nino, who defended me.
[1969-04-10 19:09:30] Bookstore Porto | I saw that the man was talking about something else: he didn't mention my novel, and never mentioned my book again.
[1969-04-10 19:10:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw that he was only responding to some of Nino's remarks. Although Nino had said it several times, that wasn't the core of his argument, for example—aristocratic arrogance, literature against authority.
[1969-04-10 19:10:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him, his voice no longer low and somber, but instead using a mocking, affected tone to repeat those expressions (thus, the pride in knowledge had now been defined as arrogance, so even literature had become anti-authoritative?); then he carefully discussed the word "authority." I thought to myself that I only knew for sure that what had made that man angry was the political implication in those words, and he didn't like those kinds of expressions.
[1969-04-10 19:11:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | "I heard him say, 'Thank God,' and he warned, 'Be careful of those uneducated young people. They'll talk nonsense about anything, and they'll quote some reckless university professor's stupid remarks.'"
[1969-04-10 19:11:30] BOOKSTORE 005 | I saw him talking about the same subject for a long time, addressing the public, not targeting Nino or me at all. I thought about how he had started attacking the elderly critic sitting next to me, and then directly targeted Adele Airota, who had actually been his original target.
[1969-04-10 19:12:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | "I'm not targeting these young people," he concluded, "but I want to point out that educated adults, driven by self-interest, follow foolish fashions like sycophants."
[1969-04-10 19:12:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him about to leave, and he whispered. I heard, "Sorry, excuse me, thank you."
[1969-04-10 19:13:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw everyone present stand up to let him pass, although there was some hostility, they all seemed somewhat indifferent.
[1969-04-10 19:13:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Adele Airota also make a somewhat dejected gesture, and politely said, "Thank you, goodbye, take care." I realized then that I had finally understood: he was a big man, so important.
[1969-04-10 19:14:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | At that moment, I saw how Nino displayed in a domineering, even annoying way that he knew who he was dealing with. I thought maybe it was precisely because he was a big shot, which surprised everyone.
[1969-04-10 19:14:30] Bookstore Porto | I heard him call the man "Professor" and he said, "Professor, where are you going? Please don't leave."
[1969-04-10 19:15:00] Bookstore Porto | I saw that Nino had long legs, and in a few steps he was standing in front of him, blocking the professor's path, and said something to the professor in that new language. I saw that I was sitting in my place, I could hear a bit indistinctly, and I didn't quite understand what was being said, but the words should have been as clear as steel wires under the bright sun.
[1969-04-10 19:15:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw the old gentleman standing there, motionless, not losing his patience immediately. After a while, he made a gesture, meaning: step aside.
[1969-04-10 19:16:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him walking toward the door.
[1969-04-10 19:16:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | When I thought about leaving the table, my mind was in a terrible mess. I found it hard to believe that Nino was really there, in that hall at Porto.
[1969-04-10 19:17:00] BOOKSTORE_LOC_005 | I saw it, he walked steadily, smiling as he came toward me.
[1969-04-10 19:17:30] Bookstore Porto | I saw us shaking hands. I saw and felt his hand was very hot, my hand was cold.
[1969-04-10 19:18:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I heard us both saying that it was a joy to meet again after such a long time.
[1969-04-10 19:18:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I knew that the worst moment of that evening had passed, and now he was standing in front of me, real and tangible. I was very excited, and my bad mood gradually eased.
[1969-04-10 19:19:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw myself introducing Nino to the critic who hadenthusiastically praised my novel. 

(Note: The term "enthusiastically praised" is translated as "enthusiastically praised" to maintain the original tone and meaning. If you'd like a more natural or stylistic variation, let me know.) 

Revised translation:  
I saw myself introducing Nino to the critic who had enthusiastically praised my novel. I heard myself say that he was a friend of mine from San Gregorio Armeno, we were high school classmates.
[1969-04-10 19:19:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw the professor critic, who had also been subtly mocked and attacked by Nino just a moment ago, but he was behaving very politely.
[1969-04-10 19:20:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him speaking very enthusiastically about San Gregorio Armeno, and the way he spoke to Nino was as if Nino were an outstanding, encouraging student. I heard him say that Nino did well, that the man had indeed deserved what he got.
[1969-04-10 19:20:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Nino explain that he had lived in Porto for many years, that he was studying economic geography, and that he smiled as he said he was the lowest-ranking teacher at the university, the assistant.
[1969-04-10 19:21:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I found his words amusing. I thought there was no longer that cynical bitterness he had as a child.
[1969-04-10 19:21:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought to myself that now he was wearing a new set of armor, lighter than the one I had been infatuated with when I was in middle school. It was as if he had shed all unnecessary burdens, allowing him to strike with more grace and speed.
[1969-04-10 19:22:00] Bookstore Porto | I saw that he wasn't wearing a wedding ring, and I felt relieved.
[1969-04-10 19:22:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw that at that moment, a female friend of Adele Airota approached me and asked me to sign a book. I thought it was an exciting thing, the first time someone was asking me to sign.
[1969-04-10 19:23:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought about it and hesitated, because I didn't want to miss Nino, not even for a moment, but I also wanted to change the impression I left on him, to make him think that I was no longer that clumsy, foolish girl.
[1969-04-10 19:23:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him chatting with the old professor—Professor Talantano—and I politely greeted my readers.
[1969-04-10 19:24:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw them, but those books were brand new, with the smell of ink, completely different from the old, smelly ones I used to borrow from the Mergellina library with Lina when we were kids. I thought I wanted to sign quickly, but I felt I shouldn't hastily ruin these new books with a ballpoint pen.
[1969-04-10 19:24:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw myself showing off the beautiful calligraphy that Professor Oliviero had taught me, writing some carefully composed dedications. I saw that this made the several ladies waiting behind very impatient.
[1969-04-10 19:25:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I could feel my heart racing as I wrote the dedication, and I kept glancing at Nino. I thought about how scared I was that he might leave.
[1969-04-10 19:25:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw that Nino hadn't left. Now Adele Airota had also approached him and Professor Tarrantano; he spoke to her with respect, yet also with ease and charm.

[1969-04-10 19:26:00] BOOKSTORE 005 | I thought of the image that came to my mind of Nino talking to Teacher Galiani in the school corridor during high school, but in an instant, he had transformed from that outstanding high school student into the young man before me.
[1969-04-10 19:26:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I know the student of Vomero, my married friend's lover; that lost boy hiding in the bathroom of a store in Piazza Martiri; Gennaro's father, yet I've never met the child. I thought to myself, back then he really shouldn't have taken that detour; it made all of us suffer.
[1969-04-10 19:27:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought, of course, that Lina's intrusion had made him lose himself. Clearly, in that situation, the experience had been just a brief episode, although exciting, it had greatly affected him physically and mentally, but that was over now. Nino had found himself again, and I was glad.
[1969-04-10 19:27:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought to myself: I should tell Lina that I saw Nino, that he's doing fine. But in the end, I changed my mind: No, I can't tell her.
[1969-04-10 19:28:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Adele Airota gently take my hand as I finished writing the dedication. I saw that almost everyone had left the hall.
[1969-04-10 19:28:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I heard her praise me, saying that I had spoken very well in introducing the novel, and that I had also done well in responding to the man's terrible dialogue—that's how she described the man with glasses.
[1969-04-10 19:29:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw her looking at me, and I had Nino and Tullante testify on my behalf, both of whom of course said a lot of good things about me. I thought to myself that I was perfectly clear—what she said wasn't true.
[1969-04-10 19:29:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Nino looking at me very seriously at last. I heard, "You don't know, this girl was already very smart in high school, read a lot of books, and was very brave and beautiful."
[1969-04-10 19:30:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | At that moment, he spoke in a polite and refined manner, humorously recounting my early conflict with the religious teacher. I felt my face grow hot.
[1969-04-10 19:30:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Adele Airota there, listening and sometimes smiling. I heard her say, "In our family, everyone immediately recognized Elena's qualities."
[1969-04-10 19:31:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I heard and then she announced that she had reserved a restaurant not far from there, and she wanted us to go have dinner together.
[1969-04-10 19:31:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw myself awkwardly muttering that I was tired and not hungry. I thought about my worries.
[1969-04-10 19:32:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I thought I needed to make them understand that it had been a long time since I'd seen Nino, and I hoped to go out with him before returning to the hotel to talk.
[1969-04-10 19:32:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I knew that dinner was a celebration for me, a thank-you for Tarantano's support of the book. It would have been very improper of me not to go, but I couldn't help myself.
[1969-04-10 19:33:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw Adele Airota give me a mocking look, then, as if to compensate me for the sacrifice I'd made, she whispered mysteriously. I heard her say that she had also invited my friend along, "I've prepared a surprise for you."
[1969-04-10 19:33:30] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw myself looking at Nino uneasily. I wondered if he would accept the invitation.
[1969-04-10 19:34:00] Quartiere Spagnolo | I saw him glance at his watch and finally accepted. I heard him say that he didn't want to disturb us.
[1969-04-10 19:34:30] Street of Porto | I saw us leaving the bookstore. Adele Airota was very careful, she and Tarrantano walked ahead, and I followed with Nino.
[1969-04-10 19:35:00] Street of Porto | I thought to myself that I would immediately realize I didn't know what to say to him, and I was afraid that as soon as I opened my mouth, I would say the wrong thing.
[1969-04-10 19:35:30] Street 005 | I saw Nino break the silence, and to keep the conversation from lagging, he praised my book again, then spoke of the Pietro family with admiration (he described them as "one of the most important and civilized families in Italy").
[1969-04-10 19:36:00] Street of Porto | I saw him and he told me he had learned from Adele Airota that I was engaged to Pietro, and he congratulated me. I heard him say he knew Mariarosa ("She was always on my mind, and two weeks ago, we had a big fight.").
[1969-04-10 19:36:30] Street 005 | I saw, especially, that he spoke with respect of the head of the Pietro family—Guido Airota, Professor Pietro. "He's a truly remarkable man." What surprised me was how familiar he seemed with Pietro's book on Dionysian worship.
[1969-04-10 19:37:00] Street of Porto | I thought about the fact that he knew I was engaged, which made me a bit uncomfortable. I realized that his praise for my novel was just an introduction, allowing him to praise the whole Pietro family and Pietro's book, which made me even more uneasy.
[1969-04-10 19:37:30] Street of Porto | I saw that I had interrupted him, so I asked how he was. But his answer was vague, just mentioning a small book he was about to publish. I thought he found the book boring, but he had to publish it.
[1969-04-10 19:38:00] Street 005 | I asked him about his life when he first arrived at Porto, whether he had faced any difficulties. He gave me a vague answer, talking about the problems he had when he first came from the south with no money in his pocket.
[1969-04-10 19:38:30] Street of Porto | I heard him suddenly ask me, "Have you gone back to live in San Gregorio Armeno?"
[1969-04-10 19:38:35] Street of Porto | I heard, "It's currently."
[1969-04-10 19:38:40] Street of Porto | I heard, "Living in Mergellina?"
[1969-04-10 19:38:45] Street of Porto | I heard, "Yes."
[1969-04-10 19:38:50] Street of Porto | I heard, "I have completely cut off all relations with my father, and I no longer see my family."
[1969-04-10 19:38:55] Street of Porto | I heard, "That's really a pity."
[1969-04-10 19:39:00] Street 005 | "I heard, 'It's probably better this way. It's just a pity I've heard nothing more about Lina."

[1969-04-10 19:40:00] Street of Porto | I thought again: In these years, if he really wanted to find out about Lina's news, he would surely have found a way.
[1969-04-10 19:40:30] Street of Porto | I saw myself, acting on a sudden impulse, saying in a straightforward tone that I didn't want to talk about it anymore. I heard, "She has left her husband and is now living with another man."
[1969-04-10 19:40:35] Street of Porto | I heard, "Did she have a boy or a girl?"
[1969-04-10 19:40:40] Street of Porto | I heard "a boy."
[1969-04-10 19:40:45] Street of Porto | I saw him make an unhappy face. I heard someone say, "Lina is very brave, even too brave. But she can't accept reality, she can't accept others, and she can't accept herself. Loving her is a very difficult thing, a very painful experience."
[1969-04-10 19:40:50] Street of Porto | "I heard 'What do you mean?'"
[1969-04-10 19:40:55] Street of Porto | I heard, "She doesn't know what dedication is."

[1969-04-10 19:42:00] Street of Porto | I couldn't stop thinking about what he had just said to me, even bringing up something about sex? It really made me uneasy.

[1969-04-10 21:03:30] At the entrance of Mask Hotel | I saw his clumsy steps and the messy hair sticking up on his head. I suddenly felt very soft-hearted.
[1969-04-11 20:00:00] at home | I remember, for example, that on the same evening I returned from Porto, I told my parents. I heard that Pietro wants to meet them, and we might get married within a year. After the wedding, we'll go live in Mergellina.

[1969-04-11 20:01:00] at home | I thought to myself that my father was a bit excited, which was normal—those issues he had never faced before always made him a little anxious.
[1969-04-11 20:01:30] at home | I saw him impatiently asking. I heard, "Is that university professor really coming to our house?"
[1969-04-11 20:02:00] at home | I saw my mother lose her temper. I heard myself say, "If he doesn't come to our house, where else would he go? If he doesn't come here, how can he propose to Elena, how can he ask for your hand in marriage?"
[1969-04-11 20:02:30] at home | I saw her make her husband shut up. I know that usually, my mother remains calmer than my father when faced with problems. She is practical and decisive, sometimes even seeming a bit unfeeling.
[1969-04-11 22:00:00] at home | I saw my father go to bed, and Elena, Peppe, and Gianni had set up their beds in the dining room.
[1969-04-11 22:00:30] at home | I saw her start to scold me. Her eyes were red, and she stared at me, speaking slowly and clearly. I saw her voice was low, but it was shouted.
[1969-04-11 22:01:00] at home | "I heard you say, 'To you, we're nothing. You always inform us at the last minute. You went to school for a few days, wrote a book, and are about to marry a university professor, so you think you're special, that you've become a princess. [1969-04-11 22:01:30] at home | I saw her angry, and she started by saying it was because of me, because I had gone away to study, thinking only of my own affairs. My younger brothers were doing terribly in school, completely useless.
[1969-04-11 22:02:00] at home | I saw and then she asked me for money, saying she needed it to buy a decent outfit for Elena and to tidy up the house, because I forced her to host my fiancé.
[1969-04-11 22:02:30] at home | I saw that I hadn't paid attention to my younger brothers' grades at school, but I immediately gave her the money. I thought, although I knew those money wasn't meant for fixing the house, she kept asking me for money, and each reason she gave was good.
[1969-04-11 22:03:00] at home | I thought that although she never said it outright, she still couldn't accept the fact that I was saving money in the post office, instead of handing over all the money I earned to her as I had before.
[1969-04-11 22:03:30] at home | I know that before, I worked at the Mazzucchelli bookstore, or maybe I took the shopkeeper's daughter to the sea, and all the money I earned went to her.
[1969-04-11 22:04:00] at home | I thought, maybe she felt that all my money belonged to her, that she wanted to convince me she belonged to me, even though I would get married, I would still belong to her forever.
[1969-04-11 22:04:30] at home | I kept myself as calm as I could, just as we had agreed.
[1969-04-11 22:05:00] at home | I heard myself telling her that I would install a telephone at home and buy a television for the house on installment.
[1969-04-11 22:05:30] at home | I saw her looking at me as if she couldn't believe it, then suddenly she made an expression of great appreciation, speaking to me in the same tone as before. I heard, "Installing a telephone and television at home?"
[1969-04-11 22:06:00] at home | I heard, "Of course."
[1969-04-11 22:06:05] at home | I heard, "You're paying?"
[1969-04-11 22:06:10] at home | I heard, "Yes."
[1969-04-11 22:06:15] Borgo | I heard, "You'll keep paying even after we get married?"
[1969-04-11 22:06:20] at home | I heard, "Yes."
[1969-04-11 22:06:25] at home | I heard her say, "Does that professor know we don't have a penny in dowry and can't even afford to host a banquet?"
[1969-04-11 22:06:30] at home | I heard, "He knows, we won't have a wedding banquet."
[1969-04-11 22:07:00] at home | I saw her mood getting worse again. I saw her eyes turn red.
[1969-04-11 22:07:30] at home | "I heard, 'What, no wedding banquet? You can make him pay for it.'"
[1969-04-11 22:07:35] Borgo | I heard, "No, we won't have a wedding banquet."
[1969-04-11 22:08:00] at home | I saw my mother start to lose her temper again, and she cursed me with all sorts of words. I thought she wanted me to respond to her, to add fuel to the fire.
[1969-04-11 22:08:30] at home | I heard, "Do you remember Lina's wedding? Do you remember the wedding banquet?"
[1969-04-11 22:08:35] at home | I heard "Remember."
[1969-04-11 22:08:40] Borgo | I heard, "You're much better than her, why don't you do it?"
[1969-04-11 22:08:45] at home | I heard "Don't want to."
[1969-04-11 22:09:00] at home | I saw that we have always communicated this way. I thought, in the end, it was better to let her vent her anger all at once rather than savor it slowly.
[1969-04-11 22:09:30] at home | I said, "Mom!" I said, "We're not having a wedding banquet, and we won't get married in a church either. We'll just get married at the civil affairs office of the city government."
[1969-04-11 22:10:00] at home | As I thought about this, I felt as if a strong wind had blown, pushing the doors and windows open.
[1969-04-11 22:10:30] at home | I saw her start to scream uncontrollably, her face red, her whole body leaning forward as she cursed in the most vile way. I know that although my mother was not religious at all.
[1969-04-11 22:11:00] Borgo | I heard her shouting that without a priest, the marriage was invalid! She said, if I hadn't married in front of God, then I wasn't a wife, but a prostitute.
[1969-04-11 22:11:30] at home | I saw her, despite her leg problems, rush like the wind to wake up my father and my brothers, telling them the thing she had been worried about all along—that I had studied for too many years and had ruined my mind.
[1969-04-11 22:12:00] at home | I heard her shouting that I was so lucky, so successful, but I let others treat me like a prostitute. She said that having a daughter who didn't believe in God would be so shameful she couldn't even leave the house.
[1969-04-11 22:12:30] at home | I saw my father come out in his underwear, looking confused. Several of my brothers and sisters wanted to find out what I had done and what trouble we were now facing.
[1969-04-11 22:13:00] at home | I saw them trying to calm my mother down, but it didn't work. She screamed and shouted that she wanted me out of the house immediately. She didn't want to endure such humiliation. I heard her say she didn't want a daughter like Lina or Pinocchio, not even one with a formal marriage.
[1969-04-11 22:13:30] at home | I saw it then, even though she didn't actually come over to slap me, just waving her hand in the air. I thought of her, but it seemed as if I were a shadow, and she was hitting a real me.
[1969-04-11 22:14:00] at home | I saw her struggling hard to calm down, which was Elena's doing.
[1969-04-11 22:14:30] at home | I saw my sister ask hesitantly. "I heard, 'Is it you or your fiancé who wants to get married at the civil affairs office?'"

text:
[1969-04-11 22:15:00] Borgo | I saw myself explaining to her, actually wanting to clarify everything for everyone. I heard that it's been a long time since I went to the church. To me, whether getting married in the church or at the civil affairs office is the same.
[1969-04-11 22:15:30] Borgo | I heard it, but for my fiancé, getting married at the Civil Affairs Bureau was very important. He understood all the issues related to religion; he thought religion was a sacred thing, but the church had interfered too much in state affairs and had become corrupted.
[1969-04-11 22:16:00] at home | I heard myself say at last, in conclusion, that if we didn't get married at the civil affairs office, then he wouldn't marry me.
[1969-04-11 22:16:30] Borgo | I saw that at this point, my father began to take my mother's side, but now he no longer joined in her complaints or scolded me.
[1969-04-11 22:17:00] at home | I heard, "He won't marry you?"
[1969-04-11 22:17:05] at home | I heard, "No."
[1969-04-11 22:17:10] at home | I heard, "What will he do? Will he break up with you?"
[1969-04-11 22:17:15] at home | I heard, "We won't get married, but we'll live together at Mergellina."
[1969-04-11 22:17:30] Borgo | I realized this was the one thing my mother could not stand. She was absolutely furious. I heard her say that if I dared to do that, she would kill me with a knife.
[1969-04-11 22:18:00] at home | I saw my father nervously running his hands through his hair, and he said to my mother. I heard, "Just shut up for a moment and don't anger me. Let's talk calmly. We both know that those who get married in front of the priest and then have a big feast might end up with a really bad marriage."
[1969-04-11 22:18:30] at home | I know this has always been a scandal for us, Mergellina. I thought he was referring to Lina.
[1969-04-11 22:19:00] at home | I thought about how my mother had finally understood that the priest wasn't a guarantee, that in this ugly world of ours, there were no guarantees at all.
[1969-04-11 22:19:30] Borgo | I saw that she stopped shouting and asked my father to assess the situation, then told me to obey.
[1969-04-11 22:20:00] at home | I saw her limping around the house at that moment, shaking her head and cursing my future husband. "I heard, 'What is he? A professor? Is he Communist Party? What a stupid professor! What kind of professor would think like that? Only an idiot would think that way!"
[1969-04-11 22:20:30] at home | I heard my father say, "Not like that. This professor has only studied religious issues; he knows better than anyone the dirty things those priests have done. That's precisely why he wants to get married at the civil affairs office."
[1969-04-11 22:21:00] at home | "I heard, 'Well, you're right, many party members do it this way. So, your daughter is like unmarried, but I don't believe that university professor at all. If he really loved our daughter, I can't believe he would let Elena live with him like a prostitute, unmarried."
[1969-04-11 22:21:30] at home | "I heard, 'In any case, if we don't believe him, we should at least believe the city government— but I do believe him, even though I haven't met him yet. He's a very important man, the kind of man many girls want to marry. I work at the city government, and I can assure you that weddings held there are just as valid, if not more so, than those held in churches.'"
[1969-04-12 01:00:00] at home | I watched them talk like that for several more hours. Later, my younger brothers and sisters couldn't take it anymore and one by one went to sleep.
[1969-04-12 01:00:30] at home | I saw myself comforting my parents, trying to convince them to accept this situation. I thought that feeling this was very important for me to enter Pietro's world.
[1969-04-12 01:01:00] at home | I thought, in addition, through this way, I felt bolder than Lina.
[1969-04-12 01:01:30] Borgo | I thought, especially, that if I met Nino again, I would hint to him: "Look, what came of that argument between me and the religious teacher. Every choice has consequences. Often, our lives are squeezed into a corner, waiting for an opportunity, and that opportunity will eventually come."
[1969-04-12 01:02:00] at home | I thought, but maybe I was exaggerating. In reality, things were simple. For at least ten years, the God of my childhood had already lost most of his influence over me. He was like an ailing old man, lying in a corner.
[1969-04-12 01:02:30] at home | I thought I didn't need a sacred marriage at all. The most essential issue was: I had to leave San Gregorio Armeno.
[1969-04-12 08:00:00] at home | I thought about how my family's fear that I was going to the civil affairs office to get married, instead of the church, wouldn't disappear in one night, but that fear gradually faded.
[1969-04-12 08:00:30] at home | I saw that the next day, my mother was extremely angry with me, yet she didn't shout. I thought about it and felt as if everything she touched—the coffee pot, the glass with milk, the sugar bowl, a fresh slice of bread—would make her want to smash it right into my face.
[1969-04-12 08:01:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her, but I ignored her. I left very early in the morning to handle the paperwork for installing a telephone at home.
[1969-04-12 09:00:00] Alba Port | I finished quickly and then ran to the Albano port, where I wandered through the bookstores.
[1969-04-12 09:00:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I thought about my determination to overcome my shyness when speaking in public, for example, the scene at Porto's bookstore.
[1969-04-12 09:01:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I saw that I had blindly picked out some books and magazines based on pure instinct, spending a lot of money.
[1969-04-12 09:01:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I saw that after much hesitation, I finally chose Freud's Three Essays on Sexuality, and I also bought two little pamphlets about sex. I know almost nothing about Freud, and the little bit of his theory that I do know is something I can't accept. I often find Nino's words echoing in my mind.
[1969-04-12 09:02:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I know, just like when I used to read textbooks at school, prepare for exams, and write essays, it was also like how I had treated the newspaper that Galiani gave me, or the Marxist pamphlets Franco Mari gave me a few years ago. I thought about wanting to "study" the modern world.
[1969-04-12 09:02:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I found it hard to explain, my understanding of the world during that time.
[1969-04-12 09:03:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I know I've talked to Pasquale, to Nino. I've had some interest in what's been happening in Cuba and Latin America. I'm aware of the inescapable poverty of Mergellina, Lina's downfall, and the fact that the school expelled my two younger brothers because they weren't as diligent in their studies as I was.
[1969-04-12 09:03:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I know I had long conversations with Franco Mari, and also an accidental meeting with Mariarosa. I think about it now, and I feel that all of this has been swallowed up in a white smoke (this world is extremely unfair and needs to be changed, but whether it's peaceful coexistence between the US and the Soviet Union, or the political reforms of the European labor parties, especially the Italian ones, they all tend to keep the proletariat in a state of waiting, keeping them in an auxiliary position, all of them are dousing the revolution, and the result is that the world gets stuck in a deadlock).
[1969-04-12 09:04:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I thought that if the Social Democratic Party won, capitalism would rule the world, and the working class would also become part of consumerism.
[1969-04-12 09:04:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I thought about these things, which stirred me up from time to time. I forced myself to update my knowledge, to keep up with current events. At first, my goal was simply to make an impression.
[1969-04-12 09:05:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I have always believed that everything can be learned, including political passion.
[1969-04-12 09:05:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I saw, while paying for these books, that my novel was placed on one of the shelves. I immediately turned my gaze elsewhere.
[1969-04-12 09:06:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I saw, every time I looked in the bookstore window, my book displayed alongside the other newly published ones. I feel a mix of fear and pride, a strong sense of pleasure, but in the end, it always turns into anxiety.
[1969-04-12 09:06:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I know, of course, that this novel was created by chance, written in twenty days, without much effort. I thought it was like a medicine that could ease my depression.
[1969-04-12 09:07:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I know, of course. I know what great literature is. I spent a long time studying classical literature, and when I wrote this novel, I never once thought that I was creating something valuable. I thought about it, but I wanted to find a way to express it. Finally, this outburst of mine became a book—a book that contained something of myself.
[1969-04-12 09:07:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I see it now, "I" is right there, I'm watching myself. I thought about how fast my heart was beating in my chest.
[1969-04-12 09:08:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I thought not only in my books, but usually in those novels, I always feel something that excites me, like a bare, jumping heart. It's the same feeling I had back in the distant past when Lina suggested we write a story together.
[1969-04-12 09:08:30] Alba Port Bookstore | I thought that this dream was later fulfilled by me. But was it what I really wanted? Writing, writing isn't something arbitrary. It has to be better than before, doesn't it?
[1969-04-12 09:09:00] Alba Port Bookstore | I thought about the novels of the present and past, about understanding how novels are written, about learning, learning everything in this world, all for the sole purpose of shaping truly real souls. No one portrays them as accurately as I do, not even Lina, who wouldn't have been able to write so well even if she had the chance.

[1969-04-12 09:20:00] Cavour Square | I stopped for a moment on Cavour Square after leaving the bookstore. I saw that the weather was very good that day. I saw the colonnade on Via Fria, supported by steel columns, and it looked very solid, cleaner and neater than usual.
[1969-04-12 09:25:00] Cavour Square | I read the newly bought book and newspaper very carefully, as I usually did.
[1969-04-12 09:30:00] Cavour Square | I saw myself taking out my newly bought notebook from my pocket and jotting down some useful information. I thought I wanted to be a real writer, to focus on my own thoughts and observe them carefully.
[1969-04-12 09:35:00] Cavour Square | I watched L'Unità from start to finish, taking notes on things I didn't know.
[1969-04-12 09:40:00] Cavour Square | I saw an article by Pietro's father in the Bridge Newspaper, and out of curiosity, I read it carefully. I thought, but I felt it wasn't as important as Nino said, the article made me feel uncomfortable.
[1969-04-12 09:40:30] Cavour Square | I thought of two reasons: first, the language used by Guido Airota-Pietro was harsher than the language used by the professor with thick glasses.
[1969-04-12 09:41:00] Cavour Square | I know that later, there's a passage where he mentions some female college students. "This is a new group," he wrote, "obviously none of them are daughters of wealthy families. These girls wear simple clothes and have received a simple education. They hope to study hard so that in the future they won't have to just stay at home."
[1969-04-12 09:41:30] Cavour Square | I thought he was implying me, he did it on purpose, or perhaps without thinking.
[1969-04-12 09:42:00] Cavour Square | I noted this down in my journal as well (what was I to the Pietro family? A flower pinned on a button in their broad vision?), which was really disheartening. I became a bit annoyed and started flipping through Corriere della Sera.
[1969-04-12 09:45:00] Cavour Square | I remember seeing it, the weather was mild, and I also remember—maybe it's invented, maybe it's real—the smell, the scent of fried pizza mixed with the smell of newspapers.
[1969-04-12 09:45:30] Cavour Square | I watched myself flipping through the newspapers page by page. Later, I saw a headline that took my breath away, and there in the middle of four columns of dense type was a photo of me. I saw a small part of our Mergellina and Mercato in the background of the photo.
[1969-04-12 09:46:00] Cavour Square | I knew the title of the article was "A Girl Full of Ambition's Erotic Memoirs — The Debut Work of Elena Greco," and the signature at the bottom was indeed that man with thick-rimmed glasses.
[1969-04-12 09:46:30] Cavour Square | I read the article and broke out in cold sweat, feeling like I was going to pass out.
[1969-04-12 09:47:00] Cavour Square | I know my book is just an introduction for him; what he really wants to say is that in the past ten years, in every field of society, culture, and production—from factories to offices, universities, publishing houses, and the film industry—this generation of young people has no value whatsoever, they're a spoiled generation, and the entire world has fallen into chaos.
[1969-04-12 09:47:30] Cavour Square | I know he sometimes quotes sentences from my novels, putting them in quotation marks, just to show: I represent this generation, I am a typical product of bad education.
[1969-04-12 09:48:00] Garibaldi Square | I know that in the end, he defined me as a girl who used banal pornography to hide her lack of talent.
[1969-04-12 09:48:30] Cavour Square | I saw myself crying. I thought about how, since the publication of that book, it was the harshest criticism I had ever seen—not in a local newspaper, but in one sold throughout Italy.
[1969-04-12 09:49:00] Garibaldi Square | What tormented me most was the sight of my smiling face appearing in such an unforgiving article.
[1969-04-12 10:30:00] On the way home | I saw myself walking home, and before going home, I threw away the newspaper. I thought about how scared I was that my mother would read the review and then use it against me.
[1969-04-12 10:30:30] On the way home | I thought about how she would cut out that article and put it in her scrapbook, and every time I offended her, she would pull it out.
[1969-04-12 11:00:00] at home | I saw that only my utensils were placed on the table. I know my father is at work, and my mother has gone to the neighbor's house, I don't know what she's going to get, and my younger brothers and sisters have already eaten.
[1969-04-12 11:05:00] at home | After I put the noodles and potatoes into the pot, I started reading my book. I thought desperately: maybe this book really has no value at all, maybe they published it just to give Adele Airota a favor.
[1969-04-12 11:10:00] at home | I wondered how I could have written such a bland sentence, expressed such an ordinary opinion? It's truly clumsy, so many useless quotation marks. I'll never write again!
[1969-04-12 11:15:00] at home | I was so depressed I couldn't taste my food, and I kept looking at my book while eating.
[1969-04-12 11:20:00] at home | I saw that Elena had returned and she gave me a note with a phone number from Signora Spagnuolo. I knew Mrs. Spagnuolo was very warm toward me, so I had those people who were urgently looking for me call her instead.
[1969-04-12 11:20:30] at home | I knew the note said there were three of my numbers: one was Gina Metotti's, who handled the printing for the publisher, one was Adele Airota's, and the last was Pietro's.
[1969-04-12 11:21:00] at home | I saw Mrs. Spagnuolo's handwriting was crooked. When I thought of those three names, I felt the idea that had just surfaced in my heart had become reality—the terrible things written by that man with thick glasses were spreading rapidly, becoming known to everyone within a single day.
[1969-04-12 11:21:30] at home | I thought about how Pietro had seen it, and his family had seen it, and the publisher's editor had seen it. Maybe Nino had seen it too, and even my teacher at Borgo. Of course, it would also catch the attention of Teacher Galiani and her several children. Who knows, maybe Lina had seen it as well.
[1969-04-12 11:22:00] at home | I saw myself suddenly start crying, which frightened Elena.
[1969-04-12 11:22:30] Borgo | I heard, "What's wrong? Elena?"
[1969-04-12 11:22:35] at home | "I feel unwell."
[1969-04-12 11:22:40] at home | I heard, "Shall I brew you a cup of chamomile tea?"
[1969-04-12 11:22:45] at home | "I heard 'Okay.'"
[1969-04-12 11:25:00] at home | I saw she hadn't even had time to make tea when someone knocked on the door—Mrs. Spagnuolo. She was very happy, a bit out of breath because she had climbed the stairs all the way up without stopping. I heard her say that my boyfriend called again, and he's still waiting on the other end of the line. His voice is really nice, with a nice northern accent.
[1969-04-12 11:26:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I saw it and immediately ran downstairs to answer the phone, apologizing to her and saying I was sorry to disturb her.
[1969-04-12 11:27:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I saw Pietro trying to comfort me. I heard him say that his mother had told him to tell me not to be sad, that the important thing was that someone was talking about the book.
[1969-04-12 11:28:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | What surprised Mrs. Spenulo was that I, whom she had always thought to be a gentle girl, shouted into the microphone. I heard, "If people talked about this book and said nothing but bad things, would you still remain indifferent?"
[1969-04-12 11:28:30] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I heard him tell me to calm down again, then he added, "There will be an article on L'Unità tomorrow."
[1969-04-12 11:29:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I saw myself coldly hanging up the phone. I heard myself say, "It's best if no one pays any attention to me."

[1969-04-13 06:00:00] at home | I watched all night, I couldn't close my eyes.
[1969-04-13 07:00:00] Street newsstand | I saw that in the morning I couldn't help but run out and buy a L'Unità. Right in front of the newsstand, I started flipping through it. I knew it was a newsstand just a few steps away from my old elementary school.
[1969-04-13 07:05:00] Street Newsstand | I saw my photo again, the same one that had been published on Corriere della Sera. I saw that this time the photo wasn't placed in the middle of the article, but at the very top, next to the title, which was: "The Young Rebel and the Old Reactionary — On Elena Greco's New Book."
[1969-04-13 07:10:00] Street Newsstand | I knew it was written by an author I had never heard of, but the person's writing was extremely good. I thought of his words, and they immediately began to heal me.
[1969-04-13 07:15:00] Street newsstand | I saw him lavish praise on my novel and criticize the authoritative professor with thick glasses.
[1969-04-13 08:00:00] at home | I saw myself returning home, and my heart felt better, even my mood had completely improved.
[1969-04-13 08:30:00] at home | I saw myself flipping through my book. I thought again now and still found it beautifully written, harmonious.
[1969-04-13 08:35:00] at home | I saw my mother speaking with a mocking expression. I heard, "Did you win the lottery?"
[1969-04-13 08:40:00] at home | I saw myself placing the newspaper on the kitchen table, saying nothing.
[1969-04-13 15:00:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I saw Mrs. Spagnuolo appear again in the afternoon; she said someone had called me. I heard her say, embarrassed and apologetic, that she was happy to be able to help a girl like me, then went on to praise me a lot.
[1969-04-13 15:05:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I saw her sighing in the hallway. I heard that "Giggia was unfortunate. When she was thirteen, her father made her work in the Solara's Capodimonte. It's a good thing she was engaged to Michele, otherwise she would have had to suffer for a lifetime."
[1969-04-13 15:10:00] Mrs. Spagnuolo's house | I saw her open the door, walk through the corridor, and lead me to the phone hanging on the wall. I noticed that she had placed a chair in front of the phone, so I could sit comfortably while making the call.

[1969-05-02 17:15:30] Elena's living room | I was about to answer him, but Nadia interjected, pushing me aside. She spoke to Lina in that slow, sultry voice, as if there was nothing worth saying between her and me. "I heard, 'Those labor inspectors are of no use, Lina. They went to the Sokolovo factory, they took notes, but then what? Everything stayed the same in the factory. The ones who spoke up got in trouble, and the quiet ones received a few lira as compensation. The police attacked us, and the Fascist members came downstairs and beat Nadia."
[1969-05-02 17:16:00] Elena's living room | I saw she hadn't finished speaking, and Pasquale said to me in an even more resolute tone, raising his voice more than before. I heard, "Tell us, you fucking bastard, what problem have you actually solved?"

[1969-05-02 17:17:00] Elena's living room | I saw Nadia say, "Please don't shout so much," and then she turned to Lina, almost whispering. "I heard, 'You shouldn't leave your companion behind.'"
[1969-05-02 17:17:30] Elena's living room | I heard, "No matter what, we're going to fail." "What do you mean?" "Inside, it's impossible to win by handing out flyers or fighting with Fascist." "Then how do we win?"
