[1969-05-02 17:19:30] Elena's living room | I saw that, but at that moment, Lina stopped me with an unexpected and impatient remark, leaving me very confused, she said. I heard, "Stop it! Elena, they're right."
[1969-05-02 17:20:00] Elena's living room | I saw that, but at this moment, Teacher Galiani returned, and I could hear her footsteps echoing in the hallway. I thought I felt sad, were they right? I wanted to fight back, I wanted to get angry with her, what exactly was she trying to say?
[1969-05-02 17:20:10] The living room of the Galiani family | I hoped that the teacher hadn't heard my cry, and I waited for Nadia to quickly get off Pasquale's lap and sit on the sofa. I also hoped to see the two of them feel embarrassed about their pretense. I noticed that Lina was also looking at them with a mocking expression.
[1969-05-02 17:20:20] Elena's living room | I saw them, but they remained in their original position. Nadia had her arm around Pasquale's neck, as if afraid she might fall, and she said to her mother who had appeared at the door. I heard, "Next time you have a guest, let me know in advance."
[1969-05-02 17:20:30] Living Room of the Galiani Family | I saw the teacher ignoring her, just coldly saying to us. I heard, "I'm sorry, I'm late. Let's go to my study."
[1969-05-02 17:21:00] Elena's living room | I saw us following her in. Pasquale pushed Nadia aside a bit, and suddenly spoke in a tone that had become unexpectedly despondent. I heard, "Come on, let's go over there."
[1969-05-02 17:22:00] Corridor of the Galiani House | I saw Galiani leading us, and in the hallway, she muttered angrily under her breath. I heard, "I hate rude behavior most."
[1969-05-02 17:23:00] Galiani's Study | I saw and then she led us into a spacious room. I saw an old writing desk inside, with many books on it and some rather formal, upholstered chairs.
[1969-05-02 17:24:00] Galiani's Study | I saw her speaking to us in a gentle and polite manner. I thought, but it was obvious that she was struggling with her bad mood.
[1969-05-02 17:25:00] Elena's Study | I saw her say that she was happy to see me and Lina. I thought, yes, but I could sense her anger between the lines, and I hoped to leave as soon as possible.
[1969-05-02 17:26:00] Elena's Study | I said, I apologized for not appearing for so long, and I spoke about the hardships of my studies, the book I had published, and all the things I had to deal with: the engagement, the upcoming wedding, and so on.
[1969-05-02 17:27:00] Galiani's Study | I heard, "Are you getting married in the church or at the civil affairs office?" "Just at the civil affairs office." "Good."
[1969-05-02 17:27:30] Galiani's Study | I saw her looking at Lina, wanting her to join our conversation. "I heard that the wedding was held in the church?" "Yes." "Are you a believer?" "No."
[1969-05-02 17:28:00] Galiani's Study | I heard, "Then why did you get married in the church?" "Everyone does it that way." "You shouldn't just follow what others do." "A lot of people do it that way."
[1969-05-02 17:28:30] Galiani's Study | I saw the question: "Are you going to Elena's wedding?" "She didn't invite me," I immediately replied. "That's not true."
[1969-05-02 17:29:00] Galiani's Study | I saw Lina smirk and say. I heard, "It's true, she's afraid I'll embarrass her."
[1969-05-02 17:29:10] Galiani's Study | I knew she was speaking in jest. I kept thinking about it, but I was still hurt. What happened? Why did she say I was wrong in front of Nadia and Pasquale, and now she's saying such hateful things in front of the teacher?
[1969-05-02 17:30:00] Galiani's Study | "I don't believe it," I said. To calm myself down, I took out my novel from my bag and handed it to Professor Galiani, saying, "I want to give this to you."
[1969-05-02 17:31:00] Galiani's Study | I saw that she didn't look at the book properly, she thanked me, and she said. I heard, "I already have one." I thought about my own matters.
[1969-05-02 17:31:30] Galiani's Study | I saw it and then returned the book to me, asking me. I heard, "What does your husband do?" "He teaches Latin literature at Mergellina." "He's much older than you, isn't he?" "He's twenty-seven."
[1969-05-02 17:32:00] Galiani's Study | I heard, "So young, already holding a teaching position at the university?" "He's really good." "What's his name?" "Pietro. Pietro."
[1969-05-02 17:32:30] Galiani's Study | I saw Teacher Galiani examining me very carefully. I thought of how, back in school, she had asked me a question and my answer hadn't been comprehensive enough.
[1969-05-02 17:33:00] Galiani's Study | I saw "He's a relative of Guido Airota-Pietro?" "He's his son," she said, smiling, clearly with malice. "I heard 'A very good marriage.' 'We love each other very much.'"
[1969-05-02 17:34:00] Galiani's Study | I heard, "Have you already started writing another book?" "I'm working on it." "I saw the article you wrote on L'Unità." "Not much." "I'm not writing there anymore, now it's just a bureaucratic newspaper."
[1969-05-02 17:35:00] Galiani's Study | I saw her speaking to Lina again, as if trying every possible way to show her friendliness, and she said to Lina. I heard, "What you do in the factory is amazing."
[1969-05-02 17:35:30] Galiani's Study | I saw Lina make an annoyed face. "I didn't do anything." "That's not true."
[1969-05-02 17:36:00] Galiani's Study | I saw Teacher Galiani stand up, riffled through the papers on the desk, and showed her a few pages. I thought it was irrefutable evidence.
[1969-05-02 17:37:00] Galiani's Study | I heard that "Nadia just randomly left the manuscripts at home, and I took a look. It's something full of courage, very original, and it's written well. I wanted to talk to you about it when I saw you."
[1969-05-02 17:38:00] Galiani's Study | I saw that what she was holding in her hand was the few pages written by Lina. I know that based on these materials, I wrote my first article for L'Unità.
[1969-05-02 17:50:00] The Galiani Family's Home | I thought, yes, I really should have pulled away. After leaving Teacher Galiani's house, I felt very bitter, and my mouth was dry.
locations: The living room of the Galiani family
Living Room of the Galiani Family

text:
[1969-05-02 17:51:00] Galiani Family | I thought about how I lacked the courage to tell my teacher that she shouldn't have treated me that way: even though she might have had the book I wrote a long time ago, she must have read it, at least roughly, and it was fine that she never mentioned my book at all, but she didn't even ask me to bring her the copy with my dedication.
[1969-05-02 17:52:00] The Galiani Family's Home | I still left the book for her before leaving. I thought about it because of my cowardice, and also because I wanted to end the relationship in a gentle way.
[1969-05-02 17:53:00] Galiani Family | I saw her neither say yes nor no; she smiled and continued talking to Lina.
[1969-05-02 17:54:00] the Galiani family's home | I saw that, especially regarding my article, she didn't mention it at all. She only referred to it once in order to lead into a negative evaluation of L'Unità. I thought about how she took out the pages that Lina had written and started talking to Lina, as if my opinions on the subject were worthless, as if I wasn't even in the room anymore.
[1969-05-02 17:55:00] The Galiani Family's Home | I thought of what I had wanted to shout at her: "Yes, Lina is very smart, that's true, I've always known she was smart. I love her intelligence, it has influenced everything I've done. But I've achieved this through my own efforts. Everyone admires me. I'm not like your daughter, who's absolutely useless."
[1969-05-02 17:56:00] The Galiani Family's Home | I watched but remained silent, I was there, listening to them discuss the work in the factory and the workers' demands.
[1969-05-02 18:00:00] Stairs of the Galiani Family | I didn't stop until I reached the stairwell, and they were still talking there. In the end, Teacher Galiani casually greeted me, but she was still speaking to Lina.
[1969-05-02 18:01:00] Stairs of the Galiani Family | I saw that they had already started calling each other "you": "You should keep in touch with me often!" Then they hugged her. I thought of it and it made me feel humiliated.
[1969-05-02 18:02:00] Stairs of the Galiani Family | I knew Nadia and Pasquale never showed up again. I thought about how I'd never get the chance to vent the anger I'd been holding inside: was it wrong to help a friend? Hadn't I also put myself out there for her? How could they criticize what I'd done like that.
[1969-05-02 18:05:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw that finally, on the stairs, in the foyer, and on the sidewalk on Vittorio Emanuele street, only me and Lina were left.
[1969-05-02 18:06:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought to myself, I was desperate to shout at her: "Do you really think I'm afraid of bringing shame upon you? What's wrong with your mind? Why did you say those two people were right? You're truly heartless. I've done everything I could to help you, to be with you, and this is how you treat me? Your mind is really sick."
[1969-05-02 18:07:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her, but as soon as we stepped outside, I hadn't even opened my mouth (if I had spoken, would anything have been different?), she took my arm and began defending me, talking about Galiani in a bad way.
[1969-05-02 18:15:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I couldn't find any opportunity to blame her, whether it was about her supporting Pasquale and Nadia, or about not letting me attend my wedding. When it came to these matters, she now acted like another Lina, a Lina who clearly didn't know what had just happened, and trying to get her to explain was pointless.
[1969-05-02 18:20:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I kept hearing her say that as we walked all the way to the Metro station at Piazza Amendola. "I heard, 'What a bunch of rotten people. Look, how that old woman treated you. She wants revenge. She can't stand you writing books and articles. She can't stand you marrying well.'"
[1969-05-02 18:21:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I heard that what especially drove her crazy was that Nadia had been brought up to be superior to others, and she should have been a source of pride for her mother, but instead she was a complete failure. Not only that, but she was involved with a bricklayer, doing disgraceful things right under her mother's nose.
[1969-05-02 18:22:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | "I heard, 'Yes, Galiani couldn't stand it at all. You shouldn't feel bad about it, whatever she says. You shouldn't have left the book with her, you shouldn't have asked if she wanted it, you shouldn't have written a dedication. Those people, you should kick them in the ass. Your biggest flaw is that you're too kind. You listen to whatever they say.'"
[1969-05-02 18:23:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | "I heard her say, 'Those who have been to school think they're the only ones with a brain, but that's not how it is. Just relax, go ahead, get married, go on your honeymoon. You've taken care of me for too long. Hurry up and write another novel. You know I expect you to live well and do something great. I love you.'"
[1969-05-02 18:25:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I was very shocked, I kept listening to her, being with her, I couldn't calm down at all. I thought about how every pause in our relationship would eventually bring about some unexpected situation, something that would throw her off balance and also me.
[1969-05-02 18:26:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought, I didn't understand whether her words were an apology to me, or if she had said them on purpose to cover up her true feelings, not wanting to confess them to me, or perhaps wanting to say a final goodbye.
[1969-05-02 18:27:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought, of course, she's hypocritical and has no conscience. As for me, even though my situation has changed, I'm still dependent on her. I feel that this dependence on her might never leave me for the rest of my life, and that makes me unbearable.
[1969-05-02 18:28:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought to myself—I couldn't suppress my impulse—that the cardiologist's diagnosis was wrong, that Nadia was right, and I wished she were really dying.
[1969-05-05 10:00:00] Spaccanapoli | One day, in a bookstore at Turin, I was talking about my book in a carefree tone, facing many readers. I thought I felt very at ease.
[1969-05-05 10:30:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw that even if someone asked about the sexual scenes on the beach in the book, using a passionate or provocative tone, I could now face it calmly. I already had a ready-made answer, and I would explain it so convincingly that people would accept it without question.
[1969-05-05 11:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw that at Turin, Professor Tarantano was accompanying me to the reader's meeting, which was also arranged by the publisher. I knew he was a close friend of Adele Airota, and he proudly said that he had really had the foresight to recognize the book's potential.
[1969-05-05 11:05:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw him enthusiastically introducing me to the audience. I knew it was the same tone he had used at Porto a while ago.
[1969-05-05 20:00:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw him at the end of the evening, when the reader's meeting ended, and he praised me, saying that I had made great progress in a short time. I heard it, and then he asked me in his usual kind tone: "They say the sexual descriptions in the book are 'degrading chapters.' Why did you readily accept them? Why do you yourself also say such things to the public?"
[1969-05-05 20:05:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw him explaining to me that, first of all, my novel had other more interesting and exciting chapters besides the one on the beach. I heard that, and those descriptions that seemed a bit bold, in fact, many girls encounter while writing.
[1969-05-05 20:10:00] Spaccanapoli | I heard him conclude by saying that pornography appears in many good literary works—the real art of storytelling—and sometimes it may cross the line, but it never becomes vulgar.
[1969-05-05 20:15:00] Spaccanapoli | I thought my mind was a mess—this very cultured man was trying to tell me, in a roundabout way, that the "sins" in my novel were actually quite minor, forgivable things. Every time I explained them so dramatically, it was as if they were deadly, and I was wrong.
[1969-05-05 20:15:30] Spaccanapoli | I thought, overall, I had exaggerated too much, I had catered to the public's short-sighted gaze.
[1969-05-05 20:16:00] Spaccanapoli | I thought to myself: Now is enough. I don't want to act so servile, trying to please others. I need to learn to say no to my readers. I shouldn't let myself sink to their level.
[1969-05-05 20:16:30] Spaccanapoli | I thought to myself that the next time I had the chance, I would respond to whoever asked questions about those pages in a more severe tone.
[1969-05-05 21:00:00] Via Caracciolo | I saw that dinner was in a hotel restaurant, booked by the publisher for us. I felt a bit embarrassed, but I still listened with interest as Tarentano quoted literary works.

[1969-05-05 21:15:00] Mask Loc 007 Hotel Restaurant | I saw him restate that I was a rather pure female writer, and he called me "dear child." I heard him say that Henry Miller, and many talented female writers of the 1920s and 1930s, wrote about sex in ways I can't even imagine now.
[1969-05-05 21:20:00] Via Caracciolo | I saw that I had written down the names of these writers in my notebook. I thought, and at the same time, I began to wonder: although this man praised me, he surely believed I had no real talent.
[1969-05-05 21:20:30] Mask Loc 007 Hotel Restaurant | I thought that in his eyes, I was just a girl who had gotten lucky with success; even the chapters that were most attractive to readers probably didn't mean much to him, they could only impress those who didn't know much, but people like him, the intellectuals, wouldn't find them impressive at all.
[1969-05-05 22:00:00] Mask Loc 007 Hotel Restaurant | I said that I was a bit tired, and I helped the person I had dinner with to stand up—he had had a bit too much to drink. I saw he was a short man with a big belly, looking like a food lover, his white hair fell in strands over his ears. His ears were large, his face was flushed, his nose was big, his lips were thin, and his eyes were lively. He smoked heavily, and his fingers were yellow.
[1969-05-05 22:05:00] Hotel Elevator | I saw him trying to embrace me, to kiss me in the elevator, even though I struggled to push him away, he didn't give up.
[1969-05-05 22:05:30] Albergheria | I thought about how I touched his stomach and the smell of alcohol on his breath, a feeling that had deeply imprinted itself in my mind.
[1969-05-05 22:06:00] Hotel Elevator | I never thought that an old man, a friend of my future mother-in-law, who was so kind and cultured, would behave in such a way.
[1969-05-05 22:07:00] Hotel Corridor | I saw that we had reached the corridor, and he quickly apologized to me. He hurried into his room and closed the door behind him. I heard him say that it was all the wine's fault.
[1969-05-05 22:30:00] Spaccanapoli | I saw that at this moment, Mariarosa, Juan, and Sylvia entered together. I saw them bring clean towels and pajamas.
[1969-05-05 22:30:30] At Mariarosa's house | I thought Mariarosa certainly heard the last sentence, and she certainly understood that we were talking about my novel, but she said not a word.
[1969-05-05 22:31:00] Stazione Centrale | I thought she could have said she liked the novel, that writing novels was possible anytime, but she didn't.
[1969-05-05 22:31:30] Stazione Centrale | I thought to myself that although she appeared kind and warm towards me on the surface, in this culture completely swept up by political fervor, my book was probably seen as a trivial little thing.
[1969-05-05 22:32:00] Spaccanapoli | I thought that some people might consider my book as the leftovers of some bolder, more audacious works—though I haven't read those books yet; or, as Franco Mari once said in a derogatory way, it's just a story about petty love and small passions.
[1969-05-05 22:32:30] Spaccanapoli | I saw that at this moment my sister-in-law pointed me to the bathroom and my room. I thought she was polite, yet also hard to figure out.
[1969-05-05 22:33:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I said goodnight to me and Franco Mari, and took the opportunity to say goodbye as well. I knew because he had to leave very early the next morning.
[1969-05-05 22:33:30] Spaccanapoli | I saw that I had only shaken his hand, and he didn't seem to want to embrace me.
[1969-05-05 22:34:00] Stazione Centrale | I saw him disappear into the same room with Mariarosa. I saw Juan's face grow dark, and Sylvia also became very unhappy. I thought to myself that I understood— the master of the house was going to sleep with the guest.
[1969-05-05 22:35:00] Porto | I saw myself entering the room that had been prepared for me. I saw and smelled a very strong smell of smoke. There was a very messy little bed in the room, no bedside table or lamp, just the overhead light in the center of the ceiling.
[1969-05-05 22:35:30] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I saw newspapers piled on the floor, along with a few magazines—*Mena Bo*, *New Mission*, *Marcatele*—and some very expensive art books, some of which were extremely worn, while others looked as if they had never been opened at all.
[1969-05-05 22:36:00] Posillipo | I saw myself opening the window and placing the ashtray on the balcony. I saw an ashtray full of cigarette butts under the bed.
[1969-05-05 22:36:30] Porto | I saw myself taking off my clothes and putting on the nightgown Mariarosa had given me. I saw that the dress was too long and too tight.
[1969-05-05 22:37:00] Bathroom at Mariarosa's House | I saw myself walking barefoot through the dim corridor to the bathroom, and it didn't matter that I had no toothbrush. I know that when I was a child, no one taught me to brush my teeth. I started developing the habit of brushing my teeth when I was at Borgo Normal University.
[1969-05-05 22:40:00] Porto | I saw myself lying in bed, trying desperately to erase the image of that Franco Mari from tonight out of my mind. I thought about the guy who loved me a few years ago. He was rich and generous. He helped me, bought me a lot of things, educated me, took me to political gatherings in Paris, and to Vesuvius, where we spent vacations at his parents' house.
[1969-05-05 22:40:30] Porto | I think of him but I can't do it. My mind is full of this current Franco Mari, very provocative, shouting slogans in a crowded classroom, and the political slogans he shouted still echo in my mind.
[1969-05-05 22:41:00] Porto | I thought about how he had belittled my book, dismissing it as insignificant, and now this Franco Mari had finally prevailed.
[1969-05-05 22:41:30] Porto | Am I imagining my future as a novelist? he asked. There are other things to do besides writing novels. Was Franco Mari right? What impression did I leave on him?
[1969-05-05 22:42:00] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I wondered what kind of memories he still kept about our past love, if he remembered it at all. Was he now complaining about me to Mariarosa, just as Nino had complained about Lina to me?
[1969-05-05 22:42:30] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I saw myself getting up and turning off the light. I thought of it and immediately lost my confidence, feeling painful. I had imagined a sweet, perhaps slightly sorrowful evening, but in the end, I was deeply sad. I couldn't wait for the night to end so I could return to San Gregorio Armeno right away.
[1969-05-05 22:45:00] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I lay in the dark, but I couldn't fall asleep. I kept turning over. I smelled someone else's body on the bed, a faintly familiar scent similar to the secret smell on my own bed at home, but I didn't know who had left it, and it made me feel slightly sick.
[1969-05-05 23:00:00] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I saw myself lying flat on the bed again, and suddenly I woke up, realizing someone had entered the room. I whispered. I heard "Who?"
[1969-05-05 23:00:30] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I saw it was Juan. He didn't beat around the bush, he was very urgent, as if he were asking me to do him a big favor. He spoke in a pleading voice. "I heard, 'Can I sleep with you?'"
[1969-05-05 23:01:00] Porto | I saw the request was so absurd that I immediately woke up. I wanted to figure out what was going on, so I asked. I heard "sleeping?"
[1969-05-05 23:01:05] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I heard, "Yes, I'm lying next to you, I won't bother you, I just don't want to be alone."
[1969-05-05 23:01:10] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I heard, "Absolutely not."
[1969-05-05 23:01:15] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I heard "Why?"
[1969-05-05 23:01:20] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I didn't know how to answer him, so I mumbled something. "I'm engaged."
[1969-05-05 23:01:25] Porto | "I heard, 'What's the big deal? We were just sleeping.'"
[1969-05-05 23:01:30] Porto | I heard, "Go ahead, please, I don't really know you."
[1969-05-05 23:01:35] Porto | I heard, "I'm Juan. I showed you my work. What else do you want?"

[1969-05-05 23:01:40] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I saw him sit down on the edge of the bed. I saw his black silhouette and caught the scent of cigar smoke in his breath.
[1969-05-05 23:01:45] Porto | "I beg you," I whispered, "I'm tired."
[1969-05-05 23:01:50] Porto | I heard, "You are a female writer. You write about love. Everything that happens to you will inspire your imagination and help you create. Let me stay by your side; it will be something you can tell about in the future."
[1969-05-05 23:02:00] Porto | I saw his fingertips brush my foot, and I immediately rushed to the switch and turned on the light. I thought I couldn't stand him anymore.
[1969-05-05 23:02:10] Porto | I saw him still sitting on the bed, wearing only his underwear and a vest.
[1969-05-05 23:02:20] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I said, "Get out!" I made it very clear to him. My tone was so decisive, I used all my strength, almost a shout, and I almost hit him.
[1969-05-05 23:02:30] Porto | I saw him slowly getting up, and he said with obvious disdain. I heard, "You're an old-fashioned person."
[1969-05-05 23:03:00] Posillipo | I saw him leave, and I closed the door, but I couldn't lock it.
[1969-05-05 23:03:30] Porto | I thought I was absolutely furious and also very scared, and many words from the San Gregorio Armeno dialect were churning in my mind.
[1969-05-05 23:04:00] Porto | I saw that I had left the light on, and I waited a little longer before [intimate act]. I wonder what impression I leave on others? What kind of woman do I really look like?
[1969-05-05 23:04:30] Porto | What made Juan make such a request? Was it the free-spirited woman in my book? Was it because of my political views?
[1969-05-05 23:05:00] Porto | I thought about the words I had said—not just a game of argument to prove that I was as capable as men, but also that I could do whatever I wanted, even when it came to sex?
[1969-05-05 23:05:30] Porto | I wondered if that was why he felt free to come into my room without hesitation—that he thought we were of the same kind? Or perhaps Mariarosa had brought Franco Mari into her room without any restraint at all?
[1969-05-05 23:06:00] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | Was it because I had caught the feverish sexual energy of the university classroom, and I myself was exuding that same energy without realizing it?
[1969-05-05 23:06:30] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I know it was also at Porto last time. I had already made peace with betraying Pietro. I wanted to be intimate with Nino, but that kind of passion had already existed for a long time — it could explain my desire and my betrayal. I thought about it, but the very idea of sex, the direct demand of the body, was something I couldn't accept. I was completely unprepared and felt sick.
[1969-05-05 23:07:00] Porto | I thought about Turin, why did I let Adele Airota's friend touch me? Why did I let Juan touch me in this house? What did I show? What did they want to show?
[1969-05-05 23:07:30] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I know that the memory of my time with Donato Nino on the beach in Ischia isn't about what happened that night on the beach and later became part of a novel's plot, but rather about the moment he appeared in Nella's kitchen.
[1969-05-05 23:08:00] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I know that at the time, he had [intimate contact] with me, and he [intimate contact] me, and he touched me, making me feel a pleasure that went against my will.
[1969-05-05 23:08:30] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | Did I think about the connection between that terrified girl and the woman now being harassed in the elevator, invaded by a stranger in her room?
[1969-05-05 23:09:00] Guest Room at Mariarosa's House | I thought of Adele Airota's friends—the cultured Tarantano, the Venezuelan painter Juan—were they all of the same sort as Nino's father, that train conductor, small-time poet, and hired writer?
[1969-05-05 23:30:00] Porto | I saw my nervousness, I couldn't sleep, my mind was full of conflicts.
[1969-05-05 23:30:30] Porto | I saw that just at this moment, Milko started crying again, his sobs would not subside. I thought of this, which stirred up the intense emotion I had felt when I held him in my arms.
[1969-05-05 23:31:00] Stazione Centrale | I saw that I couldn't control myself anymore, so I got up and followed the sound of the child's crying to a door. I saw light coming through the slightly open door.
[1969-05-05 23:31:30] Sylvia's Room | I shouted, and Sylvia answered me in a bad mood.
[1969-05-05 23:32:00] Sylvia's Room | I saw that room was a bit more comfortable than the one I was staying in, with an old wardrobe, a nightstand, and a double bed.
[1969-05-05 23:32:30] Sylvia's Room | I saw the young mother sitting cross-legged on the bed, wearing a pink short nightgown, with a fierce expression on her face. I know she had her hands spread out, the backs of her hands resting on her bare thighs, like a gesture of making a wish.
[1969-05-05 23:33:00] Sylvia's Room | I saw Mirko naked, his mouth wide open, crying so hard his whole body turned purple. His eyes were tightly shut, and his limbs were trembling.
[1969-05-05 23:33:30] Sylvia's Room | I saw that at first, Sylvia was hostile toward me, but later her tone softened. I heard her say that she didn't think she was a good mother, that she didn't know what to do, and that she was too desperate.
[1969-05-05 23:34:00] Sylvia's Room | I heard her say in a low voice, "He's always like this when he's not drinking milk. Maybe he's sick and will die in this bed."
[1969-05-05 23:34:30] Sylvia's Room | I got to the end, and she started crying. I thought about the way she spoke, and it made me feel that she was nothing like Lina at all. She had become ugly, her eyes wide and staring, her mouth twitching nervously, ruining her beauty.
[1969-05-05 23:35:00] Sylvia's Room | I heard the child's crying and the mother's sobs, which made me very soft-hearted. I wanted to embrace them and take care of them.
[1969-05-05 23:35:30] Sylvia's room | I said in a low voice, "Can I hold him?" She nodded, her voice trembling with sobs.
[1969-05-05 23:36:00] Silvia's Room | I saw myself taking the child from her lap and holding him against my chest. I thought again about that exchange of scent, sound, and warmth, just like the last time I held him. His vitality once again stirred me, bringing me joy.
[1969-05-05 23:36:30] Sylvia's Room | I saw myself pacing around the room, softly humming a lullaby I had improvised, a long, meaningless declaration of love.
[1969-05-05 23:37:00] Sylvia's Room | I saw Mirko calm down miraculously and finally fall asleep.
[1969-05-05 23:37:30] Sylvia's Room | I saw myself gently placing him beside his mother, but I didn't want to leave him. I thought about how I was afraid to return to my own room, and my subconscious told me that Juan was surely waiting for me there.
[1969-05-05 23:38:00] Sylvia's Room | I saw Sylvia thanking me, but there was no real gratitude in her tone. After hearing that thank you, she then listed a cold, detached list of my virtues: "You're smart, you know everything, you can make people respect you. You are a real mother, and your children in the future will be very lucky."
[1969-05-05 23:38:30] Sylvia's Room | I said I had to leave, trying to be polite. But suddenly she looked uneasy. She took my hand and begged me to stay. I heard he can feel you, she said. Stay with him, so he'll sleep more peacefully.
[1969-05-05 23:39:00] Sylvia's Room | I saw that I immediately accepted it, we lay in bed with the child in the middle, turned off the light, but we didn't sleep. We began to tell each other our stories.
[1969-05-05 23:45:00] Sylvia's Room | I saw her, and she told me about the hatred she felt when she discovered she was pregnant. I saw that in the dark, Sylvia had become less difficult to get along with.
[1969-05-05 23:45:30] Sylvia's Room | I know that on one hand, she kept secret from the man she deeply loved that she was pregnant, and on the other hand, she also deceived herself, believing it was like an illness that would pass. But her body began to react, gradually changing.
[1969-05-05 23:46:00] Sylvia's Room | I knew Sylvia had to tell her parents about it. She came from a very wealthy family in Monza, and after a big argument with her family, she ran away from home.
[1969-05-05 23:46:30] Sylvia's Room | I know that in the first few months, she hoped for a miracle. She had never considered an abortion, not even out of fear for her body.

[1969-05-05 23:47:00] Silvia's Room | I saw her begin to think that, out of love for the man who had made her pregnant, she would have the child. I heard him tell Sylvia, "If you're going to have a child, out of love for you, I want this child too."
[1969-05-05 23:47:30] Sylvia's Room | I saw the two of them start talking seriously. I know about love and affection, I love you, you love me. But after a few months, when the child still hadn't come, their love had already faded.
[1969-05-05 23:48:00] Sylvia's Room | I knew Sylvia was in great pain, and she kept begging him to stay. In the end, all that remained between them was resentment.
[1969-05-05 23:48:30] Sylvia's Room | I saw her give birth alone, and she was able to do it all thanks to Mariarosa.
[1969-05-05 23:49:00] Sylvia's Room | I heard her speaking very enthusiastically about Mariarosa. I heard, "She's a really great teacher, truly on the students' side, and an unparalleled Communist Party member."
[1969-05-05 23:49:30] Sylvia's Room | I told her that the entire Pietro family was admirable, that I was Pietro's fiancée, and that we would get married in the fall. I heard her say, "Marriage and family scare me—they're all just clichés."
[1969-05-05 23:50:00] Sylvia's Room | I heard her suddenly say in a sad tone, "Milko's father also teaches at the university."
[1969-05-05 23:50:05] Sylvia's Room | I heard "Is that so?"
[1969-05-05 23:50:10] Sylvia's Room | I heard him say, "Everything started when I took his class. He was very confident, smart, knowledgeable, and handsome. He had many great qualities. Before the students even began to fight, he said, 'You must reform your professors, don't let them treat you like animals.'"
[1969-05-05 23:50:15] Silvia's Room | I heard, "Did he take care of the children?"
[1969-05-05 23:50:20] Sylvia's Room | I saw her smile in the darkness, a bitter smile. I heard myself say, "A man, except for those crazy moments—when you love him, when he enters you—otherwise he's always outside of you. That is, later you don't love him anymore, and when you think about how you once wanted him, it makes you uncomfortable. I liked him, he liked me, the thing is over. I might fall for someone every day, don't you? This kind of liking lasts for a while, then it passes, only the child remains, he is part of you. The father of the child is always an outsider, first an outsider, then still an outsider. Even his name sounds different now. I used to call him Nino. Every morning when I woke up, that name would repeat in my mind, it was a magical word, but now it's a sad one."
[1969-05-05 23:50:50] Sylvia's Room | I stayed silent for a while, and finally asked in a low voice. I heard, "Does Mirko's father's name is Nino?"
[1969-05-05 23:50:55] Sylvia's Room | I heard, "Yes, everyone knows him, he's very famous at the university."
[1969-05-05 23:51:00] Sylvia's Room | I heard, "What's Nino's last name?"
[1969-05-05 23:51:05] Sylvia's Room | I heard "Nino. Nino."
[1969-05-06 06:00:00] Stazione Centrale | I left early in the morning, without waking Sylvia or the child sleeping in her arms, and I didn't see the painter.
[1969-05-06 06:10:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I only greeted Mariarosa, because she got up very early to take Franco Mari to the train station. I know she has just returned home, and she looks very tired. I thought I felt very uncomfortable.
[1969-05-06 06:10:30] Stazione Centrale | I heard her ask, "Did you sleep well?"
[1969-05-06 06:10:35] Spaccanapoli | I heard, "I talked with Sylvia for a long time."
[1969-05-06 06:10:40] Stazione Centrale | I heard, "She told you about Nino."
[1969-05-06 06:10:45] Stazione Centrale | I heard "Yes."
[1969-05-06 06:10:50] Stazione Centrale | I heard, "I know you're friends."
[1969-05-06 06:10:55] Stazione Centrale | "I heard, 'It's him who told you?'"
[1969-05-06 06:11:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I heard, "Yes, we've talked about you."
[1969-05-06 06:11:05] At Mariarosa's house | I heard, "Miro is really his child?"
[1969-05-06 06:11:10] San Gregorio Armeno | "I see," she yawned, then smiled. I heard her say, "Nino is charming, all the girls are fighting to be with him. This is a happy time, you can be with whoever you want. He always has this energy that makes people feel good, really exciting."
[1969-05-06 06:11:40] Spaccanapoli | I heard her say that in this movement, we very much needed people like him, but we had to take care of him, guide him, and help him grow.
[1969-05-06 06:12:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I heard he's a very capable man, she said, but he needs to lead; in his heart, there's always some leftover of bourgeois democracy, of company technicians, of modernists.
[1969-05-06 06:30:00] Porto | When I finished reading, we felt that the time we had spent together was too short. Both of us were sorry and vowed that next time we would stay longer.
[1969-05-06 07:00:00] Porto | I saw myself taking the luggage from the hotel and then leaving.
[1969-05-06 10:00:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I knew that only on the train, during the long journey back to San Gregorio Armeno, did I begin to accept that Nino was becoming a father again. I thought of a dull grayish white, spreading from Sylvia to Lina, from Mirko to Gennaro.
[1969-05-06 10:00:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I know the passion of Ischia, the loving nights of Mergellina, the infidelity on Piazza Martiri. I thought to myself that everything had lost its color, becoming a mechanical reaction.
[1969-05-06 10:01:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I know that Nino left San Gregorio Armeno, and is now passionately involved with Sylvia. Who knows if he has other women as well. I get angry thinking about it, as if Lina is hiding in some corner of my mind, and I feel exactly what she feels.
[1969-05-06 10:01:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I felt a bitter resentment, just as she might have felt when she heard the news, and I was also very angry, as if Nino had done something wrong to me.
[1969-05-06 10:02:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about Nino betraying us—Lina and I were both suffering the same humiliation, we both loved him, but he had never truly loved either of us.
[1969-05-06 10:02:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought, therefore, that despite his many good qualities, he was ultimately a frivolous man, shallow like an animal, sweating and excreting bodily fluids, leaving behind living creatures nurtured in the bellies of women after careless pleasures.
[1969-05-06 10:03:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I know I remember, a few years ago when he came to Mergellina to see me, we were talking in the courtyard, and Melina saw him through the window, mistaking him for his father.
[1969-05-06 10:03:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I knew that Donato's previous lovers had noticed the similarity, but I hadn't. I realized now that Melina was right and I was wrong.
[1969-05-06 10:04:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about Nino cutting off relations with his father, not because he was afraid of becoming like him, but because Nino was already like his father now, he just didn't want to admit it.
[1969-05-06 10:04:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I saw him, but I still couldn't hate him. On the steamy train, I didn't just think of the moment I saw him in the Porto bookstore—I wove him into everything that happened during those days, into every word that was said.
[1969-05-06 10:05:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I found myself thinking about sex all the time—dirty, tempting sex, everywhere in actions, words, and books.
[1969-05-06 10:05:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought of the high walls that separated men and women were collapsing, and the bonds of upbringing were also breaking apart.
[1969-05-06 10:06:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought of Nino, who was immersed in this era, part of the noisy student assembly at Porto University. He fit perfectly into that atmosphere, as well as into the chaos of Mariarosa's home; they must have been together once.
[1969-05-06 10:06:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought that, with his intelligence, desires, and ability to seduce, he would live in that era with curiosity and great confidence.
[1969-05-06 10:07:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought maybe I was wrong, and I shouldn't have assumed he was as dirty and vulgar as his father. His actions belonged to another culture.
[1969-05-06 10:07:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I know that both Silvia and Mariarosa emphasized this: the girls all wanted him, and he simply accepted their advances. There was no oppression, no right or wrong—only desire was in control.
[1969-05-06 10:08:00] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought that maybe when Nino told me that Lina had problems with sex, he was trying to tell me that the era of expectations had ended, that it was wrong and distorted to mix responsibility with pleasure.
[1969-05-06 10:08:30] On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno | I thought that if he was like his father, his obsession with women would be another version of it.
locations: On the train back to San Gregorio Armeno

text:
[1969-05-06 11:30:00] Mercato | When I arrived at San Gregorio Armeno, I felt a bit surprised and, at the same time, repelled by the thought that Nino was loved by so many people, and he loved so many people too.
[1969-05-06 11:30:30] Mercato | I thought to myself: What's wrong with admitting it? He was enjoying life, just like those who know how to enjoy it.
[1969-05-06 12:00:00] at home | I thought about when I returned to Mergellina, and I realized why all the women wanted him and why he readily accepted them. I had always wanted him, but now my desire was even stronger. I decided to try my best not to meet him again.
[1969-05-06 12:00:30] at home | I didn't know what to do about Lina. Should I tell her what I knew, or not? I'd wait until I saw her.
[1969-05-06 13:00:00] at home | I saw that upon returning home, I had no time and didn't want to think about it anymore.
[1969-05-06 13:30:00] at home | I saw Pietro calling me, and he announced that he would visit my parents next week.
[1969-05-06 13:30:30] at home | I thought about how I had accepted this reality, like accepting an unavoidable disaster.
[1969-05-07 10:00:00] at home | I saw that I had to quickly find him a hotel, I cleaned the room, did the family's ideological work, telling them not to worry, but none of it helped. My situation was getting worse and worse.
[1969-05-08 10:00:00] at home | I know that in our Mergellina, there's been more and more gossip about my book, about me personally, and about the fact that I often travel alone.
[1969-05-08 10:30:00] Borgo | I saw my mother defending me, boasting that I was about to get married. I heard her say that my decision not to get married in the church only made things worse, that I wasn't getting married in San Gregorio Armeno, but instead in Genoa, which led to even more gossip, and that really angered her.
[1969-05-08 20:00:00] at home | I saw that one night, she was very brutal with me. I heard her say that people who read my book thought the content was embarrassing, and they all talked behind my back.
[1969-05-08 20:10:00] at home | I saw my brothers shouting at me too, saying they had to fight with the butcher's son because he called me a whore. Not only that, but they also had to beat up Elisa's classmate because the guy made Elisa do the same things her sister did.
[1969-05-08 20:15:00] at home | I heard my mother hissing at me, "What did you write?"
[1969-05-08 20:15:05] at home | I heard, "Nothing, Mom!"
[1969-05-08 20:15:10] at home | I heard, "Did you write about all those disgusting things you did when you were out?"
[1969-05-08 20:15:15] at home | I heard, "What kind of dirty business it is, you go and see for yourself."
[1969-05-08 20:15:20] at home | I heard, "I don't want to waste my time on those stupid things you write."
[1969-05-08 20:15:25] at home | I heard, "Then just let me go."
[1969-05-08 20:15:30] Borgo | I heard, "If your father knew what people were saying about you, he'd throw you out of the house."
[1969-05-08 20:15:35] at home | I heard, "No need, I can walk by myself."
[1969-05-08 21:00:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I went out in the evening, leaving home to clear my mind, just so I wouldn't say things to my mother that would make me regret later.
[1969-05-08 21:10:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I thought about on the road, in the park, along the main road—I felt everyone's eyes were fixed on me, a world I was about to leave, angry at me.
[1969-05-08 21:30:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw her later when I met Giugliara, who had just gotten off work. We lived in the same building, and we walked back together.
[1969-05-08 21:35:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I knew I was worried that she would eventually say something to annoy me, as her usual personality was either stubborn or sly. I thought, but what surprised me was that she timidly said to me.
[1969-05-08 21:35:05] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I heard, "I read the book you wrote, it's great! It's so brave of you to write those things."
[1969-05-08 21:35:10] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw that I was a bit stunned. "I heard, 'What thing?'"
[1969-05-08 21:35:15] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I heard, "That's what you did on the beach."
[1969-05-08 21:35:20] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I heard, "It wasn't me, it was the characters in the book."
[1969-05-08 21:35:25] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | At that moment, she took my hand, and I had to stop. She whispered. I heard, "Yes, but you wrote it so well, Elena, just like it really happened, so dirty! This is a secret only a woman would know."
[1969-05-08 21:35:50] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | "I heard 'You tell Lina, if you see her, tell her she did the right thing, I support her. She got rid of her husband, mom, dad, brother, Marcello, Michele, and all the other crap, and she did well. I should also run away from here, but I'm not as smart as the two of you. I was born stupid, there's nothing I can do.'"
[1969-05-08 21:40:00] Apartment Building San Gregorio Armeno | I stopped on the floor where I lived, and she went back to her house, but the words she said kept echoing in my mind.
[1969-05-08 21:40:30] via Toledo | I thought what shocked me was that she talked about my success and Lina's downfall together, and to her, both were equally exciting.
[1969-05-08 21:41:00] via Toledo | I thought of some other words that were deeply etched in my mind: the disgusting things I described in my book made her feel exactly as I did, which was a new experience for me, and I couldn't make a judgment about it.
[1969-05-08 21:41:30] at home | I didn't think about it anymore when Pietro came later.
[1969-05-13 14:00:00] Train Station San Gregorio Armeno | I saw myself going to the train station to meet him, accompanying him all the way to Mercato, where there was a hotel, recommended by my father, and I had booked a room there.
[1969-05-13 14:10:00] Train Station San Gregorio Armeno | I saw Pietro looking more nervous than my family. He got off the train, dragging a big suitcase, as usual unkempt. I saw that because of the heat, his face was red and full of exhaustion.
[1969-05-13 14:20:00] San Gregorio Armeno | I saw him wanting to buy a bouquet of flowers for my mother, and he bought a large, fairly expensive bouquet. I thought this was different from his usual habits, but he was satisfied.
[1969-05-13 15:00:00] Porto | I saw that we had arrived at the hotel, and he told me to stay in the lobby alone with the flowers. I heard him promise that he would be back right away.
[1969-05-13 15:30:00] Porto | I had been watching for half an hour when he appeared. I saw him wearing a blue suit, a white shirt, a sky-blue tie, and his shoes were polished to a shine.
[1969-05-13 15:30:30] Porto | I saw myself laughing instantly. I heard him ask me, "Do I look bad?"
[1969-05-13 15:30:35] Porto | I saw that I had made him feel at ease; his clothes were very good.
[1969-05-13 16:00:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw it, but on the way, I could feel the eyes of the men around me, and their mocking laughter. I thought, as if I were walking alone, perhaps they wanted to imply and emphasize that the person accompanying me was not worth respecting.
[1969-05-13 16:00:30] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw Pietro holding a large bouquet of flowers. He wouldn't let me hold them; every detail of his was so proper. I thought of a city that wasn't suitable for me.
[1969-05-13 16:01:00] Street of San Gregorio Armeno | I saw that his empty arm was resting on my shoulder. I thought, but I felt, I should protect him.

[1969-05-13 16:30:00] at home | I saw Elena opening the door for us, then my father came out, followed by my brothers. I saw that everyone was dressed in festival clothes, and everyone was being too polite.
[1969-05-13 16:35:00] at home | I saw my mother was the last one to appear. After the sound of the toilet flushing, I heard her limping over. I saw her get her hair done and put some color on her lips and cheeks. I thought to myself, she had once been a beautiful girl.
[1969-05-13 16:40:00] at home | I saw her politely take the flowers, and we sat together in the restaurant. I knew that, in order to entertain guests, they had hidden the beds that were set up in the evening and taken down in the morning.
[1969-05-13 16:45:00] at home | I saw everything was very clean, and the tableware on the table was arranged with great care. I knew my mother had been preparing with Elena for several days, which made the dinner last endlessly.
[1969-05-13 17:00:00] at home | I was shocked to see Pietro because he suddenly became very cheerful.
[1969-05-13 17:10:00] at home | I saw him asking about my father's job at the city hall. My father spoke Italian awkwardly, so Pietro had my father speak in the local dialect. I knew my father had told him some amusing stories about city government employees, and although my fiancé didn't understand them very well, he showed great appreciation for those stories.
[1969-05-13 17:30:00] at home | I saw, especially, that I had never seen him eat so much. Every time a dish was brought out, he would compliment my mother and sister, and he would ask about the method of each dish, as if he were about to cook them himself. I know, but as far as I know, he can't even boil an egg himself.
[1969-05-13 17:40:00] at home | I saw that his favorite dish was the potato cake. After he finished, my mother added another portion to his plate, and it was generously sized. I heard her say, in that distinctive tone of hers, devoid of any emotion, that she would make the potato cake again before he left.
[1969-05-13 18:00:00] at home | I saw that within a short time, the atmosphere became very harmonious. I know even Peppe and Gianni set aside their reserve and became friends with him.
[1969-05-13 19:00:00] at home | I saw that, no matter what, the meal was still finished. Pietro became very serious and proposed to my father.
[1969-05-13 19:05:00] at home | I saw that he was very excited when he spoke about it. I saw that made my younger sister's eyes sparkle, and my two younger brothers found it amusing.
[1969-05-13 19:10:00] at home | I saw my father feeling embarrassed, stammering out some polite words. I heard that Pietro is such an outstanding and serious professor, and this request made him very honored.
[1969-05-13 19:15:00] at home | I thought this night was going to end perfectly when my mother spoke up.
[1969-05-13 19:15:30] at home | I saw her face, dark with anger. "I heard, 'We disagree with the fact that you're not getting married in the church. A wedding without a priest isn't a real wedding.'"
[1969-05-13 19:16:00] at home | I saw everyone fall into silence. My father still couldn't help but smile at Pietro, meaning that although he too was part of the "we" my wife had mentioned, he was willing to make a concession. I knew my parents must have already secretly agreed, with my mother being the one to bring up the matter.
[1969-05-13 19:16:30] at home | I saw Pietro also smile at my father, but this time, his conversation partner wasn't my father—he was only speaking to my mother. I know I've already told him my family's stance, and he's made his preparations.
[1969-05-13 19:17:00] Borgo | I saw that what he said was simple, full of tenderness, but his thoughts were clear. I heard him say that he understood, but also hoped everyone would understand him. He said he respected those who truly believed in God, but he felt he didn't belong to that kind of person.
[1969-05-13 19:17:30] at home | I heard him say that being a man who didn't believe in God didn't mean he believed in nothing. He was certain of his absolute loyalty to me. He said it was this love, not the altar, the priest, or the city officials, that made our marriage strong.
[1969-05-13 19:18:00] at home | I heard him say that refusing to get married in the church was a matter of principle for him. If he were a man without principles, I wouldn't have loved him, or I would have loved him less.
[1969-05-13 19:18:30] at home | I heard him say at last, of course, my mother didn't want to hand her daughter over to someone who could so easily betray the basic principles of his own life.
[1969-05-13 19:19:00] at home | I saw my father nodding as he listened to these words. I saw my brothers' mouths wide open in surprise, Elena was once again deeply moved, but my mother remained unmoved.
[1969-05-13 19:20:00] at home | I saw her fiddle with her wedding ring, then look at Pietro's face. She didn't continue the previous conversation, nor did she say she agreed. Instead, she spoke in a cold, determined manner, praising me. I heard her say that I was always a different child, that I was capable of doing something no other girl in the entire Mergellina could accomplish.
[1969-05-13 19:20:30] Borgo | I heard that I was her pride, and the pride of the whole family, and I had never let her down. She said I had the right to be happy, and if anyone made me suffer, it would hurt her a thousand times more.
[1969-05-13 19:21:00] at home | I listened, feeling very embarrassed, and throughout the whole thing, I wanted to figure out whether she was serious or just exaggerating as usual. I thought of her purpose as being to make it clear to Pietro that she didn't care about his position at all, nor about the things he was saying. It wasn't that the Greco family needed him, but rather that he needed the Greco family.
[1969-05-13 19:21:30] at home | I saw that I couldn't figure out her attitude, but my fiancé completely believed what she said, nodding in agreement while my mother was speaking.
[1969-05-13 19:22:00] at home | I saw that she had finally finished speaking, and then Pietro began to talk. I heard him say that he clearly knew how valuable I was, and he was grateful to my mother for raising me the way I am.
[1969-05-13 19:22:30] at home | I watched until he reached into his jacket pocket and pulled out a blue box, handing it to me shyly. I thought, what is this? He's already given me a ring, is he going to give me another one?
[1969-05-13 19:23:00] at home | I saw myself opening the box. I saw a real ring, very beautiful, made of red gold, set with a purple crystal, and surrounded by small diamonds.
[1969-05-13 19:23:30] at home | I heard Pietro whisper, "This is my grandmother's ring. If I could marry you, everyone in my family would be happy."
[1969-05-13 19:24:00] at home | I saw everyone start drinking again, and my father began telling some amusing stories about his personal life and work. Gianni asked Pietro which football team he supported, and Peppe challenged him to a arm-wrestling match. I thought this gift meant the ceremony had ended.
[1969-05-13 19:30:00] Kitchen at Home | I saw myself helping my sister clear the table. In the kitchen, I immediately made a mistake, and I asked my mother. "I heard 'How is it?'"
[1969-05-13 19:30:05] at home Kitchen | "I heard 'the ring?'"
[1969-05-13 19:30:10] at home Kitchen | I heard "Pietro."
[1969-05-13 19:30:15] at home Kitchen | I heard, "She's ugly and her legs aren't straight."
[1969-05-13 19:30:20] Kitchen at Home | I heard, "Dad wasn't much better than him either."
[1969-05-13 19:30:25] at home Kitchen | I heard, "What right do you have to talk about your father?"
[1969-05-13 19:30:30] at home Kitchen | I heard, "No."

[1974-11-01 10:15:00] Vomero | I gave up on seeing Pietro, he was always silent. I thought that the world outside the books had become increasingly heavy for him.
[1974-11-01 10:20:00] Vomero | I saw him going to the university unwillingly. I knew that because of the mess at school, he often took sick leave.
[1974-11-01 10:25:00] Vomero | I saw him say he wanted to do research at home, but he never finished his book. He rarely locked himself in his room to study, as if to free himself and beg my forgiveness, he took care of Elsa, cooked, cleaned, did the laundry, and ironed the clothes.
[1974-11-01 10:30:00] Vomero | I realized I had to be very harsh with him to get him to go to class, but I soon regretted it. I began to worry about him since those violent incidents had already involved people I knew.
[1974-11-01 10:35:00] Vomero | I thought about his dangerous situation, but he had never given up his own views. He openly opposed his students and many colleagues, summing it up in one sentence: they were doing foolish things.
[1974-11-01 10:40:00] Vomero | I thought that although I was worried about him, perhaps precisely because I was so worried, I had never supported his point of view.
[1974-11-01 10:45:00] Vomero | I thought that, under my criticism, he would reconsider, would abandon his counter-revolutionary reformism (I used that exact word), and become more flexible.
[1974-11-01 10:50:00] Vomero | I thought about it, but in his eyes, my actions made me the same as those students who attacked him and the teachers who opposed him.
[1974-11-05 20:00:00] Vomero | I thought, but things weren't like that; the situation was far more complicated. On one hand, I really wanted to protect him; on the other hand, I felt I was standing with Lina, and I supported her actions—I secretly believed she was responsible for those terrible events.
[1974-11-05 20:05:00] Vomero | I thought about this, which made me want to pick up the phone and call her sometimes, to talk about Pietro, to talk about our conflict, and then listen to her thoughts. As we talked, the conversation would naturally turn back to her.
[1974-11-05 20:10:00] Vomero | I saw, of course, but I didn't do it. I thought about discussing these issues over the phone and expecting the other person to tell the truth—it was ridiculous.

[1974-11-10 20:00:10] Vomero | I saw what I asked. "I heard 'What happened?'"
[1974-11-10 20:00:20] Vomero | I saw her say it. "I heard myself say, 'I've become the head of a computer center.'"
[1974-11-10 20:00:30] Vomero | I saw what I asked. I heard, "What do you mean?"
[1974-11-10 20:00:40] Vomero | I saw her say. I heard, "Michele rented an IBM IBM System, and I became the head of Capodimonte."
[1974-11-10 20:01:00] Vomero | I thought I hadn't believed it, so I asked her to repeat it, to explain it more clearly. Had she accepted Solara's offer? After resisting for so long, had she gone back to work for him again, just like during that time in Piazza Martiri?
[1974-11-10 20:02:00] Vomero | I saw her say, yes. She was full of passion, growing more and more happy, more and more direct. I know that Michele rented a IBM System, which was placed in a shoe warehouse in the Acherri district, and she was given charge of it. She would have her own operator and puncher, and her salary was forty-two million five hundred thousand lira per month.
[1974-11-10 20:03:00] Vomero | I saw what I said. I thought back to that time, and the female warrior I had imagined immediately vanished. I felt very sad, and all my understanding of Lina seemed to crumble.
[1974-11-10 20:03:10] Vomero | I heard, "I never thought you'd do something like this."
[1974-11-10 20:03:20] Vomero | I heard, "What should I do then?"
[1974-11-10 20:03:30] Vomero | I heard "No."
[1974-11-10 20:03:40] Vomero | I heard "Why?"
[1974-11-10 20:03:50] Vomero | I heard, "We all know what the Solara brothers are like."
[1974-11-10 20:04:00] Vomero | I heard, "Because of that? I've already decided, working for Michele is much better than working for that bastard Soccavo."
[1974-11-10 20:04:10] Vomero | I heard, "Do whatever you want."
[1974-11-10 20:04:20] Vomero | I saw and heard her breathing, she said. I heard, "I don't like the way you're talking to me, Elena. I'm making more than Enzo now, and he's a man. What's the problem?"
[1974-11-10 20:04:30] Vomero | I heard, "Nothing."
[1974-11-10 20:04:40] Vomero | I heard, "You're still thinking about the revolution, the working class, the new world, and all those other things?"
[1974-11-10 20:04:50] Vomero | I heard, "Stop talking. If you suddenly want to have a real conversation with me, okay. But if you're just wasting my time with nonsense, forget it."
[1974-11-10 20:05:00] Vomero | "I wonder if I can remind you of something? Whether you're speaking or writing, you always use words like 'really' and 'really,' and you keep saying 'suddenly.' But when do people 'really' talk about an issue, and when does something 'suddenly' happen? You know better than me, all things have causes and effects, one thing leads to another. I don't 'really' do anything anymore, Elena. I've learned to pay attention to the causes and effects of things. Only a fool would think something just suddenly happens."
[1974-11-10 20:05:30] Vomero | "I heard, 'Fine. What do you want me to believe? Everything's under your control, you're using Michele, not the other way around? Forget it, goodbye.'"
[1974-11-10 20:05:40] Vomero | I heard, "No, don't, just say what you want to say."
[1974-11-10 20:05:50] Vomero | I heard, "I have nothing to say."
[1974-11-10 20:06:00] Vomero | I heard, "Speak up, if you won't, I will."
[1974-11-10 20:06:10] Vomero | I heard, "Go ahead, let me hear."
[1974-11-10 20:06:20] Vomero | I heard, "You're criticizing me, but you say nothing about your sister?"
[1974-11-10 20:06:30] Vomero | I saw things as if in a fog, and I asked. I heard, "What does this have to do with my sister?"
[1974-11-10 20:06:40] Vomero | I heard, "Don't you know anything about Elena?"
[1974-11-10 20:06:50] Vomero | I heard, "I should know what?"
[1974-11-10 20:07:00] Vomero | I saw her let out a nasty laugh. I heard, "Ask your mother, your father, and your brothers."
[1974-11-10 20:07:10] Vomero | I saw that she didn't want to talk to me anymore, and she hung up angrily.
[1974-11-10 20:15:00] Vomero | I called my parents' house, very uneasy, and it was my mother who answered. She said. I heard, "You still think about us from time to time."
[1974-11-10 20:15:10] Vomero | I heard, "Mom, what happened to Elena?"
[1974-11-10 20:15:20] Vomero | I heard, "Something happened that happens to every woman."
[1974-11-10 20:15:30] Vomero | I heard "That is to say."
[1974-11-10 20:15:40] Vomero | I heard, "She's with a man."
[1974-11-10 20:15:50] Vomero | I heard, "Has she gotten engaged?"
[1974-11-10 20:16:00] Vomero | I heard, "Even if that's the case."
[1974-11-10 20:16:10] Vomero | I heard, "Who is she with?"
[1974-11-10 20:16:20] Vomero | I heard "and Marcello."
[1974-11-10 20:17:00] Vomero | I thought of that answer, and it pierced my heart.
[1974-11-10 20:18:00] Vomero | I realized this was the thing Lina didn't want to tell me. Marcello—the handsome Marcello from our youth, the one who had desperately and hopelessly pursued her, the young man she had humiliated by marrying Stefano Carraci—now he was with my sister Elisa, the youngest child in our family, my gentle little sister, the one I've always thought was a remarkable girl.
[1974-11-10 20:19:00] Vomero | I thought of Elena obediently following him, how my parents and brothers had not even lifted a finger to stop it, and how my entire family, including myself, had become relatives of the Solara family.
[1974-11-10 20:20:00] Vomero | I saw what I asked. I heard, "How long has it been?"
[1974-11-10 20:20:10] Vomero | "I don't know, maybe a year," I heard.
[1974-11-10 20:20:20] Vomero | "I heard, 'You've agreed?'"
[1974-11-10 20:20:30] Vomero | I heard, "Did you get our permission? Do whatever you want, and she did the same thing too."
[1974-11-10 20:20:40] Vomero | I heard, "Pietro is not Marcello."
[1974-11-10 20:20:50] Vomero | I heard, "You're right: Marcello wouldn't treat Elisa that way, just like you treated Pietro."
[1974-11-10 20:21:00] Vomero | I saw a silence, and I said. I heard, "You can tell me, ask me."
[1974-11-10 20:21:10] Vomero | I heard, "Why? You've already left. You spoke nicely: don't worry, I'll take care of you. You're always thinking about your own things and don't care about our lives at all."
[1974-11-11 09:00:00] Vomero | I saw that I had to take the children back to San Gregorio Armeno immediately. I thought about taking the train, but Pietro volunteered to drive us, so he could conveniently avoid going to work.
[1974-11-11 15:00:00] Stazione Centrale | I saw that San Gregorio Armeno was too crowded, and we hadn't even reached the Gonnella district when we got stuck in traffic. I felt once again captured by this city, sensing those unwritten laws.

Sometimes he hesitated, slowed down, which really annoyed me. I thought about how, since I got married, I had never set foot in this city again, its noise was unbearable for me.
[1974-11-11 15:20:00] Spaccanapoli | I told him to pull over as we approached Piazza Carlo III, and I moved to the driver's seat, taking control of the wheel in a very assertive manner. I drove straight to Mercato, the hotel where he had stayed the last time.
[1974-11-11 17:00:00] Porto | I saw us putting our luggage down, and I carefully dressed myself and my two daughters. Finally, we went to Mergellina, to my parents' house.
[1974-11-11 18:00:00] Elena's Parents' House | What could I possibly do? Demand that Elena cancel her engagement to Marcello, using the authority I gained through my older sister's status, my university degree, and a good marriage?
